Title: Energy Act 2023
Date: 2024-10-03
Publisher: Statute Law Database
Identifier: http://www.legislation.gov.uk/ukpga/2023/52

## Energy Act 2023

      B e it enacted  by the King’s most Excellent Majesty, by and with the
advice and consent of the Lords Spiritual and Temporal, and Commons, in this
present Parliament assembled, and by the authority of the same, as follows:—

### Licensing of carbon dioxide transport and storage

#### Licensing of activities

##### General functions

###### Principal objectives and general duties of Secretary of State and economic regulator

1

1.1

The principal objectives of the Secretary of State and the GEMA in carrying
out their respective functions under this Part are to—

1.1.a

protect the interests of current and future transport and storage network
users;

1.1.b

protect the interests of any consumers whose interests the Secretary of State
or the economic regulator (as the case may be) considers may be impacted by
the exercise of their respective functions under this Part;

1.1.c

promote the efficient and economic development and operation of transport and
storage networks, having regard to the need for licence holders to be able to
finance their licensable activities.

1.2

In this Part the GEMA is referred to as the “ economic regulator ”.

1.3

The Secretary of State and the economic regulator must carry out their
respective functions under this Part in the manner which the Secretary of
State or the economic regulator (as the case may be) considers is best
calculated to further the principal objectives, wherever appropriate by—

1.3.a

promoting effective competition between persons engaged in, or in commercial
activities connected with, the activities mentioned in  section 2 (2) ;

1.3.b

promoting the resilience of transport and storage networks;

1.3.c

protecting the public from dangers arising from the construction, operation
and decommissioning of infrastructure used for the purposes of activities
mentioned in  section 2 (2) .

1.4

In carrying out functions under this Part in accordance with the preceding
provisions of this section, the Secretary of State or the economic regulator
(as the case may be) must have regard to—

1.4.a

the principles under which regulatory activities should be transparent,
accountable, proportionate, consistent and targeted only at cases in which
action is needed, and any other principles appearing to the Secretary of State
or the economic regulator to represent the best regulatory practice;

1.4.b

the need to contribute to the achievement of sustainable development.

1.5

In carrying out functions under this Part in accordance with the preceding
provisions of this section the Secretary of State must have regard to the
Secretary of State’s duties under sections 1 and 4(1)(b) of the Climate Change
Act 2008 (carbon targets and budgets).

1.6

In carrying out functions under this Part in accordance with the preceding
provisions of this section, the economic regulator must have regard to—

1.6.a

the need to assist the Secretary of State’s compliance with the duties
mentioned in  subsection (5) ;

1.6.b

the targets specified in  subsection (8) .

1.7

In exercising their respective functions in relation to licensable activities,
the Secretary of State and the economic regulator may have regard to the
desirability of the efficient and effective operation of the energy system (or
any part of it) in the United Kingdom or any part of the United Kingdom.

1.8

The targets referred to in subsection  (6) (b)  are—

1.8.a

the net-zero emissions target, as defined in section A1(1) of the  Climate
Change (Scotland) Act 2009 (asp 12) ;

1.8.b

the interim targets, as defined in section 2 of that Act;

1.8.c

a target in, or set under, section 1 or 2 of the Climate Change Act (Northern
Ireland) 2022;

1.8.d

a target in, or set under, section 29 or 30 of the  Environment (Wales) Act
2016 (anaw 3) .

1.9

In this section—

      “ transport and storage network user ” means a person who is, or seeks
to be, a party to arrangements for carbon dioxide to be transported to a
relevant site for the purpose of disposal by way of geological storage;
“ transport and storage networks ” means infrastructure and facilities for—
the disposal of carbon dioxide by way of geological storage (or injection for
the purposes of geological storage) at a relevant site, or           the
transportation of carbon dioxide to a relevant site for the purpose of such
disposal;                 “ relevant site ” means a site that is—         in
the United Kingdom, or           in, under or over—         the territorial
sea adjacent to the United Kingdom, or           waters in a Gas Importation
and Storage Zone (within the meaning given by section 1 of the Energy Act
2008).

1.10

For the purposes of this Part activities are “licensable activities” if
undertaking them without the authority of a licence or exemption constitutes
an offence under  section 2 (1) .

##### Licensable activities

###### Prohibition on unlicensed activities

2

2.1

It is an offence for a person to carry on an activity within  subsection (2)
unless the person is authorised to do so by a licence.

2.2

The activities are—

2.2.a

operating a site for the disposal of carbon dioxide by way of geological
storage;

2.2.b

providing a service of transporting carbon dioxide by a licensable means of
transportation.

2.3

In this Part “ licensable means of transportation ” means—

2.3.a

a pipe or system of pipes, or

2.3.b

any other means of transportation that may be specified by regulations made by
the Secretary of State,

which falls within  subsection (4) .

2.4

A means of transportation falls within this subsection if it is used (with or
without other means of transportation) for transporting carbon dioxide all or
part of the way to a site for the geological storage of carbon dioxide.

2.5

A person who commits an offence under this section is liable—

2.5.a

on summary conviction in England and Wales, to a fine;

2.5.b

on summary conviction in Scotland or Northern Ireland, to a fine not exceeding
the statutory maximum;

2.5.c

on conviction on indictment, to a fine.

2.6

No proceedings may be instituted in England and Wales in respect of an offence
under this section except by or on behalf of the Secretary of State or the
economic regulator.

2.7

Regulations under  subsection (3) (b)  may make consequential, transitional,
incidental or supplementary provision including—

2.7.a

amendments (or repeals or revocations) in any provision of this Act or any
other enactment, and

2.7.b

provision modifying any standard conditions of licences or provision
determining the conditions which are to be standard conditions for the
purposes of licences authorising the undertaking of activities which are to
become licensable activities.

2.8

But regulations made by virtue of  subsection (7) (a)  may not make provision
amending (or repealing or revoking) any provision of—

2.8.a

an Act of the Scottish Parliament, or an instrument made under such an Act,
unless the Scottish Ministers have consented to the making of that provision;

2.8.b

a Measure or Act of Senedd Cymru, or an instrument made under such a Measure
or Act, unless the Welsh Ministers have consented to the making of that
provision;

2.8.c

Northern Ireland legislation, or an instrument made under Northern Ireland
legislation, unless the Department for the Economy in Northern Ireland has
consented to the making of that provision.

2.9

Regulations under  subsection (3) (b)  are subject to the affirmative
procedure.

2.10

For the purposes of this Part the person who “operates” a site for the
geological storage of carbon dioxide is the person who carries on or (where
different) controls activities at the site.

###### Consultation on proposals for additional activities to become licensable

3

3.1

Before making regulations under  section 2 (3) (b) , the Secretary of State
must give notice—

3.1.a

stating that the Secretary of State proposes to make regulations providing for
the means of transportation in question to become a licensable means of
transportation, and

3.1.b

specifying a reasonable period (of not less than 28 days from the date of
publication of the notice) within which representations or objections may be
made with respect to the proposal,

and must consider any representations or objections duly made and not
withdrawn.

3.2

The notice must be given—

3.2.a

by sending a copy of the notice to the economic regulator, the appropriate
devolved authorities and any other body the Secretary of State considers
appropriate, and

3.2.b

by publishing it in such manner as the Secretary of State considers
appropriate for bringing it to the attention of persons likely to be affected
by such regulations.

3.3

For the purposes of this section the “appropriate devolved authorities” are—

3.3.a

the Welsh Ministers, if the regulations contain provision that would be within
the legislative competence of Senedd Cymru if it were contained in an Act of
the Senedd (ignoring any requirement for the consent of a Minister of the
Crown imposed under Schedule 7B to the Government of Wales Act 2006);

3.3.b

the Scottish Ministers, if the regulations contain provision that would be
within the legislative competence of the Scottish Parliament if it were
contained in an Act of that Parliament;

3.3.c

the Department for the Economy in Northern Ireland, if the regulations contain
provision that—

3.3.c.i

would be within the legislative competence of the Northern Ireland Assembly if
it were contained in an Act of that Assembly, and

3.3.c.ii

would not, if it were contained in a Bill in the Northern Ireland Assembly,
result in the Bill requiring the consent of the Secretary of State under
section 8 of the Northern Ireland Act 1998.

###### Territorial scope of prohibition

4

Section  2 (1)  applies to activities in, above or below—

4.a

the territorial sea adjacent to the United Kingdom, or

4.b

waters in a Gas Importation and Storage Zone (within the meaning given by
section 1 of the Energy Act 2008),

as it applies to activities in the United Kingdom.

###### Exemption from prohibition

5

5.1

The Secretary of State may by regulations grant exemption from the prohibition
under  section 2 (1) .

5.2

An exemption may be granted—

5.2.a

to a specified person, or persons of a specified class;

5.2.b

generally or to such extent as may be specified;

5.2.c

unconditionally or subject to such conditions as may be specified.

5.3

Before making regulations under  subsection (1)  the Secretary of State must
give notice—

5.3.a

stating that the Secretary of State proposes to make such regulations and
setting out the terms of the proposed regulations,

5.3.b

stating the reasons why the Secretary of State proposes to make the
regulations in the terms proposed, and

5.3.c

specifying the time (which must be not less than 28 days from the date of
publication of the notice) within which representations with respect to the
proposals may be made,

and must consider any representations which are duly made in respect of the
proposals and not withdrawn.

5.4

The notice required by  subsection (3)  must be given—

5.4.a

by serving a copy of it on the economic regulator and any appropriate devolved
authority, and

5.4.b

by publishing it in such manner as the Secretary of State considers
appropriate for bringing it to the attention of those likely to be affected by
the proposed regulations.

5.5

Notice of an exemption granted to a person is to be given—

5.5.a

by serving a copy of the exemption on the person, and

5.5.b

by publishing the exemption in such manner as the Secretary of State considers
appropriate for bringing it to the attention of other persons who may be
affected by it.

5.6

Notice of an exemption granted to persons of a class must be given by
publishing the exemption in such manner as the Secretary of State considers
appropriate for bringing it to the attention of—

5.6.a

persons of that class, and

5.6.b

other persons who may be affected by it.

5.7

An exemption may be granted—

5.7.a

indefinitely, or

5.7.b

for a period specified in, or determined by or under, the exemption.

5.8

Conditions subject to which an exemption is granted may (in particular)
require any person carrying on any activity in pursuance of the exemption—

5.8.a

to comply with any direction given by a relevant authority as to such matters
as are specified in the exemption or are of a description so specified,

5.8.b

to do (or not do) such things as are specified in the exemption or are of a
description so specified, except so far as the Secretary of State or a
relevant authority consents to the person’s not doing (or doing) them, and

5.8.c

to refer for determination by the Secretary of State or a relevant authority
such questions arising under the exemption as are specified in the exemption
or are of a description so specified.

5.9

For the purposes of this section the “appropriate devolved authorities” are—

5.9.a

the Scottish Ministers, if the regulations under  subsection (1)  contain
provision that would be within the legislative competence of the Scottish
Parliament if it were contained in an Act of that Parliament;

5.9.b

the Welsh Ministers, if those regulations contain provision that would be
within the legislative competence of Senedd Cymru if it were contained in an
Act of the Senedd (ignoring any requirement for the consent of a Minister of
the Crown imposed under Schedule 7B to the Government of Wales Act 2006);

5.9.c

the Department for the Economy in Northern Ireland, if those regulations
contain provision that—

5.9.c.i

would be within the legislative competence of the Northern Ireland Assembly if
it were contained in an Act of that Assembly, and

5.9.c.ii

would not, if it were contained in a Bill in the Northern Ireland Assembly,
result in the Bill requiring the consent of the Secretary of State under
section 8 of the Northern Ireland Act 1998.

5.10

In  subsection (8)  “ relevant authority ” means a person specified in the
conditions.

###### Revocation or withdrawal of exemption

6

6.1

The Secretary of State may by regulations revoke regulations by which an
exemption was granted to a person or vary regulations by which more than one
exemption was so granted so as to terminate any of the exemptions—

6.1.a

at the person’s request,

6.1.b

in accordance with any provision of the regulations by which the exemption was
granted, or

6.1.c

if it appears to the Secretary of State inappropriate that the exemption
should continue to have effect.

6.2

The Secretary of State may by regulations revoke regulations by which an
exemption was granted to persons of a class or vary regulations by which more
than one exemption was so granted so as to terminate any of the exemptions—

6.2.a

in accordance with any provision of the regulations by which the exemption was
granted, or

6.2.b

if it appears to the Secretary of State inappropriate that the exemption
should continue to have effect.

6.3

The Secretary of State may by regulations withdraw an exemption granted to
persons of a class from any person of that class—

6.3.a

at the person’s request,

6.3.b

in accordance with any provision of the regulations by which the exemption was
granted, or

6.3.c

if it appears to the Secretary of State inappropriate that the exemption
should continue to have effect in the case of the person.

6.4

Before making regulations under  subsection (1) (b)  or (c),  (2)  or  (3) (b)
or (c), the Secretary of State must—

6.4.a

give notice of the proposal to do so (with reasons) and of a period within
which representations may be made to the Secretary of State, and

6.4.b

consider any representations which are duly made and not withdrawn.

6.5

The notice under  subsection (4)  must be given—

6.5.a

to the economic regulator and any appropriate devolved authority,

6.5.b

where the Secretary of State is proposing to make regulations under
subsection (1) (b)  or (c), by serving a copy of it on the person to whom the
exemption was granted,

6.5.c

where the Secretary of State is proposing to make regulations under subsection
(2) , by publishing it in such manner as the Secretary of State considers
appropriate for bringing it to the attention of persons of the class of
persons to whom the exemption was granted, and

6.5.d

where the Secretary of State is proposing to make regulations under
subsection (3) (b)  or (c), by serving a copy of it on the person from whom
the Secretary of State proposes to withdraw the exemption.

6.6

For the purposes of  subsection (5)  the “appropriate devolved authorities”
are—

6.6.a

the Scottish Ministers, if the regulations to which the notice relates contain
provision that would be within the legislative competence of the Scottish
Parliament if it were contained in an Act of that Parliament;

6.6.b

the Welsh Ministers, if those regulations contain provision that would be
within the legislative competence of Senedd Cymru if it were contained in an
Act of the Senedd (ignoring any requirement for the consent of a Minister of
the Crown imposed under Schedule 7B to the Government of Wales Act 2006);

6.6.c

the Department for the Economy in Northern Ireland, if those regulations
contain provision that—

6.6.c.i

would be within the legislative competence of the Northern Ireland Assembly if
it were contained in an Act of that Assembly, and

6.6.c.ii

would not, if it were contained in a Bill in the Northern Ireland Assembly,
result in the Bill requiring the consent of the Secretary of State under
section 8 of the Northern Ireland Act 1998.

6.7

Regulations under this section and  section 5  are subject to the negative
procedure.

##### Grant and conditions of licences

###### Power to grant licences

7

7.1

The economic regulator may grant a licence authorising a person to carry on—

7.1.a

activities falling within  section 2 (2) (a) ;

7.1.b

activities falling within  section 2 (2) (b) .

7.2

A licence—

7.2.a

must be in writing;

7.2.b

is to continue in force for such period as may be specified in or determined
by or under the licence, unless previously revoked in accordance with any term
of the licence.

###### Power to create licence types

8

8.1

The Secretary of State may by regulations provide that different types of
licence may be granted under  section 7 (1)  in respect of different
descriptions of activity falling within  section 2 (2) .

8.2

Regulations under this section may make consequential, transitional,
incidental or supplementary provision including—

8.2.a

amendments (or repeals or revocations) in any provision of this Act or any
other enactment, and

8.2.b

provision modifying any standard conditions of licences or provision
determining the conditions which are to be standard conditions for the
purposes of new types of licences.

8.3

Before making regulations under this section containing provision within
devolved competence, the Secretary of State must give notice to each relevant
devolved authority—

8.3.a

stating that the Secretary of State proposes to make regulations under this
section, and

8.3.b

specifying the period (of not less than 28 days from the date on which the
notice is given) within which representations may be made with respect to the
provision within the relevant devolved competence,

and must consider any representations duly made and not withdrawn.

8.4

For the purposes of this section “ relevant devolved authority ” means—

8.4.a

the Scottish Ministers, if the regulations contain provision within Scottish
devolved competence;

8.4.b

the Welsh Ministers, if the regulations contain provision within Welsh
devolved competence;

8.4.c

the Department for the Economy in Northern Ireland, if the regulations contain
provision within Northern Ireland devolved competence;

and “ the relevant devolved competence ”, in relation to a relevant devolved
authority, is to be construed accordingly.

8.5

For the purposes of this section, provision—

8.5.a

is within Scottish devolved competence if it would be within the legislative
competence of the Scottish Parliament if it were contained in an Act of that
Parliament;

8.5.b

is within Welsh devolved competence if it would be within the legislative
competence of Senedd Cymru if it were contained in an Act of the Senedd
(ignoring any requirement for the consent of a Minister of the Crown imposed
under Schedule 7B to the Government of Wales Act 2006);

8.5.c

is within Northern Ireland devolved competence if it—

8.5.c.i

would be within the legislative competence of the Northern Ireland Assembly if
it were contained in an Act of that Assembly, and

8.5.c.ii

would not, if it were contained in a Bill in the Northern Ireland Assembly,
result in the Bill requiring the consent of the Secretary of State under
section 8 of the Northern Ireland Act 1998;

and references to provision being within devolved competence are to provision
that is within Scottish, Welsh or Northern Ireland devolved competence.

8.6

Regulations under this section are subject to the affirmative procedure.

###### Procedure for licence applications

9

9.1

The Secretary of State, or the economic regulator with the approval of the
Secretary of State, may by regulations—

9.1.a

make provision about the form and manner in which an application for a licence
must be made;

9.1.b

authorise the grantor to require that an application is accompanied by a fee
for processing the application of an amount determined in accordance with the
regulations.

9.2

The Secretary of State may by regulations make provision about the procedure
for applications for a licence (in addition to any provision that may be made
under  subsection (1) ) including, for example, provision—

9.2.a

requiring that a decision to refuse a licence must be accompanied by reasons
for the decision;

9.2.b

imposing requirements with regard to the publication of decisions to refuse a
licence.

9.3

Before making regulations under  subsection (2)  or  (7)  the Secretary of
State must—

9.3.a

consult the economic regulator and the appropriate devolved authorities, and

9.3.b

specify a period of not less than 28 days within which representations or
objections with respect to the proposed regulations may be made,

and the Secretary of State must consider any representations or objections
which are duly made and not withdrawn.

9.4

Before granting a licence the economic regulator must give notice—

9.4.a

stating that the economic regulator proposes to grant the licence,

9.4.b

stating the reasons why the economic regulator proposes to grant the licence,
and

9.4.c

specifying the time (which must not be less than 28 days from the date of
publication of the notice) within which representations or objections with
respect to the proposed licence may be made,

and must consider any representations or objections which are duly made and
not withdrawn.

9.5

A notice under  subsection (4)  must be given by—

9.5.a

publishing the notice in such manner as the economic regulator considers
appropriate for bringing it to the attention of persons likely to be affected
by the grant of the licence, and

9.5.b

sending a copy of the notice to—

9.5.b.i

the Scottish Ministers, if an activity that would be authorised by the
proposed licence is within Scottish devolved competence;

9.5.b.ii

the Welsh Ministers, if an activity that would be authorised by the licence is
within Welsh devolved competence;

9.5.b.iii

the Department for the Economy in Northern Ireland, if an activity that would
be authorised by the licence is within Northern Ireland devolved competence.

9.6

Section  17 (4)  (activities authorised by a licence: devolved competence)
applies for the purposes of  subsection (5) (b)  of this section as it applies
for the purposes of  section 17 .

9.7

The Secretary of State may by regulations make provision, in relation to
licences, about the matters to be taken into account in determining whether an
applicant for a licence should be granted the licence.

9.8

Regulations under this section are subject to the negative procedure.

9.9

Consultation before the passing of this Act is as effective for the purposes
of subsections  (3)  and  (4)  as consultation after that time.

9.10

In this Part “ grantor ”, in relation to a licence or an application for a
licence, means the person who grants or, as the case may be, has power to
grant, the licence.

9.11

For the purposes of this section “ appropriate devolved authority ”, in
relation to regulations, means—

9.11.a

the Scottish Ministers, if the regulations contain provision within Scottish
devolved competence;

9.11.b

the Welsh Ministers, if the regulations contain provision within Welsh
devolved competence;

9.11.c

the Department for the Economy in Northern Ireland, if the regulations contain
provision within Northern Ireland devolved competence.

9.12

For the purposes of this section, provision—

9.12.a

is within Scottish devolved competence if it would be within the legislative
competence of the Scottish Parliament if it were contained in an Act of that
Parliament;

9.12.b

is within Welsh devolved competence if it would be within the legislative
competence of Senedd Cymru if it were contained in an Act of the Senedd
(ignoring any requirement for the consent of a Minister of the Crown imposed
under Schedule 7B to the Government of Wales Act 2006);

9.12.c

is within Northern Ireland devolved competence if it—

9.12.c.i

would be within the legislative competence of the Northern Ireland Assembly if
it were contained in an Act of that Assembly, and

9.12.c.ii

would not, if it were contained in a Bill in the Northern Ireland Assembly,
result in the Bill requiring the consent of the Secretary of State under
section 8 of the Northern Ireland Act 1998.

9.13

The Statutory Instruments Act 1946 applies in relation to the power of the
economic regulator to make regulations under  subsection (1)  as if the
economic regulator were a Minister of the Crown.

9.14

Any sums received by the economic regulator or the Secretary of State by
virtue of this section must be paid into the Consolidated Fund.

###### Competitive tenders for licences

10

10.1

The Secretary of State may by regulations make such provision as the Secretary
of State considers appropriate for facilitating the making, in prescribed
cases, of a determination on a competitive basis of the person to whom a
licence is to be granted.

10.2

That provision may include—

10.2.a

provision, in prescribed cases, for the publication of a proposal to grant a
licence;

10.2.b

provision for the inclusion in such a proposal of an invitation to apply for a
licence;

10.2.c

provision restricting the making of applications for a licence and imposing
requirements as to the period within which they must be made;

10.2.d

provision for regulating the manner in which applications are considered and
determined;

10.2.e

provision authorising the Secretary of State to direct, in relation to a
particular competition, that specified functions which would, apart from the
direction, be exercisable by the economic regulator are, so far as they relate
to that competition, to be exercised instead by a specified person.

10.3

Before making regulations under  subsection (1)  the Secretary of State must
give notice to the economic regulator and the appropriate devolved
authorities—

10.3.a

stating that the Secretary of State proposes to make regulations under this
section, and

10.3.b

specifying the period (of not less than 28 days from the date on which the
notice is given) within which representations must be made with respect to the
proposed provisions,

and must consider any representations duly made and not withdrawn.

10.4

Regulations under  subsection (1) —

10.4.a

may make provision by reference to a determination by the economic regulator
or to the opinion of the economic regulator as to any matter;

10.4.b

may dispense with or supplement provision made in relation to applications for
licences under  section 9 .

10.5

Regulations under  subsection (1)  are subject to the affirmative procedure.

10.6

For the purposes of  subsection (3)  the “appropriate devolved authorities”
are—

10.6.a

the Scottish Ministers, if the regulations contain provision that would be
within the legislative competence of the Scottish Parliament if it were
contained in an Act of that Parliament;

10.6.b

the Welsh Ministers, if the regulations contain provision that would be within
the legislative competence of Senedd Cymru if it were contained in an Act of
the Senedd (ignoring any requirement for the consent of a Minister of the
Crown imposed under Schedule 7B to the Government of Wales Act 2006);

10.6.c

the Department for the Economy in Northern Ireland, if the regulations contain
provision that—

10.6.c.i

would be within the legislative competence of the Northern Ireland Assembly if
it were contained in an Act of that Assembly, and

10.6.c.ii

would not, if it were contained in a Bill in the Northern Ireland Assembly,
result in the Bill requiring the consent of the Secretary of State under
section 8 of the Northern Ireland Act 1998.

10.7

In this section—

      “ competition ” means a determination such as is mentioned in
subsection (1) ;           “ prescribed ” means prescribed in, or determined
under, regulations under  subsection (1) ;           “ specified ”, in
relation to a direction under  subsection (2) (e) , means specified in the
direction.

###### Conditions of licences: general

11

11.1

A licence may include—

11.1.a

such conditions (whether or not relating to the activities authorised by the
licence) as appear to the grantor to be requisite or expedient having regard
to the duties imposed by  section 1  (principal objectives of Secretary of
State and economic regulator), and

11.1.b

conditions requiring the making to the economic regulator of a payment on the
grant of the licence, or payments during the currency of the licence, or both,
of such amount or amounts as may be determined by or under the licence.

11.2

Without prejudice to the generality of paragraph (a) of  subsection (1) ,
conditions included in a licence by virtue of that paragraph may require the
licence holder—

11.2.a

to comply with any direction given by the economic regulator or the Secretary
of State as to such matters as are specified in the licence or are of a
description so specified,

11.2.b

to consent to the disclosure of information provided in accordance with a
direction given to the licence holder,

11.2.c

except in so far as the economic regulator or Secretary of State consents to
the licence holder’s doing (or not doing) them, not to do (or to do) such
things as are specified in the licence or are of a description so specified,

11.2.d

to refer for determination by the economic regulator or Secretary of State
such questions arising under the licence, or under any document referred to in
the licence, as are specified in the licence or are of a description so
specified, and

11.2.e

to refer for approval by the economic regulator or the Secretary of State such
things as are (or may be) required to be done under the licence, and such
contracts or agreements made before the grant of the licence, as are specified
in the licence or are of a description so specified.

11.3

Without prejudice to the generality of paragraph (a) of  subsection (1) ,
conditions in a licence may also include—

11.3.a

provision about the revenue that the licence holder may receive in respect of
its activities (the licence holder’s “allowed revenue”);

11.3.b

provision about how the licence holder’s allowed revenue is to be calculated.

11.4

In  subsection (3)  the reference to revenue that the licence holder may
receive in respect of its activities includes revenue that is calculated by
reference to estimates of the licence holder’s decommissioning costs, as
defined in  section 92  (financing of costs of decommissioning etc).

11.5

Without prejudice to the generality of paragraph (a) of  subsection (1) ,
conditions which are described in  subsection (6)  may be included in a
licence by virtue of that paragraph, in respect of circumstances where a
person (“the licence holder”) holds such a licence, and another person (“the
candidate”)—

11.5.a

has applied or is considering whether to apply for a licence, or

11.5.b

is considering whether to apply for financial support for carbon capture
activities.

11.6

The conditions in this subsection are conditions which require the licence
holder to comply with a direction given by the economic regulator or the
Secretary of State requiring the licence holder to provide to the candidate—

11.6.a

information in relation to the activities authorised by the licence, and

11.6.b

any other assistance the candidate may reasonably require, for the purpose of
determining whether to—

11.6.b.i

apply for a licence, or

11.6.b.ii

(as the case may be) apply for financial support for carbon capture
activities.

11.7

Conditions included in a licence may contain provision for the conditions—

11.7.a

to have effect or cease to have effect at such times and in such circumstances
as may be determined by or under the conditions, or

11.7.b

to be modified in such manner as may be specified in the conditions at such
times and in such circumstances as may be so determined.

11.8

Any provision included by virtue of  subsection (7)  in a licence is to have
effect in addition to the provision made by this Part with respect to the
modification of the conditions of a licence.

11.9

Conditions included in a licence may provide for references in the conditions
to any document to operate as references to that document as revised or re-
issued from time to time.

11.10

Any sums received by the economic regulator in consequence of the provisions
of any condition of a licence must be paid into the Consolidated Fund.

###### Standard conditions of licences

12

12.1

The Secretary of State may determine the conditions that are to be the
standard conditions of licences.

12.2

The Secretary of State must publish any standard conditions determined under
subsection (1)  in whatever manner the Secretary of State considers
appropriate.

12.3

Subject to subsections  (4)  and  (5) , each condition which is a standard
condition is to be incorporated by reference in each licence.

12.4

Subsection  (3)  does not apply to a licence granted before the publication of
the standard condition.

12.5

Subject to the following provisions of this section, the grantor of a licence
in which standard conditions would, but for this subsection, be incorporated
in accordance with  subsection (3)  may exclude or modify any of those
standard conditions, to such extent as the grantor may consider requisite to
meet the circumstances of a particular case.

12.6

Before excluding any standard conditions or making any modifications under
subsection (5) , the grantor must give notice—

12.6.a

stating that the grantor proposes to exclude the conditions or make the
modifications and setting out the effect of so doing,

12.6.b

stating the reasons why the grantor proposes to exclude the conditions or make
the modifications, and

12.6.c

specifying the time (which must not be less than 28 days from the date of
publication of the notice) within which representations or objections with
respect to the proposed exclusions or modifications may be made,

and must consider any representations or objections which are duly made and
not withdrawn.

12.7

A notice under  subsection (6)  must be given—

12.7.a

by publishing the notice in whatever manner the grantor considers appropriate
for the purpose of bringing the notice to the attention of persons likely to
be affected by the making of the exclusions or modifications, and

12.7.b

by sending a copy of the notice to the appropriate devolved authorities (if
any) and the Secretary of State.

12.8

The grantor must not exclude any conditions, or make any modifications, under
subsection (5)  unless the grantor is of the opinion that the exclusions or
modifications are such that—

12.8.a

the licence holder would not be unduly disadvantaged in competing with other
holders of licences, and

12.8.b

no other holder of a licence would be unduly disadvantaged in competing with
other holders of such licences (including the holder of the licence).

12.9

If, within the time specified in the notice under  subsection (6) , the
Secretary of State (after consulting the appropriate devolved authorities (if
any)) directs the grantor not to exclude or modify any standard condition, the
grantor must comply with the direction.

12.10

The modification under  subsection (5)  of part of a standard condition does
not prevent any other part of the condition from continuing to be treated as a
standard condition for the purposes of this Part.

12.11

Where, in granting a licence, the grantor excludes or modifies any standard
conditions under  subsection (5) , the grantor must publish a notice setting
out—

12.11.a

each exclusion or modification,

12.11.b

their effects, and the reason for adopting them, and

12.11.c

how the grantor has taken account of any representations or objections made in
accordance with  subsection (6) .

12.12

For the purposes of this section the “appropriate devolved authorities” are—

12.12.a

the Welsh Ministers, if provision making the exclusions and modifications
proposed in the notice under  subsection (6)  would be within the legislative
competence of Senedd Cymru if it were contained in an Act of the Senedd
(ignoring any requirement for the consent of a Minister of the Crown imposed
under Schedule 7B to the Government of Wales Act 2006);

12.12.b

the Scottish Ministers, if provision making the exclusions and modifications
proposed in that notice would be within the legislative competence of the
Scottish Parliament if it were contained in an Act of that Parliament;

12.12.c

the Department for the Economy in Northern Ireland, if provision making the
exclusions and modifications proposed in that notice—

12.12.c.i

would be within the legislative competence of the Northern Ireland Assembly if
it were contained in an Act of that Assembly, and

12.12.c.ii

would not, if it were contained in a Bill in the Northern Ireland Assembly,
result in the Bill requiring the consent of the Secretary of State under
section 8 of the Northern Ireland Act 1998.

###### Modification of conditions of licences

13

13.1

The economic regulator may make modifications of—

13.1.a

the conditions of a particular licence;

13.1.b

the standard conditions of licences.

13.2

Before making any modifications under this section, the economic regulator
must give notice—

13.2.a

stating that it proposes to make modifications,

13.2.b

setting out the proposed modifications and their effect,

13.2.c

stating the reasons why it proposes to make the modifications, and

13.2.d

specifying the time within which representations with respect to the proposed
modifications may be made.

13.3

The time specified by virtue of  subsection (2) (d)  may not be less than 28
days from the date of the publication of the notice.

13.4

A notice under  subsection (2)  must be given—

13.4.a

by publishing the notice in such manner as the economic regulator considers
appropriate for the purpose of bringing the notice to the attention of persons
likely to be affected by the making of the modifications, and

13.4.b

by sending a copy of the notice to—

13.4.b.i

each relevant licence holder,

13.4.b.ii

the Secretary of State, and

13.4.b.iii

the appropriate devolved authorities (if any).

13.5

The economic regulator must consider any representations which are duly made.

13.6

If, within the time specified by virtue of  subsection (2) (d) , the Secretary
of State directs the economic regulator not to make any modification, the
economic regulator must comply with the direction.

13.7

Subsections  (8)  to  (10)  apply where, having complied with subsections  (2)
to  (5) , the economic regulator decides to proceed with the making of
modifications of the conditions of any licence under this section.

13.8

The economic regulator must—

13.8.a

publish the decision and the modifications in such manner as it considers
appropriate for the purpose of bringing them to the attention of persons
likely to be affected by the making of the modifications,

13.8.b

state the effect of the modifications,

13.8.c

state how it has taken account of any representations duly made, and

13.8.d

state the reason for any differences between the modifications and those set
out in the notice by virtue of  subsection (2) (b) .

13.9

Each modification has effect from the date specified by the economic regulator
in relation to that modification (subject to the giving of a direction under
paragraph 2  of  Schedule 2 ).

13.10

The date specified by virtue of  subsection (9)  may not be less than 56 days
from the publication of the decision to proceed with the making of
modifications under this section.

13.11

In this section “relevant licence holder”—

13.11.a

in relation to the modification of standard conditions, means the holder of a
licence—

13.11.a.i

which is to be modified by the inclusion of any new standard condition, or

13.11.a.ii

which includes any standard conditions to which the modifications relate which
are in effect at the time specified by virtue of  subsection (2) (d) , or

13.11.b

in relation to the modification of a condition of a particular licence (other
than a standard condition), means the holder of that particular licence.

13.12

For the purposes of this section the “appropriate devolved authorities” are—

13.12.a

the Welsh Ministers, if provision making the modifications proposed in the
notice under  subsection (2)  would be within the legislative competence of
Senedd Cymru if it were contained in an Act of the Senedd (ignoring any
requirement for the consent of a Minister of the Crown imposed under Schedule
7B to the Government of Wales Act 2006);

13.12.b

the Scottish Ministers, if provision making the modifications proposed in that
notice would be within the legislative competence of the Scottish Parliament
if it were contained in an Act of that Parliament;

13.12.c

the Department for the Economy in Northern Ireland, if provision making the
modifications proposed in that notice—

13.12.c.i

would be within the legislative competence of the Northern Ireland Assembly if
it were contained in an Act of that Assembly, and

13.12.c.ii

would not, if it were contained in a Bill in the Northern Ireland Assembly,
result in the Bill requiring the consent of the Secretary of State under
section 8 of the Northern Ireland Act 1998.

###### Modification of conditions under 

14

14.1

Subsections (2) and (3) apply where at any time the economic regulator
modifies the conditions of licences under  section 13 .

14.2

If the conditions modified are standard conditions, the economic regulator
must—

14.2.a

also make (as nearly as possible) the same modifications of those conditions
for the purposes of their incorporation in licences granted after that time,
and

14.2.b

publish the modifications in such manner as it considers appropriate for the
purpose of bringing them to the attention of persons likely to be affected by
the making of the modifications.

14.3

The economic regulator may make such incidental or consequential modifications
of any conditions of licences as it considers necessary or expedient.

14.4

The modification of part of a standard condition of a particular licence under
section 13  does not prevent any other part of the condition from continuing
to be regarded as a standard condition for the purposes of this Part.

14.5

The modification of a condition of a licence under this section has effect
subject to the giving of a direction under  paragraph 2  of  Schedule 2  in
relation to the decision to which the modification relates.

###### Modification by order under other enactments

15

15.1

Where the CMA or (as the case may be) the Secretary of State (in this section
“the relevant authority”) makes a relevant order, the order may also provide
for the modification of—

15.1.a

the conditions of a particular licence, or

15.1.b

the standard conditions of licences,

to such extent as may appear to the relevant authority to be necessary or
expedient for the purpose of giving effect to, or taking account of, any
provision made by the order.

15.2

In  subsection (1)  “ relevant order ” means—

15.2.a

an order under section 75, 83 or 84 of, or paragraph 5, 10 or 11 of Schedule 7
to, the Enterprise Act 2002 where—

15.2.a.i

one or more than one of the enterprises which have, or may have, ceased to be
distinct enterprises was engaged in the carrying on of activities authorised
or regulated by a licence, or

15.2.a.ii

one or more than one of the enterprises which will or may cease to be distinct
enterprises is engaged in the carrying on of activities authorised or
regulated by a licence, or

15.2.b

an order under section 160 or 161 of that Act where the feature, or
combination of features, of the market or markets in the United Kingdom for
goods or services which prevents, restricts or distorts competition relates to
activities authorised or regulated by a licence.

15.3

The modification under  subsection (1) (a)  of part of a standard condition of
a particular licence does not prevent any other part of the condition from
continuing to be regarded as a standard condition for the purposes of this
Part.

15.4

Where at any time the relevant authority modifies under  subsection (1) (b)
the standard conditions of licences, the relevant authority—

15.4.a

must also make (as nearly as possible) the same modifications of those
conditions for the purposes of their incorporation in licences granted after
that time, and

15.4.b

may, after consultation with the economic regulator, make such incidental or
consequential modifications as the relevant authority considers necessary or
expedient of any conditions of licences under that provision granted before
that time.

15.5

Where at any time the relevant authority modifies standard conditions under
subsection (4) (a)  for the purposes of their incorporation in licences
granted after that time, the relevant authority must publish those
modifications in such manner as the relevant authority considers appropriate.

15.6

Expressions used in  subsection (2)  and in Part 3 or (as the case may be)
Part 4 of the Enterprise Act 2002 have the same meanings in that subsection as
in that Part.

##### Interim power of Secretary of State to grant licences

###### Interim power of Secretary of State to grant licences

16

Schedule 1  makes provision about the power of the Secretary of State to grant
licences during an interim period.

##### Termination of licence

###### Termination of licence

17

17.1

If the economic regulator considers that a termination event has arisen, or is
likely to arise, the economic regulator must notify the persons mentioned in
subsection (2)  as soon as reasonably practicable.

17.2

Those persons are—

17.2.a

the Secretary of State;

17.2.b

the Scottish Ministers, if an activity authorised by the licence is within
Scottish devolved competence;

17.2.c

the Welsh Ministers, if an activity authorised by the licence is within Welsh
devolved competence;

17.2.d

the Department for the Economy in Northern Ireland, if an activity authorised
by the licence is within Northern Ireland devolved competence;

17.2.e

the Oil and Gas Authority;

17.2.f

any affected persons not falling within paragraphs  (a)  to  (e)  that the
economic regulator considers appropriate.

17.3

A notice under  subsection (1)  must specify—

17.3.a

in a case where a termination event has arisen, the date on which the economic
regulator proposes to revoke the licence, and

17.3.b

in any case, the date by which any representations must be made.

17.4

For the purposes of this section an activity authorised by a licence—

17.4.a

is within Scottish devolved competence if provision about that activity would
be within the legislative competence of the Scottish Parliament if it were
contained in an Act of that Parliament;

17.4.b

is within Welsh devolved competence if provision about that activity would be
within the legislative competence of Senedd Cymru if it were contained in an
Act of the Senedd (ignoring any requirement for the consent of a Minister of
the Crown imposed under Schedule 7B to the Government of Wales Act 2006);

17.4.c

is within Northern Ireland devolved competence if provision about that
activity—

17.4.c.i

would be within the legislative competence of the Northern Ireland Assembly if
it were contained in an Act of that Assembly, and

17.4.c.ii

would not, if it were contained in a Bill in the Northern Ireland Assembly,
result in the Bill requiring the consent of the Secretary of State under
section 8 of the Northern Ireland Act 1998.

17.5

In this section—

      “ affected person ” means a person that the economic regulator considers
may be affected by the decision as to whether the licence should be
terminated;           “ termination event ” means a state of affairs in which
the economic regulator is authorised to revoke the licence.

##### Transfer of licences

###### Transfer of licences

18

18.1

A licence—

18.1.a

is to be capable of being transferred by the licence holder, with the consent
of the economic regulator, in accordance with this section and subject to any
term of the licence relating to its transfer;

18.1.b

may include conditions which must be complied with before the licence can be
transferred.

18.2

A transfer may relate to the whole or any part of the licence.

18.3

The reference in  subsection (2)  to part of a licence is a reference to a
part of the activities authorised by the licence (whether described by
reference to activities being carried on by the licence holder or to
activities which the licence holder is authorised to carry on).

18.4

Such consent may be given subject to compliance with such modification
conditions or other conditions as the economic regulator considers necessary
or expedient.

18.5

In the case of a partial transfer, conditions imposed under  subsection (4)
may make, as respects so much of the licence as is proposed to be retained by
the transferor, provision different from that made as respects so much of the
licence as is proposed to be transferred.

18.6

Conditions imposed under  subsection (4)  may in particular require—

18.6.a

the transfer of rights, liabilities or property to the transferee;

18.6.b

the creation of rights in relation to property, rights or liabilities in
favour of the transferee;

18.6.c

the creation of other rights and liabilities as between the transferor and
transferee.

18.7

A purported transfer of a licence is to be void—

18.7.a

if the licence is not capable of transfer or the economic regulator has not
given its consent under  section 19 ,

18.7.b

if the purported transfer is in breach of a condition of the licence, or

18.7.c

if there has, before the purported transfer, been a contravention of a
condition subject to compliance with which the economic regulator’s consent is
given.

18.8

In this section—

      “ modification condition ” means a condition requiring, or otherwise
providing for the making of, modifications to the conditions of a licence;
“ transfer ” includes any form of transfer or assignment or, in Scotland,
assignation.

###### Consenting to transfer

19

19.1

Before giving consent to the transfer of a licence under  section 18 (1) , the
economic regulator must—

19.1.a

publish a notice stating that it proposes to grant consent to the transfer,

19.1.b

send a copy of the notice to—

19.1.b.i

the Scottish Ministers, if an activity authorised by the licence is within
Scottish devolved competence,

19.1.b.ii

the Welsh Ministers, if an activity authorised by the licence is within Welsh
devolved competence,

19.1.b.iii

the Department for the Economy in Northern Ireland, if an activity authorised
by the licence is within Northern Ireland devolved competence,

19.1.b.iv

the Oil and Gas Authority, and

19.1.b.v

such other persons as the economic regulator considers are likely to be
affected by the decision, and

19.1.c

consider any representations or objections that are duly made and not
withdrawn.

19.2

Section  17 (4)  (activities authorised by a licence: devolved competence)
applies for the purposes of  subsection (1) (b)  of this section as it applies
for the purposes of  section 17 .

19.3

A notice under  subsection (1)  must—

19.3.a

state the reasons why the economic regulator proposes to give consent;

19.3.b

specify any conditions the economic regulator proposes to impose under
section 18 (4) ;

19.3.c

specify the time from the date of publication of the notice (which must not be
less than two months) within which representations or objections with respect
to the proposed transfer may be made,

and must be published in such manner as the economic regulator considers
appropriate for bringing it to the attention of persons likely to be affected
by the transfer.

19.4

Subject to  subsection (6) , the economic regulator must, following
consideration of any representations or objections under  subsection (3) ,
give the Secretary of State not less than 28 days’ notice of—

19.4.a

any proposal to give consent to the transfer, and

19.4.b

any conditions the economic regulator proposes to impose under  section 18 (4)
.

19.5

If, before the expiry of the time specified in a notice under  subsection (4)
, the Secretary of State gives the economic regulator a direction not to
consent to the transfer, the economic regulator must comply with that
direction.

19.6

Where the Secretary of State gives no direction under  subsection (5) , the
economic regulator may give consent to the transfer of the licence after—

19.6.a

the expiry of the time specified in the notice under  subsection (4) , or

19.6.b

if earlier than the time in  paragraph (a) , the time at which the Secretary
of State informs the economic regulator that in relation to the notice no
direction will be given under  subsection (5) .

##### Appeal from decisions of the economic regulator

###### Appeal to the CMA

20

20.1

An appeal may be made to the CMA against a decision by the economic regulator
to proceed with the modification of a condition of a licence under  section 13
.

20.2

An appeal may be brought under this section only by—

20.2.a

a relevant licence holder (within the meaning of  section 13 );

20.2.b

a transport and storage network user whose interests are materially affected
by the decision;

20.2.c

a qualifying body or association in the capacity of representing a person
falling within paragraph (a) or (b);

20.3

The permission of the CMA is required for the bringing of an appeal under this
section.

20.4

The CMA may refuse permission to bring an appeal only on one of the following
grounds—

20.4.a

in relation to an appeal brought by a person falling within  subsection (2)
(b) , that the interests of the person are not materially affected by the
decision;

20.4.b

in relation to an appeal brought by a qualifying body or association, that the
interests of the person represented are not materially affected by the
decision;

20.4.c

in relation to any appeal—

20.4.c.i

that the appeal is brought for reasons that are trivial or vexatious;

20.4.c.ii

that the appeal has no reasonable prospect of success.

20.5

References in this section to a “qualifying body or association” are to a body
or association whose functions are or include representing persons in respect
of interests of theirs which are materially affected by the decision in
question.

20.6

In this section “ transport and storage network user ” has the same meaning as
in  section 1 .

###### Procedure on appeal to CMA

21

21.1

Schedule 2  has effect.

21.2

Except where specified otherwise in  Schedule 2 , the functions of the CMA
with respect to an appeal under  section 20  are to be carried out on behalf
of the CMA by a group constituted for the purpose by the chair of the CMA
under Schedule 4 to the Enterprise and Regulatory Reform Act 2013.

###### Determination by CMA of appeal

22

22.1

This section applies to every appeal brought under  section 20 .

22.2

In determining an appeal the CMA must have regard, to the same extent as is
required of the economic regulator, to the matters to which the economic
regulator must have regard—

22.2.a

in the carrying out of its principal objectives under  section 1 , and

22.2.b

in the performance of its duties under that section.

22.3

In determining the appeal the CMA—

22.3.a

may have regard to any matter to which the economic regulator was not able to
have regard in relation to the decision which is the subject of the appeal,
but

22.3.b

must not, in the exercise of that power, have regard to any matter to which
the economic regulator would not have been entitled to have regard in reaching
its decision had it had the opportunity of doing so.

22.4

The CMA may allow the appeal only to the extent that it is satisfied that the
decision appealed against was wrong on one or more of the following grounds—

22.4.a

that the economic regulator failed properly to have regard to any matter
mentioned in  subsection (2) ;

22.4.b

that the economic regulator failed to give the appropriate weight to any
matter mentioned in  subsection (2) ;

22.4.c

that the decision was based, wholly or partly, on an error of fact;

22.4.d

that the modifications fail to achieve, in whole or in part, the effect stated
by the economic regulator by virtue of  section 13 (8) (b) ;

22.4.e

that the decision was wrong in law.

22.5

To the extent that the CMA does not allow the appeal, it must confirm the
decision appealed against.

###### CMA’s powers on allowing appeal

23

23.1

This section applies where the CMA allows an appeal to any extent.

23.2

If the appeal is in relation to a price control decision, the CMA must do one
or more of the following—

23.2.a

quash the decision (to the extent that the appeal is allowed);

23.2.b

remit the matter back to the economic regulator for reconsideration and
determination in accordance with any directions given by the CMA;

23.2.c

substitute the CMA’s decision for that of the economic regulator (to the
extent that the appeal is allowed) and give any directions to the economic
regulator or any other party to the appeal.

23.3

If the appeal is in relation to any other decision, the CMA must do one or
both of the following—

23.3.a

quash the decision (to the extent that the appeal is allowed);

23.3.b

remit the matter back to the economic regulator for reconsideration and
determination in accordance with any directions given by the CMA.

23.4

A direction under  subsection (2)  or (3) must not require a person to do
anything that the person would not have power to do (apart from the
direction).

23.5

A person to whom a direction is given under that subsection must comply with
it.

23.6

A direction given under that subsection to a person other than the economic
regulator is enforceable as if it were an order of the High Court or (in
Scotland) an order of the Court of Session.

23.7

For the purposes of this section a decision is a “ price control decision ”,
in relation to the modification of a condition of a licence, if the purpose of
the condition is, in the CMA’s opinion, to limit or control the charges on, or
the revenue of, the holder of the licence.

23.8

In determining for the purposes of  subsection (7)  what the purpose of a
condition is, the condition may be assessed on its own or in combination with
any other conditions of the licence.

23.9

In this section and  section 24  any reference to a party to an appeal is to
be read in accordance with  Schedule 2 .

###### Time limits for CMA to determine an appeal

24

24.1

The CMA must—

24.1.a

determine an appeal against a price control decision within the period of 6
months beginning with the permission date;

24.1.b

determine an appeal against any other decision within the period of 4 months
beginning with the permission date.

24.2

Subsection  (1) (a)  or (b) does not apply if  subsection (3)  applies.

24.3

This subsection applies where—

24.3.a

the CMA has received representations on the timing of the determination from a
party to the appeal, and

24.3.b

it is satisfied that there are special reasons why the determination cannot be
made within the period specified in subsection  (1) (a)  or (b).

24.4

Where  subsection (3)  applies, the CMA must—

24.4.a

determine an appeal against a price control decision within the period
specified by it, which must not be longer than the period of 7 months
beginning with the permission date;

24.4.b

determine an appeal against any other decision within the period specified by
it, which must not be longer than the period of 5 months beginning with the
permission date.

24.5

Where  subsection (3)  applies, the CMA must also—

24.5.a

inform the parties to the appeal of the time limit for determining the appeal,
and

24.5.b

publish that time limit in such manner as it considers appropriate for the
purpose of bringing it to the attention of any other persons likely to be
affected by the determination.

24.6

In this section “ price control decision ” is to be read in accordance with
section 23 .

24.7

References in this section to the “permission date” are to the date on which
the CMA gave permission to bring the appeal in accordance with  section 20 (3)
.

###### Determination of appeal by CMA: supplementary

25

25.1

A determination by the CMA on an appeal—

25.1.a

must be contained in an order made by the CMA;

25.1.b

must set out the reasons for the determination;

25.1.c

takes effect at the time—

25.1.c.i

specified in the order, or

25.1.c.ii

determined in accordance with provision made in the order;

25.1.d

must be notified by the CMA to the parties to the appeal;

25.1.e

must be published by the CMA—

25.1.e.i

as soon as reasonably practicable after the determination is made;

25.1.e.ii

in such manner as the CMA considers appropriate for the purpose of bringing
the determination to the attention of any person likely to be affected by it
(other than a party to the appeal).

25.2

The CMA may exclude from publication under subsection  (1) (e)  any
information which it is satisfied is—

25.2.a

commercial information, the disclosure of which would, or might in the CMA’s
opinion, significantly harm the legitimate business interests of an
undertaking to which it relates, or

25.2.b

information relating to the private affairs of an individual, the disclosure
of which would, or might in the CMA’s opinion, significantly harm the
individual’s interests.

25.3

The economic regulator must take such steps as it considers necessary for it
to comply with an order of the CMA made by virtue of  subsection (1) (a) .

25.4

The steps must be taken—

25.4.a

if a time is specified in (or is to be determined in accordance with) the
order, within that time;

25.4.b

in any other case, within a reasonable time.

25.5

Subsections  (2)  to (4) of  section 14  (consequences of modification of
standard conditions) apply where a condition of a licence is modified in
accordance with  section 23  as they apply where a condition of a licence is
modified under  section 13 .

##### Information

###### Provision of information to or by the economic regulator

26

26.1

The economic regulator may provide to a person within  subsection (2)  such
information as the economic regulator considers necessary in connection with
the exercise by the economic regulator of its functions relating to the
regulation of licensable activities.

26.2

The persons within this subsection are—

26.2.a

the Oil and Gas Authority;

26.2.b

the Environment Agency;

26.2.c

the Scottish Environment Protection Agency;

26.2.d

Natural Resources Wales;

26.2.e

the Health and Safety Executive;

26.2.f

the Health and Safety Executive for Northern Ireland;

26.2.g

the CMA;

26.2.h

the Scottish Ministers;

26.2.i

the Welsh Ministers;

26.2.j

the Department for the Economy in Northern Ireland;

26.2.k

the Northern Ireland Environment Agency;

26.2.l

the Secretary of State;

26.2.m

any other person the economic regulator considers appropriate who has powers
or duties conferred by or by virtue of primary legislation which the economic
regulator considers relevant to the exercise of the economic regulator’s
functions relating to the regulation of licensable activities.

26.3

The economic regulator may by notice request from a person within  subsection
(2)  such information as the economic regulator considers necessary in
connection with the exercise by the economic regulator of its functions
relating to the regulation of licensable activities.

26.4

A person to whom a request is made under  subsection (3)  must, so far as
reasonably practicable, provide the requested information within such period,
and in such form and manner, as may be specified in the notice.

26.5

Except as provided by  subsection (6) , the disclosure of information under
this section does not breach—

26.5.a

any obligation of confidence owed by the person making the disclosure, or

26.5.b

any other restriction on the disclosure of information (however imposed).

26.6

This section does not authorise or require a disclosure of information if the
disclosure would contravene the data protection legislation (but in
determining whether a disclosure would do so, the power conferred by
subsection (1)  or, as the case may be, the duty under  subsection (4)  is to
be taken into account).

26.7

In this section “ primary legislation ” means—

26.7.a

an Act of Parliament,

26.7.b

an Act of the Scottish Parliament,

26.7.c

an Act or Measure of Senedd Cymru, or

26.7.d

Northern Ireland legislation.

###### Power of Secretary of State to require information

27

27.1

The Secretary of State may by notice in writing require a licence holder to
provide the Secretary of State with information which is reasonably required
by the Secretary of State for the purposes of the Secretary of State’s
functions under this Part.

27.2

A notice under  subsection (1)  must specify—

27.2.a

the form and manner in which information is to be provided, and

27.2.b

the time within which it is to be provided.

27.3

A licence holder may not be required under this section to provide any
information that would be protected from disclosure or production in legal
proceedings on grounds of legal professional privilege or, in Scotland,
confidentiality of communications.

27.4

Except as provided by  subsection (5) , the disclosure of information under
this section does not breach—

27.4.a

any obligation of confidence owed by the licence holder making the disclosure,
or

27.4.b

any other restriction on the disclosure of information (however imposed).

27.5

This section does not authorise or require a disclosure of information if the
disclosure would contravene the data protection legislation (but in
determining whether a disclosure would do so, a requirement imposed under
subsection (1)  is to be taken into account).

##### Other functions of the economic regulator

###### Monitoring, information gathering etc

28

28.1

The economic regulator must keep under review the carrying on in the United
Kingdom and elsewhere of the following activities—

28.1.a

operating a site for the disposal of carbon dioxide by way of geological
storage;

28.1.b

providing a service of transporting carbon dioxide by a licensable means of
transportation;

28.1.c

activities ancillary to activities mentioned in paragraph (a) or (b).

28.2

The economic regulator may, for the purpose of facilitating the performance of
its functions under this Part, collect information with respect to such
activities.

28.3

The economic regulator must give the Secretary of State or the CMA any
information they may request with respect to any matter relating to the
economic regulator’s functions under this Part.

###### Power to require information for purposes of monitoring

29

29.1

The economic regulator may, for the purpose of exercising its functions under
subsections  (1)  and  (2)  of  section 28 , serve a notice under  subsection
(2)  on any licence holder.

29.2

A notice under this subsection is a notice which—

29.2.a

requires the person on whom it is served to produce, at a time and place
specified in the notice, to the economic regulator any documents which are
specified or described in the notice and are in that person’s custody or under
their control, or

29.2.b

requires that person, if they are carrying on a business, to provide to the
economic regulator in the form and manner, and within the period, specified in
the notice, the information specified or described in the notice.

29.3

In paragraphs (a) and (b) of  subsection (2)  the reference to the economic
regulator includes a person appointed by the economic regulator for the
purpose of exercising the function in question.

29.4

A person who intentionally alters, suppresses or destroys any document or
record of information which that person has been required to produce by a
notice under  subsection (2)  is guilty of an offence liable—

29.4.a

on summary conviction in England and Wales, to a fine;

29.4.b

on summary conviction in Scotland or Northern Ireland, to a fine not exceeding
the statutory maximum;

29.4.c

on conviction on indictment, to a fine.

29.5

Except as provided by  subsection (6) , the disclosure of information under
this section does not breach—

29.5.a

any obligation of confidence owed by the person making the disclosure, or

29.5.b

any other restriction on the disclosure of information (however imposed).

29.6

This section does not authorise or require a disclosure of information if the
disclosure would contravene the data protection legislation (but in
determining whether a disclosure would do so, a requirement imposed by virtue
of  subsection (2)  is to be taken into account).

###### Duty to carry out impact assessment

30

30.1

This section applies where—

30.1.a

the economic regulator is proposing to do anything for the purposes of, or in
connection with, the carrying out of any function exercisable by it under or
by virtue of this Part, and

30.1.b

it appears to the economic regulator that the proposal is important;

but this section does not apply if it appears to the economic regulator that
the urgency of the matter makes it impracticable or inappropriate for the
economic regulator to comply with the requirements of this section.

30.2

A proposal is important for the purposes of this section only if its
implementation would be likely to do one or more of the following—

30.2.a

involve a major change in the activities carried on by the economic regulator;

30.2.b

have a significant impact on persons engaged in the capture, transportation or
storage of carbon dioxide;

30.2.c

have a significant impact on persons engaged in commercial activities
connected with the capture, transportation or storage of carbon dioxide;

30.2.d

have a significant impact on the general public in the United Kingdom or in a
part of the United Kingdom;

30.2.e

have significant effects on the environment.

30.3

Before implementing its proposal, the economic regulator must either—

30.3.a

carry out and publish an assessment of the likely impact of implementing the
proposal, or

30.3.b

publish a statement setting out its reasons for thinking that it is
unnecessary for it to carry out an assessment.

30.4

An assessment carried out under this section must—

30.4.a

include an assessment of the likely effects on the environment of implementing
the proposal, and

30.4.b

relate to such other matters as the economic regulator considers appropriate.

30.5

In determining the matters to which an assessment under this section should
relate, the economic regulator must have regard to such general guidance
relating to the carrying out of impact assessments as it considers
appropriate.

30.6

An assessment carried out under this section may take such form as the
economic regulator considers appropriate.

30.7

Where the economic regulator publishes an assessment under this section—

30.7.a

it must provide an opportunity of making representations to the economic
regulator about its proposal to members of the public and other persons who,
in the economic regulator’s opinion, are likely to be affected to a
significant extent by the proposal’s implementation,

30.7.b

the published assessment must be accompanied by a statement setting out how
representations may be made, and

30.7.c

the economic regulator must not implement its proposal unless the period for
making representations about the proposal has expired and it has considered
all the representations that were made in that period.

30.8

Where the economic regulator is required (apart from this section)—

30.8.a

to consult about a proposal to which this section applies, or

30.8.b

to give a person an opportunity of making representations about it,

the requirements of this section are in addition to, but may be performed
contemporaneously with, the other requirements.

30.9

Every report under  section 41  (annual reports on transport and storage
licensing functions) must set out—

30.9.a

a list of the assessments under this section carried out during the financial
year to which the report relates, and

30.9.b

a summary of the decisions taken during that year in relation to proposals to
which assessments carried out in that year or previous financial years relate.

30.10

The publication of anything under this section must be in such manner as the
economic regulator considers appropriate for bringing it to the attention of
the persons who, in the economic regulator’s opinion, are likely to be
affected if its proposal is implemented.

###### Reasons for decisions

31

31.1

This section applies to the following decisions of the economic regulator or
the Secretary of State—

31.1.a

the revocation of a licence;

31.1.b

the modification of the conditions of a licence;

31.1.c

the giving of any directions or consent in pursuance of a condition included
in a licence by virtue of  section 11 (2) (a)  or  (c) ;

31.1.d

the determination of a question referred in pursuance of a condition included
in a licence by virtue of  section 11 (2) (d) ;

31.1.e

the making of a final order, the making or confirmation of a provisional order
or the revocation of a final order or of a provisional order which has been
confirmed.

31.2

As soon as reasonably practicable after making such a decision the economic
regulator or the Secretary of State (“the decision maker”) must—

31.2.a

publish a notice stating the reasons for the decision in such manner as the
decision maker considers appropriate for the purpose of bringing the matters
to which the notice relates to the attention of persons likely to be
interested, and

31.2.b

send a copy of the notice to the licence holder to whose licence, or to whom,
the decision relates.

31.3

In preparing a notice under  subsection (2)  the decision maker must have
regard to the need for excluding, so far as that is practicable, any matter
which relates to the affairs of a particular individual or body of persons
(corporate or unincorporate), where the decision maker considers that
publication of that matter would or might seriously and prejudicially affect
the interests of that individual or body.

31.4

In this Part “ final order ” and “ provisional order ” have the same meaning
as in  Schedule 3  (see  paragraph 1 (12)  of that Schedule).

##### Enforcement

###### Enforcement of obligations of licence holders

32

Schedule 3  makes provision for the enforcement of conditions of licences and
of other requirements imposed on licence holders by or under this Part.

##### False statements

###### Making of false statements etc

33

33.1

A person who, in giving any information or making any application for the
purposes of any provision of this Part, or of any regulation made under any
provision of this Part, makes any statement which the person knows to be false
in a material particular, or recklessly makes any statement which is false in
a material particular, is guilty of an offence and liable—

33.1.a

on summary conviction in England and Wales, to a fine;

33.1.b

on summary conviction in Scotland or Northern Ireland, to a fine not exceeding
the statutory maximum;

33.1.c

on conviction on indictment, to a fine.

33.2

Proceedings for an offence under  subsection (1)  must not in England and
Wales be instituted except by or with the consent of the Secretary of State or
the Director of Public Prosecutions.

33.3

Proceedings for an offence under  subsection (1)  must not in Northern Ireland
be instituted except by or with the consent of the Director of Public
Prosecutions for Northern Ireland.

##### Criminal liability and procedure

###### Liability of officers of entities

34

34.1

Where an offence under this Part committed by a body corporate is proved—

34.1.a

to have been committed with the consent or connivance of an officer of the
body corporate, or

34.1.b

to be attributable to neglect on the part of an officer of the body corporate,

that officer (as well as the body corporate) commits the offence and is liable
to be proceeded against and dealt with accordingly.

34.2

In subsection (1) “ officer ”, in relation to a body corporate, means—

34.2.a

any director, manager, secretary or other similar officer of the body
corporate, or

34.2.b

any person purporting to act in any such capacity.

34.3

In subsection (2) “ director ”, in relation to a body corporate whose affairs
are managed by its members, means a member of the body corporate.

34.4

Where an offence under this Part is committed by a Scottish partnership and is
proved to have been committed with the consent or connivance of a partner, or
to be attributable to any neglect on the part of a partner, that partner (as
well as the partnership) commits the offence and is liable to be proceeded
against and dealt with accordingly.

###### Criminal proceedings

35

35.1

Proceedings for an offence under this Part may be taken, and the offence may
for all incidental purposes be treated as having been committed, in any place
in the United Kingdom.

35.2

Section 3 of the Territorial Waters Jurisdiction Act 1878 (restriction on
prosecutions) does not apply to any proceedings for an offence under this
Part.

35.3

Proceedings for an offence under this Part alleged to have been committed in
an offshore place may not be instituted in England and Wales except—

35.3.a

by the Secretary of State or a person authorised by the Secretary of State, or

35.3.b

by or with the consent of the Director of Public Prosecutions.

35.4

Proceedings for an offence under this Part alleged to have been committed in
an offshore place may not be instituted in Northern Ireland except—

35.4.a

by the Secretary of State or a person authorised by the Secretary of State, or

35.4.b

by or with the consent of the Director of Public Prosecutions for Northern
Ireland.

35.5

In this section “ offshore place ” means a place in, under or over—

35.5.a

the territorial sea adjacent to the United Kingdom, or

35.5.b

waters in a Gas Importation and Storage Zone (within the meaning given by
section 1 of the Energy Act 2008).
