“ eligible ” in relation to a carbon capture entity.

68.5

Regulations within  subsection (4)  may in particular make provision by
reference to standards or other published documents (as they have effect from
time to time).

##### Hydrogen levy

###### Appointment of hydrogen levy administrator

69

69.1

The Secretary of State may by regulations appoint a person to carry out
functions with respect to obligations of relevant market participants under
section 70 .

69.2

The Secretary of State may exercise the power under  subsection (1)  so that
more than one appointment has effect under that subsection at the same time.

69.3

An appointment may be made only with the consent of the person appointed
(except where that person is the Secretary of State).

69.4

An appointment ceases to have effect if the Secretary of State by regulations
revokes the appointment.

69.5

As soon as reasonably practicable after a person’s appointment under
subsection (1)  ceases to have effect, the Secretary of State must make one or
more transfer schemes under  section 86  to ensure the transfer of any rights
and liabilities of that person that the Secretary of State considers
appropriate.

69.6

A person appointed under  subsection (1)  is called a “hydrogen levy
administrator”.

###### Obligations of relevant market participants

70

70.1

Revenue support regulations may make provision for relevant market
participants (see  subsection (8) ) to make payments to a hydrogen levy
administrator for the purpose of enabling—

70.1.a

a hydrogen transport counterparty to make payments under a hydrogen transport
revenue support contract or in respect of liabilities incurred in connection
with hydrogen transport revenue support contracts;

70.1.b

a hydrogen storage counterparty to make payments under a hydrogen storage
revenue support contract or in respect of liabilities incurred in connection
with hydrogen storage revenue support contracts;

70.1.c

a hydrogen production counterparty to make payments under a hydrogen
production revenue support contract or in respect of liabilities incurred in
connection with the contract;

70.1.d

a counterparty to a carbon dioxide transport and storage revenue support
contract to make payments under that contract, or in respect of liabilities
incurred in connection with that contract, for a purpose connected with
hydrogen production revenue support contracts.

70.2

Revenue support regulations may make provision for relevant market
participants to make payments to a hydrogen levy administrator for the purpose
of enabling the hydrogen levy administrator—

70.2.a

to meet or reimburse such descriptions of relevant costs (whether of the
hydrogen levy administrator or another person) as the Secretary of State
considers appropriate;

70.2.b

to hold sums in reserve;

70.2.c

to cover losses in the case of insolvency or default of a relevant market
participant.

70.3

Revenue support regulations may make provision about the method of calculating
or determining amounts that are to be paid by a hydrogen levy administrator
for a purpose mentioned in subsection  (1)  or  (2) , including provision for
adjustments or apportionments in cases where an amount required to be paid by
a hydrogen levy administrator for such a purpose has not been paid in full.

70.4

Revenue support regulations may make provision to require relevant market
participants to provide financial collateral to a hydrogen levy administrator
(whether in cash, securities or any other form).

70.5

Revenue support regulations that make provision by virtue of  subsection (1)
for the payment of sums by relevant market participants must impose on a
hydrogen levy administrator a duty in relation to the collection of such sums.

70.6

In  subsection (1)  a reference to liabilities incurred in connection with a
revenue support contract includes liabilities incurred in connection with a
contract entered into by the counterparty concerned for a purpose related to
that contract.

70.7

In  subsection (2)  “ relevant costs ” means any costs in connection with the
performance of any function conferred by or by virtue of this Chapter.

70.8

In this Chapter “ relevant market participants ” means one or more
descriptions of persons specified in revenue support regulations, but a
description so specified may not include persons other than—

70.8.a

GB gas shippers;

70.8.b

Northern Ireland gas shippers.

70.9

Revenue support regulations may make provision about eligibility for
exemptions from obligations imposed on relevant market participants by
regulations within subsections  (1)  to  (4) .

###### Payments to relevant market participants

71

71.1

Revenue support regulations may make provision about amounts which must be
paid—

71.1.a

by a hydrogen levy administrator to relevant market participants, or

71.1.b

by a relevant counterparty—

71.1.b.i

to relevant market participants, or

71.1.b.ii

to a hydrogen levy administrator for the purpose of enabling payments to be
made to relevant market participants.

71.2

Regulations by virtue of subsection  (1)  may make provision—

71.2.a

for a hydrogen levy administrator to calculate or determine, in accordance
with such criteria as may be provided for by or under the regulations, amounts
which are owed by—

71.2.a.i

the hydrogen levy administrator, or

71.2.a.ii

a relevant counterparty;

71.2.b

for a relevant counterparty to calculate or determine, in accordance with such
criteria as may be provided for by or under the regulations, amounts which are
owed by—

71.2.b.i

the relevant counterparty, or

71.2.b.ii

a hydrogen levy administrator;

71.2.c

for the issuing of notices by a hydrogen levy administrator to require the
payment by a relevant counterparty of amounts calculated or determined by the
hydrogen levy administrator in accordance with paragraph  (a) (ii) ;

71.2.d

for the issuing of notices by a relevant counterparty to require the payment
by a hydrogen levy administrator of amounts calculated or determined by the
relevant counterparty in accordance with paragraph  (b) (ii) ;

71.2.e

for the provision of copies of notices such as are mentioned in paragraph (c)
or (d) to persons specified in the regulations, or the publication of such
notices.

71.3

Revenue support regulations may make provision imposing on a relevant market
participant who receives a payment from a hydrogen levy administrator or a
relevant counterparty a requirement to secure that customers of the relevant
market participant receive, by a time specified in the regulations, such
benefit from the payment as may be specified in or determined in accordance
with the regulations.

71.4

In this section “ relevant counterparty ” means any of the following—

71.4.a

a hydrogen transport counterparty;

71.4.b

a hydrogen storage counterparty;

71.4.c

a hydrogen production counterparty.

###### Functions of hydrogen levy administrator

72

72.1

Revenue support regulations may make provision—

72.1.a

specifying things that a hydrogen levy administrator may or must do, or things
that a hydrogen levy administrator may not do;

72.1.b

conferring on the Secretary of State powers to direct a hydrogen levy
administrator to do, or not to do, things specified in the regulations or the
direction.

72.2

The following provisions of this section are without prejudice to the
generality of  subsection (1) (a) .

72.3

Revenue support regulations may make provision—

72.3.a

for a hydrogen levy administrator to calculate or determine, in accordance
with such criteria as may be provided for by or under the regulations, amounts
that are owed by a relevant market participant or are to be provided as
financial collateral by a relevant market participant;

72.3.b

for the issuing of notices by a hydrogen levy administrator to require the
payment or provision of such amounts;

72.3.c

for the provision of copies of such notices to persons specified in the
regulations or the publication of such notices;

72.3.d

for the enforcement of obligations imposed by or under the regulations
(including provision about interest on late payments and imposing financial
penalties);

72.3.e

about the resolution of disputes, including provision about arbitration or
appeals (which may in particular include provision for the person conducting
an arbitration or determining an appeal to order the payment of costs or
expenses or compensation);

72.3.f

for a hydrogen levy administrator to determine the form and terms of any
financial collateral;

72.3.g

for a hydrogen levy administrator to hold sums in reserve.

72.4

Provision made by virtue of  subsection (3) (a)  or  section 70 (3)  or  (9)
or  71 (2)  or  (3)  may provide for anything that is to be calculated or
determined under the regulations to be calculated or determined—

72.4.a

by such persons,

72.4.b

in accordance with such procedure, and

72.4.c

by reference to such matters and to the opinion of such persons,

as may be specified in the regulations.

72.5

Provision made by virtue of  subsection (3) (d)  for the imposition of a
financial penalty must include provision for a right of appeal against the
imposition of the penalty.

72.6

Any sum that—

72.6.a

a relevant market participant is required by virtue of revenue support
regulations to pay to a hydrogen levy administrator, and

72.6.b

has not been paid by the date on which it is required by virtue of revenue
support regulations to be paid,

may be recovered from the relevant market participant by the hydrogen levy
administrator as a civil debt due to it.

72.7

Revenue support regulations may make provision about the application of sums
held by a hydrogen levy administrator.

72.8

The provision that may be made by virtue of  subsection (7)  includes
provision that sums are to be paid, or not to be paid, into the Consolidated
Fund.

##### Allocation of contracts

###### Power to appoint allocation bodies

73

73.1

The Secretary of State may by regulations appoint—

73.1.a

a person to carry out functions in connection with the allocation of hydrogen
production revenue support contracts;

73.1.b

a person to carry out functions in connection with the allocation of carbon
capture revenue support contracts.

73.2

The power under each paragraph of  subsection (1)  may be exercised so that
more than one appointment has effect under that paragraph at the same time.

73.3

An appointment may be made only with the consent of the person appointed
(except where that person is the Secretary of State).

73.4

An appointment ceases to have effect if—

73.4.a

the Secretary of State by regulations revokes the appointment, or

73.4.b

the person withdraws consent.

73.5

Regulations under  subsection (1)  may make provision with regard to the
cessation of an appointment, including—

73.5.a

provision requiring a person appointed under  subsection (1)  to give a period
of notice no shorter than a period specified in the regulations when
withdrawing their consent to appointment, or otherwise restricting or
subjecting to conditions a person’s power under  subsection (4)  to withdraw
consent;

73.5.b

provision enabling a person who has ceased to be appointed under  subsection
(1)  to continue to be treated as if they were so appointed, including
provision about the purposes for which, the circumstances in which, and the
period for which, such a person may be so treated.

73.6

In this Chapter—

73.6.a

a person appointed under  subsection (1) (a)  is called a “hydrogen production
allocation body”;

73.6.b

a person appointed under  subsection (1) (b)  is called a “carbon capture
allocation body”;

73.6.c

references to “allocating” a hydrogen production revenue support contract or
carbon capture revenue support contract to a person are to specifying the
person in a notification under  section 75 (1)  or  (2)  (and references to
the “ allocation ” of such a contract are to be interpreted accordingly);

73.6.d

“ allocation body ” means a hydrogen production allocation body or a carbon
capture allocation body.

73.7

Regulations under this section, other than regulations under  subsection (4)
(a) , are subject to the negative procedure.

###### Standard terms of revenue support contracts

74

74.1

The Secretary of State may issue standard terms and conditions (“standard
terms”) of—

74.1.a

hydrogen production revenue support contracts;

74.1.b

carbon capture revenue support contracts.

74.2

The Secretary of State may from time to time revise standard terms.

74.3

Standard terms issued or revised under this section must be in accordance with
provision made in revenue support regulations.

74.4

The Secretary of State must publish standard terms as issued or revised under
this section.

74.5

In publishing standard terms the Secretary of State may designate particular
standard terms as terms that may not be modified under  section 78 .

74.6

Different standard terms may be issued for different categories of hydrogen
production revenue support contract or carbon capture revenue support
contract.

###### Allocation notifications

75

75.1

A hydrogen production allocation body may, in accordance with provision made
by revenue support regulations, give a notification to a hydrogen production
counterparty specifying—

75.1.a

an eligible low carbon hydrogen producer, and

75.1.b

such other information as may be required for the purpose of making an offer
under  section 77  to contract with that low carbon hydrogen producer.

75.2

A carbon capture allocation body may, in accordance with provision made by
revenue support regulations, give a notification to a carbon capture
counterparty specifying—

75.2.a

an eligible carbon capture entity, and

75.2.b

such other information as may be required for the purpose of making an offer
under  section 77  to contract with that carbon capture entity.

75.3

A notification given under  subsection (1)  or  (2)  is called an “allocation
notification”.

75.4

Revenue support regulations may make further provision about allocation
notifications and in particular provision about—

75.4.a

the circumstances in which an allocation notification may or must be given;

75.4.b

the kinds of information that must be specified in an allocation notification
in accordance with  subsection (1) (b)  or  (2) (b) ;

75.4.c

appeals against decisions not to give allocation notifications.

###### Allocation of contracts

76

76.1

Provision that may be made in revenue support regulations for the purposes of
section 75 (1)  and  (2)  includes provision about how determinations are to
be made as regards—

76.1.a

which eligible low carbon hydrogen producer a hydrogen production revenue
support contract is to be allocated to;

76.1.b

which eligible carbon capture entity a carbon capture revenue support contract
is to be allocated to.

76.2

Provision made by revenue support regulations falling within  subsection (1)
may include—

76.2.a

provision conferring power on the Secretary of State to make rules (an
“allocation framework”) about the allocation of hydrogen production revenue
support contracts or carbon capture revenue support contracts;

76.2.b

provision for different periods within which hydrogen production revenue
support contracts or carbon capture revenue support contracts are to be
allocated (“allocation rounds”);

76.2.c

provision for different allocation frameworks to apply in respect of different
allocation rounds;

76.2.d

provision for the publication of allocation frameworks;

76.2.e

provision about matters in relation to which provision may or must be made in
an allocation framework.

76.3

Provision made by revenue support regulations falling within  subsection (2)
may impose requirements on the Secretary of State, including in particular—

76.3.a

requirements as to the giving of notice before an allocation round is
commenced;

76.3.b

restrictions on the circumstances in which amendments may be made during an
allocation round to an allocation framework or to any other matter relevant to
an allocation round (including any amount by reference to which a limit on the
contracts allocated during the round is to be determined).

76.4

An allocation framework may—

76.4.a

confer functions on an allocation body with respect to the allocation of
hydrogen production revenue support contracts or carbon capture revenue
support contracts;

76.4.b

specify targets to be met or taken into account by an allocation body in
giving allocation notifications by virtue of  section 75 , including targets
relating to—

76.4.b.i

the process used for producing hydrogen or for capturing carbon dioxide;

76.4.b.ii

outputs or capacity (whether in respect of hydrogen production or capture of
carbon dioxide);

76.4.b.iii

the geographical location of an applicant’s activities;

76.4.c

make provision by reference to standards or other published documents (as they
have effect from time to time);

76.4.d

make any provision that may be made by regulations by virtue of  subsection
(3) .

76.5

An allocation framework may include provision for—

76.5.a

the determination of a matter on a competitive basis;

76.5.b

calculations or determinations to be made under the framework, including by
such persons, in accordance with such procedure and by reference to such
matters and to the opinion of such persons, as may be specified in the
framework.

76.6

An allocation framework may—

76.6.a

include incidental, supplementary and consequential provision;

76.6.b

make transitory or transitional provision and savings;

76.6.c

make different provision for different cases or circumstances or for different
purposes;

76.6.d

make provision subject to exceptions.

76.7

Any power conferred by virtue of  subsection (2)  to make an allocation
framework includes a power to amend, add to or remove an allocation framework.

76.8

Subsections  (4)  to  (7)  are subject to any provision contained in revenue
support regulations.

###### Duty to offer to contract following allocation

77

77.1

Where an allocation notification is given to a hydrogen production
counterparty under  section 75 (1) , the counterparty must, in accordance with
provision made by revenue support regulations, offer to contract with the
eligible low carbon hydrogen producer specified in the notification on—

77.1.a

standard terms, or

77.1.b

standard terms as modified in accordance with any modification agreement
entered into between the counterparty and the eligible low carbon hydrogen
producer for the purposes of the allocation notification (see  section 78 ).

77.2

Where an allocation notification is given to a carbon capture counterparty
under  section 75 (2) , the counterparty must, in accordance with provision
made by revenue support regulations, offer to contract with the eligible
carbon capture entity specified in the notification on—

77.2.a

standard terms, or

77.2.b

standard terms as modified in accordance with any modification agreement
entered into between the counterparty and the eligible carbon capture entity
for the purposes of the allocation notification (see  section 78 ).

77.3

Revenue support regulations may make further provision about an offer to
contract made under this section, including provision about—

77.3.a

how a hydrogen production counterparty or carbon capture counterparty is to
apply or complete standard terms in relation to the offer in accordance with
information specified in an allocation notification;

77.3.b

the time within which the offer must be made;

77.3.c

how the eligible low carbon hydrogen producer or eligible carbon capture
entity to whom the offer is made may enter into a hydrogen production revenue
support contract or (as the case may be) carbon capture revenue support
contract as a result of the offer;

77.3.d

what is to happen if the eligible low carbon hydrogen producer or eligible
carbon capture entity does not enter into such a contract as a result of the
offer.

77.4

In this section, “ standard terms ”, in relation to an allocation
notification, means standard terms published under  section 74 , determined in
accordance with revenue support regulations as the standard terms that are to
apply in relation to the allocation notification.

###### Modification of standard terms

78

78.1

This section applies where a person wishes to be specified as an eligible low
carbon hydrogen producer, or an eligible carbon capture entity, in an
allocation notification (“the potential allocation notification”).

78.2

A hydrogen production counterparty or (as the case requires) carbon capture
counterparty and the person may, in accordance with provision made by revenue
support regulations, agree to modify standard terms for the purposes of any
offer that would be required under  section 77  if the potential allocation
notification is given (a “modification agreement”).

78.3

A hydrogen production counterparty or carbon capture counterparty may enter
into a modification agreement providing for the modification of any particular
standard term only if—

78.3.a

the counterparty is satisfied that—

78.3.a.i

the effect of the modification is minor, and

78.3.a.ii

the modification is necessary; and

78.3.b

the standard term has not been designated under  section 74 (5)  as a term
that may not be modified under this section.

78.4

Revenue support regulations may make further provision about modification
agreements, including—

78.4.a

the circumstances in which a person may make an application for a modification
agreement;

78.4.b

the time by which an application must be made;

78.4.c

the procedure to be followed, and the information to be given, by the person
in making an application;

78.4.d

how a hydrogen production counterparty or carbon capture counterparty is to
determine an application (including how it is to determine whether the effect
of a modification is minor and whether it is necessary);

78.4.e

the time by which determinations must be made;

78.4.f

the form of modification agreements.

78.5

Provision made by virtue of  subsection (4) (d)  may include provision under
which the counterparty may make alternative proposals for modifications in
response to an application.

78.6

In this section “ modify ” includes add to, alter or omit, and “modification”
is to be read accordingly.

###### Sections 

79

Provision made by regulations by virtue of any of sections  75  to  78  may
include provision for—

79.a

the determination of a matter on a competitive basis;

79.b

calculations or determinations to be made under the regulations, including by
such persons, in accordance with such procedure and by reference to such
matters and to the opinion of such persons, as may be specified in the
regulations.

###### Licence conditions regarding functions of certain allocation bodies

80

80.1

In section 7B of the Gas Act 1986, after subsection (5) insert—

80.1.5ZA

Without prejudice to the generality of paragraph (a) of subsection (4),
conditions for or in connection with the purpose set out in  subsection (5ZB)
may be included in a licence under section 7AA by virtue of that paragraph.

80.1.5ZB

The purpose is to facilitate or ensure the effective performance (whether in
relation to Northern Ireland or any other part of the United Kingdom), at
relevant times, of functions of a hydrogen production allocation body under
Chapter 1  of   Part 2  of the Energy Act 2023.

80.1.5ZC

In  subsection (5ZB)  “ relevant times ” means times when the hydrogen
production allocation body holds a licence under section 7AA.

80.2

Where—

80.2.a

the GEMA proposes by a modification under section 23 of the Gas Act 1986 of a
licence under section 7AA of that Act to add, remove or alter a condition such
as is mentioned in section 7B (5ZA)  of that Act, and

80.2.b

that condition relates to functions of a hydrogen production allocation body
that are exercisable in relation to Northern Ireland,

section 23 of that Act has effect as if the persons listed in subsection
(4)(b) of that section included the Department for the Economy in Northern
Ireland.

##### General provision about counterparties

###### Further provision about designations

81

81.1

A designation under  section 59 ,  61 ,  63 ,  65 , or  67  ceases to have
effect if—

81.1.a

the Secretary of State revokes the designation by notice given to the person
designated (in which case the designation ends on the date specified in the
notice), or

81.1.b

the person withdraws consent to the designation by giving not less than 3
months’ notice in writing to the Secretary of State.

81.2

At any time after the first designation under section  59 ,  61 ,  63 ,  65
or  67  has effect, the Secretary of State must, except where the Secretary of
State considers it unnecessary or not reasonably practicable to do so,
exercise the power to designate so as to ensure that at least one designation
has effect under that section.

81.3

The Secretary of State must publish a notice given to a person under—

81.3.a

section  59 (1) ,  61 (1) ,  63 (1) ,  65 (1)  or  67 (1) , or

81.3.b

subsection (1) (a) .

81.4

Revenue support regulations may make provision enabling a person who has
ceased to be a carbon dioxide transport and storage counterparty, hydrogen
transport counterparty, hydrogen storage counterparty, hydrogen production
counterparty or carbon capture counterparty to continue to be treated as such
a counterparty, including provision about the circumstances in which, and the
period for which, such a person may be so treated.

###### Application of sums held by a revenue support counterparty

82

82.1

Revenue support regulations may make provision for apportioning sums—

82.1.a

received by a revenue support counterparty from a hydrogen levy administrator
under provision made by virtue of  section 70 , or

82.1.b

received by a revenue support counterparty under a revenue support contract,

in circumstances where the revenue support counterparty is unable to fully
meet its liabilities under a revenue support contract.

82.2

The provision that may be made by virtue of  subsection (1)  includes
provision about the meaning of “unable to fully meet its liabilities under a
revenue support contract”.

82.3

In making provision by virtue of  subsection (1) , the Secretary of State must
have regard to the principle that sums should be apportioned in proportion to
the amounts that are owed.

82.4

Revenue support regulations may make provision about the application of sums
held by a revenue support counterparty.

82.5

The provision that may be made by virtue of  subsection (4)  includes
provision that sums are to be paid, or not to be paid, into the Consolidated
Fund.

##### Information and advice

###### Information and advice

83

83.1

Revenue support regulations may make provision about the provision and
publication of information and advice.

83.2

The provision that may be made by virtue of  subsection (1)  includes
provision—

83.2.a

for the Secretary of State to require a revenue support counterparty, to
provide advice to the Secretary of State or any other person, or persons of
any description, specified in the regulations;

83.2.b

for the Secretary of State to require any party to a revenue support contract
to provide information to the Secretary of State or any other person, or
persons of any description, specified in the regulations;

83.2.c

for the Secretary of State to require any of the following to provide
information or advice to the Secretary of State or any other person, or
persons of any description, specified in the regulations—

83.2.c.i

a hydrogen levy administrator;

83.2.c.ii

an allocation body;

83.2.c.iii

the GEMA;

83.2.c.iv

any other person or description of persons specified in the regulations;

83.2.d

for a revenue support counterparty to require a person specified, or of a
description specified, in the regulations to provide information to it;

83.2.e

for a hydrogen levy administrator to require—

83.2.e.i

a revenue support counterparty,

83.2.e.ii

an allocation body,

83.2.e.iii

a relevant market participant, or

83.2.e.iv

any other person or description of persons specified in the regulations,

to provide information to it;

83.2.f

for an allocation body to require any party to a hydrogen production revenue
support contract or carbon capture revenue support contract to provide
information to it;

83.2.g

for the classification and protection of confidential or sensitive
information;

83.2.h

for the enforcement of any requirement imposed by virtue of  paragraphs (a)
to  (g) .

83.3

The prohibition on disclosure of information by—

83.3.a

section 105(1) of the Utilities Act 2000;

83.3.b

Article 63(1) of the Energy (Northern Ireland) Order 2003 ( S.I. 2003/419
(N.I. 6)) ;

does not apply to a disclosure required by virtue of this section.

##### Enforcement

###### Enforcement

84

84.1

Revenue support regulations may make provision—

84.1.a

for requirements imposed under the regulations on a GB gas shipper to be
enforceable by the GEMA as if they were relevant requirements within the
meaning of sections 28 to 30O of that Act;

84.1.b

for requirements imposed under the regulations on a person who holds a licence
under Article 8(1)(c) of the Gas (Northern Ireland) Order 1996 ( S.I. 1996/275
(N.I. 2))  to be enforceable by the Northern Ireland Authority for Utility
Regulation as if they were relevant requirements within the meaning of Part 6
of the Energy (Northern Ireland) Order 2003 ( S.I. 2003/419 (N.I. 6)) .

84.2

References in subsection  (1)  to enforcement include enforcement under the
terms of a licence mentioned in any of paragraphs  (a)  and  (b)  of that
subsection.

84.3

Revenue support regulations may make provision for special allocation body
requirements (or a subset of such requirements) to be enforceable by the GEMA
as if they were relevant requirements within the meaning of sections 28 to 30O
of the Gas Act 1986.

84.4

In this section “ special allocation body requirements ” means requirements
imposed by or under revenue support regulations or regulations under  section
73  on a hydrogen production allocation body, so far as the requirements
relate to times when the body holds a licence under section 7AA of the Gas Act
1986 (including requirements in respect of functions of the body that relate
to Northern Ireland).

##### Consultation

###### Consultation

85

85.1

Before making revenue support regulations the Secretary of State must—

85.1.a

consult the persons mentioned in  subsection (2) , and

85.1.b

specify a period of not less than 28 days for the purposes of subsection  (3)
.

85.2

The persons to be consulted under subsection  (1)  are—

85.2.a

the Scottish Ministers, if the regulations contain provision that would be
within the legislative competence of the Scottish Parliament if it were
contained in an Act of that Parliament;

85.2.b

the Welsh Ministers, if the regulations contain provision that would be within
the legislative competence of Senedd Cymru if it were contained in an Act of
the Senedd (ignoring any requirement for the consent of a Minister of the
Crown imposed under Schedule 7B to the Government of Wales Act 2006);

85.2.c

the Department for the Economy in Northern Ireland, if the regulations contain
provision that—

85.2.c.i

would be within the legislative competence of the Northern Ireland Assembly if
it were contained in an Act of that Assembly, and

85.2.c.ii

would not, if it were contained in a Bill in the Northern Ireland Assembly,
result in the Bill requiring the consent of the Secretary of State under
section 8 of the Northern Ireland Act 1998;

85.2.d

such other persons as the Secretary of State considers appropriate.

85.3

The Secretary of State must consider any representations that are—

85.3.a

duly made within the period specified under subsection  (1) (b)  by persons
consulted under  subsection (1) , and

85.3.b

not withdrawn.

85.4

Before making regulations under  section 73 (1)  (power to appoint allocation
bodies) the Secretary of State must consult—

85.4.a

the Scottish Ministers, if the regulations contain provision that would be
within the legislative competence of the Scottish Parliament if it were
contained in an Act of that Parliament;

85.4.b

the Welsh Ministers, if the regulations contain provision that would be within
the legislative competence of Senedd Cymru if it were contained in an Act of
the Senedd (ignoring any requirement for the consent of a Minister of the
Crown imposed under Schedule 7B to the Government of Wales Act 2006);

85.4.c

the Department for the Economy in Northern Ireland, if the regulations contain
provision that—

85.4.c.i

would be within the legislative competence of the Northern Ireland Assembly if
it were contained in an Act of that Assembly, and

85.4.c.ii

would not, if it were contained in a Bill in the Northern Ireland Assembly,
result in the Bill requiring the consent of the Secretary of State under
section 8 of the Northern Ireland Act 1998,

and the Secretary of State must consider any representations duly made by
persons consulted under this subsection and not withdrawn.

85.5

Before publishing standard terms under  section 74  the Secretary of State
must—

85.5.a

consult the persons mentioned in  subsection (6) , and

85.5.b

specify a period of not less than 28 days for the purposes of subsection  (7)
.

85.6

The persons to be consulted under subsection  (5)  are—

85.6.a

the Scottish Ministers, if the standard terms contain provision that would be
within the legislative competence of the Scottish Parliament if it were
contained in an Act of that Parliament;

85.6.b

the Welsh Ministers, if the standard terms contain provision that would be
within the legislative competence of Senedd Cymru if it were contained in an
Act of the Senedd (ignoring any requirement for the consent of a Minister of
the Crown imposed under Schedule 7B to the Government of Wales Act 2006);

85.6.c

the Department for the Economy in Northern Ireland, if the standard terms
contain provision that—

85.6.c.i

would be within the legislative competence of the Northern Ireland Assembly if
it were contained in an Act of that Assembly, and

85.6.c.ii

would not, if it were contained in a Bill in the Northern Ireland Assembly,
result in the Bill requiring the consent of the Secretary of State under
section 8 of the Northern Ireland Act 1998;

85.6.d

such other persons as the Secretary of State considers appropriate.

85.7

The Secretary of State must consider any representations that are—

85.7.a

duly made within the period specified under subsection  (5) (b)  by persons
consulted under subsection  (5) , and

85.7.b

not withdrawn.

85.8

A requirement under this section to consult may be satisfied by consultation
before, as well as consultation after, the passing of this Act.

##### Transfer schemes

###### Transfer schemes

86

86.1

The Secretary of State may make—

86.1.a

one or more schemes for the transfer of designated property, rights or
liabilities of a person who has ceased to be a revenue support counterparty to
a person who is a revenue support counterparty;

86.1.b

one or more schemes for the transfer of designated property, rights or
liabilities of a person who has ceased to be a hydrogen levy administrator to
a person who is a hydrogen levy administrator;

86.1.c

one or more schemes for the transfer of designated property, rights or
liabilities of a person who has ceased to be a hydrogen levy administrator to
the Secretary of State;

86.1.d

one or more schemes for the transfer of designated property, rights or
liabilities of a person who has ceased to be an allocation body to a person
who is an allocation body.

86.2

In this section—

      “ transferee ” means—         in a case within  subsection (1) (a) , the
person who is a revenue support counterparty;           in a case within
subsection (1) (b) , the person who is a hydrogen levy administrator;
in a case within  subsection (1) (c) , the Secretary of State;           in a
case within  subsection (1) (d) , the person who is an allocation body;
“ transferor ” means the person who has ceased to be a revenue support
counterparty, a hydrogen levy administrator or an allocation body (as the case
may be).

86.3

On the transfer date, the designated property, rights and liabilities are
transferred and vest in accordance with the scheme.

86.4

The rights and liabilities that may be transferred by a scheme include those
arising under or in connection with a contract of employment.

86.5

A certificate by the Secretary of State that anything specified in the
certificate has vested in any person by virtue of a scheme is conclusive
evidence for all purposes of that fact.

86.6

A scheme may make provision—

86.6.a

for anything done by or in relation to the transferor in connection with any
property, rights or liabilities transferred by the scheme to be treated as
done, or to be continued, by or in relation to the transferee;

86.6.b

for references to the transferor in any agreement (whether written or not),
instrument or other document relating to any property, rights or liabilities
transferred by the scheme to be treated as references to the transferee;

86.6.c

about the continuation of legal proceedings;

86.6.d

for transferring property, rights or liabilities that could not otherwise be
transferred or assigned;

86.6.e

for transferring property, rights and liabilities irrespective of any
requirement for consent that would otherwise apply;

86.6.f

for preventing a right of pre-emption, right of reverter, right of forfeiture,
right to compensation or other similar right from arising or becoming
exercisable as a result of the transfer of property, rights or liabilities;

86.6.g

for dispensing with any formality in relation to the transfer of property,
rights or liabilities by the scheme;

86.6.h

for transferring property acquired, or rights or liabilities arising, after
the scheme is made but before it takes effect;

86.6.i

for apportioning property, rights or liabilities;

86.6.j

for creating rights, or imposing liabilities, in connection with property,
rights or liabilities transferred by the scheme;

86.6.k

for requiring the transferee to enter into any agreement of any kind, or for a
purpose, specified in or determined in accordance with the scheme.

86.7

Subsection  (6) (b)  does not apply to references in—

86.7.a

primary legislation, or

86.7.b

an instrument made under primary legislation.

86.8

A scheme may contain provision for the payment of compensation by the
Secretary of State to any person whose interests are adversely affected by it.

86.9

A transfer scheme may—

86.9.a

include incidental, supplementary or consequential provision;

86.9.b

make transitory or transitional provision or savings;

86.9.c

make different provision for different cases or circumstances or for different
purposes;

86.9.d

make provision subject to exceptions.

86.10

In this section—

      “ designated ”, in relation to a scheme, means specified in or
determined in accordance with the scheme;           “ primary legislation ”
means—         an Act of Parliament,           an Act of the Scottish
Parliament,           an Act or Measure of Senedd Cymru, or           Northern
Ireland legislation;                 “ property ” includes interests of any
description;           “ the transfer date ” means a date specified by a
scheme as the date on which the scheme is to have effect.

###### Modification of transfer schemes

87

87.1

The Secretary of State may modify a transfer scheme made under  section 86 ,
subject to  subsection (2) .

87.2

If a transfer under the scheme has taken effect, any modification under
subsection (1)  that relates to the transfer may be made only with the
agreement of the transferor or transferee affected by the modification (or,
where both the transferor and transferee are affected, with the agreement of
both of them).

87.3

A modification takes effect from such date as the Secretary of State may
specify (which may be the date when the original scheme came into effect).

87.4

In this section “ transferor ” and “ transferee ” have the same meaning as in
section 86 .

##### General

###### Shadow directors, etc

88

88.1

The Secretary of State is not, by virtue of the exercise of a power conferred
by or by virtue of this Chapter, to be regarded as—

88.1.a

a person occupying the position of director in relation to a  Chapter 1
entity;

88.1.b

a person in accordance with whose directions or instructions the directors of
a  Chapter 1  entity are accustomed to act;

88.1.c

a person in accordance with whose directions or instructions the members of a
Chapter 1 entity which is a limited liability partnership are accustomed to
act;

88.1.d

exercising any function of management in a  Chapter 1  entity;

88.1.e

a principal of a  Chapter 1  entity.

88.2

An allocation body is not, by virtue of the exercise of a power conferred by
or by virtue of this Chapter, to be regarded as—

88.2.a

a person occupying the position of director in relation to a revenue support
counterparty;

88.2.b

a person in accordance with whose directions or instructions the directors of
a revenue support counterparty are accustomed to act;

88.2.c

a person in accordance with whose directions or instructions the members of a
revenue support counterparty which is a limited liability partnership are
accustomed to act;

88.2.d

exercising any function of management in a revenue support counterparty;

88.2.e

a principal of a revenue support counterparty.

88.3

In this section “ Chapter 1  entity” means the following—

88.3.a

a revenue support counterparty;

88.3.b

a hydrogen levy administrator;

88.3.c

an allocation body.

###### Modifications of licences etc for purposes related to levy obligations

89

89.1

The Secretary of State may modify—

89.1.a

a condition of a particular licence under section 7   or 7AC  of the Gas Act
1986 (licensing of gas transporters  or code manager licence );

89.1.b

the standard conditions incorporated in licences under section 7 of the Gas
Act 1986 by virtue of section 8 of that Act;

89.1.c

a document maintained in accordance with the conditions of licences under
section 7   or 7AC  of the Gas Act 1986, or an agreement that gives effect to
a document so maintained.

89.2

The Secretary of State may modify—

89.2.a

a condition of a particular licence under Article 8(1)(a) of the Gas (Northern
Ireland) Order 1996 ( S.I. 1996/275 (N.I. 2))  (licences to convey gas);

89.2.b

the standard conditions of licences under Article 8(1)(a) of that Order;

89.2.c

a document maintained in accordance with the conditions of licences under
Article 8(1)(a) of that Order, or an agreement that gives effect to a document
so maintained.

89.3

The powers conferred by subsections  (1)  and  (2)  may be exercised only for
the purpose of facilitating or supporting enforcement of, and administration
in connection with, obligations under regulations within  section 70
(including facilitation and support by way of allowing or requiring the
provision of services).

89.4

Provision included in a licence, or in a document or agreement relating to
licences, by virtue of any power under subsection  (1)  or  (2)  may in
particular include provision of a kind that may be included in revenue support
regulations.

89.5

Provision included in a licence, or in a document or agreement relating to

authorised for licences of that type by—

89.5.a

89.5.b

Article 10(3)(a) to (d), (4), (5) or (6A) of the Gas (Northern Ireland) Order
1996 ( S.I. 1996/275 (N.I. 2)) .

89.6

For the purposes of  subsection (5) (b) , the provisions referred to in that
paragraph are to be read as if references to the Northern Ireland Authority
for Utility Regulation included the Secretary of State.

89.7

If under subsection  (1)  the Secretary of State makes modifications of the
standard conditions of a licence, the GEMA must—

89.7.a

make the same modification of those standard conditions for the purposes of
their incorporation in licences of that type granted after that time, and

89.7.b

publish the modification.

89.8

If under subsection  (2)  the Secretary of State makes modifications of the
standard conditions of a licence, the Northern Ireland Authority for Utility
Regulation must—

89.8.a

make the same modification of those standard conditions for the purposes of
their incorporation in licences of that type granted after that time, and

89.8.b

publish the modification.

89.9

Before making a modification under this section, the Secretary of State must
consult—

89.9.a

the holder of any licence being modified, and

89.9.b

such other persons as the Secretary of State considers it appropriate to
consult.

89.10

Subsection  (9)  may be satisfied by consultation before, as well as by
consultation after, the passing of this Act.

###### Sections 89 and 90: supplementary

91

91.1

In this section “ relevant power ” means a power conferred by—

91.1.a

subsection  (1)  or  (2)  of  section 89 , or

91.1.b

section 90 .

91.2

Before making modifications under a relevant power, the Secretary of State
must lay a draft of the modifications before Parliament.

91.3

If, within the 40-day period, either House of Parliament resolves not to
approve the draft, the Secretary of State may not take any further steps in
relation to the proposed modifications.

91.4

If no such resolution is made within that period, the Secretary of State may
make the modifications in the form of the draft.

91.5

Subsection  (3)  does not prevent a new draft of proposed modifications being
laid before Parliament.

91.6

In this section “ 40-day period ”, in relation to a draft of proposed
modifications, means the period of 40 days beginning with the day on which the
draft is laid before Parliament (or, if it is not laid before each House of
Parliament on the same day, the later of the 2 days on which it is laid).

91.7

For the purposes of calculating the 40-day period, no account is to be taken
of any period during which Parliament is dissolved or prorogued or during
which both Houses are adjourned for more than 4 days.

91.8

A relevant power—

91.8.a

may be exercised generally, only in relation to specified cases or subject to
exceptions (including provision for a case to be excepted only so long as
specified conditions are satisfied);

91.8.b

may be exercised differently in different cases or circumstances;

91.8.c

includes a power to make incidental, supplementary, consequential or
transitional modifications.

91.9

Provision included in a licence, or in a document or agreement relating to
licences, by virtue of a relevant power—

91.9.a

may make different provision for different cases;

91.9.b

need not relate to the activities authorised by the licence.

91.10

The Secretary of State must publish details of any modifications made under a
relevant power as soon as reasonably practicable after they are made.

91.11

A modification made under a relevant power of part of a standard condition of
a licence does not prevent any other part of the condition from continuing to
be regarded as a standard condition for the purposes of Part 1 of the Gas Act
1986 or the Gas (Northern Ireland) Order 1996.

91.12

The power conferred by a relevant power to “ modify ” (in relation to licence
conditions or a document) includes a power to amend, add to or remove, and
references to modifications are to be construed accordingly.

91.13

In section 81 of the Utilities Act 2000 (standard conditions of gas licences),
in subsection (2), after “Energy Prices Act 2022” insert  “or under  section
89  or sections  245  to  247  of the Energy Act 2023” .

#### Decommissioning of carbon storage installations

##### Financing of costs of decommissioning etc

###### Financing of costs of decommissioning etc

92

92.1

The Secretary of State may by regulations make provision for requiring
relevant persons to provide security for the performance of obligations
relating to the future abandonment or decommissioning of carbon dioxide-
related sites, pipelines or installations.

92.2

For the purposes of  subsection (1)  an installation, site or pipeline is
“carbon dioxide-related” if it is, or is to be, used for a purpose related to
the geological storage, or transportation, of carbon dioxide.

92.3

In this section references to an installation, site or pipeline include one
that is located in, under or over—

92.3.a

the territorial sea adjacent to the United Kingdom, or

92.3.b

waters in a Gas Importation and Storage Zone (within the meaning given by
section 1 of the Energy Act 2008).

92.4

The following provisions of this section are without prejudice to the
generality of  subsection (1) .

92.5

In this section “ relevant person ” means a person who—

92.5.a

holds a licence under  section 7 , or

92.5.b

is a person to whom a notice has been, or may be, given under section 29 of
the Petroleum Act 1998 (preparation of abandonment programmes) in respect of a
carbon storage installation.

92.6

Regulations under  subsection (1)  may—

92.6.a

require relevant persons to provide the Secretary of State with estimates of
costs that are likely to be incurred in connection with obligations such as
are mentioned in subsection (1) (“decommissioning costs”);

92.6.b

make provision about the estimation of decommissioning costs and about the
manner in which such estimates are to be verified (which may include provision
requiring verification by an independent third party);

92.6.c

require relevant persons to review estimates of decommissioning costs at
times, or at intervals, specified in the regulations;

92.6.d

make provision about the approval by the Secretary of State of estimates of
such costs;

92.6.e

provide for information specified, or of a description specified, in the
regulations to be supplied to the Secretary of State by relevant persons at
such intervals, or on such occasions, as may be prescribed by the regulations;

92.6.f

require the Secretary of State to consult the Oil and Gas Authority or any
other person specified in the regulations before exercising functions by
virtue of  paragraph (d) .

92.7

Regulations under  subsection (1)  may make provision—

92.7.a

requiring that security for the discharge of liabilities in respect of
decommissioning costs must be provided by way of a fund (a “decommissioning
fund”);

92.7.b

about the management of decommissioning funds;

92.7.c

about payments to a relevant person, or another person, from such funds;

92.7.d

providing for payments from such funds to be subject to the approval of the
Secretary of State;

92.7.e

imposing on a relevant authority functions with regard to—

92.7.e.i

the monitoring and oversight of decommissioning funds;

92.7.e.ii

the approval of any matter relating to such a fund.

92.8

This section is without prejudice to the breadth of subsection (4) of section
30 of the Energy Act 2008.

92.9

Regulations under subsection (1) may require the Secretary of State to publish
guidance about—

92.9.a

estimates of decommissioning costs (including factors which it may be
appropriate to consider in deciding whether or not to approve estimates of
such costs);

92.9.b

the structure, accrual and management of decommissioning funds.

92.10

Guidance by virtue of this section may make different provision for different
cases or circumstances.

92.11

In this section—

      “ carbon storage installation ” has the same meaning as in section 30 of
the Energy Act 2008;           “ decommissioning costs ” is to be interpreted
in accordance with subsection  (6) (a) ;           “ decommissioning fund ” is
to be interpreted in accordance with subsection  (7) (a) ;           “
economic regulator ” has the same meaning as in  Part 1  (see  section 55 );
“ geological storage ” has the same meaning as in  Part 1  (see  section 55 );
“ relevant authority ” means the Secretary of State, the economic regulator or
the Oil and Gas Authority.

###### Section 

93

93.1

Regulations under  section 92 (1)  may make provision—

93.1.a

enabling a relevant authority to charge fees to relevant persons in order to
cover the costs of the exercise of the authority’s functions under the
regulations;

93.1.b

about how fees payable by virtue of the regulations are to be determined;

93.1.c

about when fees payable by virtue of the regulations are to be paid.

93.2

Regulations under  section 92 (1)  may make provision about the supplying of
information, including—

93.2.a

provision for the Secretary of State to require any other person to supply
information to the Secretary of State for the purposes of the Secretary of
State’s functions under regulations under that section;

93.2.b

about the sharing by the Secretary of State with the Oil and Gas Authority or
the economic regulator of information about funds established as mentioned in
section 92 (7) (a) .

93.3

Regulations under  section 92 (1)  may make provision about compliance with
requirements imposed by or under the regulations, including—

93.3.a

provision imposing civil penalties;

93.3.b

provision making it an offence to contravene specified provisions of the
regulations.

93.4

Where regulations under  section 92 (1)  provide for the imposition of a civil
penalty, they must also provide for a right of appeal against the imposition
of the penalty.

93.5

Where regulations under  section 92 (1)  create an offence, they must also
make provision as to the mode of trial and punishment of offences, but—

93.5.a

any provision as to punishment on summary conviction must not authorise
imprisonment or, in the case of summary conviction in Scotland or Northern
Ireland, a fine exceeding the statutory maximum;

93.5.b

any provision as to punishment on conviction on indictment must not authorise
imprisonment for a term exceeding 2 years.

93.6

Regulations under  section 92 (1)  may—

93.6.a

make different provision for different purposes;

93.6.b

create exceptions to any requirement imposed by the regulations.

93.7

Regulations under  section 92 (1)  may confer any function on any person.

93.8

Regulations under  section 92 (1)  may provide for a function conferred on a
person to be exercisable on that person’s behalf by another person.

93.9

In this section—

      “ economic regulator ” has the same meaning as in  Part 1  (see  section
55 );           “ relevant authority ” means the Secretary of State, the
economic regulator or the Oil and Gas Authority;           “ relevant person ”
has the same meaning as in  section 92 .

93.10

Regulations under  section 92 (1)  may make any amendments of—

93.10.a

the Storage of Carbon Dioxide (Licensing etc.) Regulations 2010 ( S.I.
2010/2221 ),

93.10.b

the Storage of Carbon Dioxide (Licensing etc.) (Scotland) Regulations 2011 (
S.S.I. 2011/24 ),

93.10.c

the Storage of Carbon Dioxide (Termination of Licences) Regulations 2011 (
S.I. 2011/1483 ), or

93.10.d

the Storage of Carbon Dioxide (Licensing etc.) Regulations (Northern Ireland)
2015 ( S.R. (N.I.) 2015 No. 387 ),

that the Secretary of State considers appropriate in consequence of, or of
provision made under,  section 92  or this section.

93.11

Regulations under  section 92 (1)  containing any of the following (with or
without other provision) are subject to the affirmative procedure—

93.11.a

provision creating a criminal offence;

93.11.b

provision creating a civil penalty.

93.12

Any other regulations under  section 92 (1)  are subject to the negative
procedure.

###### Regulations under 

94

94.1

Before making regulations under  section 92 (1)  that contain provision within
devolved competence, the Secretary of State must give notice to each relevant
devolved authority—

94.1.a

stating that the Secretary of State proposes to make regulations under
section 92 (1) , and

94.1.b

specifying the period (of not less than 28 days from the date on which the
notice is given) within which representations may be made with respect to the
provision within the relevant devolved competence,

and must consider any representations duly made and not withdrawn.

94.2

In this section, “ relevant devolved authority ”, in relation to regulations,
means—

94.2.a

the Scottish Ministers, if the regulations contain provision within Scottish
devolved competence;

94.2.b

the Welsh Ministers, if the regulations contain provision within Welsh
devolved competence;

94.2.c

the Department for the Economy in Northern Ireland, if the regulations contain
provision within Northern Ireland devolved competence;

and “ the relevant devolved competence ”, in relation to a relevant devolved
authority, is to be construed accordingly.

94.3

For the purposes of this section, provision—

94.3.a

is within Scottish devolved competence if it would be within the legislative
competence of the Scottish Parliament if it were contained in an Act of that
Parliament;

94.3.b

is within Welsh devolved competence if it would be within the legislative
competence of Senedd Cymru if it were contained in an Act of the Senedd
(ignoring any requirement for the consent of a Minister of the Crown imposed
under Schedule 7B to the Government of Wales Act 2006);

94.3.c

is within Northern Ireland devolved competence if it—

94.3.c.i

would be within the legislative competence of the Northern Ireland Assembly if
it were contained in an Act of that Assembly, and

94.3.c.ii

would not, if it were contained in a Bill in the Northern Ireland Assembly,
result in the Bill requiring the consent of the Secretary of State under
section 8 of the Northern Ireland Act 1998;

and references to provision being within devolved competence are to provision
that is within Scottish, Welsh or Northern Ireland devolved competence.

95

95.1

.

The modifications are as follows—

This subsection applies to a person in relation to a carbon storage

the person has the right—

either—

95.3.1AB.a.5.b.ii

the person intends to carry on an activity mentioned in that subsection from,

or if the person had such a right when any such activity was last so carried
on.

95.3.1AB.a.6

;

95.3.1AB.b

in section 30(7) of that Act, in the words before paragraph (a), for “(c)”

95.3.1AB.c

in section 31 of that Act, for subsection (B1) substitute—

This subsection applies to an activity if—

where the activity is within  paragraph (a) ,  (b)  or  (c)  of section 30(6),

95.3.1AB.c.B1.b

95.3.1AB.c.B1.c

;

Act 2008;

.

95.4

##### Change of use relief

###### Change of use relief: installations

96

96.1

Section 30A of the Energy Act 2008 (installations converted for CCS
demonstration projects) is amended as follows.

96.2

For the heading substitute  “Change of use relief for certain installations” .

96.3

#### Strategy and policy statement

##### Designation of strategy and policy statement

99

99.1

The Secretary of State may designate a statement as the strategy and policy
statement for the purposes of this Part (“the CCUS strategy and policy
statement”) if the requirements set out in  section 102  are satisfied
(consultation and laying requirements).

99.2

The CCUS strategy and policy statement is a statement prepared by the
Secretary of State that sets out—

99.2.a

the strategic priorities, and other main considerations, of His Majesty’s
government in formulating its carbon dioxide capture, usage and storage policy
for the United Kingdom (“strategic priorities”),

99.2.b

the particular outcomes to be achieved as a result of the implementation of
that policy (“policy outcomes”), and

99.2.c

the roles and responsibilities of persons (whether the Secretary of State, the
economic regulator or other persons) who are involved in implementing that
policy or who have other functions that are affected by it.

99.3

In preparing a statement for designation under  subsection (1)  (or
undertaking a review under  section 101 ), the Secretary of State must take
account of any statement for the time being designated under section 131 of
the Energy Act 2013 (strategy and policy statement in respect of energy
policy).

99.4

The Secretary of State must publish the CCUS strategy and policy statement
(including any amended statement following a review under  section 101 ) in
such manner as the Secretary of State considers appropriate.

99.5

For the purposes of this section, carbon dioxide capture, usage and storage
policy “ for the United Kingdom ” includes such policy for—

99.5.a

the territorial sea adjacent to the United Kingdom, or

99.5.b

waters in a Gas Importation and Storage Zone (within the meaning given by
section 1 of the Energy Act 2008).

99.6

In this Chapter—

      “ the CCUS strategy and policy statement ” means the statement for the
time being designated under  subsection (1)  as the strategy and policy
statement for the purposes of this Part;           “ economic regulator ” has
the same meaning as in  Part 1  (see  section 55 );           “ policy
outcomes ” has the meaning given in  subsection (2) (b) ;           “
strategic priorities ” has the meaning given in  subsection (2) (a) .

##### Duties with regard to considerations in the statement

100

100.1

The economic regulator must have regard to the strategic priorities set out in
the CCUS strategy and policy statement when carrying out CCUS-related
functions under this Part or Part 1.

100.2

The Secretary of State and the economic regulator must carry out their
respective CCUS-related functions under  Part 1  and this Part in the manner
which the Secretary of State or the economic regulator (as the case may be)
considers is best calculated to further the delivery of the policy outcomes.

100.3

Subsection  (2)  is subject to the application of the principal objectives in
the carrying out of any such function.

100.4

Subsections  (1)  and  (2)  do not apply to anything done by the economic
regulator—

100.4.a

in the exercise of functions relating to the determination of disputes;

100.4.b

in the exercise of functions under section  36 (1)  or  37 (1) .

100.5

The duties imposed by subsections  (1)  and  (2)  do not affect the obligation
of the economic regulator or the Secretary of State to perform or comply with
any other duty or requirement (whether arising under this Act or another
enactment or otherwise).

100.6

The economic regulator must give notice to the Secretary of State if at any
time the economic regulator concludes that a policy outcome contained in the
strategy and policy statement is not realistically achievable.

100.7

A notice under  subsection (6)  must include—

100.7.a

the grounds on which the conclusion was reached;

100.7.b

what (if anything) the economic regulator is doing, or proposes to do, for the
purpose of furthering the delivery of the outcome so far as reasonably
practicable.

100.8

In this section—

      “ CCUS-related functions ” means functions to which the strategic
priorities are relevant (not including functions under sections  69  to  72 ,
84 (1)  or  (2)  or  89 , or other functions so far as carried out in
connection with those functions);           “ principal objectives ” means the
principal objectives of the Secretary of State and the economic regulator set
out in  section 1 (1) .

##### Review

101

101.1

The Secretary of State must review the CCUS strategy and policy statement if a
period of 5 years has elapsed since the relevant time.

101.2

In this section “ relevant time ”, in relation to the CCUS strategy and policy
statement, means—

101.2.a

the time when the statement was first designated under  section 99 , or

101.2.b

if later, the time when a review of the statement under this section last took
place.

101.3

A review under  subsection (1)  must take place as soon as reasonably
practicable after the end of the 5 year period.

101.4

The Secretary of State may review the CCUS strategy and policy statement at
any other time if—

101.4.a

a Parliamentary general election has taken place since the relevant time,

101.4.b

the economic regulator has given notice to the Secretary of State under
section 100 (6)  since the relevant time,

101.4.c

a significant change in the policy of His Majesty’s government with regard to
carbon dioxide capture, usage and storage has occurred since the relevant
time,

101.4.d

the Secretary of State has commenced a review under section 134 of the Energy
Act 2013 since the relevant time,

101.4.e

the Parliamentary approval requirement in relation to an amended statement was
not met on the last review (see  subsection (13) ).

101.5

The Secretary of State may determine that a significant change in the
government’s policy with regard to carbon dioxide capture, usage and storage
has occurred for the purposes of  subsection (4) (c)  only if—

101.5.a

the change was not anticipated at the relevant time, and

101.5.b

if the change had been so anticipated, it appears to the Secretary of State
likely that the statement would have been different in a material way.

101.6

On a review under this section the Secretary of State may—

101.6.a

amend the statement (including by replacing the whole or part of the statement
with new content),

101.6.b

leave the statement as it is, or

101.6.c

withdraw the statement’s designation as the strategy and policy statement.

101.7

The amendment of a statement under  subsection (6) (a)  has effect only if the
Secretary of State designates under  section 99  the amended statement as the
strategy and policy statement (and the procedural requirements under  section
102  apply in relation to any such designation).

101.8

For the purposes of this section, corrections of clerical or typographical
errors are not to be treated as amendments made to the statement.

101.9

The designation of a statement as the strategy and policy statement ceases to
have effect upon a subsequent designation of an amended statement as the
strategy and policy statement in accordance with  subsection (7) .

101.10

Before proceeding under  subsection (6) (b)  or  (c)  the Secretary of State
must give notice to the appropriate consultees—

101.10.a

setting out the Secretary of State’s proposed decision, and

101.10.b

specifying the period (of not less than 28 days from the date on which the
notice is given) within which representations must be made,

and the Secretary of State must consider any representations which are duly
made and not withdrawn.

101.11

For the purposes of subsection  (10) , the “appropriate consultees” are—

101.11.a

the economic regulator;

101.11.b

so far as the decision as to whether or not to proceed relates to Scottish
devolved matters, the Scottish Ministers;

101.11.c

so far as that decision relates to Welsh devolved matters, the Welsh
Ministers;

101.11.d

so far as that decision relates to Northern Ireland devolved matters, the
Department for the Economy in Northern Ireland.

101.12

For the purposes of  subsection (2) (b) , a review of a statement takes place—

101.12.a

where the decision on the review is to amend the statement under  subsection
(6) (a) —

101.12.a.i

at the time when the amended statement is designated as the CCUS strategy and
policy statement under  section 99 , or

101.12.a.ii

if the amended statement is not so designated, at the time when the amended
statement was laid before Parliament for approval under  section 102 (9) ;

101.12.b

where the decision on the review is to leave the statement as it is under
subsection (6) (b) , at the time when that decision is taken.

101.13

For the purposes of  subsection (4) (e) , the Parliamentary approval
requirement in relation to an amended statement was not met on the last review
if—

101.13.a

on the last review of the strategy and policy statement to be held under this
section, an amended statement was laid before Parliament for approval under
section 102 (9) , but

101.13.b

the amended statement was not designated because such approval was not given.

101.14

For the purposes of this section—

101.14.a

something relates to Welsh devolved matters so far as it relates to any matter
provision about which would be within the legislative competence of Senedd
Cymru if it were contained in an Act of the Senedd (ignoring any requirement
for the consent of a Minister of the Crown imposed under Schedule 7B to the
Government of Wales Act 2006);

101.14.b

something relates to Scottish devolved matters so far as it relates to any
matter provision about which would be within the legislative competence of the
Scottish Parliament if it were contained in an Act of that Parliament;

101.14.c

something relates to Northern Ireland devolved matters so far as it relates to
any matter provision about which—

101.14.c.i

would be within the legislative competence of the Northern Ireland Assembly if
it were contained in an Act of that Assembly, and

101.14.c.ii

would not, if it were contained in a Bill in the Northern Ireland Assembly,
result in the Bill requiring the consent of the Secretary of State under
section 8 of the Northern Ireland Act 1998.

##### Procedural requirements

102

102.1

This section sets out the requirements that must be satisfied in relation to a
statement before the Secretary of State may designate it as the CCUS strategy
and policy statement.

102.2

In this section references to a statement include references to a statement as
amended following a review under  section 101 (6) (a).

102.3

The Secretary of State must first—

102.3.a

prepare a draft of the statement, and

102.3.b

issue the draft to the required consultees for the purpose of consulting them
about it.

102.4

The “required consultees” are—

102.4.a

the economic regulator,

102.4.b

the Scottish Ministers,

102.4.c

the Department for the Economy in Northern Ireland, and

102.4.d

the Welsh Ministers.

102.5

The Secretary of State must then—

102.5.a

make such revisions to the draft as the Secretary of State considers
appropriate as a result of responses to the consultation under  subsection (3)
(b) , and

102.5.b

issue the revised draft for the purposes of further consultation about it to
the required consultees and to such other persons as the Secretary of State
considers appropriate.

102.6

The Secretary of State must then—

102.6.a

make any further revisions to the draft that the Secretary of State considers
appropriate as a result of responses to the consultation under  subsection (5)
(b) , and

102.6.b

prepare a report summarising those responses and the changes (if any) that the
Secretary of State has made to the draft as a result.

102.7

In relation to required consultees within  subsection (4) (b)  to (d),
references in subsections  (3) (b)  and  (5) (b)  to consultation about a
draft are to consultation about the draft so far as it relates—

102.7.a

in the case of the Scottish Ministers, to Scottish devolved matters;

102.7.b

in the case of the Department for the Economy in Northern Ireland, to Northern
Ireland devolved matters;

102.7.c

in the case of the Welsh Ministers, to Welsh devolved matters.

102.8

References in this section to relating to Scottish devolved matters, Northern
Ireland devolved matters or Welsh devolved matters are to be interpreted in
accordance with  section 101 (14) .

102.9

The Secretary of State must lay before Parliament—

102.9.a

the statement as revised under  subsection (6) (a) , and

102.9.b

the report prepared under  subsection (6) (b) .

102.10

The statement as laid under  subsection (9) (a)  must have been approved by a
resolution of each House of Parliament before the Secretary of State may
designate it as the strategy and policy statement under  section 99 .

102.11

The requirement under  subsection (3) (a)  to prepare a draft of a statement
may be satisfied by preparation carried out before, as well as preparation
carried out after, the passing of this Act.

#### Carbon dioxide storage licences

##### Specified provisions in carbon dioxide storage licences

103

103.1

Schedule 6  amends Schedule 1 to the Storage of Carbon Dioxide (Licensing
etc.) Regulations 2010 ( S.I. 2010/2221 ) (“ the 2010 Regulations ”).

103.2

Subsections (3) to (5) apply in relation to a licence granted (or having
effect as if granted) by the Oil and Gas Authority under section 18(1) of the
Energy Act 2008 which is in force immediately before the commencement of
Schedule 6 .

103.3

The licence has effect with the addition of provision having the same legal
effect as paragraph 6 of Schedule 1 to the 2010 Regulations (as inserted by
Schedule 6  to this Act).

103.4

If the licence confers power on the Oil and Gas Authority to revoke a licence
in connection with a change in control of a licence holder which is a company,
the licence has effect—

103.4.a

with the omission of such provision, and

103.4.b

with the replacement of such provision by provision having the same legal
effect as paragraph 7 of Schedule 1 to the 2010 Regulations (as inserted by
Schedule 6  to this Act).

103.5

If the licence confers power on the Oil and Gas Authority to partially revoke
a licence in connection with a change in control of a licence holder which is
a company, the licence has effect—

103.5.a

with the omission of such provision, and

103.5.b

with the replacement of such provision by provision having the same legal
effect as paragraph 8 of Schedule 1 to the 2010 Regulations (as inserted by
Schedule 6  to this Act).

103.6

A reference in any document to provisions of a licence which are to have
effect with amendments as provided for by  Schedule 6  is to be construed,
unless the nature of the document or the context otherwise requires, as a
reference to those provisions as amended.

103.7

A provision inserted in a licence by virtue of  Schedule 6  may be altered or
deleted by deed executed by the Secretary of State and the licence holder or,
as respects Scotland, by an instrument subscribed or authenticated by the
Secretary of State and the licence holder in accordance with the Requirements
of Writing (Scotland) Act 1995.

##### Content of storage permits under carbon dioxide storage licences

104

104.1

In the Storage of Carbon Dioxide (Licensing etc.) Regulations 2010 ( S.I.
2010/2221 ) (“ the 2010 Regulations ”), regulation 8 (content of storage
permits) is amended as follows—

104.1.a

after paragraph (1) insert—

104.1.a.1A

If the operator is a company, a storage permit must also include the
provisions contained in paragraph 6(2) to (11) of Schedule 1, read as if—

104.1.a.1A.a

any reference to a company were to the operator,

104.1.a.1A.b

the reference in paragraph 6(8)(b) to the licence were to the storage permit,
and

104.1.a.1A.c

paragraph 6(10)(c) were omitted.

;

104.1.b

in paragraph (2), for “In this” substitute  “In paragraph (1) of this” .

104.2

Subsection (4) applies in relation to a storage permit granted under an
existing licence.

104.3

“ Existing licence ” means a licence granted (or having effect as if granted)
by the Oil and Gas Authority under section 18(1) of the Energy Act 2008 which
is in force immediately before the commencement of subsection (1).

104.4

The storage permit has effect with the addition of provision having the same
legal effect as provision required to be included in the permit by reason of
paragraph (1A) of regulation 8 of the 2010 Regulations (as inserted by
subsection (1)(a)).

##### Offences relating to carbon dioxide storage licences

105

In section 23 of the Energy Act 2008 (offences relating to carbon dioxide
storage licences), after subsection (1) insert—

105.1A

But a licence holder does not commit an offence under subsection (1)(a) or (b)
if—

105.1A.a

the licence holder is a company, or, where there are joint licence holders,
any of them is a company, and

105.1A.b

the thing mentioned in subsection (1)(a) or (b) is a change in the control of
the company.

##### Power of OGA to require information about change in control of licence holder

106

After section 29 of the Energy Act 2008 insert—

######### Information about change in control of licence holder

########## OGA’s power to require information about change in control of licence holder

106.29A

106.29A.1

This section applies in relation to a licence granted (or having effect as if
granted) by the OGA which includes provisions prohibiting a change in control
of a licence holder which is a company without the OGA’s consent.

106.29A.2

The OGA may by notice in writing require a person within subsection (3) to
provide the OGA with any information that it requires for the purpose of
exercising its functions in relation to a change or potential change in
control of a licence holder which is a company.

106.29A.3

The persons within this subsection are—

106.29A.3.a

the company;

106.29A.3.b

the person who (if consent were granted) would take control of the company;

106.29A.3.c

if the company is a joint licence holder with another person or other persons,
that other person or those other persons;

106.29A.3.d

any person not within any of paragraphs (a) to (c) who appears to the OGA to
have information that it requires as mentioned in subsection (2).

106.29A.4

The power conferred by this section does not include power to require the
provision of any information that would be protected from disclosure or
production in legal proceedings on grounds of legal professional privilege or,
in Scotland, confidentiality of communications.

106.29A.5

Nothing in this section limits any power of the OGA to require information
under—

106.29A.5.a

regulations under this Chapter,

106.29A.5.b

the terms of a licence, or

106.29A.5.c

the terms of a permit granted under a licence.

#### Carbon storage information and samples

##### Introductory

###### Chapter 5: key definitions

107

107.1

This section applies for the purposes of this Chapter.

107.2

“ Carbon storage licence ” means a licence granted, or having effect as if
granted, by the OGA under section 18(1) of the Energy Act 2008 (and references
to a “licensee” are to a person who holds such a licence).

107.3

“ Exploration operator ”, in relation to a carbon storage licence, means a
person who is responsible for organising or supervising—

107.3.a

the carrying on of exploration, within the area within which activities are
authorised under the licence, with a view to, or in connection with, the
carrying on of activities within section 17(2)(a) or (b) of the Energy Act
2008, or

107.3.b

the establishment or maintenance in a controlled place (as defined in section
17 of the Energy Act 2008) of an installation for the purposes of such
exploration.

107.4

“ Carbon storage information ” means information acquired or created by or on
behalf of a licensee in the course of carrying out activities under the
licensee’s carbon storage licence.

107.5

“ Carbon storage samples ” means samples of substances acquired by or on
behalf of a licensee in the course of carrying out activities under the
licensee’s carbon storage licence.

107.6

“ Sanctionable requirement ” means a requirement imposed on a person by or
under a provision of this Chapter which, by virtue of the provision, is
sanctionable in accordance with this Chapter.

##### Requirements relating to information and samples

###### Retention of information and samples

108

108.1

Regulations made by the Secretary of State may require—

108.1.a

specified licensees to retain specified carbon storage information;

108.1.b

specified licensees to retain specified carbon storage samples.

108.2

“ Specified ” means specified, or of a description specified, in regulations
under this section.

108.3

Regulations under this section may include provision about—

108.3.a
