the form or manner in which information or samples are to be retained;

108.3.b

the period for which information or samples are to be retained;

108.3.c

the event that triggers the commencement of that period.

108.4

Regulations under this section may provide for requirements imposed by the
regulations to continue following a termination of rights under the licensee’s
carbon storage licence (whether by transfer, surrender, expiry or revocation
and whether in relation to all or only part of the licence).

108.5

Regulations under this section may not impose requirements which have effect
in relation to particular carbon storage information or particular carbon
storage samples at any time when an information and samples plan dealing with
the information or samples has effect.

108.6

Requirements imposed by regulations under this section are sanctionable in
accordance with this Chapter.

108.7

Before making regulations under this section, the Secretary of State must
consult each licensing authority that may under section 18(1) of the Energy
Act 2008 grant a licence in respect of the carrying on, in a place to which
the regulations would apply, of activities within section 17(2) of that Act.

108.8

Regulations under this section are subject to the negative procedure.

###### Preparation and agreement of information and samples plans

109

109.1

The responsible person must prepare an information and samples plan in
connection with any of the following (each “a licence event”)—

109.1.a

where a licensee is a company, a change in control of the company within the
meaning of paragraph 6 of Schedule 1 to the Carbon Dioxide (Licensing etc.)
Regulations 2010 ( S.I. 2010/2221 ) (inserted by  Schedule 6  to this Act);

109.1.b

a change in the identity of—

109.1.b.i

the exploration operator under a carbon storage licence, or

109.1.b.ii

where a storage permit has been granted under a carbon storage licence, the
operator in relation to the storage permit (within the meaning of regulation
1(3) of the Carbon Dioxide (Licensing etc.) Regulations 2010);

109.1.c

a transfer of rights under a carbon storage licence, whether in relation to
all or part of the area in respect of which the licence was granted;

109.1.d

a surrender of rights under a carbon storage licence in relation to all of the
area in respect of which the licence was granted, or in relation to so much of
that area in respect of which the licence continues to have effect;

109.1.e

the expiry of a carbon storage licence;

109.1.f

the termination of a carbon storage licence;

109.1.g

the revocation of a storage permit.

109.2

“ Responsible person ”, in relation to a licence event, means the person who
is or was, or the persons who are or were, the licensee in respect of the
relevant licence immediately before the licence event.

109.3

“ Relevant licence ”, in relation to a licence event, means the carbon storage
licence in respect of which the licence event occurs.

109.4

“ Information and samples plan ”, in relation to a licence event, means a plan
dealing with what is to happen, following the event, to—

109.4.a

carbon storage information held by the responsible person before the event,
and

109.4.b

carbon storage samples held by that person before the event.

109.5

The responsible person must agree the information and samples plan with the
OGA—

109.5.a

in the case of a licence event mentioned in  subsection (1) (a) ,  (b) ,  (c)
,  (d)  or  (e) , before the licence event takes place, or

109.5.b

in the case of a licence event mentioned in  subsection (1) (f)  or  (g) ,
within a reasonable period after the termination of the carbon storage licence
or revocation of the storage permit.

109.6

An information and samples plan has effect once it is agreed with the OGA.

109.7

If an information and samples plan is not agreed with the OGA as mentioned in
subsection (5) (a)  or  (b) , the OGA—

109.7.a

may itself prepare an information and samples plan in connection with the
licence event, and

109.7.b

may require the responsible person to provide it with such information as the
OGA may require to enable it to do so.

109.8

The OGA must inform the responsible person of the terms of any information and
samples plan it prepares in connection with a licence event.

109.9

Where the OGA—

109.9.a

prepares an information and samples plan in connection with a licence event,
and

109.9.b

informs the responsible person of the terms of the plan,

the plan has effect as if it had been prepared by the responsible person and
agreed with the OGA.

109.10

Where an information and samples plan has effect in connection with a licence
event, the responsible person must comply with the plan.

109.11

The requirements imposed by  subsection (5)  and  (10) , or under  subsection
(7) (b) , are sanctionable in accordance with this Chapter.

###### Information and samples plans: supplementary

110

110.1

Where an information and samples plan has effect in relation to a licence
event, the OGA and the responsible person may agree changes to the plan.

110.2

Once changes are agreed, the plan has effect subject to those changes.

110.3

Where—

110.3.a

two or more persons are the responsible person in relation to a licence event,
and

110.3.b

those persons include a company that has, since the licence event, been
dissolved,

the reference to the responsible person in  subsection (1)  does not include
that company.

110.4

An information and samples plan, in relation to a licence event, may provide
as appropriate for—

110.4.a

the retention, by the responsible person, of any carbon storage information or
carbon storage samples held by or on behalf of that person before the licence
event,

110.4.b

the transfer of any such information or samples to a new licensee, or

110.4.c

appropriate storage of such information or samples.

110.5

Where an information and samples plan makes provision under  subsection (4)
for a person, other than the responsible person, to hold information or
samples in accordance with the plan—

110.5.a

the plan may, with the consent of that other person, impose requirements on
that person in connection with the information and samples, and

110.5.b

any such requirements are sanctionable in accordance with this Chapter.

110.6

An information and samples plan prepared by the OGA under  section 109  may
not include provision under  subsection (4) (b)  for the transfer of
information or samples to another person without the consent of the
responsible person.

110.7

An information and samples plan may provide for the storage of information or
samples as mentioned in  subsection (4) (c)  to be the responsibility of the
OGA.

110.8

Where a transfer of rights under a carbon storage licence relates to only part
of the area in relation to which the licence was granted, the information and
samples plan prepared in connection with the transfer is to relate to all
carbon storage information and carbon storage samples held by the responsible
person before the licence event, and not only information and samples in
respect of that part of the area.

110.9

In this section, “ licence event ” and “ responsible person ” have the same
meaning as in  section 109 .

###### Information and samples coordinators

111

111.1

A person within  subsection (2)  (a “relevant person”) must—

111.1.a

appoint an individual to act as an information and samples coordinator, and

111.1.b

notify the OGA of that individual’s name and contact details.

111.2

The following persons are within this subsection—

111.2.a

a licensee, and

111.2.b

an exploration operator under a carbon storage licence.

111.3

The information and samples coordinator is to be responsible for monitoring
the relevant person’s compliance with its obligations under this Chapter.

111.4

A relevant person must comply with  subsection (1)  within a reasonable period
after—

111.4.a

the date on which this section comes into force, if the person is a relevant
person on that date, or

111.4.b

becoming a relevant person, in any other case.

111.5

The relevant person must notify the OGA of any change in the identity or
contact details of the information and samples coordinator within a reasonable
period of the change taking place.

111.6

The requirements imposed by this section are sanctionable in accordance with
this Chapter.

###### Power of OGA to require information and samples

112

112.1

The OGA may by notice in writing, for the purpose of carrying out any of its
functions under Chapter 3 of Part 1 of the Energy Act 2008 (storage of carbon
dioxide), require—

112.1.a

a licensee to provide it with any carbon storage information, or a portion of
any carbon storage sample, held by or on behalf of the licensee;

112.1.b

a person who holds information or samples in accordance with an information
and samples plan to provide it with any such information or a portion of any
such sample.

112.2

The notice must specify—

112.2.a

the form or manner in which the information or the portion of a sample must be
provided;

112.2.b

the time at which, or period within which, the information or the portion of a
sample must be provided.

112.3

Information requested under  subsection (1)  may not include items subject to
legal privilege.

112.4

Requirements imposed by a notice under this section are sanctionable in
accordance with this Chapter.

112.5

Where a person provides information or a portion of a sample to the OGA in
accordance with a notice under this section, any requirements imposed on the
person in respect of that information or sample by regulations under  section
108  are unaffected.

###### Prohibition on disclosure of information or samples by OGA

113

113.1

Protected material must not be disclosed—

113.1.a

by the OGA, or

113.1.b

by a subsequent holder,

except in accordance with  section 114  or  Schedule 7 .

113.2

In this section and in  Schedule 7 —

      “ protected material ” means information or samples which have been
obtained by the OGA under section  112  or  124 ;           “ subsequent
holder ”, in relation to protected material, means a person holding protected
material who has received it directly or indirectly from the OGA by virtue of
a disclosure, or disclosures, in accordance with  Schedule 7 .

113.3

References to disclosing protected material include references to making the
protected material available to other persons (where the protected material
includes samples).

###### Power of Secretary of State to require information and samples

114

114.1

The Secretary of State may require the OGA to provide the Secretary of State
with such information or samples held by or on behalf of the OGA as the
Secretary of State may require for the purpose of—

114.1.a

carrying out any function conferred by or under any Act,

114.1.b

monitoring the OGA's performance of its functions, or

114.1.c

any Parliamentary proceedings.

114.2

The Secretary of State may use information or samples acquired under
subsection (1)  (“acquired material”) only for the purpose for which it is
provided.

114.3

Acquired material must not be disclosed—

114.3.a

by the Secretary of State, or

114.3.b

by a subsequent holder,

except in accordance with this section.

114.4

For the purposes of  subsection (3) (b) , “ subsequent holder ”, in relation
to acquired material, means a person who receives acquired material directly
or indirectly from the Secretary of State by virtue of a disclosure, or
disclosures, in accordance with this section.

114.5

Subsection (3)  does not prohibit the Secretary of State from disclosing
acquired material so far as necessary for the purpose for which it was
provided.

114.6

Subsection (3)  does not prohibit a disclosure of acquired material if—

114.6.a

the disclosure is required by virtue of an obligation imposed by or under any
Act, or

114.6.b

the OGA consents to the disclosure and, where the acquired material in
question was provided to the OGA by or on behalf of another person, confirms
that that person also consents to the disclosure.

114.7

References in this section to disclosing acquired material include references
to making the acquired material available to other persons (where the acquired
material includes samples).

##### Enforcement of sanctionable requirements

###### Power of OGA to give sanction notices

115

115.1

If the OGA considers that a person has failed to comply with a sanctionable
requirement imposed on the person, it may give the person a sanction notice in
respect of that failure.

115.2

If the OGA considers that there has a been a failure to comply with a
sanctionable requirement imposed jointly on two or more persons, it may give a
sanction notice in respect of that failure—

115.2.a

to one only of those persons (subject to  section 118 (2) ),

115.2.b

jointly to two or more of them, or

115.2.c

jointly to all of them,

but it may not give separate sanction notices to each of them in respect of
the failure.

115.3

In this Chapter “ sanction notice ” means—

115.3.a

an enforcement notice (see  section 116 ),

115.3.b

a financial penalty notice (see  section 117 ),

115.3.c

a revocation notice (see  section 118 ), or

115.3.d

an operator removal notice (see  section 119 ).

115.4

Sanction notices, other than enforcement notices, may be given in respect of a
failure to comply with a sanctionable requirement even if, at the time the
notice is given, the failure to comply has already been remedied.

115.5

Where the OGA gives a sanction notice to a person in respect of a particular
failure to comply with a sanctionable requirement—

115.5.a

it may, at the same time, give another type of sanction notice to the person
in respect of that failure to comply;

115.5.b

it may give subsequent sanction notices in respect of that failure only in
accordance with  section 122  (subsequent sanction notices).

115.6

The OGA’s power to give sanction notices under this section is subject to
section 120  (duty of OGA to give sanction warning notices).

115.7

Where the OGA gives a sanction notice to a licensee in respect of a failure to
comply with a sanctionable requirement—

115.7.a

the matter is to be dealt with in accordance with this Chapter, and

115.7.b

any requirement under the licensee’s carbon storage licence to deal with the
matter in a certain way (including by arbitration) does not apply in respect
of that failure to comply.

###### Enforcement notices

116

116.1

An enforcement notice is a notice which—

116.1.a

specifies the sanctionable requirement in question,

116.1.b

gives details of the failure to comply with the requirement, and

116.1.c

informs the person or persons to whom the notice is given that the person or
persons must comply with—

116.1.c.i

the sanctionable requirement, and

116.1.c.ii

any directions included in the notice as mentioned in  subsection (2) ,

before the end of the period specified in the notice.

116.2

The notice may include directions as to the measures to be taken for the
purposes of compliance with the sanctionable requirement.

116.3

Requirements imposed by directions included in an enforcement notice as
mentioned in  subsection (2)  are sanctionable in accordance with this
Chapter.

###### Financial penalty notices

117

117.1

A financial penalty notice is a notice which—

117.1.a

specifies the sanctionable requirement in question,

117.1.b

gives details of the failure to comply with the requirement, and

117.1.c

informs the person or persons to whom the notice is given that the person or
persons must—

117.1.c.i

comply with the sanctionable requirement before the end of a period specified
in the notice, where it is appropriate to require such compliance and the
failure to comply with the requirement has not already been remedied at the
time the notice is given, and

117.1.c.ii

pay the OGA a financial penalty of the amount specified in the notice before
the end of a period specified in the notice.

117.2

The period specified under  subsection (1) (c) (ii)  must not end earlier than
the end of the period of 28 days beginning with the day on which the financial
penalty notice is given.

117.3

The financial penalty payable under a financial penalty notice in respect of a
failure to comply with a sanctionable requirement (whether payable by one
person, or jointly by two or more persons) must not exceed £1 million.

117.4

If a financial penalty notice is given jointly to two or more persons, those
persons are jointly and severally liable to pay the financial penalty under
it.

117.5

A financial penalty payable under a financial penalty notice is to be
recoverable as a civil debt if it is not paid before the end of the period
specified under  subsection (1) (c) (ii) .

117.6

The OGA must—

117.6.a

issue guidance as to the matters to which it will have regard when determining
the amount of the financial penalty to be imposed by a financial penalty
notice, and

117.6.b

have regard to the guidance when determining the amount of the penalty in any
particular case.

117.7

The OGA may from time to time review guidance issued under  subsection (6) (a)
and, if it considers appropriate, revise it.

117.8

Before issuing or revising guidance under this section, the OGA must consult
such persons as it considers appropriate.

117.9

The OGA must—

117.9.a

lay any guidance issued under this section, and any revision of it, before
each House of Parliament;

117.9.b

publish any guidance issued under this section, and any revision of it, in
such manner as the OGA considers appropriate.

117.10

The Secretary of State may by regulations subject to the affirmative procedure
amend  subsection (3)  to change the amount specified to an amount not
exceeding £5 million.

117.11

Money received by the OGA under a financial penalty notice must be paid into
the Consolidated Fund.

###### Revocation notices

118

118.1

A revocation notice may be given only in respect of a failure to comply with a
sanctionable requirement imposed on a licensee in that capacity.

118.2

Where two or more persons are the licensee in respect of a carbon storage
licence, the revocation notice must be given jointly to all of those persons.

118.3

A revocation notice is a notice which—

118.3.a

specifies the sanctionable requirement in question,

118.3.b

gives details of the failure to comply with the requirement,

118.3.c

informs the person or persons to whom the notice is given that—

118.3.c.i

where no storage permit has been granted under the carbon storage licence, the
licence is to be terminated, or

118.3.c.ii

where a storage permit has been granted under the carbon storage licence, the
permit is to be revoked,

on the date specified in the notice (“the revocation date”).

118.4

The revocation date must not be earlier than the end of the period of 28 days
beginning with the day on which the revocation notice is given.

118.5

A revocation notice may not be given in circumstances where the carbon storage
licence to be terminated, or the storage permit to be revoked, in accordance
with the notice is one which, on the date the notice is given, the OGA would
not have the power to grant.

118.6

Where a carbon storage licence is terminated in accordance with a revocation
notice—

118.6.a

the rights granted to the licensee by the licence cease on the revocation
date;

118.6.b

the revocation does not affect any obligation or liability imposed on or
incurred by the licensee under the terms and conditions of the licence;

118.6.c

the terms and conditions of the licence apply as if the licence had been
terminated in accordance with those terms and conditions, subject to  section
115 (7) (b) .

118.7

Where a storage permit is revoked in accordance with a revocation notice—

118.7.a

the authorisation granted by the storage permit ceases on the revocation date;

118.7.b

the revocation does not affect any obligation or liability imposed or incurred
under the terms and conditions of the storage permit;

118.7.c

the terms and conditions of the carbon storage licence apply as if the storage
permit had been revoked in accordance with those terms and conditions, subject
to  section 115 (7) (b) .

###### Operator removal notices

119

119.1

An operator removal notice may be given only in respect of a failure to comply
with a sanctionable requirement imposed on an exploration operator under a
carbon storage licence in that capacity.

119.2

An operator removal notice is a notice which—

119.2.a

specifies the sanctionable requirement,

119.2.b

gives details of the failure to comply with the requirement, and

119.2.c

informs the exploration operator to whom it is given that, with effect from a
date specified in the notice (“the removal date”), the licensee under whose
carbon storage licence the exploration operator operates (“the relevant
licensee”) is to be required to remove the exploration operator (see
subsection (4) ).

119.3

The OGA must—

119.3.a

give a copy of the operator removal notice to the relevant licensee, and

119.3.b

require the relevant licensee to remove the exploration operator with effect
from the removal date.

119.4

Where a licensee is required to remove an exploration operator from a
specified date, the licensee must ensure that, with effect from that date, the
exploration operator does not exercise any function of organising or
supervising any of the activities referred to in paragraphs (a) and (b) of
section 107 (3) .

119.5

The removal date must not be earlier than the end of the period of 28 days
beginning with the day on which the operator removal notice is given.

119.6

An operator removal notice may not be given in circumstances where the carbon
storage licence under which the exploration operator operates is one which, on
the date the notice is given, the OGA would not have the power to grant.

119.7

A requirement imposed on a licensee under  subsection (3) (b)  is sanctionable
in accordance with this Chapter.

###### Duty of OGA to give sanction warning notices

120

120.1

This section applies where the OGA proposes to give a sanction notice in
respect of a failure to comply with a sanctionable requirement.

120.2

The OGA must give a sanction warning notice in respect of the sanctionable
requirement to—

120.2.a

the person or persons to whom it proposes to give a sanction notice, and

120.2.b

where it proposes to give an operator removal notice, the relevant licensee
(see  section 119 (2) (c) ).

120.3

A sanction warning notice, in respect of a sanctionable requirement, is a
notice which—

120.3.a

specifies the sanctionable requirement,

120.3.b

informs the person or persons to whom it is given that the OGA proposes to
give a sanction notice in respect of a failure to comply with the requirement,

120.3.c

gives details of the failure to comply with the sanctionable requirement, and

120.3.d

informs the person or persons to whom it is given that the person or persons
may, within the period specified in the notice (“the representations period”),
make representations to the OGA in relation to the matters dealt with in the
notice.

120.4

The representations period must be such period as the OGA considers
appropriate in the circumstances.

120.5

Subsections  (6)  and  (7)  apply where the OGA gives a sanction warning
notice to a person or persons in respect of a sanctionable requirement.

120.6

The OGA must not give a sanction notice to the person or persons in respect of
a failure to comply with the requirement until after the end of the
representations period specified in the sanction warning notice.

120.7

Having regard to representations made during the representations period
specified in the sanction warning notice, the OGA may decide—

120.7.a

to give the person or persons a sanction notice in respect of the failure to
comply with the requirement detailed in the sanction warning notice under
subsection (3) (c) ,

120.7.b

to give the person or persons a sanction notice in respect of a failure to
comply with the requirement which differs from the failure detailed in the
sanction warning notice under  subsection (3) (c) , or

120.7.c

not to give the person or persons a sanction notice in respect of a failure to
comply with the requirement.

###### Publication of details of sanctions

121

121.1

The OGA may publish details of any sanction notice given in accordance with
this Chapter.

121.2

But the OGA may not publish anything that, in its opinion—

121.2.a

is commercially sensitive,

121.2.b

is not in the public interest to publish, or

121.2.c

is otherwise not appropriate for publication.

121.3

If, after details of a sanction notice are published by the OGA, the sanction
notice is—

121.3.a

cancelled on appeal, or

121.3.b

withdrawn under  section 123 ,

the OGA must publish details of the cancellation or withdrawal.

###### Subsequent sanction notices

122

122.1

This section applies where the OGA gives a sanction notice in respect of a
particular failure to comply with a sanctionable requirement (whether the
notice is given alone or at the same time as another type of sanction notice).

122.2

If the sanction notice given is a revocation notice or an operator removal
notice, no further sanction notices may be given in respect of the failure to
comply.

122.3

If the sanction notice given is a financial penalty notice which does not
require compliance with the sanctionable requirement, no further sanction
notices may be given in respect of the failure to comply.

122.4

Subsection  (5)  applies if the sanction notice given is—

122.4.a

an enforcement notice, or

122.4.b

a financial penalty notice which requires compliance with the sanctionable
requirement.

122.5

No further sanction notices may be given in respect of the failure to comply
before the end of the period specified under section  116 (1) (c)  or  117 (1)
(c) (i) , as the case may be (period for compliance with sanctionable
requirement).

###### Withdrawal of sanction notices

123

123.1

The OGA may, at any time after giving a sanction notice, withdraw the sanction
notice.

123.2

If a sanction notice is withdrawn by the OGA—

123.2.a

the notice ceases to have effect, and

123.2.b

the OGA must notify the following persons of the withdrawal of the notice—

123.2.b.i

the person or persons to whom the notice was given;

123.2.b.ii

in the case of an operator removal notice, the licensee under whose carbon
storage licence the exploration operator operates.

###### Sanctions: information powers

124

124.1

This section applies for the purposes of an investigation which—

124.1.a

concerns whether a person has failed to comply with a sanctionable
requirement, and

124.1.b

is carried out by the OGA for the purpose of enabling it to decide whether to
give the person a sanction notice, or on what terms a sanction notice should
be given to the person.

124.2

The OGA may by notice in writing, for the purposes of that investigation,
require the person to provide specified documents or other information.

124.3

“ Specified ” means specified, or of a description specified, in a notice
under this section.

124.4

A requirement under  subsection (2)  applies only to the extent—

124.4.a

that the documents requested are documents in the person’s possession or
control, or

124.4.b

that the information requested is information in the person’s possession or
control.

124.5

A requirement imposed by a notice under  subsection (2)  is sanctionable in
accordance with this Chapter.

124.6

The documents or information requested—

124.6.a

may include documents or information held in any form (including in electronic
form);

124.6.b

may include documents or information that may be regarded as commercially
sensitive;

124.6.c

may not include items that are subject to legal privilege.

124.7

The notice must specify—

124.7.a

to whom the information is to be provided;

124.7.b

where it is to be provided;

124.7.c

when it is to be provided;

124.7.d

the form and manner in which it is to be provided.

##### General

###### Appeals

125

In  Schedule 8 —

125.a

Part 1 contains provision about appeals against decisions by the OGA relating
to the preparation of an information and samples plan and appeals against the
giving of a notice under  section 112 , and

125.b

Part 2 contains provision about appeals against the imposition of sanction
notices and appeals against the giving of a notice under  section 124 .

###### Procedure for enforcement decisions

126

126.1

The OGA—

126.1.a

must determine the procedure that it proposes to follow in relation to
enforcement decisions, and

126.1.b

must issue a statement of its proposals.

126.2

The procedure mentioned in  subsection (1) (a)  must be designed to secure,
among other things, that an enforcement decision is taken—

126.2.a

by a person falling within  subsection (3) , or

126.2.b

by two or more persons, each of whom falls within  subsection (3) .

126.3

A person falls within this subsection if the person was not directly involved
in establishing the evidence on which the enforcement decision is based.

126.4

The statement mentioned in  subsection (1) (b)  must be published in whatever
way appears to the OGA to be best calculated to bring the statement to the
attention of the public.

126.5

When the OGA takes an enforcement decision, the OGA must follow its stated
procedure.

126.6

If the OGA changes its procedure in a material way, it must publish a revised
statement.

126.7

A failure of the OGA in a particular case to follow its procedure as set out
in the latest published statement does not affect the validity of an
enforcement decision taken in that case.

126.8

But  subsection (7)  does not prevent the Tribunal from taking into account
any such failure in considering an appeal under paragraph 4 or 5 of  Schedule
8  in relation to a sanction notice.

126.9

In this section, “ enforcement decision ” means—

126.9.a

a decision to give a sanction notice in respect of a failure to comply with a
sanctionable requirement, or

126.9.b

a decision as to the details of the sanction to be imposed by the notice.

###### Interpretation of 

127

In this Chapter—

      “ information and samples plan ” has the meaning given in  section 109 ;
“ items subject to legal privilege ”—         in England and Wales, has the
same meaning as in the Police and Criminal Evidence Act 1984 (see section 10
of that Act);           in Scotland, has the meaning given by section 412 of
the Proceeds of Crime Act 2002;           in Northern Ireland, has the same
meaning as in the Police and Criminal Evidence (Northern Ireland) Order 1989 (
S.I. 1989/1341 (NI 12)) ;                 “ OGA ” means the Oil and Gas
Authority;           “ protected material ” has the meaning given in  section
113 ;           “ sanction notice ” has the meaning given in  section 115 ;
“ storage permit ” has the same meaning as in the Storage of Carbon Dioxide
(Licensing etc) Regulations 2010 ( S.I. 2010/2221 ) (see regulation 1(3) of
those Regulations);           “ subsequent holder ” has the meaning given in
section 113 ;           “ Tribunal ” means the First-tier Tribunal.

#### General

##### Access to infrastructure

128

128.1

The Secretary of State may by regulations make provision about the acquisition
of rights to use relevant infrastructure (whether existing or proposed).

128.2

In exercising the power under  subsection (1)  the Secretary of State must
have regard to the need to ensure that the process for acquiring such rights
operates in a transparent and non-discriminatory manner.

128.3

Without prejudice to the generality of subsection  (1) , regulations under
that subsection may amend, revoke or replace or make provision similar or
corresponding to—

128.3.a

the Storage of Carbon Dioxide (Access to Infrastructure) Regulations 2011 (
S.I. 2011/2305 );

128.3.b

the Storage of Carbon Dioxide (Access to Infrastructure) Regulations (Northern
Ireland) 2015 ( S.R. (N.I.) 2015 No. 388 ).

128.4

Regulations under subsection  (1) —

128.4.a

may confer functions (including discretions) on any person;

128.4.b

may confer jurisdiction on a court or tribunal;

128.4.c

may create criminal offences or impose civil penalties;

128.4.d

may make other provision about enforcement;

128.4.e

must provide for any offences created by the regulations to be triable—

128.4.e.i

only summarily, or

128.4.e.ii

either summarily or on indictment.

128.5

Where regulations under subsection  (1)  impose a civil penalty, they must
also provide for a right of appeal against the imposition of the penalty.

128.6

Before making regulations under  subsection (1)  the Secretary of State must
give to the appropriate consultees a notice—

128.6.a

stating that the Secretary of State proposes to make regulations under
subsection  (1) , and

128.6.b

specifying the period (of not less than 28 days from the date on which the
notice is given) within which representations must be made with respect to the
proposed provisions,

and must consider any representations duly made and not withdrawn.

128.7

For the purposes of this section the “appropriate consultees” are—

128.7.a

the GEMA;

128.7.b

the Scottish Ministers, if the regulations contain provision that would be
within the legislative competence of the Scottish Parliament if it were
contained in an Act of that Parliament;

128.7.c

the Welsh Ministers, if the regulations contain provision that would be within
the legislative competence of Senedd Cymru if it were contained in an Act of
the Senedd (ignoring any requirement for the consent of a Minister of the
Crown imposed under Schedule 7B to the Government of Wales Act 2006);

128.7.d

the Department for the Economy in Northern Ireland, if the regulations contain
provision that—

128.7.d.i

would be within the legislative competence of the Northern Ireland Assembly if
it were contained in an Act of that Assembly, and

128.7.d.ii

would not, if it were contained in a Bill in the Northern Ireland Assembly,
result in the Bill requiring the consent of the Secretary of State under
section 8 of the Northern Ireland Act 1998;

128.7.e

the Oil and Gas Authority.

128.8

Regulations under  subsection (1)  are subject to the affirmative procedure.

128.9

In this section “ relevant infrastructure ” means—

128.9.a

a site for the geological storage of carbon dioxide that is situated in a
regulated place, or

128.9.b

a pipeline, situated in a regulated place, which is used or intended to be
used to convey carbon dioxide to a site falling within  paragraph (a) ,

and any associated installations, apparatus or works.

128.10

For the purposes of this section a site or pipeline is situated in a
“regulated place” if it is situated—

128.10.a

in the United Kingdom, or

128.10.b

in, under or over—

128.10.b.i

the internal waters of the United Kingdom,

128.10.b.ii

the territorial sea adjacent to United Kingdom, or

128.10.b.iii

waters in a Gas Importation and Storage Zone (within the meaning given by
section 1 of the Energy Act 2008).

128.11

In this section “ geological storage ” has the same meaning as in Part 1 (see
section 55 ).

##### Financial assistance

129

129.1

The Secretary of State may provide financial assistance to any person for the
purpose of encouraging, supporting or facilitating—

129.1.a

transportation of carbon dioxide;

129.1.b

storage of carbon dioxide;

129.1.c

carbon dioxide capture facilities which operate (or are to operate) in
association with facilities for any activity mentioned in paragraph  (a)  or
(b) ;

129.1.d

low carbon hydrogen production;

129.1.e

transportation of hydrogen;

129.1.f

storage of hydrogen.

129.2

The financial assistance referred to in  subsection (1)  includes expenditure
incurred by the Secretary of State for the purposes of, or in connection with—

129.2.a

the establishment of a revenue support counterparty, a hydrogen levy
administrator or an allocation body;

129.2.b

making payments to a revenue support counterparty.

129.3

Financial assistance under this section—

129.3.a

may be provided in any form and in particular by way of grants, loans,
guarantees or indemnities or by the provision of insurance;

129.3.b

may be provided subject to conditions (which may include conditions about
repayment with or without interest or other return);

129.3.c

may be provided pursuant to a contract;

129.3.d

may be provided to an investment fund for onward investment or for
administrative costs relating to onward investment;

129.3.e

may be provided by incurring expenditure for the benefit of the person
assisted;

129.3.f

may be provided by the acquisition of shares or any other interest in, or
securities of, a body corporate;

129.3.g

may be provided by the acquisition of any undertaking or of any assets.

129.4

The Secretary of State is not authorised by this section to give financial
assistance in the way described in  subsection (3) (f)  without the consent of
the body corporate concerned.

129.5

The power to provide financial assistance under this section is in addition to
(and does not limit or replace) any other power of a Minister of the Crown to
provide financial assistance.

129.6

In this section—

      “ allocation body ” has the same meaning as in  Chapter 1  (see  section
73 (6) );           “ greenhouse gas ” has the meaning given by section 92(1)
of the Climate Change Act 2008;           “ hydrogen levy administrator ” has
the same meaning as in  Chapter 1  (see  section 69 (6) );           “ low
carbon hydrogen production ” means production of hydrogen by a method which in
the opinion of the Secretary of State will contribute to a reduction in
emissions of greenhouse gases;           “ revenue support counterparty ” has
the same meaning as in  Chapter 1  (see  section 58 (6) );           “ storage
”, in relation to carbon dioxide, means any storage with a view to the
permanent containment of carbon dioxide;           “ undertaking ” means any
trade or business or any other activity providing employment.

### Licensing of hydrogen pipeline projects

#### Introductory

##### Key definitions for Part 3

130

130.1

In this Part—

      “ designated person ” means a person in relation to whom a designation
under  section 131 (1)  has effect (and any reference to designation, in
relation to a person, is to be construed accordingly);           “ designated
project ”, in relation to a person, means a hydrogen pipeline project in
relation to which the person is designated;           “ gas transporter
licence ” means a licence under section 7 of the Gas Act 1986;           “
hydrogen ” means any gas that consists wholly or mainly of hydrogen;
“ hydrogen pipeline project ” means a project involving the construction,
alteration or operation of a pipeline for the purpose of the conveyance of
hydrogen.

130.2

References in this Part to the extension or restriction of a licence are to
the giving of a direction in respect of the licence under (respectively)
section 7(4) or (4A) of the Gas Act 1986.

#### Designation in relation to hydrogen pipeline projects

##### Designation

131

131.1

The Secretary of State may by notice given to a person designate the person in
relation to a hydrogen pipeline project.

131.2

The Secretary of State may designate a person in relation to a hydrogen
pipeline project only if the Secretary of State is of the opinion—

131.2.a

that it is likely to be appropriate for conditions described in  section 137
(1) (a)  and  (b)  to be included in any gas transporter licence held by the
person for the purposes of the project (whether or not the person already
holds such a licence), and

131.2.b

that the project is likely to result in value for money.

131.3

A person may be designated only with the person’s consent.

131.4

A designation may not relate to more than one hydrogen pipeline project (but a
person who is designated in relation to one project may be designated
separately in relation to another).

##### Designation: procedure

132

132.1

The Secretary of State must publish a statement setting out—

132.1.a

the procedure that the Secretary of State expects to follow in determining
whether to exercise the power under  section 131 (1) , and

132.1.b

how the Secretary of State expects to determine whether the conditions in
section 131 (2)  are met.

132.2

A duty imposed by  subsection (1)  may be satisfied by things done before the
passing of this Act (as well as by things done after that time).

132.3

A designation notice must include—

132.3.a

a description of the hydrogen pipeline project to which the designation
relates,

132.3.b

the Secretary of State’s reasons for the designation,

132.3.c

details of any conditions to which the designation is subject, and

132.3.d

the date of the notice.

132.4

The Secretary of State must give the GEMA a copy of a designation notice.

132.5

The Secretary of State must publish a designation notice, but may exclude from
publication any material the disclosure or publication of which the Secretary
of State considers—

132.5.a

would be likely to prejudice the commercial interests of any person, or

132.5.b

would be contrary to the interests of national security.

132.6

In this section, “ designation notice ” means a notice under  section 131 (1)
.

##### Revocation of designation

133

133.1

The Secretary of State may by notice given to a designated person revoke the
person’s designation in relation to a hydrogen pipeline project if—

133.1.a

either of the conditions in  section 131 (2)  ceases to be met in relation to
the project,

133.1.b

the Secretary of State determines that a condition to which the designation is
subject has not been met, or

133.1.c

the person consents to the designation being revoked.

133.2

Section 132 (3) (a) ,  (b)  and  (d) ,  (4)  and  (5)  applies (with necessary
modifications) in relation to the revocation of a person’s designation as it
applies in relation to the designation of a person.

133.3

Where the Secretary of State gives a notice to a person under subsection  (1)
, the person’s designation in relation to the hydrogen pipeline project in
question ceases to have effect at the end of the day on which the notice is
given to the person.

133.4

The revocation of a person’s designation in relation to a hydrogen pipeline
project does not affect anything done in relation to the licence by the
Secretary of State under or by virtue of this Part while the person was
designated in relation to the project.

#### Grant etc of gas transporter licence

##### Grant, extension or restriction of gas transporter licence by Secretary of State

134

134.1

The Secretary of State may exercise the power under section 7(2) of the Gas
Act 1986 (grant of gas transporter licences) so as to grant a gas transporter
licence to a designated person, subject to subsection  (2) .

134.2

The Secretary of State may only grant a gas transporter licence which
authorises the conveyance of hydrogen through pipes for the purposes of the
person’s designated project.

134.3

The Secretary of State may exercise the power under section 7(4) of the Gas
Act 1986 (direction to extend licence) so as to extend a gas transporter
licence where—

134.3.a

the licence is held by a designated person, and

134.3.b

the extension authorises the conveyance of hydrogen through pipes for the
purposes of the person’s designated project.

134.4

The Secretary of State may exercise the power under section 7(4A) of the Gas
Act 1986 (direction to restrict licence) so as to restrict a gas transporter
licence where—

134.4.a

the licence is or was held by a designated person, and

134.4.b

the restriction is in connection with the revocation of the person’s
designation in relation to a hydrogen pipeline project.

134.5

In its application for the purposes of subsections  (1) ,  (3)  and  (4) , the
Gas Act 1986 has effect as if—

134.5.a

in the following provisions, references to the GEMA were to the Secretary of
State—

134.5.a.i

section 7(5) and (6)(a);

134.5.a.ii

section 7B(9);

134.5.a.iii

section 8(3), (4) and (5)(a);

134.5.b

in sections 7(6)(b) and 8(5)(b), references to the Secretary of State were to
the GEMA;

134.5.c

in section 7B(4)(c), the reference to the GEMA included a reference to the
Secretary of State, but only for the purpose of enabling the inclusion of
conditions requiring the rendering of a payment on the grant of a licence;

134.5.d

section 7B(9) also required a copy of the licence to be sent to the GEMA.

134.6

When granting or extending a gas transporter licence by virtue of this
section, the Secretary of State must have regard to—

134.6.a

costs, expenditure or liabilities of any description that the designated
person may reasonably be expected to incur in carrying out its activities;

134.6.b

the need to secure that the designated person is able to finance its
activities;

134.6.c

the need to secure that the designated person has appropriate incentives in
relation to the carrying on of its activities;

134.6.d

such other matters as the Secretary of State considers appropriate.

134.7

References in subsection  (6)  to a designated person’s activities are to the
person’s activities for the purposes of—

134.7.a

the designated project to which the grant or extension relates, and

134.7.b

in the case of an extension, any other designated project already authorised
by the person’s gas transporter licence.

134.8

A gas transporter licence granted, extended or restricted by the Secretary of
State by virtue of  this section  has effect for all purposes as if it had
been granted, extended or restricted by the GEMA.

##### Applications for grant etc of gas transporter licence

135

135.1

The Secretary of State may by regulations make provision about the making,
consideration and determination of relevant applications, including provision—

135.1.a

about the person to whom a relevant application must be made;

135.1.b

about the form and manner in which a relevant application must be made;

135.1.c

imposing timing requirements in relation to the making of a relevant
application;

135.1.d

requiring a relevant application to be accompanied by such information and
documents as may be specified in the regulations;

135.1.e

requiring a relevant application to be accompanied by such fee (if any) as may
be—

135.1.e.i

specified in the regulations, or

135.1.e.ii

determined, by the person to whom the application is made, in accordance with
the regulations;

135.1.f

about the matters to be taken into account in determining a relevant
application;

135.1.g

requiring a determination to be accompanied by reasons;

135.1.h

requiring determinations to be published;

135.1.i

conferring functions on the Secretary of State or the GEMA (including
functions involving the exercise of a discretion);

135.1.j

for anything falling to be determined under the regulations to be determined—

135.1.j.i

by the Secretary of State, the GEMA or another person specified in the
regulations, and

135.1.j.ii

in accordance with such procedure and by reference to such matters and to the
opinion of such persons as may be so specified.

135.2

“ Relevant application ” means an application within any of the following
paragraphs (whether made to the Secretary of State or the GEMA)—

135.2.a

an application by a designated person for the grant of a gas transporter
licence that authorises the conveyance of hydrogen through pipes for the
purposes of the person’s designated project;

135.2.b

an application by a designated person for the extension of a gas transporter
licence held by the person so that it authorises the conveyance of hydrogen
through pipes for the purposes of the person’s designated project;

135.2.c

an application by a person who is or has been designated for the restriction
of a gas transporter licence held by the person, in connection with the
person’s designation in relation to a hydrogen pipeline project ceasing to
have effect.

135.3

Provision made by virtue of subsection  (1) (j) (ii)  may in particular be
made by reference to a document as amended from time to time.

135.4

Regulations under this section—

135.4.a

may provide for cases in which an application is not required;

135.4.b

may provide for a relevant application that has been rejected by one person to
be dealt with afresh by another person.

135.5

Before making regulations under this section, the Secretary of State must
consult the GEMA.

135.6

Section 7B(1) to (2A) of the Gas Act 1986 does not apply to an application for
the grant, extension or restriction of a gas transporter licence so far as the
application is one to which regulations under this section apply.

135.7

Any sums received by the Secretary of State or the GEMA by virtue of this
section are to be paid into the Consolidated Fund.

135.8

Regulations under this section are subject to the negative procedure.

135.9

For the purposes of section 5A(1) to (10) of the Utilities Act 2000 (duty of
the GEMA to carry out impact assessment), a function exercisable by the GEMA
by virtue of regulations under this section is to be treated as if it were a
function exercisable by it under or by virtue of Part 1 of the Gas Act 1986.

#### Modification of gas transporter licence

##### Modification of gas transporter licence by Secretary of State

136

136.1

The Secretary of State may modify—

136.1.a

the conditions of a designated person’s gas transporter licence;

136.1.b

the terms of a designated person’s gas transporter licence;

136.1.c

the standard conditions incorporated in gas transporter licences by virtue of
section 8 of the Gas Act 1986;

136.1.d

a document maintained in accordance with the conditions of licences of a
relevant type or an agreement that gives effect to a document so maintained.

136.2

The Secretary of State may exercise the power under  subsection (1)  only for
the purpose of—

136.2.a

facilitating or supporting the financing of the design, construction,
commissioning or operation of a hydrogen pipeline project (or of hydrogen
pipeline projects generally), or

136.2.b

promoting value for money in connection with a hydrogen pipeline project (or
in connection with hydrogen pipeline projects generally).

136.3

When making modifications under  subsection (1) (a)  or  (b) , the Secretary
of State must have regard to—

136.3.a

the duties in sections 1 and 4(1)(b) of the Climate Change Act 2008 (carbon
targets and budgets);

136.3.b

the interests of existing and future consumers of gas conveyed through pipes,
including their interests in relation to the cost and security of supply of
gas;

136.3.c

costs, expenditure or liabilities of any description that the designated
person may reasonably be expected to incur in carrying out its activities;

136.3.d

the need to secure that the designated person is able to finance its
activities;

136.3.e

the need to secure that the designated person has appropriate incentives in
relation to the carrying on of its activities;

136.3.f

such other matters as the Secretary of State considers appropriate.

In paragraph  (b) , “ gas ” has the same meaning as in Part 1 of the Gas Act
1986 (see section 48(1) of that Act).

136.4

The Secretary of State may modify the conditions or terms of a gas transporter
licence held by a person who is or was a designated person in connection with
the revocation of the person’s designation in relation to a hydrogen pipeline
project.

136.5

For the purposes of  subsection (1) , each of the following is a relevant type
of licence—

136.5.a

a gas transporter licence;

136.5.b

a licence under section 7A(1) of the Gas Act 1986 (gas supply licence);

136.5.c

a licence under section 7AA of that Act (gas system planner licence);

136.5.d

a licence under section 7AC of that Act (code manager licence).

136.6

References in this section to a designated person’s activities are to the
person’s activities for the purposes of—

136.6.a

the designated project to which the modification relates, and

136.6.b

any other designated project authorised by the person’s gas transporter
licence.

##### Scope of modification powers under 

137

137.1

Modifications made under  section 136 (1) (a)  may include, for example,
provision—

137.1.a

about the revenue that the designated person may receive in respect of its
activities (its “allowed revenue”);

137.1.b

about how the designated person’s allowed revenue is to be calculated;

137.1.c

about the amounts that the designated person is entitled to receive, or is
required to pay, under any hydrogen transport revenue support contract (within
the meaning of Chapter 1 of Part 2) to which it is a party;

137.1.d

about activities that the designated person must, may or may not carry on;

137.1.e

about the management of the designated person’s activities, including the
manner in which they are carried out;

137.1.f

conferring functions on the GEMA, including provision enabling or requiring
the designated person to refer for determination, decision or approval by the
GEMA matters specified, or of a description specified, in the licence;

137.1.g

for the amendment of the licence for the purpose of implementing a
determination or decision of the GEMA or the Competition and Markets
Authority;

137.1.h

requiring the designated person to comply with any direction or instruction,
or to have regard to any guidance, given by the GEMA in relation to matters
specified, or of a description specified, in the licence;

137.1.i

requiring the designated person to co-operate with the GEMA and to provide
such information and assistance to the GEMA as it may require for the purposes
of carrying out any of its functions;

137.1.j

about the payment by the designated person, to the GEMA or to the Competition
and Markets Authority, of such amounts as may be determined by or in
accordance with the licence;

137.1.k

about the disclosure or publication of information by the designated person.

137.2

Modifications made under  section 136 (1) (b)  may include, for example,
provision about the circumstances in which a licence may be revoked or
suspended.

137.3

The powers under  section 136 (1)  and  (4)  to “modify” include the power to
amend, add to or remove; and references to modification in  section 136 , this
section and  section 138  are to be construed accordingly.

137.4

The powers conferred by  section 136 (1)  and  (4) —

137.4.a

may be exercised generally, only in relation to specified cases, or subject to
exceptions (including by making provision for a case to be excepted only so
long as specified conditions are satisfied);

137.4.b

may be exercised differently for different purposes or areas;

137.4.c

include power to make incidental, supplementary, consequential or transitional
modifications.

137.5

Provision included in a gas transporter licence, or in a document or agreement
described in  section 136 (1) (d) , by virtue of  section 136 —

137.5.a

need not relate to the activities authorised by the licence;

137.5.b

may do anything authorised for gas transporter licences by section 7B(4A),
(5)(a), (6) or (7) of the Gas Act 1986.

137.6

The modification under  section 136 (1)  or  (4)  of part of a standard
condition of a gas transporter licence does not prevent any other part of the
condition from continuing to be regarded as a standard condition for the
purposes of Part 1 of the Gas Act 1986.

137.7

In section 81(2) of the Utilities Act 2000 (standard conditions of gas
licences), after “ section 89 ” (as inserted by section  91 (13)  of this Act)
insert  “, section  136 (1)  or  (4) ” .

137.8

References in this section to a designated person’s activities are to the
person’s activities for the purposes of—

137.8.a

the designated project to which the modification relates, and

137.8.b

any other designated project authorised by the person’s gas transporter
licence.

##### Procedure etc relating to modifications under 

138

138.1

Before making a modification under  section 136 (1)  or  (4) , the Secretary
of State must consult—

138.1.a

the holder of any licence being modified,

138.1.b

the GEMA, and

138.1.c

such other persons as the Secretary of State considers appropriate.

138.2

If under  section 136 (1)  the Secretary of State modifies the standard
conditions of a gas transporter licence, the GEMA must—

138.2.a

make the same modification of those standard conditions for the purposes of
their incorporation in gas transporter licences granted after that time, and

138.2.b

publish the modification.

138.3

The Secretary of State must publish details of any modifications made under
section 136 (1)  and  (4)  as soon as reasonably practicable after they are
made.

138.4

The Secretary of State may exclude from publication under subsection  (3)  any
material the disclosure or publication of which the Secretary of State
considers—

138.4.a

would be likely to prejudice the commercial interests of any person, or

138.4.b

would be contrary to the interests of national security.

#### Information

##### Information and advice

139

139.1

The Secretary of State may by regulations make provision about the provision
and publication of information and advice in connection with the carrying out
of functions of any person under or by virtue of this Part.

139.2

The provision that may be made by virtue of  subsection (1)  includes
provision—

139.2.a

for the Secretary of State to require the GEMA to provide information to a
hydrogen transport counterparty or any other specified person;

139.2.b

for a hydrogen transport counterparty to require the GEMA to provide
information to it;

139.2.c

for the Secretary of State to require a designated person, a hydrogen
transport counterparty or any other specified person to provide information to
the GEMA;

139.2.d

for the GEMA to require a designated person, a hydrogen transport counterparty
or any other specified person to provide information to the GEMA;

139.2.e

for the Secretary of State to require a designated person, a hydrogen
transport counterparty, the GEMA or any other specified person to provide
information or advice to the Secretary of State or any other specified person;

139.2.f

for the classification and protection of confidential or sensitive
information;

139.2.g

for the enforcement of any requirement imposed by virtue of any of  paragraphs
(a)  to  (f) .

139.3

Section 105(1) of the Utilities Act 2000 (general restrictions on disclosure
of information) does not apply to a disclosure required by virtue of this
section.

139.4

The first regulations under this section are subject to the affirmative
procedure.

139.5

Any other regulations under this section are subject to the negative
procedure.

139.6

In this section—

      “ designated person ” includes a person who has been a designated
person;           “ hydrogen transport counterparty ” has the same meaning as
in  Chapter 1  of  Part 2  (see section  56 );           “ specified person ”
means a person specified, or of a description specified, in regulations under
this section.

139.7

See also section 34(4) of the Gas Act 1986 (general duty for the GEMA to give
information, advice and assistance to the Secretary of State or the
Competition and Markets Authority).

#### Conditions of gas transporter licences

##### Conditions of gas transporter licences for conveyance of hydrogen

140

140.1

For the purposes of this section, “ relevant licence ” means a gas transporter
licence so far as it authorises a person to convey hydrogen through pipes in
connection with the carrying on of a hydrogen pipeline project.

140.2

Without prejudice to the generality of section 7B(4)(a) of the Gas Act 1986
(conditions of licences), conditions described in subsection  (3)  may be
included in a relevant licence in respect of circumstances where a person
other than the licence holder (“the candidate”)—

140.2.a

has applied for, or is considering whether to apply for, a relevant licence,
or

140.2.b

is considering whether to apply for financial support for activities relating
to the production, transportation, storage or use of hydrogen.

140.3

The conditions referred to in subsection  (2)  are conditions that require the
licence holder to comply with a direction given by the Secretary of State or
the GEMA requiring the holder to provide to the candidate—

140.3.a

information in relation to the activities authorised by the licence, and

140.3.b

any other assistance that the candidate may reasonably require for the purpose
of determining whether to—

140.3.b.i

apply for a relevant licence, or

140.3.b.ii

apply for financial support as mentioned in  subsection (2) (b) .

140.4

A person (“ P ”) may not under section 8(3) of the Gas Act 1986 modify a
condition of a relevant licence unless P is of the opinion that the
modification is such that—

140.4.a

the licence holder would not be unduly disadvantaged in competing with one or
more other holders of relevant licences, and

140.4.b

no other holder of a relevant licence would be unduly disadvantaged in
competing with other holders of such licences (including the holder of the
relevant licence to be modified).

#### Other

##### Secretary of State directions to the GEMA

141

141.1

In exercising any functions it has in relation to relevant gas transporter
licences, the GEMA must comply with general or particular directions given to
it by the Secretary of State for the purpose of promoting value for money in
connection with a hydrogen pipeline project (or in connection with hydrogen
pipeline projects generally).

141.2

In  subsection (1) , “ relevant gas transporter licence ” means a gas
transporter licence, held by a designated person, that authorises the
conveyance of hydrogen through pipes in connection with the person’s
designated project.

##### Repeal of 

142

142.1

The Secretary of State may by regulations repeal any of the preceding
provisions of this Part.

142.2

So far as any of those provisions is still in force on a relevant date, the
Secretary of State must—

142.2.a

consider whether it is appropriate to repeal that provision, and

142.2.b

if satisfied that it is not appropriate to do so, publish a statement no later
than 3 months after that date explaining why not.

142.3

“Relevant date” in  subsection (2)  means 31 December 2040 and each five-year
anniversary of that date.

142.4

Regulations under this section are subject to the affirmative procedure.

### New technology

#### Low-carbon heat schemes

##### Low-carbon heat schemes

143

143.1

The Secretary of State may by regulations make provision for the establishment
and operation of one or more low-carbon heat schemes.

143.2

A “low-carbon heat scheme” is a scheme for encouraging the supply or
installation in the United Kingdom of relevant heating appliances through the
imposition of low-carbon heat targets on persons to whom the scheme applies.

143.3

In this Chapter—

      “ low-carbon heat target ” means a target imposed by or under scheme
regulations;           “ relevant heating appliance ” means—         a heating
appliance that generates heat but is incapable of burning fossil fuels or peat
to do so, or           a heating appliance that generates heat by burning
fossil fuels or peat, but does so only as part of a wider system to supplement
heat from air, water or the ground.

143.4

In the definition of “relevant heating appliance” in  subsection (3) , “
fossil fuel ” means—

143.4.a

coal,

143.4.b

lignite,

143.4.c

natural gas (within the meaning of the Energy Act 1976),

143.4.d

crude liquid petroleum,

143.4.e

petroleum products (within the meaning of that Act), or

143.4.f

any substance produced directly or indirectly from a substance mentioned in
paragraphs (a)  to  (e) .

143.5

The provision made by sections  144  to  150  is without prejudice to the
generality of subsection  (1) .

143.6

In this Chapter, “ scheme regulations ” means regulations under  subsection
(1) .

##### Application of scheme

144

144.1

Scheme regulations that provide for the establishment of a low-carbon heat
scheme must identify—

144.1.a

the descriptions of person to whom the scheme applies;

144.1.b

the kinds of relevant heating appliance to which the scheme applies.

144.2

A person within a description identified by virtue of  subsection (1) (a)  is
referred to in this Chapter as a “scheme participant”.

144.3

Scheme regulations may—

144.3.a

set low-carbon heat targets, or

144.3.b

provide for low-carbon heat targets to be set in accordance with provision
made by the regulations.

Section  145  contains further provision about the setting of targets.

144.4

Scheme regulations must make provision about the period or periods in relation
to which low-carbon heat targets have effect.

144.5

The provision that may be made by virtue of  subsection (4)  includes—

144.5.a

provision authorising things done by a scheme participant before the first
period in relation to which a low-carbon heat target has effect to be treated
as done by the scheme participant during that period;

144.5.b

provision authorising things done by a scheme participant during one period in
relation to which a low-carbon-heat target has effect to be treated instead as
done by the scheme participant during a different period in relation to which
such a target has effect.

##### Setting of targets etc

145

145.1

A low-carbon heat target may be set in whatever way, and by reference to
whatever criteria, the Secretary of State considers appropriate, and may for
example be set—

145.1.a

by reference to the carrying on of specified activities;

145.1.b

as a proportion of the activities of a scheme participant that must relate to
relevant heating appliances;

145.1.c

by reference to the average level of energy efficiency (determined in
accordance with scheme regulations) to be achieved in relation to heating
appliances, or specified descriptions of heating appliances, supplied or
installed by a scheme participant;

145.1.d

by reference to the average carbon intensity of heat generation (determined in
accordance with scheme regulations) of heating appliances, or specified
descriptions of heating appliances, supplied or installed by a scheme
participant;

145.1.e

where a scheme participant manufactures heating appliances, by specifying what
proportion of those heating appliances, or of specified heating appliances,
that are supplied or installed (whether or not by the scheme participant) must
be relevant heating appliances.

145.2

The power to specify an activity by virtue of  subsection (1) (a)  includes
power to specify circumstances or conditions relating to the carrying out of
the activity.

145.3

In the case of a low-carbon heat target that is imposed by virtue of
subsection  (1) (c)  or  (d)  on a scheme participant who manufactures heating
appliances, the target may be set by reference to heating appliances that are
supplied or installed (whether or not by the scheme participant).

145.4

Scheme regulations may confer a discretion on the Secretary of State or any
other person in connection with the setting of low-carbon heat targets.

145.5

The reference in subsection  (1) (d)  to the carbon intensity of heat
generation, in relation to an appliance, is a reference to the level of
greenhouse gas emissions per unit of heat generated by the appliance.

“ Greenhouse gas emissions ” means emissions of any greenhouse gas within the
meaning of section 92(1) of the Climate Change Act 2008.

145.6

Scheme regulations may provide—

145.6.a

for different weight to be given to different kinds of appliance or different
activities;

145.6.b

for low-carbon heat targets to be set at different levels for different kinds
of appliance or different activities.

145.7

Scheme regulations may provide for specified activities to count towards the
meeting of a low-carbon heat target.

145.8

In this section, “ specified ” means specified in scheme regulations.

##### Further provision about scheme regulations

146

146.1

Scheme regulations must provide for the making of determinations as to whether
a scheme participant has met a low-carbon heat target imposed on the scheme
participant.

146.2

Scheme regulations may make provision for monitoring the operation of a low-
carbon heat scheme, and may in particular make provision about—

146.2.a

the keeping of records by scheme participants and others;

146.2.b

the provision of information by scheme participants and others;

146.2.c

the audit and verification of information provided by scheme participants and
others.

146.3

Scheme regulations may make provision—

146.3.a

enabling scheme participants to pool or transfer low-carbon heat targets
imposed on them;

146.3.b

for the issuing of certificates representing activities or appliances to which
a low-carbon heat target relates;

146.3.c

enabling scheme participants to acquire certificates mentioned in  paragraph
(b)  for the purpose of meeting a low-carbon heat target;

146.3.d

about the keeping of records in relation to—

146.3.d.i

the pooling or transfer of low-carbon heat targets;

146.3.d.ii

the acquisition of certificates.

146.4

Scheme regulations may make provision—

146.4.a

requiring a scheme participant who fails to meet a low-carbon heat target to
make a payment, before a specified deadline, of an amount specified by or
determined in accordance with the regulations;

146.4.b

for a payment mentioned in  paragraph (a)  to be made to the administrator
(see  section 147 ) or to such other person as the regulations may specify;

146.4.c

for a person who fails to meet a low-carbon heat target to be subject to such
consequences (instead of or in addition to a requirement mentioned in
paragraph (a) ) as may be specified;

146.4.d

about how liability to make a payment, or to other consequences, is to be
determined where low-carbon heat targets have been pooled or transferred by
virtue of provision made under  subsection (3) (a) .

146.5

In subsection  (4) , “ specified ” means specified in scheme regulations.

##### Administration of scheme

147

147.1

Scheme regulations may provide for the appointment of a person as the
administrator of a low-carbon heat scheme.

147.2

Scheme regulations—

147.2.a

may confer functions on the administrator for the purposes of the scheme;

147.2.b

may authorise the administrator to arrange for another person to carry out any
functions of the administrator.

147.3

The functions that may be conferred on the administrator by virtue of
subsection (2)  include, for example, functions in connection with—

147.3.a

setting low-carbon heat targets;

147.3.b

determining whether low-carbon heat targets have been met;

147.3.c

obtaining information;

147.3.d

keeping records;

147.3.e

requiring scheme participants to make payments to the administrator in
connection with the costs of operating the scheme.

147.4

Only the following may be appointed as the administrator of a low-carbon heat
scheme—

147.4.a

the Secretary of State;

147.4.b

the Scottish Ministers;

147.4.c

the Welsh Ministers;

147.4.d

the Department for the Economy in Northern Ireland;

147.4.e

a public authority (other than a person within any of  paragraphs (a)  to  (d)
);

147.4.f

any combination of the above.

147.5

More than one person may be appointed as the administrator of a low-carbon
heat scheme.

147.6

Scheme regulations that appoint a public authority as the administrator of a
low-carbon heat scheme may make such amendments to primary legislation as the
Secretary of State considers appropriate for the purpose of enabling the
authority to carry out the functions conferred on it by the regulations.

147.7

In this section, “ public authority ” means a person with functions of a
public nature.

##### Enforcement, penalties and offences

148

148.1

Scheme regulations may authorise the administrator of a low-carbon heat
scheme—

148.1.a

to require the production of documents or the provision of information;

148.1.b

to question the officers of a company or other individuals;

148.1.c

to enter premises with a warrant;

148.1.d

to seize documents or records.

148.2

Scheme regulations may authorise the administrator of a low-carbon heat
scheme, in circumstances specified in the regulations—

148.2.a

to treat activities of a person (A) as activities of a different person (B)
for the purposes of the scheme, and

148.2.b

to treat a low-carbon heat target imposed on A as if it had been imposed on B.

148.3

Scheme regulations may provide that a person is liable to one or more
penalties in respect of a failure to comply with a requirement imposed on the
person by or under a low-carbon heat scheme.

148.4

Where by virtue of  subsection (3)  scheme regulations provide that a person
is liable to a financial penalty, the regulations—

148.4.a

may specify the amount of the penalty or provide for the amount of the penalty
to be determined in accordance with the regulations;

148.4.b

must provide for the penalty to be paid to the administrator or to such other
person as the regulations may specify.

148.5

Scheme regulations may create offences for failure to comply with a
requirement imposed by or under a low-carbon heat scheme.

148.6

Scheme regulations made by virtue of  subsection (5)  may provide for an
offence created by the regulations to be triable—

148.6.a

only summarily, or

148.6.b

either summarily or on indictment.

148.7

Scheme regulations made by virtue of  subsection (5)  may provide for an
offence created by the regulations to be punishable with a fine.

##### Application of sums paid by virtue of section 

149

149.1

Scheme regulations may make provision about the application of amounts paid by
virtue of section  146 (4) (a)  or  148 (3) .

149.2

Provision made by virtue of subsection  (1)  may require the payment of
amounts into the Consolidated Fund.

##### Appeals

150

150.1

Scheme regulations that, by virtue of  section 148 (3) , provide that a person
is liable to a financial penalty must also provide for a person to have a
right of appeal to a court or tribunal against the imposition of the penalty.

150.2

Scheme regulations may make provision about appeals against—

150.2.a

decisions made by the administrator of a low-carbon heat scheme, and

150.2.b

penalties imposed (other than financial penalties) or enforcement action taken
for failure to comply with a requirement imposed by or under a low-carbon heat
scheme.

150.3

Scheme regulations that make provision by virtue of subsection  (2)  must
specify the court, tribunal or person who is to hear and determine an appeal
made by virtue of that subsection.

##### Scheme regulations: procedure etc

151

151.1

Scheme regulations are subject to the negative procedure unless subsection
(2)  applies, in which case they are subject to the affirmative procedure.

151.2

This subsection applies if scheme regulations—

151.2.a

establish a low-carbon heat scheme;

151.2.b

extend the descriptions of person, or the kinds of relevant heating appliance,
to which a low-carbon heat scheme applies;

151.2.c

provide for new penalties;

151.2.d

increase the amount of existing financial penalties by more than is necessary
to reflect changes in the value of money;

151.2.e

create an offence or increase the fine for an existing offence;

151.2.f

confer new powers to enforce requirements imposed by or under a low-carbon
heat scheme;

151.2.g

amend primary legislation.

151.3

Scheme regulations may create exceptions to any requirement imposed by the
regulations.

151.4

Before making scheme regulations that apply in relation to Scotland, Wales or
Northern Ireland, the Secretary of State must give notice—

151.4.a

stating that the Secretary of State proposes to make scheme regulations,

151.4.b

setting out or describing the provisions of the regulations that apply in
relation to Scotland, Wales or Northern Ireland, and

151.4.c

specifying the period (of not less than 28 days from the date on which the
notice is given) within which representations may be made with respect to
those provisions,

and must consider any representations duly made and not withdrawn.

151.5

A notice under  subsection (4)  must be given to each relevant devolved
authority, that is to say—

151.5.a

the Scottish Ministers, so far as the regulations apply in relation to
Scotland;

151.5.b

the Welsh Ministers, so far as the regulations apply in relation to Wales;

151.5.c

the Department for the Economy in Northern Ireland, so far as the regulations
apply in relation to Northern Ireland.

151.6

The Secretary of State need not wait until the end of the period specified
under  subsection (4) (c)  before making regulations if, before the end of
that period, each relevant devolved authority to which the notice was given
has confirmed that it has made any representations it intends to make with
respect to the provisions referred to in  subsection (4) (b) .

151.7

The Secretary of State must, if requested to do so by a relevant devolved
authority, give the authority a statement setting out whether and how
representations made by the authority with respect to the provisions referred
to in  subsection (4) (b)  have been taken into account in the regulations.

##### Interpretation of Chapter 

152

In this Chapter—

      “ low-carbon heat scheme ” has the meaning given by  section 143 (2) ;
“ low-carbon heat target ” has the meaning given by  section 143 (3) ;
“ primary legislation ” means—         an Act,           an Act of the
Scottish Parliament,           a Measure or Act of Senedd Cymru, or
Northern Ireland legislation;                 “ relevant heating appliance ”
has the meaning given by  section 143 (3) ;           “ scheme participant ”
has the meaning given by  section 144 (2) ;           “ scheme regulations ”
has the meaning given by  section 143 (6) .

#### Hydrogen grid conversion trials

##### Modifications of the gas code

153

153.1

For the purposes of this section, “ hydrogen grid conversion trial ” means a
scheme designated by the Secretary of State that—

153.1.a

relates to a particular place or area (the “trial location”),

153.1.b

is designed to gather evidence for the purpose of enabling assessments to be
made about the feasibility, costs and benefits of using hydrogen for heating
or cooking,

153.1.c

requires the network for supplying gas to the trial location to be modified so
as to enable the supply of hydrogen, and

153.1.d

is intended to have effect for a definite period.

153.2

Schedule 2B to the Gas Act 1986 (the gas code) applies in relation to a
hydrogen grid conversion trial—

153.2.a

as if references to a gas transporter included a person (other than a gas
transporter) who is conducting the trial, and

153.2.b

as if it were modified in accordance with subsections  (3)  to  (5) .

153.3

Paragraph 16 (alterations etc of burners on change of calorific value) applies
as if—

153.3.a

in sub-paragraph (1), the words “at a rate not exceeding 75,000 therms a year”
were omitted, and

153.3.b

in sub-paragraph (2), the steps required to be taken in respect of premises in
the trial location also included any works required in respect of the premises
(other than works already mentioned in sub-paragraph (2)) for the purposes or
in consequence of the trial.

153.4

Paragraph 23 (entry of premises during supply) applies as if the power
conferred by sub-paragraph (1)(a) included power to enter premises in the
trial location for the purpose of inspecting anything on the premises, or
carrying out any tests on the premises, in preparation for or otherwise in
