connection with the trial.

153.5

Paragraph 24 (entry of premises to discontinue supply) applies as if the power
conferred by sub-paragraph (2) were exercisable for the purposes of the trial—

153.5.a

in relation to any premises in the trial location, and

153.5.b

notwithstanding sub-paragraph (1).

153.6

For the purposes of the application of the Rights of Entry (Gas and
Electricity Boards) Act 1954 in relation to a relevant power of entry (see
paragraph 28(5) of Schedule 2B to the Gas Act 1986), the reference in section
1(2) of the 1954 Act to a gas operator includes a reference to a person (other
than a gas transporter) who is conducting a hydrogen grid conversion trial.

153.7

In subsection  (6) , “ relevant power of entry ” means a power of entry
conferred by Schedule 2B to the Gas Act 1986, as it applies by virtue of this
section in relation to a hydrogen grid conversion trial.

##### Regulations for protection of consumers

154

154.1

The Secretary of State may by regulations make provision—

154.1.a

requiring a gas transporter to take specified steps to secure that consumers
in a trial location are properly informed about a hydrogen grid conversion
trial being conducted in the trial location;

154.1.b

requiring a gas transporter to take specified steps to secure that consumers
are given adequate warning of the need for their premises to be disconnected
for the purposes of a hydrogen grid conversion trial;

154.1.c

about the enforcement of requirements imposed by virtue of  paragraph (a)  or
(b) .

154.2

Regulations under  subsection (1)  may confer functions on gas transporters in
connection with the discharge of requirements imposed by the regulations.

154.3

The provision that may be made by virtue of subsection  (1) (c)  includes
provision for the imposition of civil penalties in respect of a failure to
comply with a requirement imposed by the regulations (but does not include
provision for the creation of a criminal offence).

154.4

The Secretary of State may by regulations make provision designed to secure
protection for consumers and other people who are affected, or likely to be
affected, by a hydrogen grid conversion trial.

154.5

The provision that may be made by regulations under  subsection (4)  includes,
for example, provision—

154.5.a

about the making of complaints about the exercise by a gas transporter of a
power conferred by a relevant statutory provision;

154.5.b

about the award of redress in specified circumstances;

154.5.c

imposing requirements on gas transporters or other persons to provide
information to consumers and others;

154.5.d

for securing that consumers and others are not required to incur expenditure,
or are not otherwise financially disadvantaged, as a result of a hydrogen grid
conversion trial;

154.5.e

for securing fair treatment of consumers and others before, during and after a
hydrogen grid conversion trial;

154.5.f

about the quality of products provided to consumers and others and the quality
of works carried out on premises owned by consumers and others;

154.5.g

about the enforcement of requirements imposed by the regulations on gas
transporters or other persons.

154.6

The provision that may be made by virtue of subsection  (5) (g)  includes
provision for the imposition of civil penalties in respect of a failure to
comply with a requirement imposed by the regulations (but does not include
provision for the creation of a criminal offence).

154.7

Where regulations under this section make provision for a civil penalty, they
must also include provision for a right of appeal to a court or tribunal
against the imposition of the penalty.

154.8

Regulations under this section are subject to the negative procedure.

154.9

In this section—

      “ consumer ” and “disconnected” have the same meaning as in Schedule 2B
to the Gas Act 1986 (see paragraph 1(1) of that Schedule);           “ gas
transporter ” means—         a gas transporter within the meaning of Part 1 of
the Gas Act 1986 (see section 7 of that Act), or           any other person
who—         is conducting a hydrogen grid conversion trial, and
does not require a licence under section 7 of the Gas Act 1986 as a result of
an exemption under section 6A of that Act;                       “ hydrogen
grid conversion trial ” and “trial location” have the same meaning as in
section 153 ;           “ specified ” means specified by regulations.

#### Miscellaneous

##### Hydrogen

###### Power to modify Gas Act 1986 in relation to hydrogen

155

155.1

The Secretary of State may by regulations provide for any provision of the Gas
Act 1986—

155.1.a

not to apply, or

155.1.b

to apply with modifications specified in the regulations,

in relation to the production, transportation, storage or use of hydrogen.

155.2

The power under  subsection (1)  may be exercised by amending the Gas Act
1986.

155.3

The power under  subsection (1)  may be exercised only for the purpose of
facilitating or promoting the production, transportation, storage or use of
hydrogen.

155.4

Before exercising the power under  subsection (1) , the Secretary of State
must consult—

155.4.a

the GEMA, and

155.4.b

such other persons as the Secretary of State considers appropriate.

155.5

Regulations under  subsection (1)  are subject to the affirmative procedure.

##### Fusion energy

###### Fusion energy facilities: nuclear site licence not required

156

156.1

Section 1 of the Nuclear Installations Act 1965 (restriction of certain
nuclear installations to licensed sites) is amended as follows.

156.2

After subsection (2) insert—

156.2.2A

Subsection (1) does not apply to a fusion energy facility.

156.2.2B

In subsection (2A), “ fusion energy facility ” means a site that is—

156.2.2B.a

used for the purpose of installing or operating any plant designed or adapted
for the production of electrical energy or heat by fusion, and

156.2.2B.b

not also used for the purpose of installing or operating a nuclear reactor.

##### Renewable and sustainable fuel

###### Treatment of recycled carbon fuel and nuclear-derived fuel as renewable transport fuel

157

After section 131C of the Energy Act 2004 insert—

########## Recycled carbon fuel and nuclear-derived fuel

157.131D

157.131D.1

An RTF order may—

157.131D.1.a

designate as recycled carbon fuel a description of liquid or gaseous fuel
which is produced wholly from waste derived from a fossil source of energy;

157.131D.1.b

designate as nuclear-derived fuel a description of liquid or gaseous fuel
which is produced wholly using, or by a process powered wholly by, nuclear
fuel.

157.131D.2

Where a designation under subsection  (1)  is in force, the recycled carbon
fuel or nuclear-derived fuel is to be treated for the purposes of this Chapter
and any RTF order as renewable transport fuel.

###### Revenue certainty scheme for sustainable aviation fuel producers: consultation and report

158

158.1

The Secretary of State must carry out a public consultation on the options for
designing and implementing a sustainable aviation fuel revenue certainty
scheme.

158.2

A “sustainable aviation fuel revenue certainty scheme” is a scheme whose
purpose is to give producers of sustainable aviation fuel greater certainty
than they otherwise would have about the revenue that they will earn from
sustainable aviation fuel that they produce.

158.3

The Secretary of State must open the consultation within the period of 6
months beginning with the day on which this Act is passed.

158.4

The Secretary of State must bring the consultation to the attention of, in
particular, such of each of the following as the Secretary of State considers
appropriate—

158.4.a

producers of sustainable aviation fuel;

158.4.b

suppliers of sustainable aviation fuel;

158.4.c

airlines.

158.5

The Secretary of State must, within the period of 18 months beginning with the
day on which this Act is passed, lay before Parliament a report on progress
made towards the development of a sustainable aviation fuel revenue certainty
scheme.

158.6

In this section, “ sustainable aviation fuel ” means aviation turbine fuel
whose use (as compared with the use of other aviation turbine fuel) will, in
the opinion of the Secretary of State, contribute to a reduction in emissions
of greenhouse gases; and for this purpose—

      “ aviation turbine fuel ” has the meaning given by article 3(1B) of the
Renewable Transport Fuel Obligations Order 2007 ( S.I. 2007/3072 );
“ greenhouse gas ” has the meaning given by section 92(1) of the Climate
Change Act 2008.

###### Renewable liquid heating fuel obligations

159

159.1

The Secretary of State may by regulations subject off-grid heating fuel
suppliers (or off-grid heating fuel suppliers of a particular description) to
an obligation in respect of renewable liquid heating fuel that corresponds to
or is similar to the obligation mentioned in section 124(2) of the Energy Act
2004 (renewable transport fuel obligation).

159.2

The regulations may, for any purpose connected with that obligation, make
provision corresponding to or similar to any provision made by, or that may be
made under, Chapter 5 of Part 2 of the Energy Act 2004 (powers etc relating to
renewable transport fuel obligation).

159.3

Before making regulations under this section, the Secretary of State must
consult such persons as the Secretary of State considers appropriate.

159.4

Regulations under this section are subject to the affirmative procedure.

159.5

In this section—

      “ off-grid heating fuel supplier ” means a person who, in the course of
business, supplies any—         renewable liquid heating fuel,
fossil fuel, or           other fuel, apart from solid fuel,         at or for
delivery to places in Great Britain with a view to its being used wholly or
mainly for the purpose of heating buildings to which there is no mains gas
supply;           “ renewable liquid heating fuel ” means fuel that is
typically supplied or stored in a liquid state and that is—         biofuel or
blended biofuel, or           fuel (other than fossil fuel or nuclear fuel)
produced—         wholly by energy from a renewable source, or
wholly by a process powered wholly by such energy;

and “biofuel”, “ blended biofuel ”, “ fossil fuel ” and “ renewable source ”
have the meanings given in section 132 of the Energy Act 2004.

##### Removals of greenhouse gases

###### Climate Change Act 2008: meaning of “UK removals”

160

In section 29(1)(b) of the Climate Change Act 2008 (UK emissions and removals
of greenhouse gases), for “land use, land-use change or forestry” substitute
“processes, mechanisms or” .

### Independent System Operator and Planner

#### Independent System Operator and Planner: functions and designation

##### The Independent System Operator and Planner (“the ISOP”)

161

161.1

This Part contains provision about the Independent System Operator and Planner
(referred to in this Part as “ the ISOP ”).

161.2

The functions of the ISOP include—

161.2.a

functions conferred by or by virtue of this Act, which include functions
relating to the matters mentioned in subsection  (3) , and

161.2.b

whatever other functions are conferred on the ISOP by or by virtue of any
enactment other than one contained in this Act.

161.3

The matters referred to in subsection  (2) (a)  are—

161.3.a

co-ordinating and directing the flow of electricity onto and over transmission
systems;

161.3.b

making and administering arrangements for the provision of services for the
purpose of facilitating the co-ordination of the flow of electricity onto and
over transmission systems;

161.3.c

carrying out strategic planning and forecasting in connection with—

161.3.c.i

the development of transmission systems,

161.3.c.ii

the provision of services referred to in  paragraph (b) , and

161.3.c.iii

other arrangements relating to the conveyance or supply of electricity;

161.3.d

carrying out strategic planning and forecasting in connection with—

161.3.d.i

the development of pipe-line systems for the conveyance of gas, and

161.3.d.ii

other arrangements relating to the conveyance or supply of gas;

161.3.e

providing advice, analysis or information in relation to the matters mentioned
in section  171 (1) .

##### Designation etc

162

162.1

The Secretary of State may by notice designate a person as the ISOP.

162.2

A notice under  subsection (1) —

162.2.a

must specify the time from which the designation has effect;

162.2.b

must be published by the Secretary of State as soon as reasonably practicable
after the notice is given.

162.3

The Secretary of State must ensure that a person is designated under
subsection (1)  at all times after a person is first designated (but at any
time not more than one person may be designated).

162.4

The Secretary of State may by notice revoke a person’s designation under
subsection (1) .

162.5

A notice under subsection  (4) —

162.5.a

must specify the time from which the revocation has effect;

162.5.b

must be published by the Secretary of State as soon as reasonably practicable
after the notice is given.

#### General duties

##### Duty to promote particular objectives

163

163.1

The ISOP must carry out its functions in the way that it considers is best
calculated to promote—

163.1.a

the net zero objective;

163.1.b

the security of supply objective;

163.1.c

the efficiency and economy objective.

163.2

The net zero objective is the objective of enabling the Secretary of State to
meet the duties imposed by—

163.2.a

section 1 of the Climate Change Act 2008 (net UK carbon account target for
2050), and

163.2.b

section 4(1)(b) of that Act (UK carbon account not to exceed carbon budget).

163.3

The security of supply objective is the objective of ensuring the security of
supply, to existing and future consumers, of—

163.3.a

electricity conveyed by distribution systems or transmission systems, and

163.3.b

gas conveyed through pipes.

163.4

The efficiency and economy objective is the objective of promoting—

163.4.a

efficient, co-ordinated and economical systems for the distribution and
transmission of electricity and the conveyance of gas;

163.4.b

efficiency (including the efficient use of energy) and economy on the part of
persons who carry out relevant activities within subsection  (5) (a) ,  (b)
or  (c) .

163.5

In this Part, “ relevant activity ” means any of the following, so far as
carried out in the course of a business—

163.5.a

an activity mentioned in section 5(1) of the Gas Act 1986 (gas transportation,
interconnection, supply, shipping, system planning, smart meter communication,
code management);

163.5.b

an activity mentioned in section 4(1) of the Electricity Act 1989 (electricity
generation, transmission, distribution, supply, interconnection, multi-purpose
interconnection, system operation, smart meter communication, code
management);

163.5.c

an activity, other than an activity within paragraph  (a)  or  (b) , in
respect of which the ISOP has functions;

163.5.d

an activity, other than an activity within paragraph  (a) ,  (b)  or  (c) ,
that is connected with—

163.5.d.i

the production, conveyance, storage or supply of energy,

163.5.d.ii

the reduction of UK emissions of targeted greenhouse gases arising from the
production, conveyance, storage, supply or consumption of energy, or

163.5.d.iii

data relating to any matter within sub-paragraph  (i)  or  (ii) , or to demand
for or consumption of energy.

163.6

For the purposes of  subsection (5) (d) —

163.6.a

“ energy ” means energy in any form and includes fuel or other substances used
to produce energy;

163.6.b

references to the production of energy include references to the conversion of
energy from one form to another;

163.6.c

references to the supply of energy include references to adjusting consumption
of energy (whether generally, at particular times, or by particular persons);

163.6.d

an activity referred to in  paragraph (d) (i)  is not a relevant activity when
carried out in relation to products for human or animal consumption;

163.6.e

“UK emissions of targeted greenhouse gases” are emissions of such gases as
are, or are treated for the purposes of Part 1 of the Climate Change Act 2008
as, emissions from sources in the United Kingdom.

163.7

In  this section , “ targeted greenhouse gas ” has the same meaning as in Part
1 of the Climate Change Act 2008 (see section 24 of that Act).

##### Duty to have regard to particular matters

164

164.1

The ISOP must, when carrying out its functions, have regard to—

164.1.a

the need to facilitate competition between persons who carry out a relevant
activity (except to the extent that such persons are, in accordance with or by
virtue of an enactment, not subject to competition in relation to the
activity);

164.1.b

the consumer impact of a relevant activity;

164.1.c

the whole-system impact of a relevant activity;

164.1.d

the desirability of facilitating innovation in relation to the carrying out of
relevant activities.

164.2

The reference in subsection  (1) (b)  to the consumer impact of a relevant
activity is a reference to the impact (or likely impact) of—

164.2.a

the behaviour of persons who carry out the activity on existing and future
consumers, and

164.2.b

the behaviour of existing and future consumers on the carrying out of the
activity.

164.3

The reference in  subsection (1) (c)  to the whole-system impact of a relevant
activity is a reference to the impact (or likely impact) of—

164.3.a

the carrying out of the activity, and

164.3.b

the behaviour of existing and future consumers in relation to the carrying out
of the activity,

in relation to the carrying out of other relevant activities.

##### Duty to have regard to strategy and policy statement

165

165.1

The ISOP must, when carrying out its functions, have regard to the strategic
priorities set out in the current strategy and policy statement.

165.2

The ISOP must give notice to the Secretary of State if at any time the ISOP
concludes that a policy outcome contained in the current strategy and policy
statement is not realistically achievable.

165.3

A notice under  subsection (2)  must include—

165.3.a

the grounds on which the conclusion was reached;

165.3.b

what (if anything) the ISOP is doing or proposes to do for the purpose of
furthering the delivery of the outcome so far as reasonably practicable.

165.4

In this section—

      “ the current strategy and policy statement ” means the statement for
the time being designated under section 131(1) of the Energy Act 2013;
“ policy outcome ” and “strategic priorities” have the same meaning as in Part
5 of the Energy Act 2013 (see section 131(5) of that Act).

165.5

Part 5 of the Energy Act 2013 is amended as follows.

165.6

In section 131 (designation of strategy and policy statement)—

165.6.a

in subsection (2)(c), after “Authority” insert  “, the Independent System
Operator and Planner” ;

165.6.b

in subsection (5), after the definition of “the 1986 Act” insert—

      “ Independent System Operator and Planner ” means the person for the
time being designated under  section 162 (1)  of the Energy Act 2023;

.

165.7

Section 134 (review of strategy and policy statement) is amended as follows.

165.8

In subsection (4), after paragraph (b) insert—

165.8.ba

the Independent System Operator and Planner has given notice to the Secretary
of State under  section 165 (2)  of the Energy Act 2023 since the relevant
time,

.

165.9

After subsection (5) insert—

165.9.5A

The Secretary of State may also review the strategy and policy statement at
any other time if the Secretary of State considers it appropriate to do so in
preparation for or in connection with the designation of a person under
section 162 (1)  of the Energy Act 2023 (Independent System Operator and
Planner).

165.10

In subsection (10), after paragraph (a) insert—

165.10.aa

the Independent System Operator and Planner,

.

165.11

In section 135(4) (procedural requirements in relation to strategy and policy
statement), after paragraph (a) insert—

165.11.aa

the Independent System Operator and Planner,

.

#### Licences

##### Licensing of electricity system operator activity

166

166.1

Part 1 of the Electricity Act 1989 is amended as follows.

166.2

In section 4(1) (prohibition on unlicensed supply, transmission etc of
electricity), after paragraph (c) insert—

166.2.ca

co-ordinates and directs the flow of electricity onto and over transmission
systems by means of which the transmission of electricity takes place;

.

166.3

Section 6 (licences authorising supply, etc) is amended as follows.

166.4

In subsection (1), after paragraph (d) insert—

166.4.da

subject to subsections  (1ZB)  and  (2ZA) , a licence authorising a person to
co-ordinate and direct the flow of electricity onto and over transmission
systems by means of which the transmission of electricity takes place (“an
electricity system operator licence”);

.

166.5

After subsection (1) insert—

166.5.1ZA

Subject to subsection  (2ZA) , the Secretary of State may grant an electricity
system operator licence.

166.5.1ZB

The first electricity system operator licence may only be granted by the
Secretary of State.

166.5.1ZC

For the purposes of this section, references to the grant of an electricity
system operator licence include the giving of a direction under section  167
of the Energy Act 2023 in respect of a transmission licence.

166.6

After subsection (2) insert—

166.6.2ZA

A person may not be granted an electricity system operator licence unless the
same person—

166.6.2ZA.a

already holds a licence granted under section 7AA of the Gas Act 1986, or

166.6.2ZA.b

is granted such a licence at the same time as the person is granted an
electricity system operator licence.

166.7

In subsection (2A), for “(d)” substitute  “(da)” .

166.8

In subsection (8), after “term of the licence” insert  “and subject to” .

166.9

After subsection (8) insert—

166.9.8A

If a person who holds an electricity system operator licence ceases at any
time to hold a licence under section 7AA of the Gas Act 1986, the person is to
be treated as ceasing to hold the electricity system operator licence at the
same time.

166.10

In section 7A (transfer of licences), after subsection (11) insert—

166.10.11ZA

An electricity system operator licence may not be transferred to a person
unless a licence granted under section 7AA of the Gas Act 1986 is also
transferred to the same person at the same time.

##### Direction for transmission licence to have effect as electricity system operator licence

167

167.1

The Secretary of State may (instead of granting an electricity system operator
licence) direct that a pre-commencement transmission licence is to have effect
as an electricity system operator licence.

167.2

A direction under this section may provide that a licence that has effect by
virtue of the direction includes such terms and conditions as are specified,
or of a description specified, in the direction (regardless of whether or the
extent to which those terms and conditions were included in the pre-
commencement transmission licence).

167.3

A direction under this section may provide for the continued effect (in
accordance with the direction) of rights, liabilities and obligations that
have effect immediately before the relevant date in connection with—

167.3.a

a pre-commencement transmission licence,

167.3.b

a document maintained in accordance with the conditions of such a licence, or

167.3.c

an agreement that gives effect to such a document.

167.4

In subsection  (3) , “ the relevant date ” means the date on which the
direction takes effect.

167.5

A direction under  this section  may make—

167.5.a

incidental, consequential, supplementary and transitional provision;

167.5.b

such amendments relating to the revocation of a pre-commencement transmission
licence as the Secretary of State considers appropriate;

167.5.c

different provision for different purposes.

167.6

Before giving a direction under this section, the Secretary of State must
consult—

167.6.a

the GEMA, and

167.6.b

such other persons as the Secretary of State considers appropriate.

167.7

Subsection  (6)  may be satisfied by consultation before the passing of this
Act (as well as by consultation after that time).

167.8

In  this Part —

      “ electricity system operator licence ” means a licence under section
6(1)(da) of the Electricity Act 1989 (as inserted by  section 166 );
“ pre-commencement transmission licence ” means a licence under section
6(1)(b) of the Electricity Act 1989 that is in force immediately before  this
section  comes into force.

##### Modification of licences etc

169

169.1

A relevant authority may modify—

169.1.a

the conditions of a particular relevant licence;

169.1.b

the standard conditions of relevant licences of a particular type;

169.1.c

a relevant document.

169.2

A relevant authority may revoke a pre-commencement transmission licence where—

169.2.a

the licence authorises the holder to co-ordinate and direct the flow of
electricity onto and over a transmission system by means of which the
transmission of electricity takes place, and

169.2.b

the first electricity system operator licence has been granted to a person.

169.3

A relevant authority may exercise the power under  subsection (1)  or  (2)
only—

169.3.a

in preparation for the designation of a person under  section 162 (1) , or

169.3.b

in connection with or in consequence of the designation of a person under that
provision.

169.4

A relevant authority may also exercise the power under subsection  (1)  where—

169.4.a

the operation or management of a relevant document is affected by steps taken
in connection with the designation of a person under  section 162 (1)  or by
the preparation for such a designation, and

169.4.b

the authority considers it appropriate to exercise the power in connection
with the operation or management of a relevant document.

169.5

The Secretary of State may direct the GEMA to exercise the power under
subsection (1)  or  (2)  if the Secretary of State considers it appropriate
for the GEMA to exercise that power.

169.6

A relevant authority may not exercise the power under  subsection (1)  or  (2)
after the end of the period of 3 years beginning with the day on which the
first designation under  section 162 (1)  has effect.

169.7

In this section—

“ pre-commencement transmission licence ” has the same meaning as in section
167 ; “ relevant authority ” means the Secretary of State or the GEMA; “
relevant document ” means a document maintained in accordance with the
conditions of a relevant licence.

##### Procedure relating to modifications under 

170

170.1

Before making a modification under  section 169 , a relevant authority must—

170.1.a

publish a notice about the proposed modification,

170.1.b

send a copy of the notice to the persons listed in subsection  (2) , and

170.1.c

consider any representations made within the period specified in the notice
about the proposed modification or the date from which it would take effect.

170.2

The persons mentioned in  subsection (1) (b)  are—

170.2.a

each relevant licence holder;

170.2.b

the GEMA (where the relevant authority is the Secretary of State) or the
Secretary of State (where the relevant authority is the GEMA);

170.2.c

the National Association of Citizens Advice Bureaux;

170.2.d

the Scottish Association of Citizens Advice Bureaux;

170.2.e

Consumer Scotland;

170.2.f

the General Consumer Council for Northern Ireland, unless the relevant
authority does not consider it appropriate for the Council to be sent a copy
of the notice in a particular case;

170.2.g

where the proposed modification relates to a licence for the purposes of
section 5 of the Gas Act 1986, the Health and Safety Executive;

170.2.h

such other persons as the relevant authority considers appropriate.

170.3

A notice under  subsection (1)  must—

170.3.a

state that the relevant authority proposes to make a modification;

170.3.b

set out the proposed modification and its effect;

170.3.c

specify the date from which the relevant authority proposes that the
modification will have effect;

170.3.d

state the reasons why the relevant authority proposes to make the
modification.

170.4

If, after complying with subsections  (1)  to  (3)  in relation to a
modification, the relevant authority decides to make the modification, it must
publish a notice about the decision.

170.5

A notice under subsection  (4)  must—

170.5.a

state that the relevant authority has decided to make the modification;

170.5.b

set out the modification and its effect;

170.5.c

specify the date from which the modification has effect;

170.5.d

state how the relevant authority has taken account of any representations made
in the period specified in the notice under  subsection (1) ;

170.5.e

state the reason for any differences between the modification set out in the
notice and the proposed modification.

170.6

A notice under this section about a modification or decision must be published
in such manner as the relevant authority considers appropriate for bringing it
to the attention of those likely to be affected by the making of the
modification or decision.

170.7

References in this section to the making of a modification, in relation to a
relevant licence, include references to the revocation of the licence.

170.8

In this section, “relevant licence holder”—

170.8.a

in relation to the modification of standard conditions of relevant licences of
any type, means the holder of a licence of that type—

170.8.a.i

that is to be modified by the inclusion of a new standard condition, or

170.8.a.ii

that includes any standard conditions to which the modification relates that
are in effect at the end of the period specified by virtue of  subsection (1)
(c) ;

170.8.b

in relation to the modification of a condition of a particular relevant
licence (other than a standard condition), means the holder of that licence;

170.8.c

in relation to the modification of a document maintained in accordance with
the conditions of a relevant licence of a particular type, means the holder of
a relevant licence of that type;

170.8.d

in relation to the revocation of a relevant licence, means the holder of that
licence.

170.9

In this section, “ relevant authority ” means the Secretary of State or the
GEMA.

#### Advice, analysis and information

##### Provision of advice, analysis or information

171

171.1

The ISOP must, so far as reasonably practicable, comply with a request by a
person within  subsection (2)  for the provision of advice, analysis or
information to the person in connection with—

171.1.a

any of the ISOP’s functions,

171.1.b

any of the objectives listed in section  163 (1) , or

171.1.c

any of the matters listed in  section 164 (1) .

171.2

The persons within this subsection are—

171.2.a

a Minister of the Crown (within the meaning of the Ministers of the Crown Act
1975: see section 8(1) of that Act);

171.2.b

the GEMA.

171.3

The ISOP must, so far as reasonably practicable, comply with a request made
under  subsection (1)  within such period, and in such form and manner, as the
person making the request may reasonably require.

##### Power to require information from regulated persons etc

172

172.1

The ISOP may by notice request from a person within  subsection (2)  such
information as the ISOP reasonably requires in connection with the exercise of
any of its functions.

172.2

A person is within this subsection if—

172.2.a

the person carries out a relevant activity, or

172.2.b

the ISOP reasonably considers that the person intends to carry out a relevant
activity.

172.3

A person to whom a request is made under  subsection (1)  must, so far as
reasonably practicable, provide the requested information within such period,
and in such form and manner, as may be specified in the notice.

172.4

Where a requirement under  subsection (3)  is imposed on a regulated person
(as defined by section 25(8) of the Electricity Act 1989), it is enforceable
by the GEMA as if it were a relevant requirement imposed on the person for the
purposes of section 25 of that Act.

172.5

Where a requirement under  subsection (3)  is imposed on a regulated person
(as defined by section 28(8) of the Gas Act 1986), it is enforceable by the
GEMA as if it were a relevant requirement imposed on the person for the
purposes of section 28 of that Act.

172.6

Where neither of  subsections (4)  and  (5)  applies, the duty imposed under
subsection (3)  on a person is enforceable by the ISOP in civil proceedings—

172.6.a

for an injunction,

172.6.b

for specific performance of a statutory duty under section 45 of the Court of
Session Act 1988, or

172.6.c

for any other appropriate remedy or relief.

172.7

Nothing in this section requires a disclosure of information that would
contravene the data protection legislation (within the meaning of the Data
Protection Act 2018 - see section 3 of that Act).

In determining whether a disclosure would do so, the duty imposed by
subsection (3)  is to be taken into account.

##### Duty to keep developments in energy sector under review

173

The ISOP must keep under review developments relating to the energy sector
that may be relevant to the carrying out of any of the ISOP’s functions.

#### Transfers, pensions and financial assistance

##### Transfers

174

Schedule 9  contains—

174.a

in  Part 1 , provision about transfer schemes relating to the ISOP;

174.b

in  Part 2 , related provision about transfers and other provision in
connection with the designation of a person as the ISOP.

##### Pension arrangements

175

Schedule 10  contains provision about pension arrangements in connection with
the ISOP.

##### Financial assistance for the ISOP

176

176.1

The Secretary of State may provide financial assistance to the ISOP.

176.2

Financial assistance under this section may be provided in any form and in
particular may be provided by way of—

176.2.a

grant,

176.2.b

loan,

176.2.c

guarantee or indemnity, or

176.2.d

the acquisition of shares or any other interest in, or securities of, a body
corporate.

176.3

Financial assistance under this section may be provided subject to such
conditions as the Secretary of State considers appropriate (which may include
conditions about repayment with or without interest or other return).

##### Cross-sectoral funding

177

177.1

In section 7 of the Electricity Act 1989 (conditions of licences: general), in
subsection (3A)—

177.1.a

for “or a distribution licence” substitute  “, a distribution licence or an
electricity system operator licence” ;

177.1.b

in paragraph (a), for “his charges for the transmission or distribution of
electricity” substitute  “the charges payable to the holder in connection with
the transmission or distribution of electricity, or in connection with the
exercise of any other functions under or by virtue of the licence,” ;

177.1.c

in paragraph (b), for “licence holders” substitute  “holders of licences under
section 6 or under Part 1 of the Gas Act 1986” .

177.2

In section 9 of that Act (general duties of licence holders), after subsection
(2A) insert—

177.2.2B

The conditions of a licence held by a person to which a duty imposed by
subsection (1) or (2) applies may include a condition requiring the person, in
performing the duty, to have regard to the interests of existing and future
consumers in relation to gas conveyed through pipes (within the meaning of the
Gas Act 1986).

177.3

In section 7B of the Gas Act 1986 (licences: general), in subsection (5)(b)—

177.3.a

after “section 7” insert  “or 7AA” ;

177.3.b

in sub-paragraph (i), for “his charges for the conveyance of gas” substitute
“the charges payable to the holder in connection with the conveyance of gas,
or in connection with the exercise of any other functions under or by virtue
of the licence,” ;

177.3.c

in sub-paragraph (ii), for the words from “licences under” to “above”
substitute  “licences under  this Part  or under section 6 of the Electricity
Act 1989” .

177.4

In section 9 of that Act (general powers and duties of gas transporters),
after subsection (2) insert—

177.4.2A

The conditions of a licence held by a gas transporter may include a condition
requiring the gas transporter, in performing a duty under subsection (1), (1A)
or (2), to have regard to the interests of existing and future consumers in
relation to electricity conveyed by distribution systems or transmission
systems (within the meaning of the Electricity Act 1989).

#### Other

##### Principal objective and general duties of Secretary of State and GEMA under Part 

178

178.1

Sections 3A to 3D of the Electricity Act 1989 and sections 4AA to 4B of the
Gas Act 1986 (principal objective and general duties) apply in relation to the
functions of the Secretary of State under sections  162  and  167  as they
apply in relation to functions under Part 1 of the Act in question.

178.2

Where the Secretary of State or the GEMA has functions under section  169 ,
170  or  172  in relation to a licence under section 6(1) of the Electricity
Act 1989, sections 3A to 3D of that Act apply in relation to those functions
as they apply in relation to functions under Part 1 of that Act.

178.3

Where the Secretary of State or the GEMA has functions under section  169 ,
170  or  172  in relation to a licence under section 7, 7ZA, 7A, 7AA, 7AB or
7AC of the Gas Act 1986, sections 4AA to 4B of that Act apply in relation to
those functions as they apply in relation to functions under Part 1 of that
Act.

##### Minor and consequential amendments

179

Schedule 11  contains further amendments to the Electricity Act 1989 and the
Gas Act 1986.

##### Interpretation of Part 

180

180.1

In this Part—

“ distribution system ” has the same meaning as in Part 1 of the Electricity
Act 1989 (see section 4(4) of that Act); “ electricity system operator licence
” has the meaning given by section  167 (8) ; “ gas ” has the same meaning as
in Part 1 of the Gas Act 1986 (see section 48(1) of that Act); “ relevant
activity ” has the meaning given by section  163 (5) ; “ relevant licence ”
means a licence for the purposes of section 4 of the Electricity Act 1989 or
section 5 of the Gas Act 1986 (prohibitions on unlicensed activities); “
transmission system ” has the same meaning as in Part 1 of the Electricity Act
1989 (see section 4(4) of that Act).

180.2

References in this Part to the distribution, generation, supply or
transmission of electricity are to be construed in accordance with section
4(4) of the Electricity Act 1989.

180.3

For the purposes of this Part, references to the ISOP’s functions are to any
functions that are exercisable by the person for the time being designated as
the ISOP (whether they are exercisable in the person’s capacity as the ISOP or
in another capacity).

##### Regulations under Part 

181

181.1

Regulations under  this Part  are subject to the negative procedure.

181.2

Subsection (1) does not apply to regulations under paragraph  9  of  Schedule
9 .

### Governance of gas and electricity industry codes

#### Key definitions for Part 6

##### Designation of codes etc

182

182.1

In this Part, “ designated document ” means a document that—

182.1.a

is maintained in accordance with the conditions of a relevant licence, and

182.1.b

is designated for the purposes of this Part by notice given by the Secretary
of State.

182.2

The designation of a document has effect from the time specified in the notice
under subsection  (1) (b) .

182.3

A notice under subsection  (1) (b)  must be published in such manner as the
Secretary of State considers appropriate for bringing it to the attention of
those likely to be affected by the designation.

182.4

The Secretary of State may revoke the designation of a document under this
section.

182.5

The Secretary of State may not designate a document, or revoke the designation
of a document, except so as to give effect to a recommendation of the GEMA.

182.6

Before making a recommendation to the Secretary of State for the purposes of
subsection (5) , the GEMA must consult such persons as it considers
appropriate.

182.7

Subsection  (6)  does not apply in relation to the designation of a document
where, immediately before being designated, the document is (or is treated as)
a qualifying document within the meaning of  Schedule 12 .

##### Meaning of “code manager” and “code manager licence”

183

183.1

In this Part, “ code manager ”, in relation to a designated document, means
the holder of a code manager licence in respect of the document.

183.2

In this Part, “ code manager licence ” means a licence under section 7AC of
the Gas Act 1986 or section 6(1)(g) of the Electricity Act 1989.

183.3

See sections  185  and  186 , which contain amendments to the Gas Act 1986 and
the Electricity Act 1989 in relation to the licences mentioned in subsection
(2) .

##### Designation of central systems

184

184.1

In this Part, “ designated central system ” means a central system that is
designated for the purposes of this Part by notice given by the Secretary of
State.

184.2

“ Central system ” means an information technology system which has one or
both of the following functions—

184.2.a

to support the operation of the provisions of one or more designated
documents;

184.2.b

to process, transmit or store data in connection with the operation of the
provisions of one or more designated documents.

184.3

The designation of a central system has effect from the time specified in the
notice under subsection  (1) .

184.4

A notice under subsection  (1)  in relation to a central system must also
specify the person (referred to in this Part as the “ responsible body ”) who
is responsible, for the purposes of this Part, for operating or procuring the
operation of the central system.

184.5

A notice under subsection  (1)  must be published in such manner as the
Secretary of State considers appropriate for bringing it to the attention of
those likely to be affected by the designation.

184.6

The Secretary of State may revoke the designation of a central system under
this section.

184.7

The Secretary of State may not designate a central system, or revoke the
designation of a central system, except so as to give effect to a
recommendation of the GEMA.

184.8

Before making a recommendation to the Secretary of State for the purposes of
subsection (7) , the GEMA must consult such persons as it considers
appropriate.

184.9

Subsection  (8)  does not apply in relation to the designation of a central
system where—

184.9.a

immediately before being designated, the central system is a qualifying
central system within the meaning of  Schedule 12 , and

184.9.b

the designation does not involve any change to the responsible body in
relation to the central system.

184.10

The Secretary of State may by notice provide—

184.10.a

that the person who is the responsible body in relation to a designated
central system is to cease to be the responsible body in relation to that
system, and

184.10.b

that a person specified in a notice under this paragraph is instead to be the
responsible body in relation to the designated central system.

184.11

The Secretary of State may not give a notice under subsection  (10)  except so
as to give effect to a recommendation of the GEMA.

##### Selection of code manager

187

187.1

The GEMA must determine whether the selection of the person who is to be the
code manager in relation to a designated document is to be made—

187.1.a

on a non-competitive basis, in accordance with regulations made by the
Secretary of State under section  188 , or

187.1.b

on a competitive basis, in accordance with regulations made by the GEMA under
section  189 .

187.2

The Secretary of State may by regulations make—

187.2.a

provision about the making of determinations under subsection  (1)  by the
GEMA (which may include provision specifying criteria to be applied by the
GEMA in making determinations);

187.2.b

provision enabling the GEMA, in circumstances specified in the regulations, to
change the basis on which the selection of a code manager is to be made.

187.3

The Secretary of State may by regulations—

187.3.a

specify requirements to be met by or in relation to a person in order for the
person to be selected as the code manager in relation to a designated
document;

187.3.b

specify persons, or persons of a particular description, who may or may not be
selected to be a code manager in relation to a designated document.

##### Selection on a non-competitive basis

188

188.1

The Secretary of State may by regulations make provision about the selection
by the GEMA, otherwise than on a competitive basis, of the person who is to be
the code manager in relation to a designated document.

188.2

Regulations under this section may make provision by reference to a
determination by the GEMA or to the opinion of the GEMA as to any matter.

188.3

Regulations under this section must make provision so as to ensure that a
person (“ P ”) may not be selected to be the code manager in relation to a
designated document unless the GEMA is satisfied that P would not, if
selected, have a financial or other interest likely to prejudice the discharge
by P of the functions of code manager.

188.4

The provision that may be made by virtue of  subsection (1)  includes
provision for the selection by the GEMA of a person (other than an individual)
formed by the GEMA.

##### Selection on a competitive basis

189

189.1

The GEMA may by regulations make provision for a determination by the GEMA on
a competitive basis of the person who is to be selected to be the code manager
in relation to a designated document.

189.2

Regulations under this section may make provision about the procedure relating
to the making of such a determination, which may include provision—

189.2.a

in prescribed cases, for the publication of a proposal to select a code
manager in relation to a designated document;

189.2.b

for the inclusion in such a proposal of an invitation to apply for selection;

189.2.c

imposing conditions in relation to the making of applications (whether in
pursuance of a proposal published as mentioned in  paragraph (a)  or
otherwise);

189.2.d

restricting the making of applications and imposing requirements as to the
period within which they must be made;

189.2.e

for regulating the manner in which applications are considered or determined;

189.2.f

authorising or requiring the GEMA, when determining whom to select, to have
regard to the person’s suitability for being selected.

189.3

Regulations under this section may make provision by reference to a
determination by the GEMA or to the opinion of the GEMA as to any matter.

189.4

Regulations under this section must make provision so as to ensure that a
person (“ P ”) may not be selected to be the code manager in relation to a
designated document unless the GEMA is satisfied that P would not, if
selected, have a financial or other interest likely to prejudice the discharge
by P of the functions of code manager.

189.5

The approval of the Secretary of State is required for the making of
regulations under this section.

189.6

In this section, “ prescribed ” means prescribed by or determined in
accordance with regulations made by the GEMA.

#### Strategic direction statement for designated documents

##### Strategic direction statement

190

190.1

The GEMA must, each year, prepare and publish a statement setting out a
strategic direction for designated documents.

190.2

A statement prepared and published under  subsection (1)  is referred to in
this Part as a “ strategic direction statement ”.

190.3

A strategic direction statement must in particular—

190.3.a

contain a strategic assessment of government policies, and of developments
relating to the energy sector, that the GEMA considers will or may require the
making of modifications to designated documents;

190.3.b

cover such other matters relating to designated documents as the Secretary of
State may specify in regulations.

190.4

In preparing a strategic direction statement, the GEMA must have regard to any
advice given to it by the Independent System Operator and Planner so far as
relevant to the matters referred to in subsection  (3) .

190.5

Before publishing a strategic direction statement in any year, the GEMA must—

190.5.a

publish a notice containing a draft of the document,

190.5.b

send a copy of the notice to the persons listed in  subsection (6) , and

190.5.c

consider any representations about the draft made within the period specified
in the notice.

190.6

The persons referred to in  subsection (5) (b)  are—

190.6.a

the Secretary of State;

190.6.b

the National Association of Citizens Advice Bureaux;

190.6.c

the Scottish Association of Citizens Advice Bureaux;

190.6.d

Consumer Scotland.

190.7

A notice under  subsection (5)  must be published by the GEMA in whatever way
it considers appropriate for the purpose of bringing the matters contained in
it to the attention of persons likely to be affected by them.

##### Transfer of functions under 

191

191.1

The Secretary of State may by regulations amend  section 190  so as to provide
for functions under that section to be exercisable by the Independent System
Operator and Planner (instead of by the GEMA).

191.2

Before making regulations under this section, the Secretary of State must
consult—

191.2.a

the GEMA,

191.2.b

the Independent System Operator and Planner, and

191.2.c

any other persons whose interests are likely to be affected by the proposal.

191.3

Regulations under this section—

191.3.a

must repeal  section 190 (4) ;

191.3.b

must add the GEMA to the list of persons in section  190 (6) ;

191.3.c

may make such other amendments to  section 190  as the Secretary of State
considers appropriate.

#### Modifications and directions

##### Modification of designated documents by GEMA

192

192.1

The GEMA may modify a designated document if any of  subsections (2)  to  (6)
applies.

192.2

This subsection applies where the GEMA considers that—

192.2.a

the designated document needs to be modified as a matter of urgency,

192.2.b

the making of the modification is likely to be delayed if done in accordance
with the normal modification procedures for the document, and

192.2.c

such a delay would have adverse effects on—

192.2.c.i

consumers, or

192.2.c.ii

any person with rights or obligations under the document, other than the GEMA.

192.3

This subsection applies where the GEMA considers that a financial or other
interest of the code manager in respect of the matter to which the
modification relates is likely to prejudice the making of the modification if
done in accordance with the normal modification procedures for the document.

192.4

This subsection applies where the GEMA considers that—

192.4.a

the modification is required for the purpose of implementing a strategic
direction statement under section  190 , and

192.4.b

the nature of the modification (for example, its complexity) is such that it
needs to be made under this section rather than in accordance with the normal
modification procedures for the designated document.

192.5

This subsection applies where the GEMA considers that the modification is
required in connection with the incorporation of the whole or part of the
provision made by the designated document into another document (whether or
not a designated document).

192.6

This subsection applies where the GEMA considers that the modification is
required in consequence of the exercise of any power conferred by  Schedule 12
(transitional provisions) in relation to a different document.

192.7

The Secretary of State may by regulations make—

192.7.a

provision specifying requirements to be met in relation to the exercise of the
power under  subsection (1) ;

192.7.b

provision supplementing  subsections (2)  to  (6) .

192.8

References in this section to the normal modification procedures for a
designated document are to provision, relating to the procedure for modifying
the document, that—

192.8.a

is contained in the document, or

192.8.b

applies pursuant to any condition of a licence in accordance with which the
document is maintained.

##### Modification under section 

193

193.1

Before making a modification under section  192 , the GEMA must—

193.1.a

publish a notice about the proposed modification,

193.1.b

send a copy of the notice to the persons listed in  subsection (2) , and

193.1.c

consider any representations made within the period specified in the notice
about the proposed modification or the date from which it would take effect.

193.2

The persons mentioned in  subsection (1) (b)  are—

193.2.a

the Secretary of State,

193.2.b

the code manager in relation to the designated document to which the proposed
modification relates, and

193.2.c

such other persons as the GEMA considers appropriate.

193.3

A notice under  subsection (1)  must—

193.3.a

state that the GEMA proposes to make a modification;

193.3.b

set out the proposed modification and its effect;

193.3.c

specify the date from which the GEMA proposes that the modification will have
effect;

193.3.d

state—

193.3.d.i

why the GEMA is seeking to make the modification under section  192  (by
reference to whichever of  subsections (2)  to  (6)  of section  192
applies), and

193.3.d.ii

the reasons for the proposed modification.

193.4

If, within the period specified by virtue of  subsection (1) (c) , the
Secretary of State directs the GEMA not to make the proposed modification, the
GEMA must comply with the direction.

193.5

If, after complying with  subsections (1)  to  (3)  in relation to a proposed
modification, the GEMA decides to make a modification, it must publish a
notice about the decision.

193.6

A notice under  subsection (5)  must—

193.6.a

state that the GEMA has decided to make the modification;

193.6.b

set out the modification and its effect;

193.6.c

specify the date from which the modification has effect;

193.6.d

state how the GEMA has taken account of any representations made in the period
specified in the notice under  subsection (1) ;

193.6.e

state the reason for any differences between the modification set out in the
notice and the proposed modification.

193.7

A notice under this section about a proposed modification or a decision must
be published in such manner as the GEMA considers appropriate for bringing it
to the attention of those likely to be affected by the making of the
modification or decision.

##### Directions relating to designated central systems

194

194.1

The GEMA may give a direction to the responsible body in relation to a
designated central system for the purpose of ensuring that the body—

194.1.a

complies with its obligations under a relevant designated document, or

194.1.b

takes such steps as the GEMA considers may be necessary for the efficient
operation or implementation of the provisions of a relevant designated
document.

194.2

When determining whether to give a direction under this section, the GEMA must
have regard to the ability of the responsible body to whom the direction would
be given—

194.2.a

to recover any costs reasonably incurred by the body in complying with the
direction, and

194.2.b

to comply with the direction without contravening any obligations of the body
under a relevant designated document or in relation to the operation of the
designated central system.

194.3

A responsible body must comply with a direction given to it under this
section.

194.4

In this section and section  195 , “ relevant designated document ”, in
relation to a designated central system, means a designated document in
respect of which the central system has a function mentioned in section  184
(2) .

##### Directions under section 

195

195.1

Before giving a direction under section  194 , the GEMA must—

195.1.a

publish a notice about the proposed direction,

195.1.b

send a copy of the notice to the persons listed in  subsection (2) , and

195.1.c

consider any representations made within the period specified in the notice
about the proposed direction or the date from which it would take effect.

195.2

The persons mentioned in  subsection (1) (b)  are—

195.2.a

the responsible body to whom the direction is proposed to be given, and

195.2.b

the code manager in relation to the relevant designated document.

195.3

A notice under  subsection (1)  must—

195.3.a

state that the GEMA proposes to give a direction;

195.3.b

set out the proposed direction and its effect;

195.3.c

specify the date from which the GEMA proposes that the direction will have
effect;

195.3.d

state the reasons why the GEMA proposes to give the direction.

195.4

If, after complying with  subsections (1)  to  (3)  in relation to a
direction, the GEMA decides to give a direction, it must publish a notice
about the decision.

195.5

A notice under subsection  (4)  must—

195.5.a

state that the GEMA has decided to give the direction;

195.5.b

set out the direction and its effect;

195.5.c

specify the date from which the direction has effect;

195.5.d

state how the GEMA has taken account of any representations made in the period
specified in the notice under  subsection (1) ;

195.5.e

state the reason for any differences between the direction set out in the
notice and the proposed direction.

195.6

A notice under this section about a proposed direction or a decision must be
published in such manner as the GEMA considers appropriate for bringing it to
the attention of those likely to be affected by the making of the direction or
decision.

#### General objectives and reports

##### Principal objective and general duties of Secretary of State and GEMA under Part 

196

Sections 4AA to 4B of the Gas Act 1986 and sections 3A to 3D of the
Electricity Act 1989 (principal objective and general duties) apply in
relation to the functions under this Part of the Secretary of State and of the
GEMA as they apply in relation to functions of the Secretary of State and of
the GEMA under Part 1 of that Act.

##### GEMA’s annual report to cover matters relating to designated documents

197

197.1

Section 5 of the Utilities Act 2000 (annual and other reports of the GEMA) is
amended as follows.

197.2

After subsection (3) insert—

197.2.3A

The annual report for each year must also include an overview of—

197.2.3A.a

developments relating to documents designated for the purposes of  Part 6  of
the Energy Act 2023 (governance of gas and electricity industry codes);

197.2.3A.b

decisions made by the Authority during the year in relation to such documents,
including details of any modifications made under  section 192  of the Energy
Act 2023.

##### Mergers of energy network enterprises

204.2

204.4.a

204.4.b

204.4.c

which those objectives could be achieved in a way that imposes less
regulation.

204.5

#### Multi-purpose interconnectors

##### Licence required for operation of multi-purpose interconnector

205

205.1

Section 4 of the Electricity Act 1989 (prohibition on unlicensed supply etc of
electricity) is amended in accordance with  subsections (2)  to  (5) .

205.2

In subsection (1)—

205.2.a

omit the “or” after paragraph (d);

205.2.b

after paragraph (d) insert—

205.2.b.da

participates in the operation of a multi-purpose interconnector; or

.

205.3

After subsection (3C) insert—

205.3.3CA

A reference in this Part to participating in the operation of a multi-purpose
interconnector is a reference to—

205.3.3CA.a

co-ordinating and directing the flow of electricity into or through a multi-
purpose interconnector; or

205.3.3CA.b

making a multi-purpose interconnector available for use for the conveyance of
electricity,

and a person is not to be regarded as participating in the operation of an
interconnector or as participating in the transmission of electricity by
reason only of activities constituting participation in the operation of a
multi-purpose interconnector.

205.4

In subsection (3D), after “(3C)(b)” insert  “and (3CA)(b)” .

205.5

After subsection (3E) insert—

205.5.3EA

In this Part “ multi-purpose interconnector ” means so much of an electric
line or other electrical plant as—

205.5.3EA.a

is situated at a place within the jurisdiction of Great Britain; and

205.5.3EA.b

subsists for both—

205.5.3EA.b.i

the conveyance of electricity (whether in both directions or in only one)
between Great Britain and a place within the jurisdiction of another country
or territory, and

205.5.3EA.b.ii

the conveyance of electricity generated in offshore waters (whether in both
directions or in only one) between a generating station and a substation or
another generating station, or between two or more substations.

205.6

In section 5 of the Electricity Act 1989 (exemptions from prohibition), in
subsection (1), after “(d)” insert  “, (da)” .

205.7

Section 6 of the Electricity Act 1989 (licences authorising supply, etc) is
amended in accordance with subsections  (8)  to  (10) .

205.8

In subsection (1)—

205.8.a

omit the “or” after paragraph (e);

205.8.b

after paragraph (e) insert—

205.8.b.ea

a licence authorising a person to participate in the operation of a multi-
purpose interconnector (“an MPI licence”); or

.

205.9

After subsection (2A) insert—

205.9.2AA

The same person may not be the holder of an MPI licence and the holder of a
licence falling within any of paragraphs (a) to (e) of subsection (1).

205.10

After subsection (6D) insert—

205.10.6E

An MPI licence authorising participation in the operation of a multi-purpose
connector—

205.10.6E.a

must specify the multi-purpose interconnector or multi-purpose interconnectors
in relation to which participation is authorised;

205.10.6E.b

may limit the forms of participation in the operation of a multi-purpose
interconnector which are authorised by the licence.

205.11

In section 64(1) of the Electricity Act 1989 (interpretation of Part 1), at
the appropriate place insert—

      “ multi-purpose interconnector ” has the meaning given by section
4(3EA);

.

##### Standard conditions for MPI licences

206

206.1

The Secretary of State must, before  subsection (6)  comes into force,
determine standard conditions for MPI licences.

206.2

Those standard conditions may contain provision—

206.2.a

for a standard condition included in an MPI licence not to have effect until
brought into operation in such manner, and in such circumstances, as may be
specified in or determined under the standard conditions;

206.2.b

for the effect of a standard condition included in an MPI licence to be
suspended in such manner, and in such circumstances, as may be so specified or
determined; or

206.2.c

for a standard condition included in such a licence the effect of which is for
the time being suspended to be brought back into operation in such manner, and
in such circumstances, as may be so specified or determined.

206.3

The Secretary of State must publish the standard conditions determined by the
Secretary of State under this section.

206.4

The publication must be in such manner as the Secretary of State considers
appropriate.

206.5

The standard conditions determined by the Secretary of State have effect
subject to any modifications made under—

206.5.a

Part 1 of the Electricity Act 1989,

206.5.b

section 37 or 45 of the Energy Act 2013, or

206.5.c

this Act.

206.6

In section 8A of Electricity Act 1989 (standard conditions of licences), after
subsection (1B) insert—

206.6.1C

Subject to subsection (2), each condition which by virtue of  section 206  of
the Energy Act 2023 is a standard condition for the purposes of MPI licences
is incorporated, by reference, in each MPI licence granted on or after the day
on which subsection  (6)  of that section comes into force.

206.7

In this section, “ MPI licence ” means a licence under section 6(1)(ea) of the
Electricity Act 1989 (inserted by section  205  of this Act).

########### Electricity transmission and the operation of multi-purpose interconnectors: independence

207.2.10NA

#### Support for energy-intensive industries

##### Electricity support payments for energy-intensive industries

211

211.1

The Secretary of State may make regulations requiring payments (“electricity
support payments”) to be made to a person who carries out an energy-intensive
activity, for the purpose of alleviating the impact on the person of
electricity costs.

211.2

In  subsection (1) , “ energy-intensive activity ” means an activity (or
description of activity) that is designated as such in the regulations.

211.3

The regulations may make provision—

211.3.a

about the circumstances in which a person is eligible for electricity support
payments;

211.3.b

about how eligibility is to be considered and determined;

211.3.c

setting out a process for applying for electricity support payments, including
provision about the form and content of applications;

211.3.d

about the calculation of electricity support payments;

211.3.e

requiring a person to provide information that is relevant to their
eligibility for electricity support payments or to the calculation of any such
payments;

211.3.f

requiring a person who supplies electricity to another person to provide
information that is relevant to the matters mentioned in  paragraph (e)
(whether to the person to whom the information relates or to another person
specified in the regulations);

211.3.g

about the sharing of information provided by virtue of  paragraph (e)  or  (f)
;

211.3.h

requiring past electricity support payments to be repaid (with or without
interest) in circumstances specified in the regulations;

211.3.i

about how amounts repaid by virtue of  paragraph (h)  are to be applied
(including provision for amounts to be held in reserve or paid into the
Consolidated Fund);

211.3.j

for the enforcement of obligations imposed by or under the regulations
(including provision about interest on late payments and imposing financial
penalties);

211.3.k

about the resolution of disputes, including provision about arbitration or
appeals (which may in particular include provision for the person conducting
an arbitration or determining an appeal to order the payment of costs or
expenses or compensation).

211.4

Where by virtue of  subsection (3) (j)  the regulations provide for the
imposition of a financial penalty, they must also provide for a right of
appeal against the imposition of the penalty.

211.5

The regulations may—

211.5.a

appoint a person, with the person’s consent, to carry out functions in
connection with electricity support payments (a “support payment
administrator”);

211.5.b

confer functions on the support payment administrator;

211.5.c

require the support payment administrator to provide information or assistance
to the Secretary of State, or to another person specified in the regulations,
in relation to any functions so conferred.

211.6

Where—

211.6.a

the regulations impose a requirement on a regulated person (as defined by
section 25(8) of the Electricity Act 1989),

211.6.b

the requirement is enforceable by a support payment administrator, and

211.6.c

the support payment administrator is the GEMA,

the regulations may provide for the requirement to be enforceable by the GEMA
as if it were a relevant requirement imposed on the person for the purposes of
section 25 of that Act.

211.7

The regulations may provide for any sum—

211.7.a

that a person is required under the regulations to pay to the Secretary of
State or to a support payment administrator, and

211.7.b

that has not been paid by the date required,

to be recoverable from the person as a civil debt due to the Secretary of
State or to the support payment administrator (as the case may be).

211.8

The regulations may make provision about the terms of a support payment
administrator’s appointment, including provision—

211.8.a

for the support payment administrator to be remunerated, or compensated for
costs that they incur;

211.8.b

about how an appointment may be terminated by the Secretary of State or by the
support payment administrator, and when termination takes effect.

211.9

If functions of a support payment administrator (“the outgoing administrator”)
are to be taken on by another support payment administrator or by the
Secretary of State (“ the successor ”), the regulations may—

211.9.a

require the outgoing administrator to take steps specified in the regulations
to enable or facilitate the carrying out of those functions by the successor;

211.9.b

provide for the transfer of any property, rights or liabilities from the
outgoing administrator to the successor;

211.9.c

provide for anything done by or in relation to the outgoing administrator in
connection with any property, rights or liabilities to be treated as done, or
to be continued, by or in relation to the successor.

“Property” in this subsection includes interests of any description.

211.10

Regulations under this section may confer a discretion on the Secretary of
State or on a support payment administrator.

211.11

Regulations under this section are subject to the affirmative procedure.

##### Levy to fund electricity support payments

212

212.1

The Secretary of State may make regulations requiring the payment of a levy by
electricity suppliers for the purpose of funding—

212.1.a

the making of electricity support payments by virtue of  section 211
(including expected future payments);

212.1.b

any other costs arising by virtue of  section 211  or this section (including
expected future costs).

212.2

The regulations may make provision—

212.2.a

about the calculation of the levy;

212.2.b

requiring electricity suppliers to provide financial collateral in respect of
their obligations to pay the levy, and about the form and terms of such
collateral;

212.2.c

for the issuing of notices to require the payment of the levy or the provision
of collateral;

212.2.d

for the provision of copies of such notices to persons specified in the
regulations or for the publication of such notices;

212.2.e

about how amounts of levy are to be applied once paid (including provision for
amounts to be held in reserve or paid into the Consolidated Fund);

212.2.f

for the recovery of unpaid amounts of levy in the event of the insolvency or
default of an electricity supplier (including provision requiring amounts to
be borne by other electricity suppliers in accordance with the regulations);

212.2.g

requiring electricity suppliers or the GEMA to provide information that is
needed to determine—

212.2.g.i

what an electricity supplier’s obligations are in relation to the levy, or

212.2.g.ii

whether an electricity supplier has complied with those obligations;

212.2.h

about the sharing of information provided by virtue of  paragraph (g) ;

212.2.i

for the enforcement of obligations imposed by or under the regulations
(including provision about interest on late payments and imposing financial
penalties);

212.2.j

about the resolution of disputes, including provision about arbitration or
appeals (which may in particular include provision for the person conducting
an arbitration or determining an appeal to order the payment of costs or
expenses or compensation).

212.3

Where by virtue of  subsection (2) (i)  the regulations provide for the
imposition of a financial penalty, they must also provide for a right of
appeal against the imposition of the penalty.

212.4

The regulations may—

212.4.a

appoint a person, with the person’s consent, to carry out functions in
connection with the levy (a “levy administrator”);

212.4.b

confer functions on the levy administrator;

212.4.c

require the levy administrator to provide information or assistance to the
Secretary of State, or to another person specified in the regulations, in
relation to any functions so conferred.

212.5

Where—

212.5.a

the regulations impose a requirement on a regulated person (as defined by
section 25(8) of the Electricity Act 1989),

212.5.b

the requirement is enforceable by a levy administrator, and

212.5.c

the levy administrator is the GEMA,

the regulations may provide for the requirement to be enforceable by the GEMA
as if it were a relevant requirement imposed on the person for the purposes of
section 25 of that Act.

212.6

The regulations may provide for any sum—

212.6.a

that a person is required under the regulations to pay to the Secretary of
State or to a levy administrator, and

212.6.b

that has not been paid by the date required,

to be recoverable from the person as a civil debt due to the Secretary of
State or to the levy administrator (as the case may be).

212.7

The regulations may make provision about the terms of a levy administrator’s
appointment, including provision—

212.7.a

for the levy administrator to be remunerated, or compensated for costs that
they incur;

212.7.b

about how an appointment may be terminated by the Secretary of State or by the
levy administrator, and when termination takes effect.

212.8

If functions of a levy administrator (“the outgoing administrator”) are to be
taken on by another levy administrator or by the Secretary of State (“ the
successor ”), the regulations may—

212.8.a

require the outgoing administrator to take steps specified in the regulations
to enable or facilitate the carrying out of those functions by the successor;

212.8.b

provide for the transfer of any property, rights or liabilities from the
outgoing administrator to the successor;

212.8.c

provide for anything done by or in relation to the outgoing administrator in
connection with any property, rights or liabilities to be treated as done, or
to be continued, by or in relation to the successor.

“Property” in this subsection includes interests of any description.

212.9

Regulations under this section may confer a discretion on the Secretary of
State or on a levy administrator.

212.10

Regulations under this section are subject to the affirmative procedure.

212.11

In this section, “ electricity supplier ” means the holder of a licence under
section 6(1)(d) of the Electricity Act 1989.

213

#### Reduction targets: carbon emissions and home-heating costs

##### Payment as alternative to complying with certain energy company obligations

214

214.1

In section 33BC of the Gas Act 1986 (promotion of reductions in carbon
emissions: gas transporters and gas suppliers), after subsection (7B) insert—

214.1.7C

The order may make provision as to circumstances in which a transporter or
supplier may meet the whole or any part of a carbon emissions reduction target
by making a buy-out payment.

214.1.7D

In this section, “ buy-out payment ” means a payment—

214.1.7D.a

of an amount (“ the buy-out price ”) determined by the Secretary of State,

214.1.7D.b

to a person approved by the Administrator (an “approved person”),

214.1.7D.c

for a purpose approved by the Administrator (an “approved purpose”).

214.1.7E

Provision made by virtue of subsection  (7C)  may include provision about the
determination by the Secretary of State of the buy-out price, including
provision—

214.1.7E.a

enabling the Secretary of State to set different buy-out prices—

214.1.7E.a.i

for different parts of the period to which the order relates;

214.1.7E.a.ii

for different cases (including different buy-out prices for different
transporters or suppliers);

214.1.7E.b

requiring the Secretary of State to publish the buy-out price.

214.1.7F

If the order makes provision by virtue of subsection  (7C) , the order may
also make provision—

214.1.7F.a

as to the procedure to be followed by the Administrator in approving a person
as an approved person or a purpose as an approved purpose;

214.1.7F.b

specifying criteria by reference to which the Administrator is to determine
whether to approve a person or purpose.

214.1.7G

Provision made by virtue of subsection  (7C)  may include further provision
about buy-out payments, including in particular provision—

214.1.7G.a

as to the procedure to be followed by a transporter or supplier who proposes
to make a buy-out payment, including provision—

214.1.7G.a.i

requiring a transporter or supplier to notify the Administrator of specified
matters by a specified time;

214.1.7G.a.ii

as to circumstances in which a transporter or supplier must make the buy-out
payment to which notification given to the Administrator relates;

214.1.7G.a.iii

about the process for seeking approval of a person as an approved person, or
of a purpose as an approved purpose;

214.1.7G.b

preventing a transporter or supplier from treating a buy-out payment as a
payment pursuant to any other obligation (whether statutory or contractual),
or vice versa;

214.1.7G.c

setting out circumstances in which a requirement imposed on a transporter or
supplier by provision made by virtue of subsection (5)(ba) or (bb) may be—

214.1.7G.c.i

met, in whole or in part, by the making of a buy-out payment;

214.1.7G.c.ii

varied as a result of a buy-out payment;

214.1.7G.d

about the effect of provision included in the order by virtue of subsection
(7)(c) to (e) on a person’s ability to meet the whole or any part of a carbon
emissions reduction target by making a buy-out payment.

214.1.7H

Where an order includes provision for the making of a buy-out payment, the
references in subsections (5)(be) and (7)(b) to action include a reference to
the making of a buy-out payment.

214.2

214.2.a

has made” ;

In section 41A of the Electricity Act 1989 (promotion of reductions in carbon
