responsible may include energy consumed by—

255.4.a

assets located elsewhere than in the United Kingdom or an offshore area, or

255.4.b

activities carried on elsewhere than in the United Kingdom or an offshore
area.

255.5

The provisions of this Part relating to greenhouse gas emissions apply to the
emissions resulting from energy consumption to which this Part applies whether
such emissions occur in the United Kingdom, in an offshore area or elsewhere.

255.6

ESOS regulations may make provision about the attribution of energy
consumption to participants, including in particular provision about the
treatment for the purposes of the regulations of—

255.6.a

a participant’s consumption of energy generated by that participant;

255.6.b

energy consumption by a person over whom a participant has control or
influence;

255.6.c

energy consumption shared between a participant and one or more other
participants or other persons;

255.6.d

energy consumed by assets held on trust by or for a participant.

255.7

In this section, “ offshore area ” means—

255.7.a

waters landward of the seaward limit of the territorial sea adjacent to the
United Kingdom,

255.7.b

any designated area within the meaning of section 1(7) of the Continental
Shelf Act 1964, and

255.7.c

any area for the time being designated under section 41(3) of the Marine and
Coastal Access Act 2009,

and includes the places above those areas and the bed and subsoil of the sea
within those areas.

#### Assessments, energy savings and emissions reductions

##### Requirement for assessment of energy consumption

256

256.1

ESOS regulations may require the carrying out of assessments of—

256.1.a

a participant’s energy consumption;

256.1.b

the greenhouse gas emissions resulting from that consumption.

Such an assessment is referred to as an “ ESOS assessment ”.

256.2

The provision that may be made by virtue of  subsection (1)  includes in
particular provision about—

256.2.a

the frequency of ESOS assessments;

256.2.b

the period or periods to which assessments must relate;

256.2.c

how assessments are to be carried out;

256.2.d

the information that must be provided or obtained for the purposes of an
assessment;

256.2.e

the matters that must be taken into account in an assessment;

256.2.f

record-keeping in relation to an assessment.

256.3

ESOS regulations may make provision requiring an ESOS assessment, or specified
parts of an ESOS assessment, to be carried out, approved or audited by a
person appointed by a participant (referred to as “ an assessor ”).

256.4

Regulations made by virtue of  subsection (1)  may include provision enabling
or requiring an ESOS assessment to include recommendations relating to energy
savings or emissions reductions.

256.5

The provision that may be made by virtue of  subsection (4)  includes in
particular provision about—

256.5.a

the matters about which recommendations may, must, or must not be made;

256.5.b

the matters that must be taken into account in making a recommendation;

256.5.c

the carrying out of a cost-benefit analysis before including a recommendation
in a report.

256.6

“ Cost-benefit analysis ”, in relation to a recommendation or requirement to
take action, means—

256.6.a

an estimate of the likely costs to a participant of acting in accordance with
the recommendation or requirement;

256.6.b

an estimate of the energy savings or emissions reductions likely to result
from such action;

256.6.c

an analysis of the costs referred to in  paragraph (a)  together with an
analysis of the savings or reductions referred to in  paragraph (b)  and of
any other benefits likely to arise.

256.7

ESOS regulations may make provision about the reporting of ESOS assessments,
including in particular provision—

256.7.a

about the production of written reports;

256.7.b

about the form and content of such reports;

256.7.c

about the dissemination of such reports within an undertaking and between
related undertakings.

256.8

ESOS regulations may make provision requiring a participant to notify a scheme
administrator of specified matters relating to the participant’s compliance
with requirements imposed by virtue of this section and may in particular
include provision—

256.8.a

about the procedure for giving such notice;

256.8.b

about the form and content of notices;

256.8.c

about the publication of certain information contained within a notice;

256.8.d

requiring a participant to justify its choice of assessor.

256.9

ESOS regulations may provide for any requirement imposed by virtue of
subsection (1) —

256.9.a

to be treated as having been complied with by a participant in specified
circumstances, or

256.9.b

not to apply to a participant in specified circumstances.

##### Assessors

257

257.1

ESOS regulations may confer functions on an assessor in relation to assessing,
monitoring and reporting on compliance with requirements imposed by the
regulations.

257.2

ESOS regulations may provide that a participant may only appoint as an
assessor a person of a specified description.

257.3

A description may be specified for the purposes of  subsection (2)  by
reference to any criteria, including by reference to—

257.3.a

a person’s competence, qualifications or experience;

257.3.b

a person’s inclusion in a designated list or register;

257.3.c

a person’s membership of a designated body;

257.3.d

a person’s participation in a designated accreditation scheme;

257.3.e

a person’s relationship to a participant.

257.4

For the purposes of this section, “ designated ” means designated by the
Secretary of State or a scheme administrator in accordance with ESOS
regulations.

257.5

A body may only be designated for the purposes of this section if the body is
willing to be so designated.

257.6

ESOS regulations may make provision about—

257.6.a

the giving of designations for the purposes of  subsection (4) ;

257.6.b

reviewing such designations;

257.6.c

circumstances in which such a designation may be removed;

257.6.d

maintaining and publishing a list of such designations.

257.7

ESOS regulations may make provision enabling a list or register of persons who
may, or who may not, be appointed as an assessor for the purposes of
subsection (2)  to be maintained by—

257.7.a

a designated body;

257.7.b

a scheme administrator;

257.7.c

the Secretary of State.

257.8

ESOS regulations may confer functions or impose requirements on a person
responsible for maintaining a designated list or register and may in
particular include provision—

257.8.a

about the process for including a person in a list or register;

257.8.b

about the details to be included in a list or register;

257.8.c

for ensuring those details remain up to date;

257.8.d

about the publication of a list or register;

257.8.e

for the purpose of ensuring that a person included in a list or register
continues to meet the criteria for appointment as an assessor;

257.8.f

for the purpose of ensuring the quality of ESOS assessments;

257.8.g

about the temporary or permanent removal of a person from a list or register
in specified circumstances.

257.9

The regulations may make provision authorising a scheme administrator to share
reports, notices or other information relating to an energy savings
opportunity scheme with a designated body for the purposes referred to in
subsection (8) (e)  or  (f) .

257.10

ESOS regulations may make provision—

257.10.a

enabling the Secretary of State or a scheme administrator to give a direction
relating to the maintenance of a list or register;

257.10.b

requiring a person responsible for maintaining a list or register to comply
with such a direction.

##### ESOS action plans

258

258.1

ESOS regulations may require participants to produce ESOS action plans.

258.2

An “ESOS action plan” is a written statement of—

258.2.a

any action a participant proposes to take for the purpose of achieving energy
savings or emissions reductions;

258.2.b

any energy savings or emissions reductions targets a participant intends to
achieve.

258.3

Where an ESOS action plan does not include any proposals for taking such
action or any such targets, provision made by virtue of  subsection (1)  may
require that a participant include an explanation in the plan.

258.4

ESOS regulations may make provision about the production of ESOS action plans,
including in particular provision about—

258.4.a

when a participant must produce a plan;

258.4.b

the period to which a plan must relate;

258.4.c

the form and content of a plan;

258.4.d

the matters that must be taken into account in producing a plan.

258.5

ESOS regulations may make provision about the publication of ESOS action
plans.

##### Action to achieve energy savings or emissions reductions

259

259.1

ESOS regulations may make provision—

259.1.a

imposing requirements (other than the requirements referred to in  paragraph
(b) ) on participants so as to encourage them to—

259.1.a.i

take specified action for the purpose of achieving energy savings or emissions
reductions, or

259.1.a.ii

achieve specified energy savings or emissions reductions, or

259.1.b

requiring participants to—

259.1.b.i

take specified action for the purpose of achieving energy savings or emissions
reductions, or

259.1.b.ii

achieve specified energy savings or emissions reductions.

259.2

The kinds of action that may be specified for the purposes of  subsection (1)
are—

259.2.a

taking action in accordance with a recommendation made in an ESOS assessment;

259.2.b

taking action in accordance with an ESOS action plan;

259.2.c

taking any other action of a specified kind;

259.2.d

taking action to achieve a target included in an ESOS action plan;

259.2.e

taking action to achieve any other specified outcome;

259.2.f

adopting processes, practices or systems of a specified kind;

259.2.g

conforming to specified standards.

259.3

The provision that may be made by virtue of  subsection (1) (a)  includes in
particular—

259.3.a

provision requiring a participant to report—

259.3.a.i

on whether the participant has taken the specified action, or on the steps
taken by the participant towards doing so, or

259.3.a.ii

on whether the participant has achieved the specified energy savings or
emissions reductions, or on the progress made by the participant towards doing
so;

259.3.b

provision requiring a participant to provide an explanation for any of the
matters mentioned in  paragraph (a) .

259.4

Provision made by virtue of  subsection (1) (b)  may include a requirement for
a participant to report on action taken or energy savings or emissions
reductions achieved.

259.5

Regulations made by virtue of  subsection (1)  may make provision—

259.5.a

requiring participants to produce and retain evidence;

259.5.b

about the verification of matters about which the participant has reported;

259.5.c

about the publication of reports.

259.6

ESOS regulations may—

259.6.a

specify the requirements imposed on a participant by virtue of  subsection (1)
by reference to a cost-benefit analysis;

259.6.b

specify circumstances in which a participant is required to take action;

259.6.c

impose a requirement to take a specified action on all participants in an
energy savings opportunity scheme, or on all participants of a specified
description.

#### Administration, enforcement and appeals

##### Scheme administration

260

260.1

ESOS regulations may appoint one or more public authorities to carry out
functions with respect to—

260.1.a

administering an energy savings opportunity scheme;

260.1.b

monitoring compliance with, and enforcing requirements imposed by, the
regulations.

260.2

A person appointed by virtue of subsection  (1)  is referred to as a “ scheme
administrator ”.

260.3

The regulations may make provision for a scheme administrator to authorise
another person to exercise specified functions of the scheme administrator.

260.4

Regulations made by virtue of subsection  (1)  may in particular include
provision about—

260.4.a

the obtaining of information by, and the provision of information to, a scheme
administrator;

260.4.b

the determination by a scheme administrator of information in default of its
being provided;

260.4.c

the auditing and verification of information;

260.4.d

the keeping, production and inspection of records;

260.4.e

the determination by a scheme administrator of whether an undertaking is a
participant in an energy savings opportunity scheme;

260.4.f

cooperation and information sharing between scheme administrators.

260.5

ESOS regulations may make provision imposing requirements on a participant
relating to the provision of such facilities and services, including transport
and accommodation, as may be necessary to facilitate the carrying out of any
of the scheme administrator’s functions.

260.6

ESOS regulations may confer functions on a scheme administrator in relation to
the publication of information relating to an energy savings opportunity
scheme or its participants.

260.7

ESOS regulations may make provision—

260.7.a

about the giving of guidance by a scheme administrator or the Secretary of
State in connection with the operation of an energy savings opportunity
scheme;

260.7.b

requiring specified persons to have regard to such guidance.

260.8

ESOS regulations may make provision requiring the payment by participants to
the scheme administrator of fees for or in connection with the carrying out by
the scheme administrator of the scheme administrator’s functions.

260.9

ESOS regulations may confer a power on a national authority to require a
scheme administrator to provide the authority with such information—

260.9.a

relating to an energy savings opportunity scheme, and

260.9.b

relevant to the exercise of the authority’s functions,

as the authority requests.

260.10

In this section—

      “ national authority ” means—         the Secretary of State;
the Welsh Ministers;           the Scottish Ministers;           the
Department for the Economy in Northern Ireland;                 “ public
authority ” means a person with functions of a public nature.

##### Enforcement, penalties and offences

261

261.1

ESOS regulations may authorise a scheme administrator—

261.1.a

to require the production of documents or the provision of information by any
person;

261.1.b

to question the officers of an undertaking;

261.1.c

to enter premises with a warrant;

261.1.d

to inspect premises and anything on premises and when doing so—

261.1.d.i

to take measurements, photographs, recordings or copies;

261.1.d.ii

to seize documents or records;

261.1.d.iii

to require any person at the premises to provide facilities and assistance to
the extent that is within that person’s control;

261.1.e

to issue a notice requiring a participant to take steps specified in the
notice for the purpose of—

261.1.e.i

demonstrating compliance with requirements imposed by or under ESOS
regulations, or

261.1.e.ii

remedying a failure to comply with such requirements.

261.2

ESOS regulations may make provision requiring a participant to give notice to
a scheme administrator where the participant is unlikely to comply, or has
failed to comply, with a requirement imposed by or under the regulations.

261.3

ESOS regulations may provide that a person is liable to one or more penalties
in respect of—

261.3.a

a failure to comply with a requirement imposed on the person by or under the
regulations;

261.3.b

making a false or misleading statement in connection with an energy savings
opportunity scheme.

261.4

The provision that may be made by virtue of  subsection (3)  includes
provision—

261.4.a

for the publication of specified information relating to the failure to
comply;

261.4.b

authorising a scheme administrator to impose a financial penalty.

261.5

Where by virtue of  subsection (3)  ESOS regulations provide for the
imposition of a financial penalty, the regulations—

261.5.a

must provide for the penalty to be paid to the scheme administrator or such
other person as the regulations may specify;

261.5.b

may specify the amount of the penalty or provide for the amount to be
determined by the scheme administrator in accordance with the regulations;

261.5.c

may provide for the payment of a further penalty (of an amount specified by or
determined in accordance with the regulations) for each day on which the
failure to comply is not remedied;

261.5.d

may specify how the penalty may be recovered.

261.6

ESOS regulations may create offences relating to energy savings opportunity
schemes.

261.7

Regulations made by virtue of  subsection (6)  may provide for an offence
created by the regulations to be triable—

261.7.a

only summarily, or

261.7.b

either summarily or on indictment.

261.8

Regulations made by virtue of  subsection (6)  may provide for an offence
created by the regulations to be punishable with a fine.

261.9

Regulations may—

261.9.a

provide for defences against offences;

261.9.b

make provision about matters of procedure and evidence in proceedings relating
to offences;

261.9.c

include provision about the liability of a director, manager, secretary or
other officer of a body corporate, or a partner of a Scottish partnership, or
of a person purporting to act in such a capacity, where an offence under the
regulations—

261.9.c.i

is committed with the consent or connivance of such a person, or

261.9.c.ii

is attributable to neglect on the part of such a person.

261.10

References in this section to a scheme administrator include references to a
person authorised by a scheme administrator in accordance with provision in
ESOS regulations made by virtue of  section 260 (3) .

##### Appeals

262

262.1

ESOS regulations that provide for the imposition of a financial penalty must
also provide for a right of appeal to a court or tribunal against the
imposition of the penalty.

262.2

ESOS regulations may confer rights of appeal against—

262.2.a

decisions made in relation to an energy savings opportunity scheme, and

262.2.b

penalties imposed (other than financial penalties) or enforcement action taken
for failure to comply with the requirements of the regulations.

262.3

Regulations that make provision by virtue of subsection  (2)  must specify the
court, tribunal or person who is to hear and determine an appeal made by
virtue of that subsection.

262.4

The provision that may be made by virtue of  subsection (1)  or  (2)
includes, in particular, provision about—

262.4.a

the grounds on which an appeal may be made;

262.4.b

the procedure for making an appeal (including any fee which may be payable);

262.4.c

suspending the effect of any decision, penalty or enforcement action pending
determination of the appeal;

262.4.d

the powers of the court, tribunal or person to which an appeal is made.

#### Procedure etc for regulations

##### ESOS regulations: procedure etc

263

263.1

Before making ESOS regulations, the Secretary of State must consult such
persons likely to be affected by the regulations as the Secretary of State
considers appropriate.

263.2

Subsection  (1)  may be satisfied by consultation before this section comes
into force (as well as by consultation after that time).

263.3

Before making ESOS regulations that contain provision within devolved
competence, the Secretary of State must give notice—

263.3.a

stating that the Secretary of State proposes to make ESOS regulations,

263.3.b

setting out or describing the provisions of the regulations that contain
provision within devolved competence, and

263.3.c

specifying the period (of not less than 28 days from the date on which the
notice is given) within which representations may be made with respect to
those provisions,

and must consider any representations duly made and not withdrawn.

263.4

A notice under subsection  (3)  must be given to each relevant devolved
authority, that is to say—

263.4.a

the Scottish Ministers, so far as the regulations contain provision within
Scottish devolved competence;

263.4.b

the Welsh Ministers, so far as the regulations contain provision within Welsh
devolved competence;

263.4.c

the Department for the Economy in Northern Ireland, so far as the regulations
contain provision within Northern Ireland devolved competence.

263.5

The Secretary of State need not wait until the end of the period specified
under  subsection (3) (c)  before making ESOS regulations if, before the end
of that period, each relevant devolved authority to which the notice was given
has confirmed that it has made any representations it intends to make with
respect to the provisions referred to in subsection  (3) (b) .

263.6

The Secretary of State must, if requested to do so by a relevant devolved
authority, give the authority a statement setting out whether and how
representations made by the authority with respect to the provisions referred
to in subsection  (3) (b)  have been taken into account in the regulations.

263.7

References in subsection  (3)  to provision within devolved competence are to
provision that is within Scottish, Welsh or Northern Ireland devolved
competence.

263.8

Where the Secretary of State makes ESOS regulations that have effect in
relation to the compliance period beginning on 6 December 2019 (see regulation
4 of the Energy Savings Opportunity Schemes Regulations 2014 ( S.I. 2014/1643
))—

263.8.a

subsections  (3)  to  (7)  do not apply, and

263.8.b

before making the regulations, the Secretary of State must consult—

263.8.b.i

the Scottish Ministers, so far as the regulations contain provision within
Scottish devolved competence,

263.8.b.ii

the Welsh Ministers, so far as the regulations contain provision within Welsh
devolved competence, and

263.8.b.iii

the Department for the Economy in Northern Ireland, so far as the regulations
contain provision within Northern Ireland devolved competence,

and  subsection (2)  applies to consultation under paragraph  (b)  as it
applies to consultation under  subsection (1) .

263.9

ESOS regulations may create exceptions to any requirement imposed by the
regulations.

263.10

ESOS regulations may—

263.10.a

make provision about application to the Crown;

263.10.b

to the extent that they bind the Crown, restrict or modify the application of
the regulations.

263.11

ESOS regulations containing any of the following (with or without other
provision) are subject to the affirmative procedure—

263.11.a

provision extending the descriptions of undertaking to which the regulations
apply;

263.11.b

provision made by virtue of  section 259 (1) (b)  of a kind not previously
provided for in ESOS regulations;

263.11.c

provision conferring on a scheme administrator enforcement powers of a kind
not previously provided for in ESOS regulations;

263.11.d

provision creating penalties;

263.11.e

provision increasing the amount of financial penalties by more than is
necessary to reflect changes in the value of money;

263.11.f

provision creating an offence or increasing the fine for an existing offence;

263.11.g

provision for the payment of a new fee.

263.12

Any other ESOS regulations are subject to the negative procedure.

#### Directions and financial assistance

##### Directions to scheme administrators

264

264.1

The Secretary of State may give directions to a scheme administrator.

264.2

The power to give directions under this section includes a power to vary or
revoke the directions.

264.3

A scheme administrator must comply with any direction given to it under this
section.

##### Financial assistance to scheme administrators and participants

265

265.1

The Secretary of State may give, or arrange for the giving of, financial
assistance to—

265.1.a

scheme administrators;

265.1.b

participants.

265.2

“ Financial assistance ” means grants, loans, guarantees or indemnities, or
any other kind of financial assistance.

265.3

Financial assistance under this section may be given subject to such
conditions as may be determined by, or in accordance with arrangements made
by, the Secretary of State.

#### Interpretation

##### Interpretation of 

266

266.1

In this Part—

      “ assessor ” has the meaning given by  section 256 (3) ;           “
cost benefit analysis ” has the meaning given by  section 256 (6) ;
“ emissions reduction ” has the meaning given by  section 254 (5) ;
“ energy consumption ” has the meaning given by ESOS regulations;           “
energy saving ” has the meaning given by  section 254 (4) ;           “ energy
savings opportunity scheme ” has the meaning given by  section 254 (2) ;
“ ESOS action plan ” has the meaning given by  section 258 (2) ;           “
ESOS assessment ” has the meaning given by  section 256 (1) ;           “ ESOS
regulations ” means regulations made under  section 254 (1) ;           “
greenhouse gas ” has the meaning given by section 92 of the Climate Change Act
2008;           “ participant ” means an undertaking to which an energy
savings opportunity scheme applies;           “ related undertaking ”, in
relation to a participant, means a fellow subsidiary undertaking of, or a
group undertaking in relation to, that participant;           “ scheme
administrator ” has the meaning given by  section 260 (2) ;           “
specified ” means specified in ESOS regulations;           “ undertaking ”,
“group undertaking” and “fellow subsidiary undertaking” have the meanings
given by section 1161 of the Companies Act 2006.

266.2

For the purposes of this Part, provision—

266.2.a

is within Welsh devolved competence if it would be within the legislative
competence of Senedd Cymru if it were contained in an Act of the Senedd
(ignoring any requirement for the consent of a Minister of the Crown imposed
under Schedule 7B to the Government of Wales Act 2006);

266.2.b

is within Scottish devolved competence if it would be within the legislative
competence of the Scottish Parliament if it were contained in an Act of that
Parliament;

266.2.c

is within Northern Ireland devolved competence if it—

266.2.c.i

would be within the legislative competence of the Northern Ireland Assembly if
it were contained in an Act of that Assembly, and

266.2.c.ii

would not, if it were contained in a Bill in the Northern Ireland Assembly,
result in the Bill requiring the consent of the Secretary of State under
section 8 of the Northern Ireland Act 1998.

### Core fuel sector resilience

#### Introduction

##### General objective

267

The functions of the Secretary of State under this Part must be exercised with
a view to—

267.a

ensuring that economic activity in the United Kingdom is not adversely
affected by disruptions to core fuel sector activities, and

267.b

reducing the risk of emergencies affecting fuel supplies.

##### “Core fuel sector activity” and other key concepts

268

268.1

In this Part “ core fuel sector activity ” means an activity of a kind
mentioned in  subsection (2) , so far as the activity—

268.1.a

is carried on in the United Kingdom in the course of a business, and

268.1.b

contributes (directly or indirectly) to the supply of core fuels to consumers
in the United Kingdom or persons carrying on business in the United Kingdom.

268.2

The kinds of activity are—

268.2.a

storing oil or renewable transport fuel;

268.2.b

handling oil or renewable transport fuel;

268.2.c

the carriage of oil or renewable transport fuel by sea or inland water;

268.2.d

transporting oil or renewable transport fuel by road or rail;

268.2.e

conveying oil or renewable transport fuel by pipes;

268.2.f

processing or producing oil or renewable transport fuel (whether by refining,
blending or otherwise).

268.3

In  subsection (2)  the references to “oil” do not include crude oil which has
not yet entered any refinery or terminal in the United Kingdom.

268.4

In this Part “ core fuels ” means—

268.4.a

crude oil based fuels, and

268.4.b

renewable transport fuels.

268.5

In this Part “ core fuel sector resilience ” means the capability of core fuel
sector participants to—

268.5.a

manage the risk of,

268.5.b

reduce the potential adverse impact of, and

268.5.c

facilitate recovery from,

disruptions to core fuel sector activities.

268.6

In this Part “ core fuel sector participant ” means—

268.6.a

a person carrying on core fuel sector activities;

268.6.b

a  Part 12  facility owner.

268.7

For the purposes of this Part there is “continuity of supply of core fuels”
where the supply of core fuels to consumers in all areas of the United
Kingdom, and persons carrying on business in all areas of the United Kingdom—

268.7.a

is reliable and continuous, and

268.7.b

is maintained at normal levels.

268.8

In  subsection (7)  “ normal levels ” means levels that—

268.8.a

are not substantially below average monthly levels of supply in the United
Kingdom (taking account of regional variations), and

268.8.b

are consistent with a reasonable balance between supply and demand.

268.9

For the purposes of  subsection (8)  “average monthly levels” are to be
calculated by reference to levels of supply in the five years preceding the
calculation.

268.10

In this Part “relevant activities or assets”—

268.10.a

in relation to a person carrying on core fuel sector activities, means the
person’s core fuel sector activities (and includes any land or assets under
the person’s control that are associated with those activities);

268.10.b

in relation to a  Part 12  facility owner, means the owned facility.

268.11

In this Part—

268.11.a

“ Part 12  facility owner” means the owner of a pipeline, terminal, or other
facility or infrastructure which is used, or any part of which is used, for
the purposes of core fuel sector activities;

268.11.b

in relation to a  Part 12  facility owner, “ the owned facility ” means the
facility or infrastructure mentioned in  paragraph (a) .

268.12

In  subsection (11)  “ owner ”, in relation to any facility or infrastructure,
means—

268.12.a

a person in whom the facility or infrastructure is vested, or

268.12.b

a lessee of the facility or infrastructure.

268.13

In this Part references to a “person carrying on core fuel sector activities”
include any person carrying on such activities (whether or not as the owner of
the oil or renewable transport fuel).

#### Powers for resilience purposes

##### Directions

###### Directions to particular core fuel sector participants

269

269.1

The Secretary of State may, for the purpose of maintaining or improving core
fuel sector resilience, direct a person to whom this section applies to do
anything in relation to the person’s relevant activities or assets (for
example, to acquire and install specific equipment, or carry out specific
works, at the person’s own expense).

269.2

The Secretary of State may not give a direction under  subsection (1)  unless
the Secretary of State considers that the persons to whom this section applies
have failed to make sufficient progress with the steps that the Secretary of
State considers necessary for maintaining or improving core fuel sector
resilience.

269.3

Where there is disruption to, or a failure of, continuity of supply of core
fuels, the Secretary of State may direct a person to whom this section applies
to do anything in relation to the person’s relevant activities or assets which
the Secretary of State considers necessary or expedient for the purpose of—

269.3.a

restoring continuity of supply of core fuels, or

269.3.b

counteracting the disruption or failure, or its potential adverse impact.

269.4

If the Secretary of State considers that there is a significant risk of
disruption to, or a failure of, continuity of supply of core fuels, the
Secretary of State may direct a person to whom this section applies to do
anything in relation to the person’s relevant activities or assets which the
Secretary of State considers necessary or expedient for the purpose of—

269.4.a

reducing the risk, or

269.4.b

reducing the potential adverse impact of the disruption or failure.

269.5

The Secretary of State may not make a direction under subsection  (1) ,  (3)
or  (4)  unless the Secretary of State considers—

269.5.a

that, the corresponding cases (if any) are not sufficiently numerous to
justify making regulations under  section 272 , or

269.5.b

that, by reason of urgency, it is not practicable to achieve the aims of the
direction by regulations under  section 272 .

269.6

In  subsection (5) (a)  the reference to “corresponding cases” is to persons
to whom this section applies in relation to whom the Secretary of State
considers it would be appropriate to take action corresponding to the
direction.

269.7

This section applies to the following persons—

269.7.a

a person carrying on core fuel sector activities in the course of a business
which has capacity in excess of 500,000 tonnes;

269.7.b

a  Part 12  facility owner if the owned facility has capacity in excess of
20,000 tonnes.

269.8

For the purposes of this Part—

269.8.a

a business “has capacity in excess of” a specified number of tonnes if in the
most recently ended calendar year core fuel sector activities were carried on
in that business in relation to more than that number of tonnes of core fuel;

269.8.b

a facility or infrastructure “has capacity in excess of” a specified number of
tonnes if in the most recently ended calendar year it was used for the
purposes of core fuel sector activities in relation to more than that number
of tonnes of core fuels.

###### Procedure for giving directions

270

270.1

Before giving a person a direction under  section 269  the Secretary of State
must give the person a written notice accompanied by a draft of the proposed
direction.

270.2

The notice under  subsection (1)  must—

270.2.a

state that the Secretary of State proposes to give the person a direction in
the form of the accompanying draft;

270.2.b

explain why the Secretary of State proposes to give the direction;

270.2.c

state when it is intended that the direction will come into effect;

270.2.d

specify a period within which the person may make written representations with
respect to the proposal.

270.3

The period specified under  subsection (2) (d)  must begin with the date on
which the notice is given to the person and must be not less than 14 days.

270.4

Before giving a direction under  section 269 , the Secretary of State must
consult—

270.4.a

so far as the direction relates to relevant activities or assets in England,
Scotland or Wales, the Health and Safety Executive;

270.4.b

so far as the direction relates to relevant activities or assets in England,
the Environment Agency;

270.4.c

so far as the direction relates to relevant activities or assets in Scotland,
the Scottish Environment Protection Agency;

270.4.d

so far as the direction relates to relevant activities or assets in Wales, the
Natural Resources Body for Wales;

270.4.e

so far as the direction relates to relevant activities or assets in Northern
Ireland—

270.4.e.i

the Health and Safety Executive for Northern Ireland, and

270.4.e.ii

the Department of Agriculture, Environment and Rural Affairs in Northern
Ireland;

270.4.f

any other persons the Secretary of State thinks appropriate.

270.5

The Secretary of State must decide whether to give the person the proposed
direction (with or without modifications), after considering any
representations made by—

270.5.a

the person mentioned in  subsection (1) , and

270.5.b

any person consulted in accordance with  subsection (4) .

270.6

The Secretary of State must give written notice of that decision to the person
mentioned in  subsection (1) .

270.7

If the decision is to give the proposed direction, the notice must—

270.7.a

contain the direction, and

270.7.b

state the time when the direction is to take effect.

270.8

Consultation under  subsection (4)  with the Environment Agency, the Scottish
Environment Protection Agency or the Natural Resources Body for Wales must be
with reference to that body’s functions under the Control of Major Accident
Hazards Regulations 2015 ( S.I. 2015/483 ).

270.9

Consultation under  subsection (4)  with the Department of Agriculture,
Environment and Rural Affairs in Northern Ireland must be with reference to
the department’s functions under the Control of Major Accident Hazards
Regulations (Northern Ireland) 2015 ( S.R. (N.I.) 2015 No. 325 ).

###### Offence of failure to comply with a direction

271

Any person who, without reasonable excuse, fails to comply with a direction
given to the person under  section 269  commits an offence and is liable—

271.a

on summary conviction in England and Wales, to imprisonment for a term not
exceeding the general limit in a magistrates’ court or a fine (or both);

271.b

on summary conviction in Scotland, to imprisonment for a term not exceeding 12
months or a fine not exceeding the statutory maximum (or both);

271.c

on summary conviction in Northern Ireland, to imprisonment for a term not
exceeding 6 months or a fine not exceeding the statutory maximum (or both);

271.d

on conviction on indictment, to imprisonment for a term not exceeding 2 years
or a fine (or both).

##### Corresponding powers to make regulations

###### Corresponding powers to make regulations

272

272.1

The Secretary of State may, for the purpose of maintaining or improving core
fuel sector resilience, by regulations require persons of a class or
description specified in the regulations to do anything in relation to their
relevant activities or assets.

272.2

The Secretary of State may not make any provision by regulations under
subsection (1)  unless the Secretary of State considers that the persons
mentioned in paragraphs  (a)  and  (b)  of  subsection (5)  have failed to
make sufficient progress with the steps that the Secretary of State considers
necessary for maintaining or improving core fuel sector resilience.

272.3

Where there is disruption to, or a failure of, continuity of supply of core
fuels, the Secretary of State may by regulations require persons of a class or
description specified in the regulations to do anything in relation to their
relevant activities or assets which the Secretary of State considers necessary
or expedient for the purpose of—

272.3.a

restoring continuity of supply of core fuels, or

272.3.b

counteracting the disruption or failure, or its potential adverse impact.

272.4

If the Secretary of State considers that there is a significant risk of
disruption to, or a failure of, continuity of supply of core fuels, the
Secretary of State may by regulations require persons of a class or
description specified in the regulations to do anything in relation to their
relevant activities or assets which the Secretary of State considers necessary
or expedient for the purpose of—

272.4.a

reducing the risk, or

272.4.b

reducing the potential adverse impact of the disruption or failure.

272.5

A class or description specified for the purposes of subsection  (1) ,  (3)
or  (4)  may not include persons other than—

272.5.a

persons carrying on core fuel sector activities in the course of a business
which has capacity in excess of 1,000 tonnes, or

272.5.b

Part 12  facility owners whose owned facility has capacity in excess of 1,000
tonnes.

272.6

Regulations under this section may provide that any person who, without
reasonable excuse, fails to comply with a requirement imposed by the
regulations commits an offence.

272.7

Before making regulations under this section the Secretary of State must
consult—

272.7.a

so far as the regulations relate to relevant activities or assets in England,
Scotland or Wales, the Health and Safety Executive;

272.7.b

so far as the regulations relate to relevant activities or assets in England,
the Environment Agency;

272.7.c

so far as the regulations relate to relevant assets or activities in Scotland,
the Scottish Environment Protection Agency;

272.7.d

so far as the regulations relate to relevant activities or assets in Wales,
the Natural Resources Body for Wales;

272.7.e

so far as the regulations relate to relevant activities or assets in Northern
Ireland—

272.7.e.i

the Health and Safety Executive for Northern Ireland, and

272.7.e.ii

the Department of Agriculture, Environment and Rural Affairs in Northern
Ireland;

272.7.f

any other persons the Secretary of State thinks appropriate.

272.8

Regulations under this section are subject to the affirmative procedure.

272.9

Consultation under  subsection (7)  with the Environment Agency, the Scottish
Environment Protection Agency or the Natural Resources Body for Wales must be
with reference to that body’s functions under the Control of Major Accident
Hazards Regulations 2015 ( S.I. 2015/483 ).

272.10

Consultation under  subsection (7)  with the Department of Agriculture,
Environment and Rural Affairs in Northern Ireland must be with reference to
the department’s functions under the Control of Major Accident Hazards
Regulations (Northern Ireland) 2015 ( S.R. (N.I.) 2015 No. 325 ).

##### Information

###### Power to require information

273

273.1

The Secretary of State may by notice in writing require any of the following
to provide the Secretary of State with information relating to their relevant
activities or assets—

273.1.a

a person carrying on core fuel sector activities in the course of a business
which has capacity in excess of 1,000 tonnes;

273.1.b

a  Part 12  facility owner whose owned facility has capacity in excess of
1,000 tonnes.

273.2

The Secretary of State may by notice in writing require a relevant wetstock
manager to provide the Secretary of State with information relating to the
relevant activities or assets of a person carrying on core fuel sector
activities to whom the relevant wetstock manager provides stock management
services.

273.3

In this Part “ relevant wetstock manager ” means a person who provides to
persons who make retail supplies of core fuels in the United Kingdom stock
management services in respect of such supplies.

273.4

The Secretary of State may only require information under this section for the
purpose of maintaining or improving core fuel sector resilience.

273.5

A notice under  subsection (1)  or  (2)  may—

273.5.a

specify the manner in which information is to be provided;

273.5.b

specify time limits for providing information;

273.5.c

require information to be provided at specified intervals.

273.6

Before giving a person a notice under  subsection (1)  or  (2)  the Secretary
of State must—

273.6.a

notify the person in writing of the proposed contents of the notice and of the
period within which the person may make written representations with respect
to the proposed requirement, and

273.6.b

consider any representations made by the person.

273.7

The period notified under  subsection (6) (a)  must begin on the date on which
the notification is given and (subject to  subsection (8) ) must be not less
than 14 days.

273.8

The Secretary of State may notify a period under  subsection (6) (a)  that is
less than 14 days but not less than 7 days if the Secretary of State considers
that it is it is necessary to do so by reason of urgency.

###### Duty to report incidents

274

274.1

If at any time a person—

274.1.a

knows, or has reason to suspect, that a notifiable incident is occurring or
has occurred, and

274.1.b

meets the condition in  paragraph (a) ,  (b)  or  (c)  of  subsection (2) ,

that person must notify the Secretary of State of the incident as soon as
possible.

274.2

The conditions mentioned in  subsection (1) (b)  are that—

274.2.a

the person is carrying on core fuel sector activities in the course of a
business which has capacity in excess of 500,000 tonnes;

274.2.b

the person is a  Part 12  facility owner in whose case the owned facility has
capacity in excess of 500,000 tonnes;

274.2.c

the person is of a class or description specified in regulations made by the
Secretary of State under this subsection.

274.3

In this section “ notifiable incident ”, in relation to a person, means an
incident which affects the person’s relevant activities or assets in such a
way as to create a significant risk of, or cause—

274.3.a

disruption to, or

274.3.b

a failure of,

the continuity of supply of core fuels.

274.4

The Secretary of State may by notice in writing require a person who has given
a notice under  subsection (1)  to provide further information about the
incident.

274.5

Before giving a person a notice under  subsection (4)  the Secretary of State
must—

274.5.a

notify the person in writing of—

274.5.a.i

the proposed contents of the notice, and

274.5.a.ii

the period within which the person may make written representations with
respect to the proposal, and

274.5.b

consider any representations made by the person.

274.6

The period notified under  subsection (5) (a) (ii)  must begin on the date on
which the notification is given and (subject to  subsection (7) ) must be not
less than 14 days.

274.7

The Secretary of State may notify a period under  subsection (5) (a) (ii)
that is less than 14 days but not less than 7 days if the Secretary of State
considers that it is necessary to do so by reason of urgency.

274.8

A notice under  subsection (4)  may specify—

274.8.a

the manner in which information is to be provided, and

274.8.b

time limits for providing information.

274.9

Where a notification under  subsection (1)  is not made in writing, it must be
confirmed in writing as soon as possible.

274.10

Regulations under  subsection (2) (c)  may specify the meaning that “relevant
activities or assets” is to have in  subsection (3)  in relation to persons of
a class or description of persons specified in the regulations.

274.11

Regulations under  subsection (2) (c)  are subject to the affirmative
procedure.

###### Contravention of requirement under 

275

275.1

A person who, without reasonable excuse, fails to comply with a requirement
imposed by a notice under  section 273 (1)  or  (2)  or  274 (4)  commits an
offence.

275.2

A person who, without reasonable excuse, fails to comply with  section 274 (1)
commits an offence.

275.3

A person who commits an offence under this section is liable—

275.3.a

on summary conviction in England and Wales, to imprisonment for a term not
exceeding the general limit in a magistrates’ court or a fine (or both);

275.3.b

on summary conviction in Scotland, to imprisonment for a term not exceeding 12
months or a fine not exceeding the statutory maximum (or both);

275.3.c

on summary conviction in Northern Ireland, to imprisonment for a term not
exceeding 6 months or a fine not exceeding the statutory maximum (or both);

275.3.d

on conviction on indictment, to imprisonment for a term not exceeding 2 years
or a fine (or both).

###### Provision of information at specified intervals

276

276.1

The Secretary of State may by regulations require any of the following to
provide to the Secretary of State, at intervals specified in the regulations,
information relating to their relevant activities or assets—

276.1.a

a person carrying on core fuel sector activities in the course of a business
which has capacity in excess of 1,000 tonnes;

276.1.b

a  Part 12  facility owner whose owned facility has capacity in excess of
1,000 tonnes.

276.2

The Secretary of State may by regulations require a relevant wetstock manager
to provide to the Secretary of State, at intervals specified in the
regulations, information relating to the relevant activities or assets of a
person carrying on core fuel sector activities to whom the relevant wetstock
manager provides stock management services.

276.3

The power to make regulations under this section may only be exercised for the
purpose of maintaining or improving core fuel sector resilience.

276.4

The regulations may make provision about—

276.4.a

the information to be provided;

276.4.b

the manner in which information is to be provided;

276.4.c

time limits for providing information.

276.5

Regulations under this section may provide that any person who, without
reasonable excuse, fails to comply with a requirement imposed by the
regulations commits an offence.

276.6

Regulations under this section are subject to the affirmative procedure.

###### Disclosure of information held by the Secretary of State

277

277.1

Subsection  (2)  applies to information held by the Secretary of State which
was provided to the Secretary of State under  section 273 ,  274  or  276 .

277.2

The information may be disclosed—

277.2.a

to any government department or devolved authority for the purpose of—

277.2.a.i

maintaining or improving core fuel sector resilience, or

277.2.a.ii

restoring, or counteracting a disruption to, or failure of, continuity of
supply of core fuels (or counteracting the potential adverse impact of any
such disruption or failure), or

277.2.b

if the disclosure is necessary for the purpose of criminal proceedings.

277.3

Nothing in this section authorises the making of a disclosure which—

277.3.a

contravenes the data protection legislation (as defined in section 3 of the
Data Protection Act 2018), or

277.3.b

is prohibited by any of Parts 1 to 7 of, or Chapter 1 of Part 9 of, the
Investigatory Powers Act 2016.

In determining whether a disclosure would fall within paragraph  (a)  or  (b)
, the powers conferred by this section are to be taken into account.

277.4

In subsection  (2)  “ devolved authority ” means—

277.4.a

the Welsh Ministers,

277.4.b

the Scottish Ministers, or

277.4.c

a Northern Ireland department.

###### Disclosure of information by HMRC

278

278.1

His Majesty’s Revenue and Customs (or anyone acting on their behalf) may
disclose information to the Secretary of State for the purpose of facilitating
the exercise by the Secretary of State of functions relating to core fuel
sector resilience.

278.2

A person who receives information as a result of this section may not—

278.2.a

use the information for a purpose other than that mentioned in  subsection (1)
, or

278.2.b

further disclose the information,

except with the consent of the Commissioners for His Majesty’s Revenue and
Customs (which may be general or specific).

278.3

If a person discloses information in contravention of  subsection (2) (b)
which relates to a person whose identity—

278.3.a

is specified in the disclosure, or

278.3.b

can be deduced from it,

section 19 of the Commissioners for Revenue and Customs Act 2005 (offence of
wrongful disclosure) applies in relation to that disclosure as it applies in
relation to a disclosure of information in contravention of section 20(9) of
that Act.

278.4

This section does not limit the circumstances in which information may be
disclosed under section 18(2) of the Commissioners for Revenue and Customs Act
2005 or under any other enactment or rule of law.

278.5

Nothing in this section authorises the making of a disclosure which—

278.5.a

contravenes the data protection legislation (as defined in section 3 of the
Data Protection Act 2018), or

278.5.b

is prohibited by any of Parts 1 to 7 of, or Chapter 1 of Part 9 of, the
Investigatory Powers Act 2016.

In determining whether a disclosure would fall within paragraph  (a)  or  (b)
, the powers conferred by this section are to be taken into account.

##### Appeal against notice or direction

###### Appeal against notice or direction

279

279.1

A person to whom a direction under  section 269  or a notice under  section
273  or  274 (4)  is given may appeal to the First-tier Tribunal against the
direction or notice on the ground that the decision to give it—

279.1.a

is based on an error of fact,

279.1.b

is wrong in law, or

279.1.c

is unfair or unreasonable.

279.2

On an appeal under this section the Tribunal may—

279.2.a

confirm or cancel the direction or notice, or

279.2.b

refer the matter back to the Secretary of State for reconsideration with such
directions (if any) as the Tribunal considers appropriate.

#### Enforcement

##### Offences

###### False statements etc

280

280.1

It is an offence for a person to make a statement which the person knows is
false or materially misleading—

280.1.a

in responding to a requirement imposed by the Secretary of State—

280.1.a.i

under  section 273  (power to require information),

280.1.a.ii

under  section 274 (4)  (duty to report incidents), or

280.1.a.iii

under regulations under  section 276  (provision of information at specified
intervals), or

280.1.b

in making any other statement to the Secretary of State in connection with any
of the Secretary of State’s functions under this Part.

280.2

A person who commits an offence under this section is liable—

280.2.a

on summary conviction in England and Wales, to imprisonment for a term not
exceeding the general limit in a magistrates’ court or a fine (or both);

280.2.b

on summary conviction in Scotland, to imprisonment for a term not exceeding 12
months or a fine not exceeding the statutory maximum (or both);

280.2.c

on summary conviction in Northern Ireland, to imprisonment for a term not
exceeding 6 months or a fine not exceeding the statutory maximum (or both);

280.2.d

on conviction on indictment, to imprisonment for a term not exceeding 2 years
or a fine (or both).

###### Offences under regulations

281

281.1

This section applies to regulations under—

281.1.a

section 272  (corresponding powers to make regulations);

281.1.b

section 276  (provision of information at specified intervals).

281.2

Regulations to which this section applies may provide for an offence under the
regulations to be triable—

281.2.a

only summarily, or

281.2.b

either summarily or on indictment.

281.3

Regulations to which this section applies may provide for an offence under the
regulations that is triable either way to be punishable—

281.3.a

on summary conviction in England and Wales with imprisonment for a term not
exceeding the period specified or a fine (or both);

281.3.b

on summary conviction in Scotland or Northern Ireland with imprisonment for a
term not exceeding the period specified or a fine not exceeding the statutory
maximum (or both);

281.3.c

on conviction on indictment, with imprisonment for a term not exceeding the
period specified, which may not exceed two years, or a fine (or both).

281.4

A period specified under  subsection (3) (a)  may not exceed the general limit
in a magistrates’ court.

281.5

A period specified under  subsection (3) (b)  may not exceed—

281.5.a

in relation to Scotland, 12 months;

281.5.b

in relation to Northern Ireland, 6 months.

281.6

Regulations to which this section applies may provide for a summary offence
under the regulations to be punishable—

281.6.a

with imprisonment for a term not exceeding the period specified,

281.6.b

with—

281.6.b.i

in England and Wales, a fine (or a fine not exceeding an amount specified,
which must not exceed level 4 on the standard scale), or

281.6.b.ii

in Scotland or Northern Ireland, a fine not exceeding the amount specified,
which must not exceed level 5 on the standard scale, or

281.6.c

with both.

281.7

A period specified under subsection (6)(a) may not exceed—

281.7.a

in relation to England and Wales—

281.7.a.i

6 months, in relation to offences committed before the date on which section
281(5) of the Criminal Justice Act 2003 comes into force, or

281.7.a.ii

51 weeks, in relation to offences committed on or after that date,

281.7.b

in relation to Scotland, 12 months,

281.7.c

in relation to Northern Ireland, 6 months.

281.8

In this section “ specified ” means specified in the regulations.

###### Proceedings for offences

282

Proceedings for an offence under this Part (including an offence created by
regulations under  section 272  or  276 )—

282.a

may not be brought in England and Wales except by or with the consent of the
Secretary of State or the Director of Public Prosecutions;

282.b

may not be brought in Northern Ireland except by or with the consent of the
Secretary of State or the Director of Public Prosecutions for Northern
Ireland.

###### Liability of officers of entities

283

283.1

Where an offence under this Part committed by a body corporate is proved—

283.1.a

to have been committed with the consent or connivance of an officer of the
body corporate, or

283.1.b

to be attributable to neglect on the part of an officer of the body corporate,

that officer (as well as the body corporate) commits the offence and is liable
to be proceeded against and dealt with accordingly.

283.2

In subsection (1) “ officer ”, in relation to a body corporate, means—

283.2.a

any director, manager, secretary or other similar officer of the body
corporate, or

283.2.b

any person purporting to act in any such capacity.

283.3

In subsection (2) “ director ”, in relation to a body corporate whose affairs
are managed by its members, means a member of the body corporate.

283.4

Where an offence under this Part is committed by a Scottish partnership and is
proved to have been committed with the consent or connivance of a partner, or
to be attributable to any neglect on the part of a partner, that partner (as
well as the partnership) commits the offence and is liable to be proceeded
against and dealt with accordingly.

##### Enforcement undertakings

###### Enforcement undertakings

284

284.1

Subsection  (2)  applies if—

284.1.a

the Secretary of State has reasonable grounds to suspect that a person has
committed an offence falling within  subsection (5) ,

284.1.b

the person offers to the Secretary of State an enforcement undertaking in
respect of the relevant act or omission, and

284.1.c

the Secretary of State accepts that undertaking.

284.2

Unless the person has failed to comply with the undertaking (or any part of
it) the person may not at any time be convicted of that offence in respect of
the relevant act or omission.

284.3

In this Part “ enforcement undertaking ” means an undertaking to take, within
any period specified in the undertaking, action—

284.3.a

for any of the purposes in  subsection (4) , or

284.3.b

of a description specified in regulations made by the Secretary of State.

284.4

The purposes mentioned in  subsection (3)  are—

284.4.a

to secure that the offence does not continue or recur,

284.4.b

to secure that the position is, so far as possible, restored to what it would
have been if the offence had not been committed, or

284.4.c

to benefit any person affected by the offence.

284.5

The following offences fall within this subsection—

284.5.a

an offence under—

284.5.a.i

section 271  (failure to comply with a direction),

284.5.a.ii

section 275  (contravention of requirement under  section 273  or  274 ), or

284.5.a.iii

section 280  (false statements etc);

284.5.b

an offence, other than an offence triable only summarily, that is created by
regulations under—

284.5.b.i

section 272  (corresponding powers to make regulations), or

284.5.b.ii

section 276  (provision of information at regular intervals).

284.6

The reference in  subsection (4) (c)  to action to “ benefit any person
affected by the offence ” includes action by way of the payment of a sum of
money.

284.7

Where a person from whom the Secretary of State has accepted an enforcement
undertaking has failed to comply fully with the undertaking but has complied
with part of it, the partial compliance must be taken into account in any
decision whether to institute any criminal proceedings in respect of the
offence in question.

284.8

In this section “ relevant act or omission ” means an act or omission of the
person to which the grounds mentioned in  subsection (1) (a)  relate.

284.9

Regulations under  subsection (3) (b)  are subject to the affirmative
procedure.

284.10

Schedule 20  contains further provision about enforcement undertakings,
including provision about—

284.10.a

procedure;

284.10.b

compliance certificates;

284.10.c

appeals.

##### Guidance

###### Guidance: criminal and civil sanctions

285

285.1

The Secretary of State must issue guidance as to—

285.1.a

the sanctions (including criminal sanctions) to which a person who commits an
offence under this Part may be liable,

285.1.b

the action which the Secretary of State may take to enforce offences under
this Part, whether by virtue of  section 284  and  Schedule 20  or otherwise,
and

285.1.c

the circumstances in which the Secretary of State is likely to take any such
action.

285.2

The Secretary of State—

285.2.a

must issue guidance about how the Secretary of State intends to exercise the
Secretary of State’s functions under  section 284  and  Schedule 20 ;

285.2.b

must have regard to the guidance in exercising the Secretary of State’s
functions under those provisions.

285.3

Before issuing guidance under this section, the Secretary of State must—

285.3.a

prepare a draft of the proposed guidance;

285.3.b

consult such persons as the Secretary of State considers appropriate;

285.3.c

comply with the requirements of  section 286 .

285.4

The Secretary of State may from time to time revise guidance issued under this
section and issue revised guidance.

285.5

Subsection  (3)  applies to revised guidance as it applies to the original
guidance.

285.6

The Secretary of State must arrange for the publication of guidance (or
revised guidance) issued under this section.

###### Guidance: Parliamentary scrutiny

286

286.1

Before issuing guidance under  section 285 , the Secretary of State must lay a
draft of the proposed guidance before both Houses of Parliament.

286.2

The Secretary of State must not issue the guidance until after the period of
40 days beginning with—

286.2.a

the day on which the draft is laid before both Houses of Parliament, or

286.2.b

if the draft is laid before the House of Lords on one day and the House of
Commons on another, the later of those two days.

286.3

If before the end of that period either House resolves that the guidance
should not be issued, the Secretary of State may not issue it.

286.4

In reckoning any period of 40 days for the purposes of  subsection (2) , no
account is to be taken of any time during which—

286.4.a

Parliament is dissolved or prorogued, or

286.4.b

both Houses are adjourned for more than four days.

#### General

##### Financial assistance

###### Financial assistance for resilience and continuity purposes

287

287.1

The Secretary of State may, with the consent of the Treasury, provide
financial assistance to a core fuel sector participant for the purpose of—

287.1.a

maintaining or improving core fuel sector resilience, or

287.1.b

securing or maintaining continuity of supply of core fuels.

287.2

Financial assistance under this section may be given in any form.

287.3

Financial assistance under this section may, in particular, be given by way
of—

287.3.a

grants,

287.3.b

loans,

287.3.c

guarantee or indemnity,

287.3.d

the acquisition of shares or any other interest in, or securities of, a body
corporate,

287.3.e

the acquisition of any undertaking or assets, or

287.3.f

incurring expenditure for the benefit of the person assisted.

287.4

Financial assistance under this section may be given on such terms and
conditions as the Secretary of State considers appropriate (including
provision for repayment, with or without interest).

287.5

The Secretary of State is not authorised by this section to give financial
assistance in the way described in  subsection (3) (d)  without the consent of
the body corporate concerned.

##### Power to amend thresholds

###### Power to amend thresholds

288

288.1

The Secretary of State may by regulations amend or modify any provision
mentioned in  subsection (2)  for the purpose of varying any amount for the
time being specified in that provision.

288.2

The provisions are—

288.2.a

section 269 (7)  (directions to core fuel sector participants);

288.2.b

section 272 (5)  (corresponding powers to make regulations);

288.2.c

section 273 (1)  (power to require information);

288.2.d

section 274 (2) (a)  and (b) (duty to report incidents);

288.2.e

section 276 (1)  (provision of information at specified intervals).

288.3

Regulations under  this section  are subject to the affirmative procedure.

##### Interpretation of 

###### Interpretation of 

289

289.1

In this Part—

      “ company ” means a company within the meaning of section 1 of the
Companies Act 2006;           “ continuity of supply of core fuels ” is to be
interpreted in accordance with  section 268 (7) ;           “ core fuel sector
activity ” has the meaning given by  section 268 ;           “ core fuel
sector participant ” has the meaning given by  section 268 (6) ;           “
core fuel sector resilience ” has the meaning given by  section 268 (5) ;
“ core fuels ” has the meaning given by  section 268 (4) ;           “ crude
oil ” means any liquid hydrocarbon mixture occurring naturally in the earth
whether or not treated to render it suitable for transportation, and includes—
crude oils from which distillate fractions have been removed, and
crude oils to which distillate fractions have been added;                 “
crude oil based fuel ” means any fuel comprised wholly or mainly of crude oil
or substances derived from crude oil;           “ enactment ” includes—
an enactment contained in subordinate legislation (as defined in section 21 of
the Interpretation Act 1978);           an enactment contained in, or in an
instrument made under, a Measure or Act of Senedd Cymru;           an
enactment contained in, or in an instrument made under, an Act of the Scottish
Parliament;           an enactment contained in, or in an instrument made
under, Northern Ireland legislation;           any retained direct EU
legislation;                 “ enforcement undertaking ” has the meaning given
by  section 284 ;           “ oil ” means—         crude oil;           crude
oil based fuels;           components;                 “ the owned facility ”,
in relation to a  Part 12  facility owner, has the meaning given by  section
268 (11) ;           “ Part 12 facility owner ” has the meaning given by
section 268 (11) ;           “ person carrying on core fuel sector activities
” is to be interpreted in accordance with  section 268 (13) ;           “
relevant activities or assets ” is to be interpreted in accordance with
section 268 (10) ;           “ relevant wetstock manager ” has the meaning
given by  section 273 (3) ;           “ renewable transport fuel ” has the
meaning given by section 132 of the Energy Act 2004;           “ terminal ”
means any site for the storage in bulk of oil or renewable transport fuel.

289.2

In this Part references to the “ capacity ” of a business or of a facility or
infrastructure are to be interpreted in accordance with  section 269 (8) .

289.3

References in this Part to a person carrying on business include references to
a person carrying on business in partnership with one or more other persons.

289.4

For the purposes of the definition of “oil” in  subsection (1)  “ component ”
means any substance (whether or not derived from crude oil) of a kind which is
mixed with other substances to produce a crude oil based fuel.

### Offshore wind electricity generation, oil and gas

#### Offshore wind electricity generation

##### Meaning of “relevant offshore wind activity”

290

290.1

In this Chapter, “ relevant offshore wind activity ” means—

290.1.a

the planning, construction, operation or decommissioning of offshore wind
electricity infrastructure, or

290.1.b

the identification of an area for activity within  paragraph (a)  (whether or
not any particular offshore wind electricity infrastructure is in
contemplation).

290.2

In subsection (1), “ offshore wind electricity infrastructure ” means—

290.2.a

a generating station, in the UK marine area, that generates electricity from
wind (an “offshore wind generating station”), or

290.2.b

infrastructure, in the UK marine area, used or intended for use in connection
with—

290.2.b.i

an offshore wind generating station, or

290.2.b.ii

the conveyance of electricity generated by an offshore wind generating
station.

290.3

For the purposes of the reference in  subsection (2) (b) (ii)  to
infrastructure used or intended for use in connection with the conveyance of
electricity generated by an offshore wind generating station, it does not
matter whether the infrastructure is also used or intended for use in
connection with the conveyance of electricity generated from other sources.

##### Strategic compensation for adverse environmental effects

291

291.1

This section applies where a public authority is subject to one or more
environmental compensation obligations in relation to relevant offshore wind
activities.

291.2

“ Environmental compensation obligation ” means—

291.2.a

a statutory duty (however expressed) to secure that measures are taken to
compensate for adverse environmental effects of an activity, or

291.2.b

a statutory condition (however expressed) requiring a public authority, before
granting consent for the doing of an act by a person (“ P ”) in connection
with an activity, to be satisfied that P will take or secure the taking of
measures to compensate for adverse environmental effects of the act.

291.3

The public authority may determine that—

291.3.a

measures taken or secured by the authority in the exercise of any of its
functions, or

291.3.b

measures to be taken or secured by the authority in the exercise of any of its
functions,

are to count towards discharging the environmental compensation obligation or
obligations to which the authority is subject.

291.4

In this Chapter, “ adverse environmental effect ” means—

291.4.a

anything that adversely affects the integrity of any site comprised in the
national site network, or

291.4.b

anything that hinders the achievement of the conservation objectives stated
for a protected marine area.

291.5

The measures referred to in subsection  (3)  may be measures taken at the site
or sites of the activities to which the measures relate or elsewhere.

291.6

In this section—

      “ act ” includes omission;           “ the national site network ” has
the same meaning as in the Conservation of Habitats and Species Regulations
2017 ( S.I. 2017/1012 );           “ protected marine area ” means an area
designated under—         section 116 of the Marine and Coastal Access Act
2009 or section 13 of the Marine Act (Northern Ireland)  2013 (c. 10 (N.I.))
(marine conservation zones), or           section 67(1)(a) of the Marine
(Scotland) Act  2010 (asp 5)  (marine protected areas);                 “
statutory ”, in relation to a duty or condition, means imposed by or under
primary legislation.

291.7

For the purposes of subsection  (3) , a public authority (“ authority A ”)
may, with the consent of another public authority (“ authority B ”), treat
measures taken or secured (or to be taken or secured) by authority B as taken
or secured (or to be taken or secured) by authority A in the exercise of any
of its functions.

291.8

In subsection  (4) (b) , the reference to the conservation objectives stated
for a protected marine area is a reference to the conservation objectives
stated for the area pursuant to (as the case may be) section 117(2)(b) of the
Marine and Coastal Access Act 2009, section 14(2)(b) of the Marine Act
(Northern Ireland) 2013 or section 68(3)(b) of the Marine (Scotland) Act 2010.

##### Marine recovery fund

292

292.1

The Secretary of State may by regulations make provision for the
establishment, operation and management of one or more marine recovery funds.

292.2

A marine recovery fund is a fund—

292.2.a

into which payments may be made in respect of relevant offshore wind
activities, and

292.2.b

out of which payments may be made towards expenditure on measures to
compensate for adverse environmental effects of relevant offshore wind
activities.

292.3

The following provisions of this section are without prejudice to the
generality of subsection  (1) .

292.4

Regulations under this section may make provision—

292.4.a

enabling a determination to be made, by or on behalf of the relevant person,
as to whether (and, if so, the extent to which) a payment into the fund
discharges a compensation condition imposed on another person in connection
with the granting of consent in respect of a relevant offshore wind activity;

292.4.b

for a payment into the fund to be treated as discharging a compensation
condition to the extent (if any) determined by virtue of paragraph  (a) .

292.5

“ Compensation condition ”, in relation to a person, means a condition
requiring the person to take measures to compensate for adverse environmental
effects of a relevant offshore wind activity.

292.6

“Relevant person”, for the purposes of a determination made by virtue of
subsection (4) (a) , means the person who imposed the compensation condition.

292.7

Regulations under this section may make provision—

292.7.a

enabling payments to be made out of the fund towards expenditure described in
subsection  (2) (b) ;

292.7.b

about the persons to whom such a payment may be made;

292.7.c

enabling conditions to be imposed on a person to whom such a payment is made
in connection with the taking of measures described in subsection  (2) (b) .

292.8

Regulations under this section may make provision—

292.8.a

about the recovery of costs incurred in connection with the exercise of
functions conferred by the regulations;

292.8.b

conferring functions, including functions involving the exercise of a
discretion, on the Secretary of State;

292.8.c

for the delegation of functions conferred on the Secretary of State, where the
functions relate to the operation or management of a marine recovery fund.

292.9

Regulations made by virtue of subsection  (8) (c)  may provide that a function
may be delegated—

292.9.a

to a Scottish public authority only if the function relates to the taking or
securing of measures in Scotland;

292.9.b

to a Welsh public authority only if the function relates to the taking or
securing of measures in Wales;

292.9.c

to a Northern Ireland public authority only if the function relates to the
taking or securing of measures in Northern Ireland.

292.10

Regulations made by virtue of subsection  (8) (c)  must provide that the
delegation of a function—

292.10.a

to a Scottish public authority requires the consent of the Scottish Ministers;

292.10.b

to a Welsh public authority requires the consent of the Welsh Ministers;

292.10.c

to a Northern Ireland public authority requires the consent of DAERA.

292.11

Regulations made by virtue of subsection  (8) (c)  must provide that the
delegation of a function—

292.11.a

may be cancelled by the Secretary of State in accordance with the regulations;

292.11.b

does not prevent the Secretary of State from carrying out any function
delegated.

292.12

Before making regulations under this section, the Secretary of State must
consult—

292.12.a

the Scottish Ministers, so far as the regulations relate to relevant offshore
wind activities in Scotland,

292.12.b

the Welsh Ministers, so far as the regulations relate to relevant offshore
wind activities in Wales,

292.12.c

DAERA, so far as the regulations relate to relevant offshore wind activities
in Northern Ireland, and

292.12.d

such other persons as the Secretary of State considers appropriate.

292.13

Regulations under this section are subject to the negative procedure.

##### Assessment of environmental effects etc

293

293.1

The appropriate authority may by regulations make—

293.1.a

provision for and in connection with the assessment of the environmental
effects of relevant offshore wind activities in relation to protected sites;

293.1.b

provision about the taking or securing of measures by a public authority in
compensation for any adverse environmental effects of relevant offshore wind
activities in relation to protected sites (“compensatory measures”).

293.2

The appropriate authority is the Secretary of State, subject to paragraphs
(a)  to  (c) —

293.2.a

the Scottish Ministers are the appropriate authority in relation to relevant
offshore wind activities in the Scottish inshore region;

293.2.b

the Welsh Ministers are the appropriate authority in relation to relevant
offshore wind activities in the Welsh inshore region, subject to subsection
(3)  and other than in relation to qualifying Secretary of State functions;

293.2.c

DAERA is the appropriate authority in relation to relevant offshore wind
activities in the Northern Ireland inshore region, other than in relation to
qualifying Secretary of State functions.

293.3

In subsection  (2) (b) , “ relevant offshore wind activity ” does not include
an activity within  section 290 (1) (a)  relating to a generating station that
has a capacity such that the construction or extension of the generating
station would be a nationally significant infrastructure project (within the
meaning given by sections 14 and 15 of the Planning Act 2008).

293.4

The provision that may be made by virtue of subsection  (1)  includes
provision—

293.4.a

specifying the matters to be dealt with by an assessment;

293.4.b

about the procedure to be followed in carrying out an assessment, including
when an assessment must be carried out and matters that must be taken into
account;

293.4.c

specifying the person by whom an assessment, or a specified kind of
assessment, must be carried out;

293.4.d

requiring an assessment to be carried out by a specified person in specified
circumstances;

293.4.e

authorising or requiring the supply of information (including information the
supply of which would not otherwise be permitted) for the purposes of an
assessment;

293.4.f

enabling a person carrying out an assessment (an “assessor”) to require a
person who has applied for consent to provide the assessor with assistance for
the purposes of or in connection with the assessment;

293.4.g

prohibiting the granting of consent in respect of an activity where an
assessment has not been carried out in accordance with the regulations;

293.4.h

about when or how compensatory measures must or may be provided;

293.4.i

disapplying or otherwise modifying, whether generally or in specified
circumstances or subject to specified conditions, any of the provisions listed
in subsection  (5) (a) ,  (b) ,  (c)  or  (d)  (as the case may be).

293.5

The provisions referred to in subsection  (4) (i)  are—

293.5.a

in the case of regulations made by the Secretary of State—

293.5.a.i

section 126 of the Marine and Coastal Access Act 2009;

293.5.a.ii

regulations 9 and 10 and Part 6 of the Conservation of Habitats and Species
Regulations 2017 ( S.I. 2017/1012 );

293.5.a.iii

regulations 6, 27, 28 and 30 to 37 of the Conservation of Offshore Marine
Habitats and Species Regulations 2017 ( S.I. 2017/1013 );

293.5.a.iv

any other provision that relates to the taking or securing of compensatory
measures, where the provision is made by or under an Act;

293.5.b

in the case of regulations made by the Scottish Ministers—

293.5.b.i

section 83 of the Marine (Scotland) Act  2010 (asp 5) ;

293.5.b.ii

regulations 3 and 3A and Part 4 of the Conservation (Natural Habitats, &c.)
Regulations 1994 ( S.I. 1994/2716 );

293.5.b.iii

regulations 9 and 10 and Part 6 of the Conservation of Habitats and Species
Regulations 2017 ( S.I. 2017/1012 );

293.5.b.iv

any other provision that relates to the taking or securing of compensatory
