8.3.b.t

in relation to a licence granted under  section 7  of the Energy Act 2023, the
objectives and duties of the Gas and Electricity Markets Authority under
section 1  of that Act.

8.4

In subsection (6)—

8.4.a

for “or section 6” substitute  “, section 6” ;

8.4.b

before “would” insert  “or  section 7  of the Energy Act 2023” .

##### Enterprise and Regulatory Reform Act 2013

9

In Schedule 4 to the Enterprise and Regulatory Reform Act 2013, in paragraph
35(3) (membership of CMA panel), in the definition of “specialist utility
functions”, after paragraph (b) insert—

9.ba

an appeal under  section 20  of the Energy Act 2023;

.

  Carbon dioxide storage licences: licence provisions

Section 103

  In the Storage of Carbon Dioxide (Licensing etc.) Regulations 2010 ( S.I.
2010/2221 ), in Schedule 1 (provisions to be included in a licence), after
paragraph 5 insert—     Change in control of licence holder   6       1
This paragraph applies if—     a     the licence holder is a company, or
b     where two or more persons are joint licence holders, any of those
persons is a company,       and references in this paragraph to a company are
to such a company.         2     A change in control of a company is not
permitted without the consent of the authority.         3     There is a
“change in control” of a company if a person takes control of the company, not
having previously been a person who controlled the company.         4     If a
change in control of a company is contemplated, the company must apply in
writing to the authority for consent at least three months before the date on
which it is proposed that the change would occur (if consent were given).
5     The authority may—     a     consent to the change in control
unconditionally,         b     consent to the change in control subject to
conditions, or         c     refuse consent to the change in control.
6     If the authority proposes to grant consent subject to any condition or
to refuse consent, the authority must, before making a final decision—     a
give the company an opportunity to make representations, and         b
consider any representations that are made.             7     The general rule
is that the authority must decide an application within three months of
receiving it, but the authority may delay its decision by notifying the
interested parties in writing.         8     Conditions as mentioned in sub-
paragraph (5)(b) may be imposed on the person taking control of the company
(as well as on the company), and may include—     a     conditions relating to
the arrangements for the change in control, including the date by which it
must occur,         b     conditions relating to the performance of activities
permitted by the licence, and         c     financial conditions.
9     The authority’s decision on the application, and any conditions as
mentioned in sub-paragraph (5)(b), must be notified in writing to the
interested parties.         10     In this paragraph “ the interested parties
” means—     a     the company,         b     the person who (if consent were
granted) would take control of the company, and         c     if the company
is a joint licence holder with another person or other persons, that other
person or those other persons.             11     For the purposes of this
paragraph, “control” of a company is to be construed in accordance with
sections 450(2) to (4) and 451(1) to (5) of the Corporation Tax Act 2010, but
read as if—     a     for the words “the greater part” wherever they occur in
section 450(3), there were substituted  “one-third or more” ,         b     in
section 451(4) and (5), for “may” there were substituted  “must” , and
c     in section 451(4) and (5), any reference to an associate of a person
included only—     i     a relative (as defined in section 448(2) of that Act)
of the person,         ii     a partner of the person, and         iii     a
trustee of a settlement (as defined in section 620 of the Income Tax (Trading
and Other Income) Act 2005) of which the person is a beneficiary.
Revocation of licence re change in control   7       1     This paragraph
applies in connection with a change in control of a licence holder which is a
company (see paragraph 6).         2     In the event of—     a     any breach
or non-observance by the company of any of the terms of paragraph 6,         b
any breach of a condition (imposed in accordance with paragraph 6) subject to
which the authority gave its consent to a change in control of the company, or
c     any failure to provide full and accurate information in response to a
notice given by the authority to the company under section 29A,       the
authority may, by giving the company and any joint licence holders notice in
writing, revoke the licence with effect from the date specified in the notice.
Partial revocation of licence re change in control   8       1     This
paragraph applies if two or more persons are joint licence holders and any of
them is a company.         2     If an event mentioned in paragraph 7(2)(a),
(b) or (c) occurs in connection with a change in control of the company, the
authority may exercise the power in paragraph 7 to revoke the licence in so
far as it applies to that company (without revoking it in so far as it applies
to the other person or persons who are joint licence holders).

  Permitted disclosures of material obtained by OGA

Section 113

##### Disclosure by OGA to specified persons

1

1.1

Section  113  does not prohibit a disclosure of protected material by the OGA
which—

1.1.a

is made to a person mentioned in column 1 of the table below,

1.1.b

is made for the purpose of facilitating the carrying out of that person’s
functions, and

1.1.c

is a disclosure of protected material obtained by the OGA under a provision
mentioned in the corresponding entry of column 2 of the table.

    Column 1 Column 2   A Minister of the Crown Section 112  or  124 His
Majesty’s Revenue and Customs Section 112  or  124 The Competition and Markets
Authority Section 112  or  124 The Scottish Ministers Section 112 The Welsh
Ministers Section 112 A Northern Ireland Department Section 112 The Office for
Budget Responsibility Section 112 An enforcing authority Section 112  or  124
The Statistics Board Section 112  or  124 The GEMA Section 112  or  124 The
Crown Estate Section 112 A manager of the Crown Estate in Scotland Section 112

1.2

In the table—

      “ enforcing authority ” has the same meaning as in Part 1 of the Health
and Safety at Work etc Act 1974 (see section 18(7)(a) of that Act);
“ manager of the Crown Estate in Scotland ” means a person who for the time
being is discharging functions in relation to the management of any property,
rights or interests to which section 90B(5) of the Scotland Act 1998 applies;
“ Minister of the Crown ” has the same meaning as in the Ministers of the
Crown Act 1975.

1.3

Section 113  does not prohibit a disclosure of protected material by the OGA
which—

1.3.a

is a disclosure of protected material obtained by it under  section 112 ,

1.3.b

is made to the Natural Environment Research Council, or any other similar body
carrying on geological activities, and

1.3.c

is made for the purpose of enabling the body to prepare and publish reports
and surveys of a general nature using information derived from the protected
material.

1.4

A person to whom protected material is disclosed by virtue of  sub-paragraph
(1)  or  (3)  may use the protected material only for the purpose mentioned in
sub-paragraph (1) (b)  or  (3) (c)  (as the case may be).

1.5

Section 113  does not prohibit a person mentioned in  sub-paragraph (4)  from
disclosing the protected material so far as necessary for the purpose
mentioned in that sub-paragraph.

1.6

The Secretary of State may by regulations amend the table in  sub-paragraph
(1) —

1.6.a

to remove a person from column 1,

1.6.b

to add to column 1 a person to whom  sub-paragraph (7)  applies, or

1.6.c

to add, remove or change entries in column 2.

1.7

This sub-paragraph applies to—

1.7.a

persons holding office under the Crown;

1.7.b

persons in the service or employment of the Crown;

1.7.c

persons acting on behalf of the Crown;

1.7.d

government departments;

1.7.e

publicly owned companies as defined in section 6 of the Freedom of Information
Act 2000.

1.8

Regulations under  sub-paragraph (6)  are subject to the affirmative
procedure.

##### Disclosure required for returns and reports prepared by OGA

2

2.1

Section 113  does not prohibit the OGA from using protected material obtained
by the OGA under  section 112  for the purpose of—

2.1.a

preparing such returns and reports as may be required under obligations
imposed by or under any Act;

2.1.b

preparing and publishing reports and surveys of a general nature using
information derived from the protected material.

2.2

Section 113  does not prohibit the OGA from disclosing protected material so
far as necessary for those purposes.

##### Disclosure in exercise of certain OGA powers

3

Section 113  does not prohibit a disclosure of protected material if it is
made in the exercise of the OGA’s powers under  section 121  (publication of
details of sanctions).

##### Disclosure after specified period

4

4.1

Section 113  does not prohibit protected material obtained by the OGA under
section 112  from being—

4.1.a

published, or

4.1.b

made available to the public (where the protected material includes samples),

by the OGA or a subsequent holder at such time as may be specified in
regulations made by the Secretary of State.

4.2

Regulations under  sub-paragraph (1)  may include provision permitting
protected material to be published, or made available to the public,
immediately after it is provided to a person.

4.3

Before making regulations under  sub-paragraph (1) , the Secretary of State
must consult such persons as the Secretary of State considers appropriate.

4.4

Sub-paragraph  (3)  does not apply if the Secretary of State is satisfied that
consultation is unnecessary having regard to consultation carried out by the
OGA in relation to what time should be specified in regulations under  sub-
paragraph (1) .

4.5

Regulations under  sub-paragraph (1)  are subject to the affirmative
procedure.

4.6

In determining the time to be specified in respect of protected material in
regulations under  sub-paragraph (1) , the Secretary of State must have regard
to the following factors—

4.6.a

whether the specified time will allow owners of protected material a
reasonable period of time to satisfy the main purpose for which they acquired
or created the material;

4.6.b

any potential benefits to the carbon storage industry of protected material
being published or made available at the specified time;

4.6.c

any potential risk that the specified time may discourage persons from
acquiring or creating carbon storage information or carbon storage samples;

4.6.d

any other factors the Secretary of State considers relevant.

4.7

In balancing the factors mentioned in  sub-paragraph (6) (a)  to  (d) , the
Secretary of State must take into account the principal objectives of the
Secretary of State set out in  section 1 (1) .

4.8

For the purposes of  sub-paragraph (6) (a) , the owner of protected material
is the person by whom, or on whose behalf, the protected material was provided
to the OGA under  section 112 .

##### Disclosure with appropriate consent

5

5.1

Section 113  does not prohibit a disclosure of protected material if it is
made with the appropriate consent.

5.2

For this purpose a disclosure is made with the appropriate consent if—

5.2.a

in the case of disclosure by the OGA, the original owner consents to the
disclosure;

5.2.b

in the case of disclosure by a subsequent holder—

5.2.b.i

the OGA consents to the disclosure, and

5.2.b.ii

where the protected material in question was provided to the OGA under
section 112 , the OGA confirms that the original owner of the material also
consents to the disclosure.

5.3

For the purposes of  sub-paragraph (2) , the original owner of protected
material provided to the OGA is the person by whom, or on whose behalf, the
protected material was so provided.

##### Disclosure required by legislation

6

Section 113  does not prohibit a disclosure of protected material required by
virtue of an obligation imposed by or under this or any other Act.

##### Disclosure for purpose of proceedings

7

7.1

Section 113  does not prohibit a disclosure of protected material by the OGA
for the purposes of, or in connection with—

7.1.a

civil proceedings, or

7.1.b

arbitration proceedings.

7.2

Section 113  does not prohibit a disclosure of protected material by the OGA
for the purposes of, or in connection with—

7.2.a

the investigation or prosecution of criminal offences, or

7.2.b

the prevention of criminal activity.

  Carbon storage information and samples: appeals

Section 125

##### Appeals against decisions relating to information and samples

###### Appeals in relation to information and samples plans

1

1.1

A person affected by any decision of the OGA to which effect is given by the
preparation of an information and samples plan may appeal against it to the
Tribunal—

1.1.a

on the ground that the decision was not within the powers of the OGA, or

1.1.b

on the ground that the plan is unreasonable.

1.2

On an appeal under this paragraph the Tribunal may—

1.2.a

affirm, vary or quash the decision under appeal,

1.2.b

remit the decision under appeal to the OGA for reconsideration with such
directions (if any) as the Tribunal considers appropriate, or

1.2.c

substitute its own decision for the decision under appeal.

###### Appeals against notices requiring provision of information or samples

2

2.1

A person affected by any decision of the OGA to which effect is given by the
giving of a notice requiring the provision of information or samples under
section 112  may appeal against it to the Tribunal—

2.1.a

on the ground that the decision was not within the powers of the OGA, or

2.1.b

on the ground that the length of time given to comply with the notice is
unreasonable.

2.2

On an appeal under this paragraph the Tribunal may—

2.2.a

affirm, vary or quash the decision under appeal,

2.2.b

remit the decision under appeal to the OGA for reconsideration with such
directions (if any) as the Tribunal considers appropriate, or

2.2.c

substitute its own decision for the decision under appeal.

##### Appeals relating to enforcement of sanctionable requirements

###### Appeals in relation to sanction notices

3

3.1

Where a sanction notice is given under  section 115  in respect of a failure
to comply with a sanctionable requirement, an appeal may be made—

3.1.a

under  paragraph 4  (on the ground that there was no such failure to comply);

3.1.b

under  paragraph 5  (against the sanction imposed by the notice).

3.2

Where an appeal is made in relation to a sanction notice, the notice ceases to
have effect until a decision is made by the Tribunal to confirm, vary or
cancel the notice.

3.3

Where, on an appeal made in relation to a sanction notice—

3.3.a

the Tribunal makes a decision to confirm or vary the notice, and

3.3.b

an appeal is or may be made in relation to that decision,

the Tribunal, or the Upper Tribunal, may further suspend the effect of the
notice pending a decision which disposes of proceedings on such an appeal.

###### Appeals against finding of failure to comply

4

4.1

An appeal may be made to the Tribunal by the person, or by any of the persons,
to whom a sanction notice is given in respect of a failure to comply with a
sanctionable requirement, on the grounds that the person, or persons, did not
fail to comply with the requirement.

4.2

On an appeal under this paragraph, the Tribunal may confirm or cancel the
sanction notice.

4.3

Where sanction notices are given on more than one occasion in respect of the
same failure to comply with a sanctionable requirement—

4.3.a

an appeal under this paragraph may be made only in relation to the sanction
notice, or any of the sanction notices, given on the first of those occasions,
and

4.3.b

appeals in relation to sanction notices given on subsequent occasions in
respect of that failure to comply may be made only under  paragraph 5 .

###### Appeals against sanction imposed

5

5.1

Where a sanction notice is given in respect of a failure to comply with a
sanctionable requirement, a person mentioned in sub- paragraph (2) may appeal
to the Tribunal against any of the decisions of the OGA mentioned in  sub-
paragraph (3)  (as to the sanction imposed by the notice) on the grounds
mentioned in  sub-paragraph (4) .

5.2

The persons who may appeal are—

5.2.a

the person, or any of the persons, to whom the notice was given, and

5.2.b

in the case of an operator removal notice under  section 119 , the licensee
under whose carbon storage licence the exploration operator operates.

5.3

The decisions against which an appeal may be made are—

5.3.a

where an enforcement notice has been given, the decision as to—

5.3.a.i

the measures that are required to be taken for the purposes of compliance with
the sanctionable requirement, or

5.3.a.ii

the period for compliance with the sanctionable requirement;

5.3.b

where a financial penalty notice has been given, the decision—

5.3.b.i

to impose a financial penalty, or

5.3.b.ii

as to the amount of the financial penalty imposed;

5.3.c

where a revocation notice has been given, the decision to terminate the carbon
storage licence or to revoke the storage permit;

5.3.d

where an operator removal notice has been given, the decision to require the
removal of the exploration operator.

5.4

The grounds on which an appeal may be made are that the decision of the OGA—

5.4.a

was unreasonable, or

5.4.b

was not within the powers of the OGA.

5.5

On an appeal under this paragraph against a decision made in relation to an
enforcement notice, the Tribunal may—

5.5.a

confirm or quash the decision, in the case of a decision mentioned in  sub-
paragraph (3) (a) (i)  (remedial action), or

5.5.b

confirm or vary the decision, in the case of a decision mentioned in  sub-
paragraph (3) (a) (ii)  (period for compliance),

and confirm, vary or cancel the enforcement notice accordingly.

5.6

On an appeal under this paragraph against a decision made in relation to a
financial penalty notice, the Tribunal may—

5.6.a

confirm or quash the decision, in the case of a decision mentioned in  sub-
paragraph (3) (b) (i)  (imposition of penalty), or

5.6.b

confirm or vary the decision, in the case of a decision mentioned in  sub-
paragraph (3) (b) (ii)  (amount of penalty),

and confirm, vary or cancel the financial penalty notice accordingly.

5.7

The Tribunal must have regard to any guidance issued by the OGA under  section
117 (6) (a)  when deciding whether to confirm or vary a decision as to the
amount of a financial penalty under  sub-paragraph (6) (b) .

5.8

On an appeal under this paragraph against a decision to terminate a carbon
storage licence, to revoke a storage permit or to require the removal of an
exploration operator the Tribunal may—

5.8.a

confirm the decision,

5.8.b

vary the decision by changing the revocation date or the removal date, as the
case may be, or

5.8.c

quash the decision,

and confirm, vary or cancel the sanction notice in question accordingly.

5.9

Where a decision is quashed under  sub-paragraph (5) (a) ,  (6) (a)  or  (8) ,
the Tribunal may remit the decision to the OGA for reconsideration with such
directions (if any) as the Tribunal considers appropriate.

###### Appeals against information requirements

6

6.1

A person to whom a notice is given under  section 124  may appeal against it
to the Tribunal on the grounds that—

6.1.a

the giving of the notice is not within the powers of the OGA, or

6.1.b

the length of time given to comply with the notice is unreasonable.

6.2

On an appeal under this paragraph the Tribunal may—

6.2.a

confirm, vary or cancel the notice, or

6.2.b

remit the matter under appeal to the OGA for reconsideration with such
directions (if any) as the Tribunal considers appropriate.

Independent System Operator and Planner: transfers

Section 174

##### Transfer schemes

###### Power to make a transfer scheme

1

1.1

The Secretary of State may make one or more schemes for the transfer of
designated property, rights or liabilities from one person to another person—

1.1.a

in preparation for or in connection with the designation of a person under
section 162 (1) , or

1.1.b

for the purpose of enabling the ISOP to carry out any of its functions.

1.2

The Secretary of State may, during the period of 7 years beginning with the
day on which this Act is passed, make one or more schemes for the transfer of
designated property, rights or liabilities from one person to another person
in connection with the operation or management of—

1.2.a

a document maintained in accordance with the conditions of a relevant licence,
or

1.2.b

an agreement that gives effect to a document so maintained.

1.3

In this Schedule

1.3.a

“ transfer scheme ” means a scheme under either or both of  sub-paragraphs (1)
and  (2) ;

1.3.b

“ transferor ”, in relation to a transfer scheme, means a person from whom
property, rights or liabilities are or are to be transferred under the scheme;

1.3.c

“ transferee ”, in relation to a transfer scheme, means a person to whom
property, rights or liabilities are or are to be transferred under the scheme.

1.4

In  this Part  of this Schedule—

1.4.a

“ designated ”, in relation to a transfer scheme, means specified in or
determined in accordance with the scheme;

1.4.b

“ the TUPE regulations ” means the Transfer of Undertakings (Protection of
Employment) Regulations 2006 ( S.I. 2006/246 );

1.4.c

references to property are to property situated in the United Kingdom or
elsewhere;

1.4.d

references to the transfer of property include the grant of a lease;

1.4.e

references to rights and liabilities—

1.4.e.i

are references to rights and liabilities of any kind, arising (in any way or
at any time) under the law of a part of Great Britain or of a place outside
Great Britain;

1.4.e.ii

include rights and liabilities arising under or by virtue of an enactment.

###### Consultation

2

2.1

Before making a transfer scheme, the Secretary of State must consult—

2.1.a

the transferor (or, if there is more than one transferor, the transferors),
and

2.1.b

such other persons as the Secretary of State considers appropriate.

2.2

Sub-paragraph (1)  may be satisfied by consultation before the passing of this
Act (as well as by consultation after that time).

###### Transfer of property, rights and liabilities

3

3.1

The transfer of designated property, rights and liabilities under a transfer
scheme takes effect on the date (or dates) specified in or determined in
accordance with the scheme.

3.2

Sub-paragraph (1)  has effect notwithstanding any provision (whether under an
enactment or agreement or otherwise) that would otherwise prevent or restrict
the transfer.

3.3

The things that may be transferred under a transfer scheme include—

3.3.a

rights, powers, duties and liabilities under or in connection with a contract
of employment (see paragraph  4 );

3.3.b

property, rights and liabilities that could not otherwise be transferred;

3.3.c

property acquired, and rights and liabilities arising, after the making of the
scheme;

3.3.d

criminal liabilities.

4

4.1

This paragraph applies where, under a transfer scheme, an employee to whom the
scheme applies becomes an employee of a transferee.

4.2

The transfer scheme may apply to—

4.2.a

all persons who are employees of a transferor,

4.2.b

such descriptions of a transferor’s employees as the scheme may specify, or

4.2.c

such employees of a transferor as the scheme may specify.

4.3

The transfer scheme may include provision—

4.3.a

that has the same or similar effect as the TUPE regulations (so far as those
regulations do not apply to any extent in relation to the transfer);

4.3.b

about the pension entitlements of the employee enjoyed immediately before the
transfer.

4.4

The transfer scheme must contain provision enabling an employee to whom the
scheme applies to object to the transfer before the relevant time, including
provision as to how such an objection is to be made and as to the consequences
of it.

4.5

The transfer scheme may provide that a person who is assigned to work for a
transferor (whether on secondment or otherwise and whether or not on a full-
time basis), but who does not have a contract of employment with the
transferor, is to be treated for the purposes of any provision of the scheme
as an employee of the transferor.

4.6

The transfer scheme may provide that a collective agreement that, immediately
before the relevant time, had effect in relation to an employee’s employment
with a transferor is to have effect on and after the relevant time in relation
to the employee’s employment with a transferee.

4.7

In this paragraph—

“ collective agreement ” has the same meaning as in the Trade Union and Labour
Relations (Consolidation) Act 1992 (see section 178(1) of that Act); “
employee ” has the same meaning as in the TUPE regulations (see regulation
2(1) of the regulations); “ the relevant time ” means the time at which the
transfer of the person’s employment takes effect in accordance with the
transfer scheme.

5

5.1

A transfer scheme may make provision requiring a transferor to provide such
co-operation to a transferee as the transferee may reasonably require in
connection with the implementation of the scheme.

5.2

The co-operation that may be required by virtue of sub-paragraph  (1)
includes, in particular, co-operation in relation to—

5.2.a

the provision of information;

5.2.b

consultation with representatives of employees transferred by the scheme.

6

6.1

A transfer scheme may make supplementary, incidental, transitional or
consequential provision and may in particular—

6.1.a

create rights, or impose liabilities, in relation to property, rights or
liabilities transferred;

6.1.b

make provision about the continuing effect of things done by a transferor in
respect of anything transferred;

6.1.c

make provision about the continuation of things (including legal proceedings)
in the process of being done by, on behalf of, or in relation to, a transferor
in respect of anything transferred;

6.1.d

make provision for references to a transferor in any instrument or other
document in respect of anything transferred to be treated as references to the
transferee;

6.1.e

prevent a right of pre-emption, right of reverter, right of forfeiture, right
to compensation or other similar right from arising or becoming exercisable as
a result of the transfer;

6.1.f

dispense with any formality in relation to the transfer of anything by the
scheme;

6.1.g

make provision for the shared ownership or use of property;

6.1.h

require a transferor, an associate of a transferor, or a transferee, to enter
into any agreement of any kind, or for a purpose, specified in or determined
in accordance with the scheme.

6.2

Sub-paragraph  (1) (d)  does not apply to references in—

6.2.a

primary legislation,

6.2.b

subordinate legislation within the meaning of the Interpretation Act 1978 (see
section 21(1) of that Act), or

6.2.c

an instrument made under an Act of the Scottish Parliament, an Act or Measure
of Senedd Cymru, or Northern Ireland legislation.

6.3

Any requirement imposed on a person by a transfer scheme is enforceable by the
Secretary of State in civil proceedings—

6.3.a

for an injunction,

6.3.b

for specific performance of a statutory duty under section 45 of the Court of
Session Act 1988, or

6.3.c

for any other appropriate remedy or relief.

6.4

A certificate issued by the Secretary of State to the effect that any
property, interest, right or liability transferred in accordance with a
transfer scheme to a person specified in the certificate at a time so
specified is conclusive evidence of the matters so specified.

6.5

In  this paragraph —

“ associate ” has the meaning given by section 1152 of the Companies Act 2006;
“ primary legislation ” means— an Act, an Act of the Scottish Parliament, an
Act or Measure of Senedd Cymru, or Northern Ireland legislation.

7

A transfer scheme may—

7.a

make different provision for different purposes;

7.b

make provision subject to exceptions.

###### Compensation

8

8.1

A transfer scheme may provide for a transferor to be entitled to compensation
from the Secretary of State, in accordance with provision made by or under the
scheme, to the extent that the scheme makes provision—

8.1.a

in preparation for or in connection with the first designation of a person
under  section 162 (1) , or

8.1.b

for the purpose of facilitating the carrying on by the ISOP of any of its
functions.

8.2

Where a transferor is entitled to compensation by virtue of  sub-paragraph (1)
, the amount of compensation is to be the amount—

8.2.a

agreed by the Secretary of State and the transferor, or

8.2.b

in the absence of such agreement, determined by an independent valuer.

8.3

For the purposes of sub-paragraph  (2)  an independent valuer must be
appointed—

8.3.a

by the Secretary of State and the transferor, or

8.3.b

in the absence of such agreement, by the Secretary of State on behalf of both
the Secretary of State and the transferor.

8.4

The Secretary of State may by regulations make provision—

8.4.a

for determining when there is an absence of agreement for the purposes of
sub-paragraph (2) (b)  or  (3) (b) ;

8.4.b

about the procedure to be followed by an independent valuer in making a
determination for the purposes of  sub-paragraph (2) (b)  (“a compensation
determination”);

8.4.c

specifying matters to which an independent valuer must have regard, or
assumptions that an independent valuer must apply, in making a compensation
determination;

8.4.d

for an independent valuer to require the Secretary of State or the transferor
to provide such information to the independent valuer as the independent
valuer reasonably requires for the purposes of making a compensation
determination;

8.4.e

for an independent valuer’s determination to be binding on the Secretary of
State and the transferor for the period specified in or determined under the
regulations;

8.4.f

about remuneration and expenses of an independent valuer;

8.4.g

about enforcement of requirements imposed by the regulations.

8.5

Regulations under sub-paragraph  (4)  may confer a discretion on a person.

###### Taxation

9

9.1

The Treasury may by regulations make provision varying the way in which a
relevant tax has effect in relation to—

9.1.a

anything transferred, acquired or disposed of under a transfer scheme, or

9.1.b

anything done for the purposes of, or in relation to, a transfer under a
transfer scheme.

9.2

The provision that may be made under  sub-paragraph (1) (a)  includes, in
particular, provision for—

9.2.a

a tax provision not to apply, or to apply with modifications, in relation to
anything transferred;

9.2.b

anything transferred to be treated in a specified way for the purposes of a
tax provision;

9.2.c

the Secretary of State to be required or permitted to determine, or to specify
the method for determining, anything that needs to be determined for the
purposes of any tax provision so far as relating to anything transferred.

9.3

The provision that may be made under  sub-paragraph (1) (b)  includes, in
particular, provision for—

9.3.a

a tax provision not to apply, or to apply with modifications, in relation to
anything done for the purposes of, or in relation to, the transfer;

9.3.b

anything done for the purposes of, or in relation to, the transfer to have or
not have a specified consequence or be treated in a specified way;

9.3.c

the Secretary of State to be required or permitted to determine, or to specify
the method for determining, anything that needs to be determined for the
purposes of any tax provision so far as relating to anything done for the
purposes of, or in relation to, the transfer.

9.4

A statutory instrument containing regulations under this paragraph is subject
to annulment in pursuance of a resolution of the House of Commons.

9.5

In this paragraph—

“ relevant tax ” means income tax, corporation tax, capital gains tax, stamp
duty, stamp duty reserve tax, stamp duty land tax or value added tax; “ tax
provision ” means any provision— about a relevant tax, and made by an
enactment.

###### Power to amend transfer scheme

10

10.1

The Secretary of State may amend a transfer scheme if the Secretary of State
considers that the amendment is appropriate—

10.1.a

in preparation for or in connection with the designation of a person under
section 162 (1) ,

10.1.b

for the purpose of enabling the ISOP to carry out any of its functions, or

10.1.c

for the purpose of enabling a transferor to carry out any of its functions.

10.2

The power under  sub-paragraph (1)  is not exercisable in relation to a
transfer scheme after the end of the period of 12 months beginning with the
day on which the scheme takes effect.

10.3

Paragraphs  2  to  7  apply in relation to the amendment of a transfer scheme
as they apply in relation to a transfer scheme.

10.4

A transfer scheme may provide for a transferor or transferee under the scheme
to be entitled to compensation in consequence of the amendment of the scheme.

10.5

Paragraph  8 (2)  to  (5)  applies (with any necessary modifications) in
relation to an entitlement to compensation under  sub-paragraph (4)  as it
applies in relation to an entitlement to compensation under  paragraph 8 (1) .

###### National Security and Investment Act 2021

11

The making of a transfer scheme is not a trigger event for the purposes of the
National Security and Investment Act 2021.

##### Other provision about transfers and designation

###### Provision of information or assistance

12

12.1

The Secretary of State may direct a person within  sub-paragraph (2)  to
provide the Secretary of State with such specified information or assistance
as the Secretary of State may reasonably require—

12.1.a

in preparation for or in connection with the designation of a person under
section 162 (1) , or

12.1.b

in connection with the making of a transfer scheme.

12.2

A person is within this sub-paragraph if—

12.2.a

property, rights or liabilities are likely to be transferred from or to the
person by a transfer scheme, or

12.2.b

the person is a body corporate that is likely to be transferred under a
transfer scheme.

12.3

The Secretary of State may direct a person (other than a person within sub-
paragraph  (2) ) to provide the Secretary of State with such specified
information or assistance as the Secretary of State may reasonably require in
preparation for or in connection with the designation of a person under
section 162 (1) .

12.4

A direction under  sub-paragraph (1)  or  (3)  must—

12.4.a

be in writing, and

12.4.b

specify the sub-paragraph under which it is given.

12.5

The power to give a direction under  sub-paragraph (3)  ceases to be
exercisable—

12.5.a

at the end of the period of 3 years beginning with the time from which the
first designation under  section 162 (1)  has effect, or

12.5.b

if at any time before the end of that period a transfer scheme is made under
paragraph  1 (1) , at the end of the period of 3 years beginning with the date
(or, if there is more than one, the first date) from which the transfer of
property, rights or liabilities under the scheme takes effect.

12.6

A person to whom a direction is given under  sub-paragraph (1)  or  (3)  must,
so far as reasonably practicable, provide the Secretary of State with the
specified information or assistance—

12.6.a

within the specified period, and

12.6.b

in the specified form and manner.

12.7

A direction under  sub-paragraph (1)  or  (3)  is enforceable by the Secretary
of State in civil proceedings—

12.7.a

for an injunction,

12.7.b

for specific performance of a statutory duty under section 45 of the Court of
Session Act 1988, or

12.7.c

for any other appropriate remedy or relief.

12.8

The Secretary of State—

12.8.a

must reimburse a person in respect of costs reasonably incurred by the person
in complying with a direction under  sub-paragraph (1)  or  (3) ;

12.8.b

may reimburse a person in respect of costs reasonably incurred by the person
in complying with a request (whether made before or after the day on which
this Act is passed) to provide the Secretary of State with information
reasonably required by the Secretary of State for a purpose mentioned in sub-
paragraph  (1) (a)  or  (b) .

12.9

In this paragraph—

“ assistance ” includes assistance provided in a country or territory other
than the United Kingdom; “ information ” includes documents; “ specified ”
means specified in the direction.

###### Co-operation

13

13.1

A person within  sub-paragraph (2)  must co-operate with, and so far as
practicable must not take any step that may reasonably be expected to impede,
the Secretary of State in relation to the doing of anything by the Secretary
of State—

13.1.a

in preparation for or in connection with the first designation of a person
under  section 162 (1) , or

13.1.b

in connection with the making of a transfer scheme.

13.2

The persons within this sub-paragraph are—

13.2.a

National Grid plc and its associates (within the meaning of section 1152 of
the Companies Act 2006);

13.2.b

any person who, at any time during the period mentioned in sub-paragraph  (3)
, has acquired property, rights or liabilities from a person within  paragraph
(a)  (whether or not as a result of a transfer scheme under  paragraph 1 ).

13.3

The period mentioned in sub-paragraph  (2) (b)  is the period beginning on 20
July 2021 and ending with the first designation of a person under  section 162
(1) .

###### Reimbursement and compensation: further provision

14

14.1

The Secretary of State may reimburse a person in respect of expenditure
reasonably incurred by the person—

14.1.a

in preparation for or in connection with the designation of a person under
section 162 (1) , or

14.1.b

in connection with the making of a transfer scheme.

14.2

The Secretary of State may make regulations providing for the payment of
compensation by the Secretary of State to a person (other than the transferor
in relation to a transfer scheme) who has suffered loss or damage in
consequence of anything done by the Secretary of State in preparation for or
in connection with the designation of a person under  section 162 (1) .

Independent System Operator and Planner: pensions

Section 175

##### Introductory

1

1.1

In this Schedule—

“ active member ” has the same meaning as in section 124(1) of the Pensions
Act 1995; “ associate ” has the same meaning as in section 1152 of the
Companies Act 2006; “ member ” has the same meaning as in section 124(1) of
the Pensions Act 1995; “ prescribed ” means prescribed by regulations made by
the Secretary of State; “ qualifying accrued rights ” means— any right which,
at the relevant time, has accrued to or in respect of a qualifying member of a
qualifying pension scheme to future benefits under the scheme, any entitlement
under a qualifying pension scheme to the present payment of a pension or other
benefit that a qualifying member of the scheme has at the relevant time, or
any entitlement to benefits, or rights to future benefits, under a qualifying
pension scheme that a person who has survived a qualifying member of the
scheme has at the relevant time in respect of the member; “ qualifying member
”, in relation to a qualifying pension scheme, means a person who is or has
been a member of the scheme; “ qualifying pension scheme ” means a pension
scheme that provides for the payment of pensions or other benefits to or in
respect of employees or former employees of— a transferor in relation to a
transfer scheme under paragraph  1  of  Schedule 9 , or an associate of such a
transferor; “ the relevant time ” means the time immediately before the
prescribed date (which may be before the passing of this Act).

1.2

For the purposes of the definition of “qualifying accrued rights” in sub-
paragraph  (1) —

1.2.a

references to pensions or other benefits (including future benefits) include
money purchase benefits;

1.2.b

references to a right include a pension credit right.

1.3

In the event that a section of a qualifying pension scheme is constituted as a
separate pension scheme the members of which consist of or include persons who
are qualifying members of the qualifying pension scheme, any reference in this
Schedule to the qualifying pension scheme includes a reference to that
separate pension scheme.

##### Participation in qualifying pension schemes and transfer of assets and rights

2

2.1

The Secretary of State may by regulations make such pensions provision as the
Secretary of State considers appropriate—

2.1.a

in preparation for or in connection with the designation of a person under
section 162 (1) , or

2.1.b

otherwise in connection with the making of a transfer scheme under paragraph
1  of  Schedule 9 .

2.2

“ Pensions provision ” means provision in connection with a qualifying pension
scheme, including provision for—

2.2.a

enabling an entity to which  sub-paragraph (3)  applies to participate in the
scheme;

2.2.b

the division of the scheme into different sections;

2.2.c

the participation in the different sections of different persons (including
entities to which  sub-paragraph (3)  applies);

2.2.d

the allocation of assets, rights, liabilities or obligations between the
different sections;

2.2.e

the transfer of assets and qualifying accrued rights from the scheme to
another pension scheme (whether or not a qualifying pension scheme), without
the need for any approval or consent to the transfer;

2.2.f

the valuation of assets and qualifying accrued rights in accordance with
provision made by the regulations, for the purposes of their allocation to a
particular section or for the purposes of their transfer as mentioned in
paragraph  (e) ;

2.2.g

the discharge of liabilities in respect of qualifying accrued rights that are
transferred.

2.3

This sub-paragraph applies to the following entities—

2.3.a

the ISOP;

2.3.b

an associate of the ISOP;

2.3.c

any other entity which employs a person—

2.3.c.i

whose contract of employment is transferred by a transfer scheme under
paragraph  1  of  Schedule 9 , and

2.3.c.ii

who is an active member of the qualifying pension scheme at the relevant time.

2.4

Regulations under  sub-paragraph (1)  may have retrospective effect.

2.5

Before making regulations under  sub-paragraph (1) , the Secretary of State
must consult—

2.5.a

the trustee of the qualifying pension scheme or schemes in question, and

2.5.b

the person who is the principal employer in relation to that scheme or those
schemes.

##### Amendment of qualifying pension schemes

3

3.1

The Secretary of State may by regulations make such amendments of a qualifying
pension scheme as the Secretary of State considers appropriate—

3.1.a

in preparation for or in connection with the designation of a person under
section 162 (1) ,

3.1.b

otherwise in connection with the making of a transfer scheme under paragraph
1  of  Schedule 9 , or

3.1.c

in connection with the making of regulations under paragraph  2  of this
Schedule.

3.2

The provision that may be made under  sub-paragraph (1)  includes—

3.2.a

provision authorising or requiring the amount of pensions or other benefits
payable to or in respect of qualifying members of the scheme to be determined
in particular circumstances by reference to pensionable service under the
scheme in question before and after the relevant time;

3.2.b

provision for the transfer out of assets, rights, liabilities or obligations
from one or more new sections of a qualifying pension scheme to another
pension scheme (whether or not a qualifying pension scheme);

3.2.c

provision for the transfer in of assets, rights, liabilities or obligations to
one or more new sections of one qualifying pension scheme from one or more new
sections of another qualifying pension scheme.

3.3

Regulations under  sub-paragraph (1)  may have retrospective effect.

3.4

Before making regulations under  sub-paragraph (1) , the Secretary of State
must consult—

3.4.a

the trustee of the qualifying pension scheme being amended, and

3.4.b

the person who is the principal employer in relation to that scheme.

3.5

In this paragraph—

3.5.a

the reference to making amendments of a qualifying pension scheme includes a
reference to amending the trust deed or rules of that scheme or any other
instrument relating to the constitution, management or operation of the
scheme;

3.5.b

references to a “new” section of a qualifying pension scheme are to one of the
sections into which the scheme is divided by regulations under paragraph  2
(1) ;

3.5.c

“ pensionable service ” has the same meaning as in section 124(1) of the
Pensions Act 1995.

##### Protection against adverse treatment

4

4.1

When exercising the power to make regulations under paragraph  2  or  3 , the
Secretary of State must ensure that the following requirements are met in
respect of each person who is or has been a qualifying member of a qualifying
pension scheme—

4.1.a

the general scheme requirement;

4.1.b

where the regulations relate to a person’s rights or entitlements to money
purchase benefits other than pensions in payment, the money purchase
requirement.

4.2

The general scheme requirement is that the provision for the payment of
pensions or other benefits that is contained in a qualifying pension scheme or
any other pension scheme to which a transfer is made by virtue of paragraph  2
(2) (e)  is, in all material respects, at least as good immediately after the
exercise of the power as it is immediately before its exercise.

4.3

The money purchase requirement is that the value of the rights or entitlements
to money purchase benefits, other than pensions in payment, that a person has
under a qualifying pension scheme or any other pension scheme to which a
transfer is made by virtue of paragraph  2 (2) (e)  immediately after, and as
a result of, the exercise of the power is at least equivalent to the value of
the person’s rights or entitlements before its exercise.

4.4

Nothing in  sub-paragraph (1)  requires—

4.4.a

the different sections (if any) of a qualifying pension scheme to be
established in a particular way,

4.4.b

particular provisions of the sections, or of a pension scheme to which a
transfer is made by virtue of paragraph  2 (2) (e) , to take the same or
similar form, or

4.4.c

any power or duty conferred or imposed by a qualifying pension scheme to be
exercised or performed in a particular way.

4.5

The power of the Secretary of State to amend a qualifying pension scheme may
not be exercised in any way that would or might adversely affect any provision
of the scheme made in respect of qualifying accrued rights unless—

4.5.a

the applicable consent requirements are satisfied in respect of the exercise
of the power in that way, or

4.5.b

the scheme is amended in the prescribed manner.

4.6

The applicable consent requirements are the requirements that apply in
relation to obtaining the consent of members of the scheme to its amendment
(including any such requirements set out in the trust deed or rules of the
scheme).

##### Information and assistance

5

5.1

The Secretary of State may direct a person within  sub-paragraph (3)  to
provide the Secretary of State with—

5.1.a

such specified pensions information, or

5.1.b

such specified assistance,

as the Secretary of State may reasonably require in preparation for or in
connection with the exercise of a power conferred on the Secretary of State by
this Schedule.

5.2

“ Pensions information ” means information that—

5.2.a

relates to pensions or other benefits under a qualifying pension scheme, or

5.2.b

relates to the administration of a qualifying pension scheme in respect of
pensions or other benefits under the scheme.

5.3

The following persons are within this sub-paragraph—

5.3.a

the trustee of a qualifying pension scheme;

5.3.b

any person who exercises functions on behalf of a person within  paragraph (a)
;

5.3.c

any person who is or has been an employer of a qualifying member of a
qualifying pension scheme.

5.4

The power under  sub-paragraph (1)  ceases to be exercisable—

5.4.a

at the end of the period of 3 years beginning with the time from which the
first designation under  section 162 (1)  has effect, or

5.4.b

if at any time before the end of that period a transfer scheme is made under
paragraph  1 (1)  of  Schedule 9 , at the end of the period of 3 years
beginning with the date (or, if there is more than one, the first date) from
which the transfer of property, rights or liabilities under the scheme takes
effect.

5.5

A person to whom a direction is given under  sub-paragraph (1)  must, so far
as reasonably practicable, provide the Secretary of State with the specified
pensions information or assistance—

5.5.a

within the specified period, and

5.5.b

in the specified form and manner.

5.6

A direction under  sub-paragraph (1)  is enforceable by the Secretary of State
in civil proceedings—

5.6.a

for an injunction,

5.6.b

for specific performance of a statutory duty under section 45 of the Court of
Session Act 1988, or

5.6.c

for any other appropriate remedy or relief.

5.7

The Secretary of State must reimburse a person for costs reasonably incurred
by the person in complying with a direction under sub-paragraph (1).

5.8

In this paragraph, “ specified ” means specified in the direction.

##### Consultation

6

Any requirement imposed by this Schedule to carry out consultation may be
satisfied by consultation before the passing of this Act (as well as by
consultation after that time).

##### National Security and Investment Act 2021

7

The exercise by the Secretary of State of a power conferred on the Secretary
of State by any provision of this Schedule is not a trigger event for the
purposes of the National Security and Investment Act 2021.

Governance of gas and electricity industry codes: transitional provision

Section 200 (1)

##### Meaning of “qualifying document”, “qualifying contract” and “qualifying central system”

1

1.1

In this Schedule, “ qualifying document ” means a document that—

1.1.a

is maintained in accordance with the conditions of a relevant licence, and

1.1.b

is designated for the purposes of this Schedule by notice given by the
Secretary of State.

1.2

Where at any time after the day on which  this paragraph  comes into force the
whole or part of the provision made by a qualifying document is incorporated
into a different document (“document B”), document B is to be treated for the
purposes of this Schedule as if it were a qualifying document even if it is
not designated under  sub-paragraph (1) (b) .

1.3

In this Schedule, “ qualifying contract ” means a contract—

1.3.a

that constitutes the whole or part of the arrangements under which a
qualifying document has effect,

1.3.b

that relates to the governance of a qualifying document, or

1.3.c

that is a central system contract.

1.4

For the purposes of  sub-paragraph (3) (c) , a contract is a “central system
contract” if—

1.4.a

it relates to the operation of a qualifying central system, and

1.4.b

the person responsible for operating or procuring the operation of the central
system is a party to the contract.

1.5

In this Schedule, “ qualifying central system ” means a central system that is
designated for the purposes of this Schedule by notice given by the Secretary
of State.

1.6

The Secretary of State may revoke a designation under sub-paragraph  (1) (b)
or  (5) .

1.7

The Secretary of State may not designate a document or central system under
sub-paragraph  (1) (b)  or  (5) , or revoke a designation, except so as to
give effect to a recommendation of the GEMA.

1.8

Before making a recommendation to the Secretary of State for the purposes of
sub-paragraph  (7) , the GEMA must consult such persons as it considers
appropriate.

##### Purposes for which powers under this Schedule may be exercised

2

2.1

The GEMA may exercise a power conferred on it by  paragraph 4 ,  6 ,  7 ,  8
or  11  only if the GEMA considers it appropriate to exercise the power—

2.1.a

for the purposes of or in connection with establishing the role of code
manager in respect of a document that is expected to become a designated
document,

2.1.b

in preparation for the granting of a code manager licence to a person in
respect of a designated document,

2.1.c

for the purposes of facilitating the carrying out by the GEMA of its functions
under this Part,

2.1.d

for the purposes of promoting the efficient governance of arrangements under
one or more qualifying documents (subject to sub-paragraph  (2) ), or

2.1.e

for the purposes of harmonising the governance of particular qualifying
documents or of qualifying documents in general.

2.2

Sub-paragraph  (1) (d)  does not apply to the exercise of the power conferred
by paragraph  6  in relation to a qualifying contract within paragraph  1 (3)
(b)  or  (c) .

##### Expiry of powers under this Schedule

3

The powers conferred on the GEMA by  paragraphs 4 ,  6 ,  7 ,  8  and  11  in
relation to a particular qualifying document expire—

3.a

when the document becomes a designated document, or

3.b

if earlier, at the end of the period of 7 years after the day on which this
Act is passed.

##### Modification of qualifying documents and relevant licences

4

4.1

The GEMA may modify—

4.1.a

a qualifying document;

4.1.b

the conditions of a particular relevant licence;

4.1.c

the standard conditions of relevant licences of a particular type.

4.2

Before making a modification under  sub-paragraph (1) , the GEMA must—

4.2.a

publish a notice about the proposed modification,

4.2.b

send a copy of the notice to the persons listed in  sub-paragraph (3) , and

4.2.c

consider any representations made within the period specified in the notice
about the proposed modification or the date from which it would take effect.

4.3

The persons mentioned in  sub-paragraph (2) (b)  are—

4.3.a

the Secretary of State;

4.3.b

each relevant licence holder;

4.3.c

the National Association of Citizens Advice Bureaux;

4.3.d

the Scottish Association of Citizens Advice Bureaux;

4.3.e

Consumer Scotland;

4.3.f

where the proposed modification relates to a licence for the purposes of
section 5 of the Gas Act 1986, the Health and Safety Executive;

4.3.g

such other persons as the GEMA considers appropriate.

4.4

A notice under sub-paragraph  (2)  must—

4.4.a

state that the GEMA proposes to make a modification;

4.4.b

set out the proposed modification and its effect;

4.4.c

specify the date from which the GEMA proposes that the modification will have
effect;

4.4.d

state the reasons why the GEMA proposes to make the modification.

4.5

If, after complying with sub-paragraphs  (2) to  (4)  in relation to a
modification, the GEMA decides to make a modification, it must publish a
notice about the decision.

4.6

A notice under  sub-paragraph (5)  must—

4.6.a

state that the GEMA has decided to make the modification;

4.6.b

set out the modification and its effect;

4.6.c

specify the date from which the modification has effect;

4.6.d

state how the GEMA has taken account of any representations made in the period
specified in the notice under sub-paragraph  (2) ;

4.6.e

state the reason for any differences between the modification set out in the
notice and the proposed modification.

4.7

A notice under this paragraph about a modification or decision must be
published in such manner as the GEMA considers appropriate for bringing it to
the attention of those likely to be affected by the making of the modification
or decision.

4.8

In this paragraph, “relevant licence holder”—

4.8.a

in relation to the modification of a qualifying document, means the holder of
a relevant licence in accordance with the conditions of which the document is
maintained;

4.8.b

in relation to the modification of standard conditions of relevant licences of
any type, means the holder of a relevant licence of that type—

4.8.b.i

that is to be modified by the inclusion of any new standard condition, or

4.8.b.ii

that includes any standard conditions to which the modifications relate which
are in effect during the period specified by virtue of  sub-paragraph (2) (c)
;

4.8.c

in relation to the modification of a condition of a particular relevant
licence (other than a standard condition), means the holder of that particular
relevant licence.

4.9

For the purposes of  this paragraph , “ modification ”, in relation to a
qualifying document, includes the incorporation of the whole or part of the
provision made by the document into another document.

5

5.1

Sub-paragraphs (2)  and  (3)  apply where at any time the GEMA modifies the
conditions of licences of any type under  paragraph 4 .

5.2

If the conditions modified are standard conditions, the GEMA must—

5.2.a

also make (as nearly as may be) the same modifications of those conditions for
the purposes of their incorporation in licences of that type granted after
that time, and

5.2.b

publish the modifications in such manner as it considers appropriate for the
purpose of bringing them to the attention of persons likely to be affected by
the making of the modifications.

5.3

The GEMA may make such incidental or consequential modifications of any
conditions of licences of any type as it considers necessary or expedient.

5.4

The modification of part of a standard condition of a particular licence under
paragraph 4  does not prevent any other part of the condition from continuing
to be regarded as a standard condition for the purposes of Part 1 of the
Electricity Act 1989 (in the case of a licence under section 6(1) of that Act)
or Part 1 of the Gas Act 1986 (in the case of a licence under section 7, 7ZA,
7A or 7AB of that Act).

##### Amendment or termination of qualifying contracts

6

6.1

The GEMA may amend a qualifying contract.

6.2

Before making an amendment under  sub-paragraph (1) , the GEMA must—

6.2.a

send a notice about the proposed amendment to the persons listed in  sub-
paragraph (4) , and

6.2.b

consider any representations made within the period specified in the notice
about the proposed amendment or the date from which it would take effect.

6.3

A notice under  sub-paragraph (2)  must—

6.3.a

state that the GEMA proposes to make an amendment;

6.3.b

set out the proposed amendment and its effect;

6.3.c

specify the date from which the GEMA proposes that the amendment will have
effect;

6.3.d

state the reasons why the GEMA proposes to make the amendment.

6.4

The persons mentioned in  sub-paragraph (2) (a)  are—

6.4.a

each person who is a party to the contract to which the proposed amendment
relates;

6.4.b

any person liable by virtue of paragraph  12  to make a payment by way of
compensation as a result of the proposed amendment;

6.4.c

such other persons as the GEMA considers appropriate.

6.5

If, after complying with  sub-paragraphs (2)  to  (4)  in relation to an
amendment, the GEMA decides to make an amendment, it must send a notice to the
persons listed in  sub-paragraph (4)  about the decision.

6.6

A notice under  sub-paragraph (5)  must—

6.6.a

state that the GEMA has decided to make the amendment;

6.6.b

set out the amendment and its effect;

6.6.c

specify the date from which the amendment has effect;

6.6.d

state how the GEMA has taken account of any representations made in the period
specified in the notice under  sub-paragraph (2) ;

6.6.e

state the reason for any differences between the amendment set out in the
notice and the proposed amendment.

6.7

In this paragraph, “ amend ”, in relation to a contract, includes terminate.

##### Arrangements in connection with code consolidation

7

7.1

The GEMA may, in connection with the consolidation of one or more qualifying
documents, make a scheme for the purpose of securing the continued effect of
rights or liabilities under a contract that is a qualifying contract within
paragraph  1 (3) (a) .

7.2

“ Consolidation ”, in relation to a qualifying document, means the
incorporation of the whole or part of the provision made by the document into
another document.

7.3

A scheme under this paragraph may make incidental, supplementary or
consequential provision (including provision amending the qualifying
contract).

##### Transfer schemes

8

8.1

The GEMA may make one or more schemes for the transfer of designated property,
rights or liabilities from one person (“ the transferor ”) to another person
(“ the transferee ”) where the condition in  sub-paragraph (2)  is met.

8.2

The condition is that the designated property, rights or liabilities—

8.2.a

relate to the operation of the provisions of a qualifying document, and

8.2.b

are reasonably required by the transferee for the purposes of its obligations
under a code manager licence (whether or not the licence has yet been granted
to the transferee).

8.3

On the transfer date, the designated property, rights and liabilities are
transferred and vest in accordance with the scheme.

8.4

The rights and liabilities that may be transferred by a scheme include those
arising under or in connection with a contract of employment.

8.5

A certificate by the GEMA that anything specified in the certificate has
vested in any person by virtue of a scheme is conclusive evidence for all
purposes of that fact.

8.6

A scheme may make provision—

8.6.a

for anything done by or in relation to the transferor in connection with any
property, rights or liabilities transferred by the scheme to be treated as
done, or to be continued, by or in relation to the transferee;

8.6.b

for references to the transferor in any agreement (whether written or not),
instrument or other document relating to any property, rights or liabilities
transferred by the scheme to be treated as references to the transferee;

8.6.c

about the continuation of legal proceedings;

8.6.d

for transferring property, rights or liabilities that could not otherwise be
transferred or assigned;

8.6.e

for transferring property, rights and liabilities irrespective of any
requirement for consent that would otherwise apply;

8.6.f

for preventing a right of pre-emption, right of reverter, right of forfeiture,
right to compensation or other similar right from arising or becoming
exercisable as a result of the transfer of property, rights or liabilities;

8.6.g

for dispensing with any formality in relation to the transfer of property,
rights or liabilities by the scheme;

8.6.h

for transferring property acquired, or rights or liabilities arising, after
the scheme is made but before it takes effect;

8.6.i

for apportioning property, rights or liabilities;

8.6.j

for creating rights, or imposing liabilities, in connection with property,
rights or liabilities transferred by the scheme;

8.6.k

for requiring the transferee to enter into any agreement of any kind, or for a
purpose, specified in or determined in accordance with the scheme.

8.7

Sub-paragraph (6) (b)  does not apply to references in—

8.7.a

primary legislation, or

8.7.b

an instrument made under primary legislation.

8.8

A scheme may—

8.8.a

include incidental, supplementary or consequential provision;

8.8.b

make transitory or transitional provision or savings;

8.8.c

make different provision for different purposes;

8.8.d

make provision subject to exceptions.

8.9

In this paragraph—

“ designated ”, in relation to a scheme, means specified in or determined in
accordance with the scheme; “ primary legislation ” means— an Act of
Parliament, an Act of the Scottish Parliament, an Act or Measure of Senedd
Cymru, or Northern Ireland legislation; “ property ” includes interests of any
description; “ the transfer date ” means a date specified by a scheme as the
date on which the transfer is to have effect.

9

9.1

Before making a scheme under paragraph  8 , the GEMA must consult—

9.1.a

the transferor;

9.1.b

the transferee;

9.1.c

such other persons as the GEMA considers appropriate.

9.2

The approval of the Secretary of State is required for the making of a scheme
under paragraph  8 .

10

10.1

The GEMA may modify a scheme under paragraph  8 .

10.2

The power under  sub-paragraph (1)  is not exercisable in relation to a scheme
after the end of the period of 12 months beginning with the day on which the
scheme takes effect.

10.3

Paragraphs 8  and  9  apply in relation to the modification of a scheme as
they apply in relation to the making of the scheme.

##### Information

11

11.1

The GEMA may direct a person who holds information reasonably required by the
GEMA—

11.1.a

in preparation for the granting of a code manager licence, or

11.1.b

for the purposes of or in connection with the exercise of any of the other
functions of the GEMA under  this Schedule ,

to provide the information to the GEMA.

11.2

A person to whom a direction is given under  sub-paragraph (1)  must, so far
as reasonably practicable, provide the GEMA with the information—

11.2.a

within the period specified in the direction, and

11.2.b

in the form and manner so specified.

11.3

A direction given to a person under  sub-paragraph (1)  is enforceable by the
GEMA in civil proceedings—

11.3.a

for an injunction,

11.3.b

for specific performance of a statutory duty under section 45 of the Court of
Session Act 1988, or

11.3.c

for any other appropriate remedy or relief.

##### Compensation

12

12.1

The relevant code manager must make a payment to a person within  sub-
paragraph (2)  in compensation for financial loss suffered by the person in
consequence of the exercise by the GEMA of—

12.1.a

the power under paragraph  6  in relation to a qualifying contract within
paragraph  1 (3) (b)  or  (c) , or

12.1.b

the power under paragraph  8  (transfer schemes).

12.2

The persons within this sub-paragraph are—

12.2.a

a person who is a party to a contract that is amended or terminated under
paragraph  6 ;

12.2.b

the transferor in relation to a scheme under paragraph  8 ;

12.2.c

a person, other than the transferor or transferee in relation to a scheme
under paragraph  8 , who has a right in relation to anything transferred by
the scheme.

12.3

The amount of a payment under  sub-paragraph (1)  is to be—

12.3.a

in a case relating to the exercise of the power under paragraph  6 , such
amount as the GEMA considers to be just;

12.3.b

in a case relating to the exercise of the power under  paragraph 8 , an amount
specified in or determined in accordance with provision made in the scheme in
question.

12.4

In this paragraph, “ the relevant code manager ” means—

12.4.a

in relation to the exercise of the power under paragraph  6 , the person who
holds a code manager licence in relation to the document to which the
qualifying contract in question relates;

12.4.b

in relation to the exercise of the power under  paragraph 8 , the person who
is the transferee in relation to the scheme in question.

12.5

The GEMA may in a particular case direct—

12.5.a

which person is the relevant code manager for the purposes of this paragraph;

12.5.b

that two or more persons are jointly to be the relevant code manager for those
purposes.

12.6

The Secretary of State may in a particular case direct that the duty under
sub-paragraph (1)  is to be discharged by a person specified in the direction
(instead of by the relevant code manager).

##### Other

13

Any requirement imposed by this Schedule to carry out consultation may be
satisfied by consultation before the passing of this Act (as well as by
consultation after that time).

  Governance of gas and electricity industry codes: pensions

Section 200 (2)

##### Introductory

1

1.1

In this Schedule—

      “ active member ” has the same meaning as in section 124(1) of the
Pensions Act 1995;           “ associate ” has the same meaning as in section
1152 of the Companies Act 2006;           “ member ” has the same meaning as
in section 124(1) of the Pensions Act 1995;           “ prescribed ” means
prescribed by regulations made by the GEMA;           “ qualifying accrued
rights ” means—         any right which, at the relevant time, has accrued to
or in respect of a qualifying member of a qualifying pension scheme to future
benefits under the scheme,           any entitlement under a qualifying
pension scheme to the present payment of a pension or other benefit that a
qualifying member of the scheme has at the relevant time, or           any
entitlement to benefits, or rights to future benefits, under a qualifying
pension scheme that a person who has survived a qualifying member of the
scheme has at the relevant time in respect of the member;                 “
qualifying member ”, in relation to a qualifying pension scheme, means a
person who is or has been a member of the scheme;           “ qualifying
pension scheme ” means a scheme that provides for the payment of pensions or
other benefits to or in respect of employees or former employees of—         a
transferor in relation to a scheme under paragraph  8  of  Schedule 12 , or
an associate of such a transferor;                 “ the relevant time ” means
the time immediately before the prescribed date (which may be before the
passing of this Act).

1.2

For the purposes of the definition of “qualifying accrued rights” in sub-
paragraph  (1) —

1.2.a

references to pensions or other benefits (including future benefits) include
money purchase benefits;

1.2.b

references to a right include a pension credit right.

1.3

In the event that a section of a qualifying pension scheme is constituted as a
separate pension scheme the members of which consist of or include persons who
are qualifying members of the qualifying pension scheme, any reference in this
Schedule to the qualifying pension scheme includes a reference to that
separate pension scheme.

##### Participation in qualifying pension schemes and transfer of assets and rights

2

2.1

The GEMA may by regulations make such pensions provision as it considers
appropriate in preparation for the granting of a code manager licence to a
person in respect of a designated document.

2.2

“ Pensions provision ” means provision in connection with a qualifying pension
scheme, including provision for—

2.2.a

enabling a person to participate in the scheme;

2.2.b

the division of the scheme into different sections;

2.2.c

the participation in the different sections of different persons;

2.2.d

the allocation of assets, rights, liabilities or obligations between the
different sections;

2.2.e

the transfer of assets and qualifying accrued rights from the scheme to
another pension scheme (whether or not a qualifying pension scheme), without
the need for any approval or consent to the transfer;

2.2.f

the valuation of assets and qualifying accrued rights in accordance with
provision made by the regulations, for the purposes of their allocation to a
particular section or for the purposes of their transfer as mentioned in
paragraph  (e) ;

2.2.g

the discharge of liabilities in respect of qualifying accrued rights that are
transferred.

2.3

Regulations under  sub-paragraph (1)  may have retrospective effect.

2.4

Before making regulations under  sub-paragraph (1) , the GEMA must consult—

2.4.a

the trustee of the qualifying pension scheme or schemes in question, and

2.4.b

the person who is the principal employer in relation to that scheme or those
schemes.

2.5

The approval of the Secretary of State is required for the making of
regulations under  sub-paragraph (1) .

##### Amendment of qualifying pension schemes

3

3.1

The GEMA may by regulations make such amendments of a qualifying pension
scheme as it considers appropriate—

3.1.a

in preparation for the granting of a code manager licence to a person in
respect of a designated document, or

3.1.b

in connection with the making of regulations under paragraph  2 .

3.2

The provision that may be made under  sub-paragraph (1)  includes—

3.2.a

provision authorising or requiring the amount of pensions or other benefits
payable to or in respect of qualifying members of the scheme to be determined
in particular circumstances by reference to pensionable service under the
scheme in question before and after the relevant time;

3.2.b

provision for the transfer out of assets, rights, liabilities or obligations
from one or more new sections of a qualifying pension scheme to another
pension scheme (whether or not a qualifying pension scheme);

3.2.c

provision for the transfer in of assets, rights, liabilities or obligations to
one or more new sections of one qualifying pension scheme from one or more new
sections of another qualifying pension scheme.

3.3

Regulations under  sub-paragraph (1)  may have retrospective effect.

3.4

Before making regulations under  sub-paragraph (1) , the GEMA must consult—

3.4.a

the trustee of the qualifying pension scheme being amended, and

3.4.b

the person who is the principal employer in relation to that scheme.

3.5

The approval of the Secretary of State is required for the making of
regulations under  sub-paragraph (1) .

3.6

In this paragraph—

3.6.a

the reference to making amendments of a qualifying pension scheme includes a
reference to amending the trust deed or rules of that scheme or any other
instrument relating to the constitution, management or operation of the
scheme;

3.6.b

references to a “new” section of a qualifying pension scheme are to one of the
sections into which the scheme is divided by regulations under  paragraph 2
(1) ;

3.6.c

“ pensionable service ” has the same meaning as in section 124(1) of the
Pensions Act 1995.

##### Protection against adverse treatment

4

4.1

When exercising the power to make regulations under  paragraph 2  or  3 , the
GEMA must ensure that the following requirements are met in respect of each
person who is or has been a qualifying member of a qualifying pension scheme—

4.1.a

the general scheme requirement;

4.1.b

where the regulations relate to a person’s rights or entitlements to money
purchase benefits other than pensions in payment, the money purchase
requirement.

4.2

The general scheme requirement is that the provision for the payment of
pensions or other benefits that is contained in a qualifying pension scheme or
any other pension scheme to which a transfer is made by virtue of  paragraph 2
(2) (e)  is, in all material respects, at least as good immediately after the
exercise of the power as it is immediately before its exercise.

4.3

The money purchase requirement is that the value of the rights or entitlements
to money purchase benefits, other than pensions in payment, that a person has
under a qualifying pension scheme or any other pension scheme to which a
transfer is made by virtue of paragraph  2 (2) (e)  immediately after, and as
a result of, the exercise of the power is at least equivalent to the value of
the person’s rights or entitlements before its exercise.

4.4

Nothing in  sub-paragraph (1)  requires—

4.4.a

the different sections (if any) of a qualifying pension scheme to be
established in a particular way,

4.4.b

particular provisions of the sections, or of a pension scheme to which a
transfer is made by virtue of  paragraph 2 (2) (e) , to take the same or
similar form, or

4.4.c

any power or duty conferred or imposed by a qualifying pension scheme to be
exercised or performed in a particular way.

4.5

The power of the GEMA to amend a qualifying pension scheme may not be
exercised in any way that would or might adversely affect any provision of the
scheme made in respect of qualifying accrued rights unless—

4.5.a

the applicable consent requirements are satisfied in respect of the exercise
of the power in that way, or

4.5.b

the scheme is amended in the prescribed manner.

4.6

The applicable consent requirements are the requirements that apply in
relation to obtaining the consent of members of the scheme to its amendment
(including any such requirements set out in the trust deed or rules of the
scheme).

##### Information

5

5.1

The GEMA may direct a person who holds relevant pensions information to
provide it to the GEMA.

5.2

“ Pensions information ” means specified information that—

5.2.a

relates to pensions or other benefits under a qualifying pension scheme, or

5.2.b

relates to the administration of a qualifying pension scheme in respect of
pensions or other benefits under the scheme.

5.3

A person to whom a direction is given under  sub-paragraph (1)  must, so far
as reasonably practicable, provide the specified pensions information—

5.3.a

within the specified period, and

5.3.b

in the specified form and manner.

5.4

A direction under  sub-paragraph (1)  is enforceable by the GEMA in civil
proceedings—

5.4.a

for an injunction,

5.4.b

for specific performance of a statutory duty under section 45 of the Court of
Session Act 1988, or

5.4.c

for any other appropriate remedy or relief.

5.5

In this paragraph, “ specified ” means specified in the direction.
