43.5

Regulations made by virtue of sub-paragraph (1) may, in particular, impose
requirements relating to—

43.5.a

the keeping of records by relevant persons;

43.5.b

the provision of information by relevant persons and others;

43.5.c

the audit and verification of that information.

##### Step-in arrangements

44

The regulations may make provision for, or in connection with, securing that
the holder of a heat network authorisation (“the new entity”) is able
effectively to carry on a regulated activity in relation to a relevant heat
network in the place of another person (“the old entity”) when directed to do
so by the Regulator under a power conferred by a condition in its heat network
authorisation (see  paragraph 17 ).

45

45.1

The regulations may provide for the Regulator to make one or more schemes
making such provision as to property, rights and liabilities as is necessary
or expedient for the purpose of enabling the new entity to carry on the
regulated activity in relation to the relevant heat network in an effective
manner.

45.2

Regulations made by virtue of  sub-paragraph (1)  may, in particular,
authorise a scheme to provide for—

45.2.a

the transfer of property, rights or liabilities;

45.2.b

the creation of interests in, or rights in relation to, property;

45.2.c

the creation of rights and liabilities as between the old entity and the new
entity;

45.2.d

the modification of interests, rights or liabilities of third parties;

45.2.e

the enforcement of a right or liability for whose transfer or creation the
scheme provides;

45.2.f

the entering into of agreements and the execution of instruments for the
purposes of, or in connection with, the transfer of property or the transfer
or creation of rights or liabilities;

45.2.g

the time at which a transfer, creation or modification is to take place;

45.2.h

the assessment and payment of compensation.

45.3

Regulations made by virtue of  sub-paragraph (1)  may provide for the scheme—

45.3.a

to contain incidental, supplementary, consequential, transitional, transitory
or saving provision;

45.3.b

to make different provision for different purposes.

45.4

The regulations may provide for the modification of a scheme.

46

46.1

The regulations may—

46.1.a

provide for the old entity to give the Regulator such information and
assistance as the Regulator may require for the purposes of, or in connection
with, the making or implementation of a scheme;

46.1.b

provide for the Regulator, for the purposes of, or in connection with, the
making or implementation of a scheme, to direct the old entity to take, or to
refrain from taking, such steps as are specified in the direction.

46.2

The regulations may provide for the Regulator—

46.2.a

to make payments to the new entity in respect of costs incurred in connection
with carrying on the regulated activity in relation to the heat network;

46.2.b

to indemnify the new entity in respect of liabilities arising from, or in
connection with, carrying on the regulated activity in relation to the heat
network.

##### Special administration regime

47

The regulations may make provision for, or in connection with, a special
administration regime for companies that are holders of heat network
authorisations.

48

48.1

The regulations may make provision for a court to make an order (a “heat
network administration order”) in relation to a company that is the holder of
a heat network authorisation directing that the affairs, business and property
of the company are to be managed by a person appointed by the court (referred
to in  this Part  as the heat network administrator of the company).

48.2

The regulations may make provision about the court that has jurisdiction in a
particular case.

48.3

The regulations may limit the effect of a heat network administration order
applying to a non-GB company or a non-NI company to—

48.3.a

its affairs and business so far as carried on in Great Britain or Northern
Ireland (as the case may be), and

48.3.b

its property in Great Britain or Northern Ireland (as the case may be).

49

49.1

The regulations may make provision about the objectives of a heat network
administration order and the means by which the objectives may be secured.

49.2

The regulations may, in particular, require the heat network administrator to
exercise functions so as to achieve the objectives set out in  sub-paragraph
(3)  so far as possible.

49.3

The objectives referred to in  sub-paragraph (2)  are—

49.3.a

to secure that the supply of heating, cooling or hot water is continued at the
lowest cost which it is reasonably practicable to incur,

49.3.b

to secure that the company’s relevant heat network is and continues to be
maintained and developed as an efficient and economical system, and

49.3.c

to secure that it becomes unnecessary, by using such means as are allowed by
the regulations, for the heat network administration order to remain in force.

49.4

The regulations may make provision about the means that may be used,
including—

49.4.a

the rescue as a going concern of the company subject to the heat network
administration order;

49.4.b

a transfer as a going concern of so much of the undertaking of the company
subject to the heat network administration order as is associated with the
company’s relevant heat network.

49.5

Regulations made by virtue of  sub-paragraph (4)  may also provide for the
heat network administrator to make arrangements for securing that heat network
consumers who are supplied with heating, cooling or hot water by the company’s
relevant heat network have an alternative supply of heating, cooling or hot
water (as the case may be).

49.6

The regulations may make provision about—

49.6.a

the means by which a transfer falling within  sub-paragraph (4) (b)  may be
effected;

49.6.b

the circumstances in which the objectives set out in  sub-paragraph (3)  may
or may not be achieved by means of such a transfer.

49.7

In  this paragraph , “ the company’s relevant heat network ”, in relation to a
company that is the holder of a heat network authorisation, means the relevant
heat network to which the authorisation relates.

50

50.1

The regulations may make provision for applying, with such modifications as
appear to the appropriate authority to be appropriate, the provisions
mentioned in  sub-paragraph (2) .

50.2

The provisions referred to in  sub-paragraph (1)  are—

50.2.a

sections 156 to 167 of, and Schedules 20 and 21 to, the Energy Act 2004
(special administration regime for energy licensees);

50.2.b

sections 171 and 196 of the Energy Act 2004 (interpretation), so far as
relating to the provisions mentioned in  paragraph (a) ;

50.2.c

sections 19 to 33  of, and the Schedule to, the Energy Act (Northern Ireland)
2011 (c. 6 (N.I.))  (special administration regime for protected energy
companies);

50.2.d

section 35 of the Energy Act (Northern Ireland) 2011 (interpretation), so far
as relating to the provisions mentioned in  paragraph (c) .

50.3

In this paragraph, “ the appropriate authority ” means—

50.3.a

in relation to England and Wales and Scotland, the Secretary of State;

50.3.b

in relation to Northern Ireland, the Department.

51

In  this Part —

“ company ” means— a company registered under the Companies Act 2006, or an
unregistered company; “ heat network administration order ” has the meaning
given by  paragraph 48 ; “ heat network administrator ” has the meaning given
by  paragraph 48 ; “ non-GB company ” means a company incorporated outside
Great Britain; “ non-NI company ” means a company incorporated outside
Northern Ireland; “ unregistered company ” means a company that is not
registered under the Companies Act 2006.

##### Supply to premises

52

52.1

The regulations may make provision about—

52.1.a

offers to connect premises to a relevant heat network, the terms of such
offers and acceptance of such an offer;

52.1.b

the conduct of holders of heat network authorisations towards heat network
consumers or in relation to premises connected or proposed to be connected to
a relevant heat network.

52.2

Regulations made by virtue of this paragraph may make provision relating to
the connection of premises to a relevant heat network whether a connection is
for the purpose of—

52.2.a

supplying heating, cooling or hot water to premises, or

52.2.b

supplying thermal energy to a relevant heat network.

52.3

The following paragraphs of this Part make further provision about regulations
that may be made by virtue of  this paragraph .

53

The regulations may—

53.a

impose duties, in circumstances specified by the regulations, to make and
maintain a connection between a relevant heat network and any premises;

53.b

impose duties as to providing such equipment as may be needed to make the
connection function;

53.c

provide for the procedure to be followed when seeking to have a connection
made between a relevant heat network and any premises;

53.d

provide for persons seeking a connection to premises to pay an amount in
respect of costs incurred in making the connection or in respect of the cost
of equipment provided;

53.e

provide for the giving of security for the payment of such an amount in
respect of the cost of equipment provided;

53.f

make provision about the terms upon which a connection is made (including
provision for deeming a contract to have been made and for making schemes for
determining the terms and conditions to be incorporated in such a contract).

54

The regulations may—

54.a

make provision as to the meters and other equipment that may be installed for
the purposes of making and maintaining a connection between a relevant heat
network and any premises;

54.b

impose requirements as to the operation of such meters and other equipment.

55

The regulations may—

55.a

prohibit the making of a charge where, for the purpose of meeting the needs of
a disabled person, a meter or other equipment is moved or replaced;

55.b

make provision as to the steps that may be taken if payments relating to the
supply of heating, cooling or hot water are not made (including provision for
removing a connection to a relevant heat network or otherwise preventing the
further supply of heating, cooling or hot water);

55.c

make provision as to the arrangements that may apply, and the steps that may
be taken, if—

55.c.i

premises are supplied with heating, cooling or hot water without agreement as
to the terms on which the supply is made, or

55.c.ii

a connection is made to a relevant heat network, or restored, without
authority;

55.d

make provision in connection with securing the rights of a holder of a heat
network authorisation as owner of equipment provided by it.

56

The regulations may—

56.a

confer powers to enter premises for the purposes of installing, inspecting,
repairing, replacing, altering or removing meters or other equipment;

56.b

confer powers to enter premises for the purposes of reading a register on a
meter or other equipment;

56.c

make provision for the issuing of warrants to enter premises for the purposes
of exercising powers conferred by regulations made by virtue of this paragraph
where conditions specified in the regulations are satisfied;

56.d

make provision as to the persons who may exercise powers conferred by
regulations under this paragraph.

57

The regulations may revoke or amend the Heat Network (Metering and Billing)
Regulations 2014 ( S.I. 2014/3120 ).

##### Consumer protection

###### Standards of performance

58

58.1

The regulations may prescribe such standards of performance in connection with
the regulated activities of holders of heat network authorisations, so far as
affecting—

58.1.a

heat network consumers supplied by the relevant heat networks to which their
authorisations relate, or

58.1.b

potential heat network consumers who would be supplied by those relevant heat
networks,

as in the Regulator’s opinion ought to be achieved as regards those persons.

58.2

The regulations may—

58.2.a

specify the circumstances in which the holders of heat network authorisations
are to inform persons of rights conferred on them under regulations made by
virtue of  this paragraph ;

58.2.b

provide for exemptions from standards of performance;

58.2.c

require the holders of heat network authorisations to provide information
about their compliance with standards of performance.

58.3

The regulations may provide—

58.3.a

for compensation to be made to persons affected by a failure to meet a
standard of performance;

58.3.b

for the determination of the amount of compensation.

58.4

The regulations may provide for the making of compensation under regulations
made by virtue of this paragraph in respect of a failure to meet a standard of
performance not to prejudice any other remedy which may be available in
respect of the act or omission which constituted the failure.

58.5

Regulations made in relation to England and Wales and Scotland by virtue of
sub-paragraphs (1)  to  (3) , may provide for the Regulator to make provision
by regulations about the matters referred to in those sub-paragraphs.

58.6

The regulations may require that regulations made by the Regulator by virtue
of  sub-paragraph (5)  are made with the consent of the Secretary of State.

58.7

Regulations made by the Regulator by virtue of  sub-paragraph (5)  are to be
made by statutory instrument.

59

59.1

The regulations may provide for the Regulator, from time to time—

59.1.a

to determine such standards of overall performance in connection with
regulated activities as, in the Regulator’s opinion, ought to be achieved by
holders of heat network authorisations;

59.1.b

to publish those standards.

59.2

The regulations may provide for the Regulator to determine different standards
for different descriptions of holders of heat network authorisations.

59.3

The regulations may require holders of heat network authorisations to conduct
their regulated activities in such a way as can reasonably be expected to lead
to compliance with standards set under regulations made by virtue of  this
paragraph .

60

60.1

The regulations may make provision about the steps to be taken in connection
with prescribing or determining standards of performance under  paragraph 58
or  59 .

60.2

The regulations may, in particular, make provision about—

60.2.a

conducting research;

60.2.b

publishing information about proposals to prescribe or determine standards;

60.2.c

considering representations about proposals;

60.2.d

consulting such persons or descriptions of person as are specified in the
regulations.

###### Consumer advocacy bodies

61

61.1

The regulations may provide for Part 1 of the Consumers, Estate Agents and
Redress Act 2007 (consumer advocacy bodies) to apply in relation to heat
network consumers as it applies in relation to gas or electricity consumers,
with such modifications as appear to the appropriate authority to be
appropriate.

61.2

The regulations may provide for sections 24 and 25 of the Consumers, Estate
Agents and Redress Act 2007 (provision of information to consumer advocacy
bodies) to apply in relation to relevant persons as they apply to regulated
providers within the meaning of section 25 of that Act, with such
modifications as appear to the appropriate authority to be appropriate.

61.3

The regulations may also make provision extending to Northern Ireland or
applying in relation to the General Consumer Council for Northern Ireland that
corresponds to such provision in Part 1 of the Consumers, Estate Agents and
Redress Act 2007 as does not extend to Northern Ireland or does not apply in
relation to the General Consumer Council for Northern Ireland (as the case may
be).

61.4

In this paragraph, “ the appropriate authority ” means—

61.4.a

in relation to England and Wales and Scotland, the Secretary of State;

61.4.b

in relation to Northern Ireland, the Department.

###### Complaints handling and redress schemes

62

The regulations may provide for Part 2 of the Consumers, Estate Agents and
Redress Act 2007 (complaints handling and redress schemes)—

62.a

to apply in relation to heat network consumers in England, Wales or Scotland
as it applies in relation to gas or electricity consumers, with such
modifications as appear to the Secretary of State to be appropriate;

62.b

to apply in relation to relevant persons in England, Wales or Scotland as it
applies in relation to regulated providers within the meaning of that Part,
with such modifications as appear to the Secretary of State to be appropriate.

###### Consumer complaints and dispute resolution arrangements: Northern Ireland

63

63.1

The regulations may, in relation to Northern Ireland, provide for consumer
complaints legislation to apply in relation to a heat network consumer or
potential heat network consumer as it applies in relation to a customer or
potential customer of, or user of electricity or gas supplied by, an
authorised supplier, with such modifications as appear to the Department to be
appropriate.

63.2

In  this paragraph , “ consumer complaints legislation ” means Article 22 of
the Energy (Northern Ireland) Order 2003 ( S.I. 2003/419 (N.I. 6))  and such
other provisions of that Order as relate to it.

64

The regulations may, in relation to Northern Ireland, make provision about the
resolution of disputes involving a heat network consumer or potential heat
network consumer (including by providing for a scheme under which complaints
may be made to, and investigated and determined by, an independent person or
may be referred to arbitration).

###### Documents for Citizens Advice, Consumer Scotland and the General Consumer Council for Northern Ireland

65

The regulations may make provision requiring the Regulator, where the
Regulator publishes a document of a description specified in the regulations,
to send a copy of the document to—

65.a

Citizens Advice and Consumer Scotland, or

65.b

the General Consumer Council for Northern Ireland (as the case may be).

##### Financial arrangements

66

66.1

The regulations may provide for the Regulator to include in the conditions of
heat network authorisations provision requiring the payment of sums relating
to the costs incurred by the Secretary of State or the Department in giving
financial assistance under regulations made by virtue of  paragraph 50  that
apply—

66.1.a

any provision of sections 165 to 167 of the Energy Act 2004 (grants, loans,
indemnities and guarantees given by the Secretary of State), or

66.1.b

any provision of sections 28 to 30 of the Energy Act (Northern Ireland) 2011
(grants, loans, indemnities and guarantees given by the Department).

66.2

The regulations may—

66.2.a

provide for the Secretary of State or the Department to give directions to the
Regulator for the purpose of securing that sums relating to those costs are
included in the sums payable by virtue of conditions in heat network
authorisations;

66.2.b

provide for the Regulator to comply with any such direction.

67

67.1

The regulations may provide for the Regulator to include in—

67.1.a

the conditions of a heat network authorisation, or

67.1.b

the conditions of an installation and maintenance licence,

provision requiring the payment of sums relating to the costs incurred by a
person or body in providing, or arranging for the provision of, consumer
advocacy and advice in relation to heat network consumers.

67.2

The regulations may—

67.2.a

provide for the Secretary of State or the Department to give directions to the
Regulator for the purpose of securing that sums relating to those costs are
included in the sums payable by virtue of conditions in heat network
authorisations or installation and maintenance licences;

67.2.b

provide for the Regulator to comply with any such direction.

68

The regulations may make provision for the Regulator to pay into the
Consolidated Fund or the Consolidated Fund of Northern Ireland sums received
in consequence of—

68.a

provision made by or under the regulations, or

68.b

a condition of a heat network authorisation, code manager licence or
installation and maintenance licence.

##### Miscellaneous and general

###### Consultation and cooperation

69

The regulations may—

69.a

make provision about consultation and cooperation with such persons or
descriptions of person as are specified in the regulations;

69.b

make provision as to the purposes of such cooperation.

70

The regulations may require the Regulator to assist a public authority that
carries out, in relation to Wales or Scotland, functions as regards limiting
targeted greenhouse gases in relation to heat networks (including by providing
information).

###### Objectives of the Secretary of State and the Department

71

71.1

The regulations may make provision about the objectives of the Secretary of
State and the Department in carrying out functions under the regulations.

71.2

Regulations made by virtue of  sub-paragraph (1)  may, in particular, provide
that the principal objective of the Secretary of State or the Department is to
protect the interests of existing and future heat network consumers.

71.3

The regulations may specify particular interests of existing and future heat
network consumers that are to be protected.

###### Offences

72

72.1

The regulations may provide for the creation of offences.

72.2

The regulations may deal with matters relating to such offences, including the
provision of defences and evidentiary matters.

73

73.1

The regulations may provide for an offence created by virtue of regulations
made under  paragraph 72  to be triable—

73.1.a

only summarily, or

73.1.b

either summarily or on indictment.

73.2

The regulations must provide for such an offence to be punishable on
indictment with a fine.

73.3

The regulations must provide for such an offence to be punishable on summary
conviction in England and Wales with a fine.

73.4

The regulations must provide for such an offence to be punishable on summary
conviction in Scotland or Northern Ireland with a fine not exceeding an amount
specified in the regulations.

###### Crown application

74

74.1

The regulations may make provision about application to the Crown.

74.2

The regulations may also, to the extent that they bind the Crown, restrict or
modify the application of the regulations.

74.3

Regulations made by virtue of  sub-paragraph (2)  may, in particular, provide
that a power exercisable in relation to land in which there is a Crown or
Duchy interest is subject to a requirement to obtain consent from a person
specified in the regulations.

74.4

In  this paragraph , “ Crown or Duchy interest ” means—

74.4.a

an interest belonging to His Majesty in right of the Crown or the Duchy of
Lancaster, or to the Duchy of Cornwall;

74.4.b

an interest which belongs to a government department or which is held in trust
for His Majesty for the purposes of a government department;

74.4.c

an interest which belongs to an office-holder in the Scottish Administration
or which is held in trust for His Majesty for the purposes of the Scottish
Administration by such an office-holder.

74.5

This includes, in particular—

74.5.a

an interest which belongs to His Majesty in right of His Majesty’s Government
in Northern Ireland, and

74.5.b

an interest which belongs to a Northern Ireland department or which is held in
trust for His Majesty for the purposes of a Northern Ireland department.

74.6

A reference in this paragraph to an office-holder in the Scottish
Administration is to be construed in accordance with section 126(7) of the
Scotland Act 1998.

  Licensing of activities relating to load control

Section 249

1

The Electricity Act 1989 is amended as follows.

2

After section 56FB insert—

######## New licensable activities: load control of energy smart appliances

2.56FBA

2.56FBA.1

The Secretary of State may by regulations amend this Part so as—

2.56FBA.1.a

to provide for one or more activities within subsection  (2)  to be added to
the activities which are licensable activities, or

2.56FBA.1.b

where regulations have previously been made under paragraph  (a)  in relation
to an activity—

2.56FBA.1.b.i

to amend the definition of the activity, or

2.56FBA.1.b.ii

to provide for the activity to cease to be a licensable activity.

2.56FBA.2

The activities within this subsection are activities connected with—

2.56FBA.2.a

the carrying on or facilitating of load control;

2.56FBA.2.b

the provision of services or facilities related to load control;

but not the activities mentioned in subsection  (3) .

2.56FBA.3

The activities within this subsection are—

2.56FBA.3.a

the provision of relevant electronic communications networks;

2.56FBA.3.b

the making, selling, importing or distributing of energy smart appliances;

2.56FBA.3.c

things done by end-users of energy smart appliances (in their capacity as
such).

2.56FBA.4

Regulations under  subsection (1) (a)  may define activities which are to
become licensable activities in any manner the Secretary of State considers
appropriate, including—

2.56FBA.4.a

by reference to the purpose for which an activity is carried out; and

2.56FBA.4.b

by reference to the position of an activity in a sequence of activities
necessary to secure a particular outcome.

2.56FBA.5

Regulations under this section may make consequential, transitional,
incidental or supplementary provision, including—

2.56FBA.5.a

amendments (or repeals) of any provision of this Act or any other enactment,
including any enactment comprised in, or an instrument made under, an Act of
the Scottish Parliament;

2.56FBA.5.b

in the case of regulations under  subsection (1) (a) , provision determining
the conditions which are to be standard conditions for the purposes of
licences authorising the undertaking of the activities;

2.56FBA.5.c

provision modifying any standard conditions of licences.

2.56FBA.6

Transitional provision under subsection  (5)  may in particular include
provision about persons already undertaking activities that are to become
licensable activities by virtue of  subsection (1) (a) , such as provision—

2.56FBA.6.a

about the application to such persons of section 4(1);

2.56FBA.6.b

about the granting of licences to such persons.

2.56FBA.7

Regulations under this section may, in particular, also make provision—

2.56FBA.7.a

for licences to authorise the holder to carry out the licensable activities in
any area, or only in an area specified in the licence;

2.56FBA.7.b

enabling the terms of the licence to be modified so as to extend or restrict
the area in which the licence holder may carry on the licensable activities;

2.56FBA.7.c

specifying that a licence, and any modification of a licence, must be in
writing;

2.56FBA.7.d

for a licence, if not previously revoked, to continue in force for such period
as may be specified in or determined by or under the licence;

2.56FBA.7.e

conferring functions on the Secretary of State or the Authority.

2.56FBA.8

In this section, “energy smart appliance”, “load control” and “relevant
electronic communications network” have the same meaning as in Part 8 of the
Energy Act 2023.

######## Regulations under 

2.56FBB

2.56FBB.1

Before making regulations under  section 56FBA , the Secretary of State must
consult—

2.56FBB.1.a

the Authority, and

2.56FBB.1.b

such other persons as the Secretary of State thinks appropriate.

2.56FBB.2

Subsection (1) may be satisfied by consultation before, as well as by
consultation after, the passing of this Act.

2.56FBB.3

The power to make such regulations may not be exercised after the end of a
period of seven years beginning with the day on which the first such
regulations come into force (for any purpose).

2.56FBB.4

Regulations under  section 56FBA  may not be made unless a draft of the
statutory instrument containing them has been laid before, and approved by
resolution of, each House of Parliament.

3

At the end of section 56FC(2) (competitive tenders: definition of “new
licensable activities”), insert  “or regulations under  section 56FBA (1) (a)
” .

4

In section 106(2)(a) (regulations and orders), after “State” insert  “(other
than regulations under  section 56FBA )” .

  Enforcement undertakings

Section 284

##### Procedure

1

1.1

The Secretary of State must publish a procedure for entering into enforcement
undertakings.

1.2

The Secretary of State may revise the procedure (and must publish any revised
procedure).

1.3

The Secretary of State must consult any persons the Secretary of State
considers appropriate before publishing or revising the procedure.

##### Variation of terms

2

The terms of an enforcement undertaking (including, in particular, the action
specified under it and the period so specified within which the action must be
taken) may be varied if both parties agree in writing.

##### Compliance certificates

3

3.1

Where the Secretary of State is satisfied that an enforcement undertaking has
been complied with, the Secretary of State must issue a certificate to that
effect (referred to in this Schedule as a “ compliance certificate ”).

3.2

A person may at any time apply to the Secretary of State for a compliance
certificate.

3.3

The Secretary of State may specify in what form an application under  sub-
paragraph (2)  must be made and what information (if any) must accompany it.

3.4

Where an application is made under  sub-paragraph (2) , the Secretary of State
must give the applicant notice in writing of the Secretary of State’s decision
on the application within 14 days beginning with the day after the day on
which the application is received.

##### Inaccurate, incomplete or misleading information

4

Where the Secretary of State is satisfied that a person who has given an
enforcement undertaking has provided inaccurate, misleading or incomplete
information in relation to the undertaking, the Secretary of State may treat
the person as having failed to comply with the undertaking (and, if the
Secretary of State decides so to treat the person, must by notice revoke any
compliance certificate given to the person in respect of the enforcement
undertaking).

##### Appeal against decision under 

5

5.1

An appeal lies to the First-tier Tribunal against a decision of the Secretary
of State to refuse an application for a compliance certificate or, in reliance
on paragraph  4 , to treat the person as having failed to comply with an
enforcement undertaking.

5.2

The grounds for appeal are that the decision is—

5.2.a

based on an error of fact,

5.2.b

wrong in law,

5.2.c

unfair or unreasonable, or

5.2.d

wrong for any other reason.

5.3

On an appeal under this paragraph, the First-tier Tribunal may—

5.3.a

confirm the Secretary of State’s decision or direct that it is not to have
effect;

5.3.b

award costs or, in Scotland, expenses.

Petroleum licences: amendments to model clauses

Section 300

##### Petroleum (Production) (Landward Areas) Regulations 1995

1

In the Petroleum (Production) (Landward Areas) Regulations 1995 ( S.I.
1995/1436 ), Schedule 3 (model clauses for petroleum exploration and
development licences in landward areas) is amended as follows.

2

After clause 37 insert—

######### Change in control of Licensee

2.37A

2.37A.1

This clause applies if—

2.37A.1.a

the Licensee is a company, or

2.37A.1.b

where two or more persons are the Licensee, any of those persons is a company,

and references in this clause to a company are to such a company.

2.37A.2

A change in control of a company is not permitted without the consent of the
Oil and Gas Authority (“the OGA”).

2.37A.3

There is a “change in control” of a company if a person takes control of the
company, not having previously been a person who controlled the company.

2.37A.4

If a change in control of a company is contemplated, the company must apply in
writing to the OGA for consent at least three months before the date on which
it is proposed that the change would occur (if consent were given).

2.37A.5

The OGA may—

2.37A.5.a

consent to the change in control unconditionally,

2.37A.5.b

consent to the change in control subject to conditions, or

2.37A.5.c

refuse consent to the change in control.

2.37A.6

If the OGA proposes to grant consent subject to any condition or to refuse
consent, the OGA must, before making a final decision—

2.37A.6.a

give the company an opportunity to make representations, and

2.37A.6.b

consider any representations that are made.

2.37A.7

The general rule is that the OGA must decide an application within three
months of receiving it, but the OGA may delay its decision by notifying the
interested parties in writing.

2.37A.8

Conditions as mentioned in paragraph (5)(b) may be imposed on the person
taking control of the company (as well as on the company), and may include—

2.37A.8.a

conditions relating to the arrangements for the change in control, including
the date by which it must occur,

2.37A.8.b

conditions relating to the performance of activities permitted by this
licence, and

2.37A.8.c

financial conditions.

2.37A.9

The OGA’s decision on the application, and any conditions as mentioned in
paragraph (5)(b), must be notified in writing to the interested parties.

2.37A.10

In this clause “ the interested parties ” means—

2.37A.10.a

the company,

2.37A.10.b

the person who (if consent were granted) would take control of the company,
and

2.37A.10.c

if the company and another person or persons are the Licensee, that other
person or those other persons.

2.37A.11

For the purposes of this clause, the question of whether a person has control
of a company is to be determined in accordance with the test set out in clause
37(4).

3

3.1

Clause 38 (power of revocation) is amended as follows.

3.2

In paragraph (2)—

3.2.a

after sub-paragraph (i) insert—

3.2.a.j

if the Licensee is a company, any breach of a condition subject to which the
Oil and Gas Authority gave its consent to a change in control of the Licensee
(see clause 37A);

3.2.a.k

if the Licensee is a company, any failure to provide full and accurate
information in response to a notice given by the Oil and Gas Authority to that
company under section 5D of the Petroleum Act 1998;

;

3.2.b

in the closing words, after “(g)” insert  “or (j) or (k)” .

3.3

Omit paragraphs (3) to (5).

4

4.1

Clause 38A (power of partial revocation) is amended as follows.

4.2

For paragraph (1) substitute—

4.2.1

This clause applies in a case where two or more persons are the Licensee and—

4.2.1.a

an event mentioned in clause 38(2)(c), (d), (e) or (g) occurs in relation to
one of those persons;

4.2.1.b

an event mentioned in clause 38(2)(b) occurs which consists of a breach of
clause 37A(2) or (4) in relation to a change in control of one of those
persons;

4.2.1.c

an event mentioned in clause 38(2)(j) occurs in relation to a change in
control of one of those persons (see clause 37A); or

4.2.1.d

an event mentioned in clause 38(2)(k) occurs which consists of a failure by
one of those persons as mentioned in that provision.

4.3

In paragraph (2), for “or (b)” substitute  “, (b), (c) or (d)” .

For paragraph (1) substitute—

9.2.1

This clause applies in a case where two or more persons are the Licensee and—

9.2.1.a

an event mentioned in clause 39(2)(c), (d), (e) or (g) occurs in relation to
one of those persons;

9.2.1.b

an event mentioned in clause 39(2)(b) occurs which consists of a breach of
clause 38A(2) or (4) in relation to a change in control of one of those
persons;

9.2.1.c

an event mentioned in clause 39(2)(j) occurs in relation to a change in
control of one of those persons (see clause 38A); or

9.2.1.d

an event mentioned in clause 39(2)(k) occurs which consists of a failure by
one of those persons as mentioned in that provision.

9.3

In paragraph (2), for “or (b)” substitute  “, (b), (c) or (d)” .

###### Part 2 of Schedule 3

10

Part 2 of Schedule 3 (current model clauses for landward production licences
deriving from Schedule 3 to the 1966 regulations) is amended in accordance
with paragraphs  11  to  13 .

11

After clause 36 insert—

########## Change in control of Licensee

11.36A

11.36A.1

This clause applies if—

11.36A.1.a

the Licensee is a company, or

11.36A.1.b

where two or more persons are the Licensee, any of those persons is a company,

and references in this clause to a company are to such a company.

11.36A.2

A change in control of a company is not permitted without the consent of the
Oil and Gas Authority (“the OGA”).

11.36A.3

There is a “change in control” of a company if a person takes control of the
company, not having previously been a person who controlled the company.

11.36A.4

If a change in control of a company is contemplated, the company must apply in
writing to the OGA for consent at least three months before the date on which
it is proposed that the change would occur (if consent were given).

11.36A.5

The OGA may—

11.36A.5.a

consent to the change in control unconditionally,

11.36A.5.b

consent to the change in control subject to conditions, or

11.36A.5.c

refuse consent to the change in control.

11.36A.6

If the OGA proposes to grant consent subject to any condition or to refuse
consent, the OGA must, before making a final decision—

11.36A.6.a

give the company an opportunity to make representations, and

11.36A.6.b

consider any representations that are made.

11.36A.7

The general rule is that the OGA must decide an application within three
months of receiving it, but the OGA may delay its decision by notifying the
interested parties in writing.

11.36A.8

Conditions as mentioned in paragraph (5)(b) may be imposed on the person
taking control of the company (as well as on the company), and may include—

11.36A.8.a

conditions relating to the arrangements for the change in control, including
the date by which it must occur,

11.36A.8.b

conditions relating to the performance of activities permitted by this
licence, and

11.36A.8.c

financial conditions.

11.36A.9

The OGA’s decision on the application, and any conditions as mentioned in
paragraph (5)(b), must be notified in writing to the interested parties.

11.36A.10

In this clause “ the interested parties ” means—

11.36A.10.a

the company,

11.36A.10.b

the person who (if consent were granted) would take control of the company,
and

11.36A.10.c

if the company and another person or persons are the Licensee, that other
person or those other persons.

11.36A.11

For the purposes of this clause, the question of whether a person has control
of a company is to be determined in accordance with the test set out in clause
36(3).

an event mentioned in clause 42(2)(j) occurs in relation to a change in
control of one of those persons (see clause 41A); or

33.2.1.d

an event mentioned in clause 42(2)(k) occurs which consists of a failure by
one of those persons as mentioned in that provision.

33.3

In paragraph (2), for “or (b)” substitute  “, (b), (c) or (d)” .

###### Part 2 of Schedule 10

34

Part 2 of Schedule 10 (current model clauses for seaward production licences
deriving from Schedule 4 to the 1988 Regulations as they had effect on and
after 16 December 1996) is amended in accordance with paragraphs  35  to  37 .

35

After clause 41 insert—

########## Change in control of Licensee

35.41A

35.41A.1

This clause applies if—

35.41A.1.a

the Licensee is a company, or

35.41A.1.b

where two or more persons are the Licensee, any of those persons is a company,

and references in this clause to a company are to such a company.

35.41A.2

A change in control of a company is not permitted without the consent of the
Oil and Gas Authority (“the OGA”).

35.41A.3

There is a “change in control” of a company if a person takes control of the
company, not having previously been a person who controlled the company.

35.41A.4

If a change in control of a company is contemplated, the company must apply in
writing to the OGA for consent at least three months before the date on which
it is proposed that the change would occur (if consent were given).

35.41A.5

The OGA may—

35.41A.5.a

consent to the change in control unconditionally,

35.41A.5.b

consent to the change in control subject to conditions, or

35.41A.5.c

refuse consent to the change in control.

35.41A.6

If the OGA proposes to grant consent subject to any condition or to refuse
consent, the OGA must, before making a final decision—

35.41A.6.a

give the company an opportunity to make representations, and

35.41A.6.b

consider any representations that are made.

35.41A.7

The general rule is that the OGA must decide an application within three
months of receiving it, but the OGA may delay its decision by notifying the
interested parties in writing.

35.41A.8

Conditions as mentioned in paragraph (5)(b) may be imposed on the person
taking control of the company (as well as on the company), and may include—

35.41A.8.a

conditions relating to the arrangements for the change in control, including
the date by which it must occur,

35.41A.8.b

conditions relating to the performance of activities permitted by this
licence, and

35.41A.8.c

financial conditions.

35.41A.9

The OGA’s decision on the application, and any conditions as mentioned in
paragraph (5)(b), must be notified in writing to the interested parties.

35.41A.10

In this clause “ the interested parties ” means—

35.41A.10.a

the company,

35.41A.10.b

the person who (if consent were granted) would take control of the company,
and

35.41A.10.c

if the company and another person or persons are the Licensee, that other
person or those other persons.

35.41A.11

For the purposes of this clause, the question of whether a person has control
of a company is to be determined in accordance with the test set out in clause
41(4).

In paragraph (2), for “or (b)” substitute  “, (b), (c) or (d)” .

###### Schedule 6

59

Schedule 6 (model clauses for petroleum exploration and development licences)
is amended in accordance with paragraphs  60  to  62 .

60

After clause 35 insert—

########## Change in control of Licensee

60.35A

60.35A.1

This clause applies if—

60.35A.1.a

the Licensee is a company, or

60.35A.1.b

where two or more persons are the Licensee, any of those persons is a company,

and references in this clause to a company are to such a company.

60.35A.2

A change in control of a company is not permitted without the consent of the
Oil and Gas Authority (“the OGA”).

60.35A.3

There is a “change in control” of a company if a person takes control of the
company, not having previously been a person who controlled the company.

60.35A.4

If a change in control of a company is contemplated, the company must apply in
writing to the OGA for consent at least three months before the date on which
it is proposed that the change would occur (if consent were given).

60.35A.5

The OGA may—

60.35A.5.a

consent to the change in control unconditionally,

60.35A.5.b

consent to the change in control subject to conditions, or

60.35A.5.c

refuse consent to the change in control.

60.35A.6

If the OGA proposes to grant consent subject to any condition or to refuse
consent, the OGA must, before making a final decision—

60.35A.6.a

give the company an opportunity to make representations, and

60.35A.6.b

consider any representations that are made.

60.35A.7

The general rule is that the OGA must decide an application within three
months of receiving it, but the OGA may delay its decision by notifying the
interested parties in writing.

60.35A.8

Conditions as mentioned in paragraph (5)(b) may be imposed on the person
taking control of the company (as well as on the company), and may include—

60.35A.8.a

conditions relating to the arrangements for the change in control, including
the date by which it must occur,

60.35A.8.b

conditions relating to the performance of activities permitted by this
licence, and

60.35A.8.c

financial conditions.

60.35A.9

The OGA’s decision on the application, and any conditions as mentioned in
paragraph (5)(b), must be notified in writing to the interested parties.

60.35A.10

In this clause “ the interested parties ” means—

60.35A.10.a

the company,

60.35A.10.b

the person who (if consent were granted) would take control of the company,
and

60.35A.10.c

if the company and another person or persons are the Licensee, that other
person or those other persons.

60.35A.11

For the purposes of this clause, the question of whether a person has control
of a company is to be determined in accordance with the test set out in clause
35(4).

61.1

61.2

61.2.a

after sub-paragraph (i) insert—

61.2.a.j

if the Licensee is a company, any breach of a condition subject to which the
Oil and Gas Authority gave its consent to a change in control of the Licensee
(see clause 35A);

61.2.a.k

if the Licensee is a company, any failure to provide full and accurate
information in response to a notice given by the Oil and Gas Authority to that
company under section 5D of the Act;

;

in the closing words, after “(g)” insert  “or (j) or (k)” .

  Accession to Convention on Supplementary Compensation for Nuclear Damage

Section 305

1

In section 13 of the Nuclear Installations Act 1965 (“ the 1965 Act ”)
(exclusion, extension or reduction of compensation in certain cases), in
subsection (5A), after “(1ZA),” insert  “(1ZAA),” .

2

2.1

Section 16 of the 1965 Act (satisfaction of claims) is amended as follows.

2.2

In subsection (1ZA) after “or 9” insert  “, other than CSC-only claims,” .

2.3

After subsection (1ZA) insert—

2.3.1ZAA

Notwithstanding subsection (1), if the amount payable by a person in respect
of CSC-only claims for compensation under this Act in respect of any one
occurrence or event constituting a breach of a duty imposed on that person by
section 7, 7B, 8 or 9 reaches, in the aggregate and apart from interest or
costs, the equivalent in sterling of 300 million special drawing rights, that
person is not required to satisfy further claims for compensation.

2.4

In subsection (1A) for “or (3B)” substitute  “, (1ZAA), (3B), (3BA), (3BB),
(3BC) or (3BD)” .

2.5

In subsection (3)(a) after “subsection (1)” insert  “, (1ZA), (1ZAA), (1ZB)”
. 

2.6

In subsection (3B)—

2.6.a

after “or 10” insert  “, other than CSC-only claims (“non-CSC-only claims”),”
,  

2.6.b

after “further” insert  “non-CSC-only” , and

2.6.c

after “special relevant claims” insert  “or CSC claims (or both)” .

2.7

After subsection (3B) insert—

2.7.3BA

To the extent that further non-CSC-only claims for compensation are special
relevant claims, the appropriate authority may be required to satisfy them up
to the equivalent in sterling of 1,500 million euros (in the aggregate and
apart from interest or costs). 

2.7.3BB

To the extent that further non-CSC-only claims for compensation are CSC
claims, the appropriate authority may be required to satisfy them up to the
equivalent in sterling of the aggregate of 700 million euros and the value of
the CSC international pooled funds (in the aggregate and apart from interest
or costs).

2.7.3BC

To the extent that further non-CSC-only claims for compensation are both
special relevant claims and CSC claims, the appropriate authority may be
required to satisfy them up to the equivalent in sterling of the aggregate of
1,500 million euros and the value of the CSC international pooled funds (in
the aggregate and apart from interest or costs).

2.7.3BD

If the amount payable in respect of CSC-only claims in respect of any one
occurrence or event constituting a breach of a duty imposed on a person by
section 7, 7B, 8, 9 or 10 reaches, in the aggregate and apart from interest or
costs, the equivalent in sterling of the aggregate of 300 million special
drawing rights and the value of the CSC international pooled funds, the
appropriate authority is not required to satisfy further such claims for
compensation.

2.7.3BE

If the CSC international pooled funds are (or will be) reduced by virtue of
claims to which subsection (3) applies by 50%, the appropriate authority is
not required to satisfy further claims for compensation if that would give
rise to a further reduction of those funds except to the extent that those
further claims are non-UK CSC claims.

2.8

In subsection (3C)(a) after “subsection (3B)” insert  “or, in a case where the
relevant reciprocating territory is also a CSC territory (as defined by
section 16AA), (3BB)” .

2.9

In subsection (3D)—

2.9.a

in paragraph (b)(i) and (ii) after “subsection (1ZA)” insert  “, (1ZAA),” ,
and

2.9.b

in paragraph (b)(iii) after “subsection (3B)” insert  “, (3BA), (3BB), (3BC),
(3BD), (3BE)” .

3

In section 16A of the 1965 Act (section 16: supplementary), in subsection
(7)(b) for “section 18(1A)” substitute  “section 16(3BA)” .  

4

After section 16A of the 1965 Act insert—

######## Section 16: CSC-related definitions

4.16AA

4.16AA.1

This section applies for the purposes of section 16.

4.16AA.2

A claim for compensation under this Act in the case of a breach of a duty
imposed by section 7, 7B, 8, 9 or 10 is a CSC claim if—

4.16AA.2.a

the injury or damage for which compensation is claimed is such injury or
damage as is mentioned in subsection  (3) ,

4.16AA.2.b

the significant impairment of the environment by reference to which
compensation is claimed by virtue of section 11A(1) or 11G(1) or paragraph 1
of Schedule 1A is such significant impairment of the environment as is
mentioned in subsection  (3) , or

4.16AA.2.c

the preventive measures by reference to which compensation is claimed by
virtue of section 11H(1) or (2) are preventive measures relating to such
injury, damage or significant impairment of the environment as is mentioned in
subsection  (3) .

4.16AA.3

The injury, damage and significant impairment of the environment referred to
in subsection  (2)  are—

4.16AA.3.a

injury, damage or significant impairment of the environment that is incurred
within the territorial limits of the United Kingdom or another CSC territory;

4.16AA.3.b

injury, damage or significant impairment of the environment that is incurred
in or above the exclusive economic zone or on the continental shelf of the
United Kingdom or another CSC territory in connection with the exploitation or
exploration of the natural resources of that exclusive economic zone or
continental shelf;

4.16AA.3.c

injury or damage that is incurred in or above the sea outside the territorial
limits of any country or territory by, or by persons or property on, a ship or
aircraft registered in the United Kingdom or another CSC territory;

4.16AA.3.d

injury or damage that is incurred in or above the sea outside the territorial
limits of any country or territory by a national of the United Kingdom or
another CSC territory;

4.16AA.3.e

injury or damage that is incurred outside the territorial limits of any
country or territory by, or by persons or property on, an artificial island,
installation or structure that is subject to the jurisdiction of the United
Kingdom or another CSC territory.

4.16AA.4

A CSC claim is a CSC-only claim if—

4.16AA.4.a

the injury or damage for which compensation is claimed is such injury or
damage as is mentioned in subsection  (5) ,

4.16AA.4.b

the significant impairment of the environment by reference to which
compensation is claimed by virtue of section 11A(1) or 11G(1) or paragraph 1
of Schedule 1A is such significant impairment of the environment as is
mentioned in subsection  (5) , or

4.16AA.4.c

the preventive measures by reference to which compensation is claimed by
virtue of section 11H(1) or (2) are preventive measures relating to such
injury, damage or significant impairment of the environment as is mentioned in
subsection  (5) .

4.16AA.5

The injury, damage and significant impairment of the environment referred to
in subsection  (4)  are—

4.16AA.5.a

injury, damage or significant impairment of the environment that is incurred
within the territorial limits of a CSC-only territory;

4.16AA.5.b

injury, damage or significant impairment of the environment that is incurred
in or above the exclusive economic zone or on the continental shelf of a CSC-
only territory in connection with the exploitation or exploration of the
natural resources of that exclusive economic zone or continental shelf;

4.16AA.5.c

injury or damage that is incurred in or above the sea outside the territorial
limits of any country or territory by, or by persons or property on, a ship or
aircraft registered in a CSC-only territory;

4.16AA.5.d

injury or damage that is incurred in or above the sea outside the territorial
limits of any country or territory by a national of a CSC-only territory;

4.16AA.5.e

injury or damage that is incurred outside the territorial limits of any
country or territory by, or by persons or property on, an artificial island,
installation or structure that is subject to the jurisdiction of a CSC-only
territory.

4.16AA.6

A CSC-only territory is a CSC territory that is not—

4.16AA.6.a

the United Kingdom,

4.16AA.6.b

any other CSC territory that is a relevant territory in relation to a relevant
international agreement other than the CSC,

4.16AA.6.c

a country mentioned in section 26(1B)(b),

4.16AA.6.d

an overseas territory mentioned in section 26(1B)(c) or (d), or

4.16AA.6.e

a relevant reciprocating territory.

4.16AA.7

A CSC claim is a non-UK CSC claim if—

4.16AA.7.a

the injury or damage for which compensation is claimed is such injury or
damage as is mentioned in subsection  (8) ,

4.16AA.7.b

the significant impairment of the environment by reference to which
compensation is claimed by virtue of section 11A(1) or 11G(1) or paragraph 1
of Schedule 1A is such significant impairment of the environment as is
mentioned in subsection  (8) , or

4.16AA.7.c

the preventive measures by reference to which compensation is claimed by
virtue of section 11H(1) or (2) are preventive measures relating to such
injury, damage or significant impairment of the environment as is mentioned in
subsection  (8) .

4.16AA.8

The injury, damage and significant impairment of the environment referred to
in subsection  (7)  are—

4.16AA.8.a

injury, damage or significant impairment of the environment that is incurred
within the territorial limits of a CSC territory other than the United
Kingdom;

4.16AA.8.b

injury, damage or significant impairment of the environment that is incurred
in or above the exclusive economic zone or on the continental shelf of a CSC
territory other than the United Kingdom in connection with the exploitation or
exploration of the natural resources of that exclusive economic zone or
continental shelf;

4.16AA.8.c

injury or damage that is incurred in or above the sea outside the territorial
limits of any country or territory by, or by persons or property on, a ship or
aircraft registered in the United Kingdom or another CSC territory;

4.16AA.8.d

injury or damage that is incurred in or above the sea outside the territorial
limits of any country or territory by a national of the United Kingdom or
another CSC territory;

4.16AA.8.e

injury or damage that is incurred outside the territorial limits of any
country or territory by, or by persons or property on, an artificial island,
installation or structure that is subject to the jurisdiction of the United
Kingdom or another CSC territory.

4.16AA.9

In this section—

      “ CSC territory ” means—         a country that is a party to the CSC,
or           an overseas territory of such a country, if the CSC applies to
the overseas territory,                 “ national ”, in relation to a CSC
territory, includes—         that CSC territory and any part of it,
a public or private body established in the CSC territory or part of it,
whether a body corporate or not,           a partnership established in the
CSC territory or part of it, and           a trust the validity of which is
governed by the law of the CSC territory, and                 “ the CSC ”
means the Convention on Supplementary Compensation for Nuclear Damage (as
amended or supplemented from time to time).

4.16AA.10

A reference in this section to a national of the United Kingdom is to be
construed in accordance with section 16A(8).

judgments), in subsection (3B)(a) and (b) after “section 16(1ZA)” insert  “,
(1ZAA)” .

7

After section 25B of the 1965 Act (amounts in euros) insert—

######## Special drawing rights

7.25C

7.25C.1

In this Act “ special drawing rights ” means special drawing rights as defined
by the International Monetary Fund; and for the purpose of determining the
equivalent in sterling on any day of a sum expressed in special drawing
rights, one special drawing right is to be treated as equal to such a sum in
sterling as the International Monetary Fund have fixed as being the equivalent
of one special drawing right—

7.25C.1.a

for that day, or

7.25C.1.b

if no sum has been so fixed for that day, for the last day before that day for
which a sum has been so fixed.

7.25C.2

A certificate given by or on behalf of the Treasury stating—

7.25C.2.a

that a particular sum in sterling has been so fixed for a particular day, or

7.25C.2.b

that no sum has been so fixed for a particular day and that a particular sum
in sterling has been so fixed for a day which is the last day for which a sum
has been so fixed before the particular day,

is to be conclusive evidence of those matters for the purposes of subsection
(1)  of this section; and a document purporting to be such a certificate is in
any proceedings to be received in evidence and, unless the contrary is proved,
to be deemed to be such a certificate.

7.25C.3

The Treasury may charge a reasonable fee for any certificate given in
pursuance of subsection  (2)  of this section.

7.25C.4

Any fee received by the Treasury by virtue of subsection  (3)  is to be paid
into the Consolidated Fund.

8.1

Section 26 of the 1965 Act (interpretation) is amended as follows.

8.2

In subsection (1)—

8.2.a

after the definition of “cover period” insert—

      “ CSC claim ” has the meaning given by section  16AA ;           “ CSC
international pooled funds ” means the funds referred to by Article III.1(b)
of the Convention on Supplementary Compensation for Nuclear Damage;
“ CSC-only claim ” has the meaning given by section  16AA ;

;

8.2.b

in the definition of “event”—

8.2.b.i

after “(1ZA),” insert  “(1ZAA),” , and
